webTitle: And your one luxury item is...

fields.headline: And your one luxury item is...
fields.standfirst: Some desert island castaways choose a piano or golf clubs to take with them. Others have a TV crew recording their every move. All Tom Hanks gets when he's washed up is a volleyball called Wilson
fields.trailText: Philip French: The big change is not internal... but purely physical.
fields.body:
From Shakespeare's The Tempest and Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe to William Golding's Lord of the Flies and the 1964 science-fiction movie Robinson Crusoe on Mars, writers have been intrigued by the notion of people cast ashore on desert islands. Audiences share this fascination and every week since Roy Plomley devised Desert Island Discs in 1942 several million listeners have tuned in to hear how various celebrities would cope with loneliness and privation, and what eight gramophone records they'd take with them to ease the pain.

The latest exercise in the Crusoe genre is Cast Away, which reunites Robert Zemeckis and Tom Hanks, the director and star of Forrest Gump, which was, of course, an updating of another eighteenth-century moral fiction, Voltaire's Candide.

Hanks plays Chuck Noland, a workaholic FedEx systems engineer who spends his time flying around the world trying to make his company's parcel delivery service faster than that of its rivals. We first meet him a couple of blocks from Red Square trying to imbue FedEx's Moscow branch with the Stakhanovite spirit. 'We live or die by the clock,' he tells them.

Back home in Memphis, Tennessee, he has a fiancée, Kelly (Helen Hunt), a research scientist working on her doctorate and, except for a nagging tooth, all seems well with his life. After a pre-Christmas dinner, he promises to be home for New Year and possible nuptials, after he's accompanied a Fed-Ex cargo plane to the Antipodes. Unfortunately, the plane loses radio contact with Tahiti in a storm and in a superbly extended crash sequence that leaves you searching for a seat belt, Chuck is washed up on a small island, the only survivor.

Robinson Crusoe actually had it lucky with a wrecked ship from which to salvage for rifles, gunpowder, tools, clothes, timber and so on. He also had a rather grand island to explore, to map and to colonise. Chuck Noland, whose name suggests someone dumped in no man's land, has wound up on a hard place as inhospitably rocky as the one that provided the briefest of sanctuaries to the eponymous hero of William Golding's brilliant and remorseless Pincher Martin.

Chuck has nothing except for a few random parcels, containing a woman's party dress, a pair of ice-skates, a volleyball, some VHS cassettes and a document annulling a marriage. When the body of his dead pilot is washed up, he keeps the man's boots but can't bring himself to remove the belt. Crusoe managed to retrieve some of the ship's instruments; Chuck has a fine pocket watch, a family heirloom given him by his fiancée, whose photo is in the cover.

The first days on the island are well managed - the discovery of coconuts, the shaping of tools, the hope of imminent rescue, the descent into despair. The film's colour is cold, unromantic, quite unlike the gorgeous Technicolor hues of the 1949 (British) and 1980 (American) versions of The Blue Lagoon, both shot in the same area of the South Seas.

There are neat details here. The retrieved volleyball is given a face painted in blood, named Wilson after its manufacturer, and becomes a cross between a mute companion and a fetishist Cargo Cult object. An ice skate becomes a primitive dental tool for the most painful exercise in sadomasochistic orthodontics since Marathon Man.

Unlike Crusoe, Noland defecates (hiding behind a bush) and urinates boldly into the sea, and it's during a moonlight slash that he spots a distant light which raises rapidly dashed hopes of rescue. Of his sexual yearnings, we hear nothing and, unlike Crusoe, he has little in the way of larger social or spiritual experiences.

There's no frisson like the solitary footstep on the sand. No modern Man Friday appears. In fact, there are no unforgettable images that lodge in the mind like those scenes in Luis Buñuel's Robinson Crusoe, where the hero climbs a hill to shout out the Twenty-third Psalm as a defiant challenge to an indifferent universe, or where Friday innocently puts on a woman's dress and throws Crusoe into a perverse crisis of revulsion and attraction.

Cast Away, in fact, jumps four years from the first terrible weeks to the final period, when Noland has adapted to his new environment, but is preparing to escape on a raft. The big change is not internal (we never discover his religion, his politics or his aesthetic interests other than his love of Elvis Presley) but purely physical.

Tom Hanks spent 18 months getting into condition for the second part of the movie under Dr Paul McAuley, credited as 'Weight Loss Adviser', and the American Humane Society saw to it that in the scenes involving the skewering of crabs and other foodstuffs 'no animal was harmed'.

To reveal that Hanks makes it home is merely to acknowledge that this is a big-budget Hollywood picture, produced by its star, and there is a drawn-out, sentimental coda that more or less re-enacts Tennyson's 'Enoch Arden', that great Victorian poem about a desert-island survivor returning to discover that life has changed and his wife has remarried.

Weirdly, however, this finale turns into a tribute to Noland's employers, and the real-life boss of the organisation, Paul Smith (billed 'As Himself'), turns up to welcome Chuck back to 'the FedEx family'. Unlike FedEx, however, Cast Away finishes up delivering a neatly wrapped, somewhat disappointing package rather slowly.

webTitle: Wordsworth: a Life by Juliet Barker read by Steven Pacey

fields.headline: Wordsworth: a Life by Juliet Barker read by Steven Pacey
fields.trailText: The beautiful readings in Juliet Barker's biography bring Wordsworth and his circle to life
fields.body:
Wordsworth: a Life
Juliet Barker
Read by Steven Pacey with Jonathan Keeble and Patience Tomlinson
Running time 6hrs
Penguin Audiobooks £12.99

Juliet Barker's narrative of Wordsworth's life is enriched with generous extracts from journals and correspondence, recreating revolutionary France, Grand Tour Europe and the Lake District, as well as his relationships with family and fellow writers. Along with quotations from Wordsworth's poems, these extracts are beautifully read in authentic accents, with the two readers adopting realistically ageing voices as the decades pass. In this way, Wordsworth and his circle are presented as vibrant, multi-faceted people involved as energetically in political issues and the countryside as in the purchase of a Turkish rug for William's study.

Wordsworth matures from a 13-year-old orphan beset by financial difficulties to a hugely energetic young revolutionary and, finally, to the grand old man of letters of whom 'cheap trainers' - those arriving by the newly opened railway line to trample over his Rydal Mount lawns - hoped to catch a glimpse. Vignettes of domestic life are vivid: Dorothy's ardent passion for her brother, William, symbolised by her wearing the wedding ring all night before his marriage to Mary; William and Mary's 'keen heart anguish' following the death of two of their children within six months of each other; Dorothy's comparing the remaining three children unfavourably with the dead ones; these events are as tragic as anything in Dickens.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: No Logo

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: This timely, vivid and trenchant analysis of the globalised international economy was the Zeitgeist book of 2000 and an essential text for the Seattle demonstrators.
fields.body:
No Logo
Naomi Klein
HarperCollins £8.99, pp490
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Ever since Vance Packard's The Hidden Persuaders, each postwar generation has thrown up at least one fascinating analysis of the late capitalist marketplace. This timely, vivid and trenchant analysis of the globalised international economy, from the sweatshops and 'Export Processing Zones' of the Far East to Gap superstores of the West, was the Zeitgeist book of 2000 and an essential text for the Seattle demonstrators.

Klein, a young Canadian consumer journalist, moves the focus of her investigation from branding to cool-hunting to multinational consumer production to contract-employment in a barely controlled polemic against companies such as Virgin, Starbucks and Gap. Underpinning her analysis is some impressive factual reporting, and part of No Logo 's appeal is the skill with which Klein weaves her own growing realisation of corporate power into the trajectory of her research.

What's more, as well as deploying an impressive arsenal of statistics illustrative of the deep structural shifts that have occurred in the economies of the Western world since the early Nineties, Klein also writes with a sharp eye to the absurdities of the brave new world she's describing.

From an improbable cast that includes Michael Jordan, Frank Vigil, Malcolm Gladwell, Wayne Grytting and Alice Nutter, the quintessential No Logo character is a certain Faith Plotkin who, to 'brand' herself more successfully, became Faith Popcorn, the author of the 1991 bestseller, The Popcorn Report. This gives a clue to the central weakness of the book - its failure to acknowledge (or examine) the role played by the globalised English language in the dissemination of Nike, Benetton and Hilfiger products.

Perhaps No Logo 's second obvious weakness is its fascination with the now outmoded Nineties' concept of 'synergy'. Actually, Klein did not need to leave her work-station to apprehend this point. A book that was originated by the communications giant Random House-Bertelsmann is actually published in Britain by Rupert Murdoch's publishing arm. None of this takes away from a thrilling rhetorical achievement, a genuine thought-provoker with an engaging informality of tone that makes for infectious reading.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: A tour round the thoughts of a flight crew, plus Those Are Real Bullets, Aren't They?, Lost, The Danish Girl and On the Missionary Trail
fields.body:
Flying
Henry Sutton
Sceptre £6.99, pp330
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Apparently, Henry Sutton wrote this, his fourth novel, to combat his own fear of flying, but if he succeeds in allaying anyone else's fear, it will only be by inducing the far greater fear that 'It's All Just About Sex'.

In the course of two Atlantic crossings, we're given the tour of a flight crew's fantasies. Meanwhile, humanity's great achievement - flight - is drained of its romance: 'What [the pilot] gets is artificial pressure... made-up stresses to give [him] some idea of the physical sensation of flying' and individuality, our major desire, is cruelly despatched as another character is described as 'the sum of everyone she'd ever worked with - the voice of 5,000 cabin crew'.

Sutton's writing is minutely observed, credible and slick, but having evoked the existential Void, Sutton fails to provoke any thought on the matter, making this a rather pointless excursion, all told.

Those Are Real Bullets, Aren't They?
Peter Pringle and Philip Jacobson
4th Estate £7.99, pp310
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Irish Republican Army was a spent force well before 1972, when a group of paratroopers, determined to 'crack heads', shot 27 Catholic marchers, stone-throwers and bystanders on Bloody Sunday, an event which rekindled anti-English sentiment, underscored the need for demilitarisation and yet made it even less feasible.

Agitators were rarely armed with more than rubble, but minimum force had come to mean shooting to kill. Supposedly 'aimed shots' killed Barney McGuigan, unarmed and uninvolved, who had raised his hands and a makeshift white flag as he went to help a wounded man. The circumstances of the other dozen deaths are no less tragic and ludicrous.

Those Are Real Bullets, Aren't They? is a unique and, therefore, vital account of Bloody Sunday, incorporating new interviews and evidence since the present Government reopened the inquiry. This is an important, essential and harrowing book.

Lost
Hans-Ulrich Treichel
Picador £5, pp145
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Should this novella have continued into the mid-teens of the plump, permanently unhealthy and parentally neglected narrator, he might well have found kindred spirits in Grigor Samsa and Harry Haller (Metamorphosis and Steppenwolf). Growing up with the absence of Arnold, the brother his parents lost while fleeing from the Russians at the end of the Second World War, the protagonist is subjected to a battery of (pre-DNA testing) examinations, to determine the probability of Foundling 2307 being his sibling. Every detail is revealed to the reader but his name and yet nothing is revealed to his parents of his inner life and anguish. The story may be mundane, a clever exercise in characterisation only just meriting a longer format, but the dread of 'Waiting for Arnold' (to take what little affection his parents have to give), has the impact of Hesse or Kafka; strangely endearing.

The Danish Girl
David Ebershoff
Phoenix £6.99, pp310
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In 1925, the artist Greta Waud needed more than just a reliable model; she needed a 'Muse', a catalyst for her 'Art', to surmount the indifference of critics and evade the comparisons to her husband. When she and Einar discovered his feminine alter ego, Lili, as a man and artist, Einar began to slip into her shadow, and some years later became the first hermaphrodite to undergo sexual reassignment surgery.

The transition was agonising, but as Greta allowed Lili to explore her femininity and Einar allowed Greta to develop her art, they also discovered a deeper fidelity to the people they'd been waiting to become. Ebershoff writes seductively and compassionately; his first novel is a flawless accomplishment. In looking to the distant past for inspiration, like Patricia Ducker, Ebershoff neglects the feminist thesis that 'the personal is political', but tells a tremendous story all the same.

On the Missionary Trail
Tom Hiney
Vintage £7.99, pp 367
Buy it at a discount at BOL

In the early nineteenth century, George Bennet and the Reverend Daniel Tyerman were among the first envoys of the London Missionary Society (whose most famous member was David Livingstone, although this pair were no less heroic). Travelling by whaler to Polynesia, New Zealand and Australia and then on to China, India and Africa, they and their colleagues had to contend with cannibals and the justifiable fear and suspicion of Europeans, whose diseases had ravaged some native populations.

On the Missionary Trail has already been serialised on Radio 4 and this splendidly illustrated paperback, from the author of an acclaimed biography of Raymond Chandler, should win many more devotees, being an accessible, detailed recreation of genuine adventures in exotic lands, before the West altered the native cultures forever.

fields.headline: The value of a Pound in your pocket
fields.standfirst: The influence of the 'brilliant and repulsive' modernist is keenly felt in the work of current poets
fields.trailText: The influence of the 'brilliant and repulsive' modernist is keenly felt in the work of current poets
fields.body:
Selected Poems
Derek Mahon
Penguin £9.99, pp224
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Passing Measures: A Collection of Poems
Peter Riley
Carcanet £9.95 pp124
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Men in the Off Hours
Anne Carson
Jonathan Cape £10, pp120
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Ezra Pound
selected by Thom Gunn
Faber £4.99, pp96

W H Auden
selected by John Fuller
Faber £4.99, pp96

William Shakespeare
selected by Ted Hughes
Faber £4.99, pp96

The revised edition of Derek Mahon's Selected Poems, now including new work and selections from The Hudson Letter and The Yellow Book, shows a body of work remarkably consistent in tone and technique. Mahon rarely puts a foot wrong in this finely tuned selection, its confidence sustained throughout. He gives us the overwhelming pull of the sea, the travelled voice uneasy in its history, wrestling with notions of personal space, art and cultural presence.

Mahon's is a lyrical voice in which the self is confident in the value of poetry as a mode for mediation between the limitations and frustrations of reality and the darkness of the human psyche. His poems take us delicately into places we might not want to know. With his ironic and Francophone tastes, Mahon can be both political and sceptical at once. Critics have drawn comparisons with elements in Lowell, but Mahon is colder, his verse more drivingly controlled. Yet for a 'dark' poet he positively glows at times.

There are numerous landmark poems in this collection: the classic 'A Disused Shed in Co Wexford', the art poems 'The Hunt by Night' and 'Girls on the Bridge', which is fine despite a predictable final line, the villanelle 'Antarctica', the disturbing 'Dawn at St Patrick's' and beautifully delicate 'Noon at St Michael's', through to a selection from The Yellow Book, and the rich final poem, 'St Patrick's Day'.

But there is too much certainty, too much knowledge of what in modernism and modernity he doesn't want, doesn't trust. This is a world coloured by a priori memory of what might have been better. You feel the ache in every poem. It reveals itself most churlishly in a poem like 'Rock Music'. For me, the telling poem in the selection is 'An Image from Beckett', a poem which shows an awareness of tradition and innovation, of isolation and presence.

Peter Riley belongs to neither the so-called 'mainstream', nor the avant-garde, terminologies he'd be likely to reject. As he has said in an interview, he doesn't believe 'in the necessarily dichotomised condition of our culture'. Still, there's nothing 'mainstream' in the negative sense about Riley, one of Britain's major, if insufficiently recognised poets. Some years ago I worked with Riley on a selection that roughly equates with this one, now published as Passing Measures: A Collection of Poems, and therefore might feel closer to the work than others I review. But in the 'small press scene', or 'linguistically innovative' community, it is not unusual for a manuscript to change hands like this, for notes to be scribbled in the margins.

The reader can walk with him through a poem, while interpreting the spread of the landscape or the seascape, almost independently of the poet-guide. Much of Riley's poetry is about movement through places, considering the still points in a journey - the points that will remain or change outside your experience as you pass through. Riley paints sound pictures of place. He best epitomises the New Lyricism that has blurred the boundaries between pure linguistic innovation based on rhetorical language and the lyric of self. He consistently examines the tension between 'nature' and pastoral versions of 'nature'. The stand-out pieces of this volume are the 'Sea Watches'.

I have been looking forward to Ann Carson's new book, though it came more quickly than I thought it would. Men in the Off Hours is a large collection of poetry, texts, translations, and essayistic poetry prose. In a sense, this book marks the end of one aspect of the modernist experiment. It's simply all been done before. The techniques of blurring the lyrical self and personae, of Bakhtinian shifts in narrative, of Derridean genre ploys, have been much exploited. Carson does bring something fresh and unusual to the processes, and brings life to what Thom Gunn has noted on Pound's Homage to Sextus Propertius, that 'the line is more garrulous, as is suitable to a poetry of wit, gossip, and opinion'.

Unfortunately, many of the pieces in the book seem like offcuts from other more focused projects. Liminality can be camouflage for inadequate self-editing. This volume is far too long, and some sequences dull. However, the book gets stronger as it goes on, and the 'Akhmatova' pieces are stunning.

Among the Faber series of poets selecting poets, Ezra Pound, Poems selected by Thom Gunn is the most striking. In varying degrees, none of the poets reviewed here can escape the shadow of Pound. In his blunt, unequivocal introduction, Gunn gets to the brilliance and repulsiveness of Pound. fields.headline: The smell of the outback
fields.trailText: Ever since I spent a formative year in the Victorian bush I have been fascinated by Australian literature.
fields.body:
Ever since I spent a formative year in the Victorian bush, discovered the stories of Henry Lawson and first read the novels of Patrick White, I have been fascinated by Australian literature. Much like the American writing of the nineteenth century, it seemed to have a peculiarly intimate relationship with landscape, as anyone who has ever read Miles Franklin's My Brilliant Career or, from a later generation, Picnic At Hanging Rock will acknowledge.

This is partly because so many distinctive Australianisms, words such as 'paddock', 'station' and 'creek', were adapted by the first settlers precisely to describe unfamiliar landscape features, but more particularly because so much of the early writing took place on the land, and described the life of the outback. It's a tradition that can be traced to the contemporary work of writers like Murray Bail (Eucalyptus) and Peter Carey (Illywhacker and Ned Kelly).

Australian-English, the language of this fiction, is also famous for its vivid bluntness, although as an instrument of thought and self-expression it is subtle, witty and evocative. As a variety of English, it is particularly appealing for the way in which it has kept alive and rejuvenated a number of English dialect words, for instance 'fossick', an old Cornish term meaning to search unsystematically. I could cheerfully spend an afternoon with an Australian-English dictionary - one of my favourite obscure books is Bruce Moore's Lexicon of Cadet Language (Canberra, 1993).

So it was all the more surprising to me that I should have utterly neglected to read Pobby and Dingan (Cape £8.99, pp90), a novella by Ben Rice published towards the end of last year. Normally, of course, our rule is to look forwards not back, but this little book, the author's first, is so extraordinary, it must be the exception.

The story is set in Lightning Ridge, New South Wales, the opal capital of Australia, a bleak, hard-scrabble community cut off from civilisation, but motivated by the obsessive quest for precious stones. Pobby and Dingan are the imaginary friends of Kellyanne Williamson, an opal miner's daughter. Just as the opal takes its value and colour from absence rather than substance, the first-person tale that's unfolded by Ashmol Williamson, Kellyanne's bemused brother, is one of a bizarre vanishing, the inexplicable disappearance, possibly fatal, of Kellyanne's imaginary friends.

At first, Ashmol reckons his sister is a 'fruit-loop' to think such things. 'Pobby and Dingan aren't dead,' I said, hiding my anger in a swig from my can of Mello Yello. 'They never existed. Things that never existed can't be dead. Right?' The puzzling pain of this extraordinary loss is compounded for Ashmol when, in the family's search for Pobby and Dingan, his father gets accused of 'ratting' on a rival's opal claim, a serious accusation in the gold-rush atmosphere of the community.

The town of Lightning Ridge becomes plunged into a furious debate about the true nature of Williamson's intentions, while Ashmol, fired by a chivalrous love for his grief-stricken sister, organises the citizens into the hunt for Pobby and Dingan, a surreal quest inspired by his own need to explain to himself his relationship with his sister.

It would be wrong to reveal the resolution of this remarkable book, but it gives nothing away to say that the penultimate scene, in which the people of Lightning Ridge say farewell to Pobby and Dingan, is both intensely moving and brilliantly realised.

You would never know from the way in which Rice handles the tricky business of internal monologue, with only the slightest hint of influence from Salinger's Holden Caulfield, that Rice was a first-timer. So confident is Rice of his brilliant act of literary ventriloquism that he actually has one Lightning Ridge schoolboy ask Kellyanne: 'Do Pobby and Dingan speak Australian?'

As far as the book as a whole is concerned, the question is redundant. Every character in this pocket masterpiece is speaking Australian with a vengeance. The way in which the rhythms of everyday speech are used to narrate this spellbinding and suggestive fable is just one of its exceptional qualities.

I have no idea if Ben Rice is actually an Aussie (the jacket says he was born in Devon), but he writes as if he has the Australian landscape, its people and their vernacular in his bones, and he also knows exactly what to leave out to evade the ever-present risk of caricature and the slide into unconscious humour.

In the week that the literary press has been reviewing Peter Carey's True History of the Kelly Gang (Faber), a novel characterised by a typically brilliant use of untutored Australian by Ned Kelly, the country's unacknowledged national hero, the arrival of Ben Rice is, I think, an important milestone in the literature of Australia. Rice was born in 1972, so he was still in his teens when Illywhacker was short-listed for the Booker Prize and when Oscar and Lucinda won it.

With Pobby and Dingan , Ben Rice makes a strong claim to be a leader of the new generation. This novel marks one of those debuts that may well turn out to have been of the greatest significance.

webTitle: Observer review: The Great Hedge of India by Roy Moxham

fields.headline: Privets on parade...
fields.standfirst: Roy Moxham unearths a horticultural marvel worthy of Spike Milligan in The Great Hedge of India
fields.trailText: Roy Moxham unearths a horticultural marvel worthy of Spike Milligan in The Great Hedge of India
fields.body:
The Great Hedge of India
Roy Moxham
Constable £14.99, pp234
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Spike Milligan in his wildest flights of fancy could not have done better. To levy a duty on salt, the British established a Customs line across the whole of India which in 1869 extended from the Indus to the Mahanadi in Madras - a distance of 2,300 miles. Guarded by 12,000 men, it would have stretched from London to Constantinople: an immense, impenetrable... hedge.

A hedge? Surely not. Well, yes, actually. It has been quietly forgotten since the days of Victoria, and largely ignored by historians, but as Roy Moxham discovered in his expedition along the nine miles of shelving of the India Office Records, it was very much a feature of the Empire.

The opening pages of this marvellous book put me in mind of one of the great Milligan masterpieces, The Jet-Propelled Guided Naafi. In 1956, tea was so important to Britain's fighting men that Her Majesty's Government would stop at nothing to keep them supplied, and so devised a self-contained missile capable of carrying 82 staff, 10 Naafi pianos, 60,000 gallons of tea and 12 tons of buttered crumpets.

Moxham came across the annual reports of the India Inland Customs department, in which the hedge is described in Goonish detail. 'In populated parts of the country, where smuggling [of salt] is rife, the men are active in preventing the passage of contraband goods by a barrier which, in its most perfect form, is utterly impassable to man or beast, and all the outlets through which are guarded.

'The dry hedge is chiefly composed of dwarf Indian plum... But in most places, material is procured at a cost of enormous labour: white ants and jungle fires perpetually destroy the dry hedge, at which our work is ceaseless; while storms and whirlwinds, especially in the plain of the Punjab, carry away whole furlongs and even, occasionally, miles of it in an hour. 'In its most perfect form, the hedge is a live one, from 10 to 14 feet in height, and six to 12 feet thick, composed of closely clipped thorny trees and shrubs, among which the babool, Indian plum, the carounda, the prickly pear and the thuer (euphorbia) are the most numerous.'

Moxham sets out to find the remnants of this quintessentially British folly, writing an affectionate and scholarly narrative which reveals the shocking greed that drove these strangest of gardeners to devise what Sir John Strachey, Indian civil servant, described as 'a monstrous system, to which it would be almost impossible to find a parallel in any tolerably civilised country'.

It is perhaps no coincidence that Spike Milligan, our latest honorary knight, was born in India.

fields.headline: With a song in my Hart
fields.standfirst: What links Santa Claus and Salman Rushdie? Find out in Reading Lyrics
fields.trailText: What links Santa Claus and Salman Rushdie? Find out in Reading Lyrics
fields.body:
Reading Lyrics
edited by Robert Gottlieb and Robert Kimball
Pantheon £30, pp730

The way you walk and whisper and look. These, as we know, were just some of the things that made Lorenz Hart exclaim: 'I could write a book.' That simple secret of the plot - that he loves you a lot - is the very stuff of these 700 elegantly double-columned pages.

This exemplary piece of book production raises at least one overwhelming question: is it for the musical lyric that twentieth-century poetry will be remembered? Or, to put it another way, what line of Eliot or Pound is as memorable as Oscar Hammerstein's 'Oh, what a beautiful morning' or even 'You'll never walk alone'? It also, by the way, illustrates the connections between Tim Rice and P.G. Wodehouse.

Reading Lyrics meets a real need by gathering more than 1,000 show lyrics, mainly by Americans but with half-a-dozen English excursions. Around substantial servings of the likes of Ira Gershwin, Cole Porter and Hart, whose entire works have already secured hefty volumes, Robert Gottlieb and Robert Kimball have brought together 180 lyricists to illuminate that distinct strand of twentieth-century art which sprang from, and transformed, the twin products of operetta and Tin Pan Alley before disappearing, around 1975, in 'the era of Andrew Lloyd Webber's sung-through pastiches'.

The essence of Reading Lyrics is neatly summed up in the laconic memoirs of Howard Dietz, author of 'Dancing in the Dark', who said, simply: 'The best lyric writers are the ones who write the most singable words... a good lyric writer can put words to music and have it come out as though he'd put music to words.'

Open Gottlieb and Kimball's volume at random and the point is made. Even when a tune is elusive, many of the songs collected here have a lyric quality, even if it is not always on the level of Billy Strayhorn's 'Lush Life'. The tune, too, can survive alone. Duke Ellington's 'Take the "A" Train' (oddly absent) and 'Don't Get Around Much Anymore' were both originally lyricless. And in some moods - versions by Shostakovich or Charlie Parker - one is more than happy to forgo the words 'Tea For Two'. These, emblematic of composition on the hoof, were supplied on the road as a dummy lyric by Irving Caesar (whose 'Swanee' is also absent).

Often thought quintessentially urban, lyrics harbour pastoral yearnings. So we find Caesar's 'Darling, this place is/ A lover's oasis,/ Where life's weary chase is/ Unknown./ Far from the cry of the city...' (Chances are you're now humming along.) And also Gus Kahn's more satirical 'Makin' Whoopee': 'Picture a little love nest/ Down where the roses cling,/ Picture the same sweet love nest,/ Think what a year can bring./ He's washing dishes and baby clothes.' I was about to stop there, but it needs the perfect false rhyme of: 'He's so ambitious he even sews.'

Perhaps the pastoral trend began with 'Bungalow in Quogue': 'How clear the voice of Nature calls;/ I'll go and get some overalls,/ And get a last year's almanac/ To read at night when things are slack.'

Gottlieb and Kimball also make clear something often forgotten: that it was 'performing flea' P.G. Wodehouse's genius, with Kern's music, to bring sassy, idiomatic life to a form that had been twee - something of which Irving Berlin is all too often accused. This volume shows his great wit and invention. A full collection is imminent but, for now, be assured that there is more sex in 'You'd Be Surprised' than Madonna could ever supply.

Following Dietz's dictum, much of Porter - dare one say it - drops away. His topical lists wear thin. How much more effective is Herman Hupfield's limiting himself, in 'As Time Goes By', to '... we get a trifle weary/ With Mister Einstein's theory'. That apostrophe is redolent of much unobtrusive scholarship. Gottlieb and Kimball have also gone back to as many original sources as possible, and supplied various indexes, so that it is easy to find that, for example, the Wodehouse lyric was introduced by Sam Hardy and Juliette Day into a 1917 show, The Riviera Girls.

Dorothy Fields has a good showing - a full collection is needed - including the rare 'Have Feet, Will Dance' (from a vanished 1957 TV show). But the collection also overlooks recently discovered extra lyrics for Johnny Mercer's splendidly paradoxical 'Too Marvellous For Words'.

On a recent disc, Philip Chaffin sings more of those adjectives: 'Adding words like magical,/ Mystical,/ Seems just apotheostical'. This is a trifle forced, but who could fail to relish: 'The sweetest words/ In Keats' and Shelley's lyrics/ Aren't sweet enough/ To be your panegyrics'? There are, however, perfect references to Webster's dictionary and 'a love song for the birds'. Here Gottlieb and Kimball get it right.

What links Santa Claus and Salman Rushdie? Rushdie, in ad-writing days, coined 'Naughty, but nice' - an echo of Haven Gillespie, author of 'Santa Claus Is Comin' To Town'. He, of course, is 'checking it twice,/ Gonna find out/ Who's naughty and nice'. That's a far cry from his haunting 'That Lucky Old Sun' and 'You Go To My Head'.

Reading Lyrics puts one in mind of those characters in Pinter's Old Times who communicate by song (better than silence). This wonderful book belongs alongside Paul Keegan's New Penguin Book of English Verse. Only then can we begin to settle the argument between the poet and the songwriter.

There are, however, perfect references to Webster's dictionary and 'a love song for the birds'. Here Gottlieb and Kimball get it right. What links Santa Claus and Salman Rushdie? Rushdie, in ad-writing days, coined 'Naughty, but nice' - an echo of Haven Gillespie, author of 'Santa Claus Is Comin' To Town'. He, of course, is 'checking it twice,/ Gonna find out/ Who's naughty and nice'. That's a far cry from his haunting 'That Lucky Old Sun' and 'You Go To My Head'. Reading Lyrics puts one in mind of those characters in Pinter's Old Times who communicate by song (better than silence). This wonderful book belongs alongside Paul Keegan's New Penguin Book of English Verse. Only then can we begin to settle the argument between the poet and the songwriter.

webTitle: Observer review: Perfect Tense by Michael Bracewell

fields.headline: Dull day at the office, dear?
fields.trailText: A Wordsworthian moment lifts Michael Bracewell's narrator out of the mudanity of daily routine in Perfect Tense
fields.body:
Perfect Tense
Michael Bracewell
Jonathan Cape £10, pp169

Michael Bracewell's new novel is not a story as such but an extended internal monologue by an anonymous narrator, an Everyman for the modern age, charting his own grinding progress through an unremarkable office day.

Single and settled into the drone of early middle age, the narrator commutes each day from the suburbs to an inauspicious position in the homogenous London offices of a company whose function is left unspecified. The stages of his journey - a particular quality of morning light over the railway bridge, a glimpse of a young woman in a coffee shop - trigger Proustian recollections of previous office buildings, former jobs and colleagues: 'It is as though every office I've ever worked in is all around me, as a landscape.'

And this is more or less it, on the surface. The book is made up of layers of detailed and carefully observed descriptions of London and its environs, coupled with patchy self-analysis and reflections on the human condition; the narrator gradually shifts into a figure of the Absurd, an outsider whose partially self-imposed exile from normal social commerce leaves him in the position of a detached onlooker: 'I suddenly felt distanced from my surroundings, as though I was seeing everything through a thick sheet of glass.'

The problem with attempting to transmute the mundanity of daily routine into the stuff of fiction, and thence into an allegory of the essential boredom of existence, is that, by definition, there is an inherent tedium in the subject. The fleeting, prosopographical sketches of the narrator's colleagues and fellow-commuters leave them as interchangeable types but never quite allow them the comedy of caricature; his aperçus and speculations on the peculiarities of social behaviour are neither original nor particularly witty ('Accent hopping is a reflex which occurs in the office when you quite simply alter your accent to suit the person you're talking to').

Bracewell's skill is to offer a picture of shared experience; anyone who has worked in an office will recognise these streets with their dingy pubs and sandwich shops; the sudden morning urge to leap on a train to a faraway destination instead of going to work, and the paradoxical fear of redundancy, the prospect of a worse boredom than the office holds out.

Yet, in the midst of this grey routine, the narrator experiences an almost Wordsworthian visionary moment that lifts him above the apparent emptiness of his life, offering the possibility of hope and redemption. These glimpses of tenderness, together with the spare clarity of Bracewell's prose, make this miniature portrait of urban life one of the more vivid in recent fiction.

webTitle: Observer review: Emerald Germs of Ireland by Patrick McCabe

fields.headline: Crazed fantasist? Serial killer?
fields.standfirst: Patrick McCabe's narrator in Emerald Germs of Ireland is difficult to follow, but do we care?
fields.trailText: Patrick McCabe's narrator in Emerald Germs of Ireland is difficult to follow, but do we care?
fields.body:
Emerald Germs of Ireland
Patrick McCabe
Picador £14.99, pp380
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Patrick McCabe's latest book, Emerald Germs of Ireland, has two chapter 13s. Given the associations of that number, this might be deliberate, but given that the book hasn't been perfectly proofread (there's an odd slip with the punctuation), it might not be. It doesn't matter overmuch; although the chapters are linked, they are mostly interchangeable and mostly identical in tone and action.

They are, ostensibly, the story of Pat McNab, a Norman Bates character who still lives with his mother at the age of 45, until he kills her. More killings duly follow, in Pat's creepy old house two miles from the town of Gullytown, or, as Pat refers to it in one chapter, 'the Town of Liars'. But telling lies from truths is a fruitless task in a book that tries to be as stylistically insane as its protagonist.

The narrative voice, responsible for the opening sequence, 'An Introduction', and the more pedantic asides that follow, is oddly imprecise. It sometimes takes a lofty view as if trying, after the event, to make sense of Pat's slaughter of so many townfolk, a number that 'might be around the 55, 55 mark', most of them destined to fertilise his garden.

Whether we trust this voice or not is moot, partly because it seems privy to a vast amount of information that only Pat himself might have, and there is no clear indication of what happens to Pat, and partly because it also allows great discrepancies, as to the fate of Pat's dad, for example. It is also anarchically uneven in tone; at the beginning, it attributes its idioms to various people ('as Timmy Sullivan described him'; 'as Honky McCool might put it'; 'as the Americans say'), but as it proceeds, various registers blend and clash, from the lofty to the demotic, to no obvious purpose bar a straining for effect.

Sometimes, the voice insists that something cannot be described accurately; at others, it insists, wrongly, that only one particular word or term will do. This style, so unsettled, so alternately anxious or careless about its own linguistic authority, is extraordinarily circumlocutory and inefficient, and when it says: 'Let us not mince words here', the joke is obvious. It simply becomes irritating after a short while.

Pat McNab is clearly obsessed with his dead mother; clearly a bit of a drunk; clearly has trouble with reality, compounded by brushes with hallucinogens and beatings to the head. (Some resulting hallucinations take up whole chapters of surreal trips through movie clichés - sci-fi, gangster, et cetera). 'There are many theories with regard to "perception" and the relationship one might contrive with the "ineluctable modality of the visible",' says the narrator, with another hefty and tedious wink to the weary reader.

So, granted, we are in a shifting, oneiric universe where Pat McNab may or may not be a cross-dressing, mum-obsessed psychopath straight out of Hitchcock or de Palma, or we may be in the head of a lunatic fantasist, off his head on drink and drugs, weaving together storylines from old songs and movies. The question, then, is whether this is sufficiently funny or focused, and the answer, sadly, is that it is not.

McNab's character develops a little, in that through his story we see any number of influences that might have made him go terminally loopy: a bullying father, a brutal schoolmaster and treacherous friends; sexual inadequacy and taunting; a dominant mother. We also end up in a queer complicity with poor old Pat, whose victims seem deserving of their deaths (though, given that few of them start with much life beyond central-casting stereotyping, this isn't so strange).

The ongoing joke seems to be the gap between the twee sentiment or idyll of ballads and old songs (the 'emerald germs' which accompany every grisly death, and give each chapter its title) and the unhappiness of little people's little lives and deaths in Gullytown. The tales are maddening in their inconsistencies and alternative narrative branches, boring in their wordy breaks for tension-slackening exegesis, and clichéd even in their looting of genre clichés (including genre clichés that McCabe himself has previously handled to better effect). Emerald Germs reads as if Patricia Highsmith's Ripley books had been rewritten by Ardal O'Hanlon, but without decent jokes.

webTitle: Observer review: An Obedient Father, The Fundamentals of Play and The Mineral Palace

fields.headline: Gatsby's engaging modern makeover
fields.standfirst: An Obedient Father, The Fundamentals of Play and The Mineral Palace have a lot to live up to. Do they succeed?
fields.trailText: An Obedient Father, The Fundamentals of Play and The Mineral Palace have a lot to live up to. Do they succeed?
fields.body:
An Obedient Father
Akhil Shama
Faber & Faber £9.99, pp282
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Fundamentals of Play
Caitlin Macy
Viking £9.99, pp320
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The Mineral Palace
Heidi Julavits
Virago £9.99, pp326
Buy it at a discount at BOL

An Obedient Father is being compared to Dostoyevsky, The Fundamentals of Play to F. Scott Fitzgerald and The Mineral Palace to Faulkner. Such descriptions sound like marketing come-ons, as if what readers want is what customers want: more of the same, only a little different.

The little difference in the case of An Obedient Father would seem to be that it is late-twentieth-century India rather than nineteenth-century Russia in which Ram, the father in the title, commits his crimes. Obedient to his gross appetites, it seems to Ram that 'being good was, for me, one of those impossible tasks given to the heroes of fairy tales'.

He is not agonising over his weight here, though it is immense, or his bribe-taking, which, as an education official in Rajiv Gandhi's India, could also be called corpulent, but his self-indulgence wherever opportunity presents itself, whether at the wedding party for his boss's son, where Ram gets drunk and misbehaves, or in his own bedroom where, for several weeks when his daughter was 12, he repeatedly inflicted himself sexually upon her.

This is rather casually dropped into a story whose tension comes from the intimations that Ram may be fired or put in jail for his reckless career. Since he is guilelessly honest with the reader, and eager to please us as well, he comes across as likeable or pathetic rather than monstrous. What is more, the victim herself has, upon becoming a widow, moved in with him, bringing her own young daughter. She even seems to root for him, in a mournful and bitter way. As she becomes angrier and punishes Ram, it is the wronged daughter who seems loathsome.

Love crops up only to be proven mutable, corruptible, ruined or destroyed. Arranged marriages surprisingly blossom only to sour or be ended, the one mother who is loving and loved goes mad, Ram spoils the love he gives his daughter. But when his other daughter visits from America, it is clear this is not merely a tale of personal corruption but a chronicle of how, in a culture of selfish disregard, it is nearly impossible to be loving or honest. It could make sense to call this parable of modern India a Brechtian comedy; words from The Threepenny Opera could be invoked - 'First feed the face/ and then tell right from wrong'. But Akhil Sharma is an investment banker, not a Marxist, and this exceedingly human work has a flavour all its own.

At the other end of the spectrum, in both human and economic terms, is Caitlin Macy's elegant Fundamentals of Play. It is choreographed around people for whom life is a game to be played with style and lightness. The source of the Fitzgerald comparison is obvious: the narrator is an intelligent, modest Nick Carroway sort of fellow, George, who is the observer of a Daisy and Gatsby: the ineffably desirable social-set Kate, who is engaged to a young man of her class but ditches him for striver Harry Lombardi.

Summer heat in New York comes into it, and even a swell place out on Long Island. For me, with a New England boarding school-New York past, the doings of these New England boarding school alumni in New York had tremendous resonance. But I grew up in the town where The Great Gatsby is set.

The book is about what makes someone cool as compared with what makes them worthwhile. Kate has unruffled ease and adventurousness. Working-class Lombardi, on the other hand, is described by one of Kate's friends as being 'like a coffee table that's a bit of a mistake, but once you get it home, you hardly notice because it holds your magazines so well'.

While money, liquor and class-consciousness abound, as in Gatsby, the mode is Jamesian: those in the know manipulate their more innocent moral betters. The plot is ingenious in the Jamesian manner as well, with ambiguities teetering on the point of a pin and actions only clear retrospectively.

The Fitzgerald comparison is very predictable - and presumably courted - but, as George tells us about his experience of books, it is tone that one remembers. Here it is elegiac, sure, world-weary - at once deadpan and lyrical.

Heidi Julavits's The Mineral Palace ain't no Faulkner, but then Faulkner wasn't always Faulkner. If this resembles his work at all, it is the late potboiling Faulkner. Here, pretty young wife of callow, unfaithful new doctor goes off to bleak Colorado town during the Depression. Miserable and lonely taking care of their odd, unresponsive baby, wife gets job on local newspaper to write pap but discovers the town's seamy side.

It is here that you expect fulfilment of a cliché - girl reporter makes good, uncovers corruption, helps downtrodden, finds true love - since that's how it's been set up, but instead you get at least two too many wives wry with knowledge of their husband's infidelities and a melodramatic gothic past for the heroine.

webTitle: Observer review: As She Climbed Across the Table by Jonathan Lethem

fields.headline: It's a funny old universe
fields.standfirst: Anthropologist meets physicist. The rest is epistemology in Jonathan Lethem's As She Climbed Across the Table
fields.trailText: Anthropologist meets physicist. The rest is epistemology in Jonathan Lethem's As She Climbed Across the Table
fields.body:
As She Climbed Across the Table
Jonathan Lethem
Faber & Faber £9.99, pp192
Buy it at a discount at BOL

This is Jonathan Lethem's second novel to be published in the UK and like the first, Motherless Brooklyn, it has a wonderful momentum: compressed, quick-witted, unfailingly inventive. The mood is lighter - more Howard Hawks screwball comedy than film noir - but the scenario is familiar and the humour is irresistible; three times, with me as a subject in ideal lab conditions, it produced that rarest of experimental data: actual, audible laughter.

As it twists and turns, As She Climbed Across the Table gives vent to more intellectual curiosity than many a po-faced novel of ideas. And, most endearingly of all, it echoes Motherless Brooklyn's spirit - acerbic, impatient but fundamentally affectionate.

For a brief moment - perhaps only the first lines of the book - Lethem's narrator, Philip Engstrand, seems to have got his bearings. His world, admittedly, is a distinctive one. He is an anthropologist at the University of North California at Beauchamp, specialising in the study of academia - 'departmental politics and territorial squabbles, the places where disciplines overlapped, fed back and interfered'.

His work is, as he says, 'irrelevant but strong', and only published in German periodicals. But it makes sense to him, he earns an honest wage and, above all, - this being a tale of romance - he has found Alice Coombs. A particle physicist, she is the person he has been hoping to find. They are in love. His life seems to have a plan, and he feels as if he knows what it is.

And then everything falls apart. Before he can really respond, Alice has moved out of their flat to set up a 24-hour watch on a physics experiment which has created a void, a hole in the universe: something, at any rate, which makes things disappear and reappear - who knows where; perhaps in parallel invisible universes. Two blind men have moved in in her place, another woman is on the scene (nature, as they say, abhorring a vacuum) and a nightmarish Chekhovian love chain - Petya loves Masha, Masha loves Schrödinger etc - is shaping up nicely.

Cue scenes of Philip in the other woman's office in the middle of the night, being told to relax. 'I am relaxed. It's just buried under layers of incredulity and panic. But underneath those I'm very relaxed.'

With a sickening jolt, Philip is returned to the maelstrom of individual consciousness, trying to get a grip on a reality which, as quantum physics has taught us, cannot be fixed without an observer and which is always affected by that observer. This way, ladies and gentlemen, for the epistemological minefield. First exhibit: dark matter. Physicists know that 90 per cent of the matter in the universe must exist - otherwise, none of their equations would balance. The only problem is that it is impossible to detect; it just has to be taken on trust until the right experiments come along. In a similar admirable spirit of bloody-mindedness, Philip doesn't want to understand why Alice has gone; he just wants her back.

Faber has reversed the order of publication of Lethem's books, and there is a risk in this. After Motherless Brooklyn, people may expect another detective novel, the comedy to be closer to violence, and the characters to have further to fall. But this should only be a temporary distraction. In its mild way, As She Climbed Across the Table has just as good a right hook.

fields.standfirst: Justin Cartwright tries to grasp the difference between the real and the unreal at the heart of New Labour in Half in Love
fields.trailText: Justin Cartwright tries to grasp the difference between the real and the unreal at the heart of New Labour in Half in Love
fields.body:
Half in Love
Justin Cartwright
Sceptre £14.99, pp309
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Surprisingly few novelists have tried to capture the authentic inauthenticity of Blair's Britain, and none has succeeded. The subject seems to lend itself to caricature - Julian Barnes's curious England, England is an example - instead of sustained examination, as if the Government and its electorate were creations of Tom Sharpe rather than of, say, Philip Roth. The ostensible ambition of Justin Cartwright's novel is to set this record straight, to essay in fiction a credible vision of a nation in search of a vision of itself. He throws in a love story, too, for good measure.

One of the difficulties in presenting a coherent literary critique of contemporary Britishness and, more especially, Englishness is that the parameters of the debate are so wearily familiar. Interrogating our collective identity is a staple of a self-absorbed media and invariably produces a stubborn triumvirate of observations: that presentation has triumphed over substance in public life; that football hooligans are the last poisonous gasp of empire; that the nation is unhealthily obsessed with celebrity.

Cartwright does not stray from this received template. Richard McAllister, the hero of Half in Love, is the conscience of a headline-paranoid Cabinet, he is stabbed by an 'Ingerland' supporter at a football match, and is in love with a married British actress, Joanna Jermyn, who has made good in Hollywood.

The very predictability of this plotting looks a little like a symptom of the reality it describes: England, in Cartwright's view, is a nation trapped in clichés of its own making; in the absence of the old truisms national character has been replaced by an assemblage of cut-outs. Thus, Richard's assailant, a skin head called Carl Planky, is a cartoonish soccer thug (as if there were any other kind); while Richard's father is a self-conscious antique from an age and a class which believed that if it no longer had the right to the country's wealth, at least still felt proprietorial over 'its tone...'

The star-crossed - Daily Star-crossed - lovers, meanwhile, are paid to present the expected versions of themselves to their public. Joanna portrays a heritage confection of studied Englishness for the benefit of American film producers. Richard, one of the Prime Minister's old school friends, finds himself an unwilling disciple of a controlling, cultish administration. When Richard's love for Joanna threatens to become a tabloid exclusive, he is pressurised to stay apart from her by a government terrified of 'chaos or rumour or scandal'.

The novel adopts an irritating atmosphere of selective verisimilitude, in which the the Prime Minister is not namechecked. Blair, however, is present in all but name, shepherded by his media minder and stooge, Talfryn, an Alastair Campbell from the valleys who Cartwright nicely portrays desperately trying to keep the lid on life when it threatens to get the way of the project: 'It's one bloody fuck-up after another,' he confides glumly to Richard of his job.

As a result of his near-fatal attack, Richard has stepped back from politics and has been charged by the Prime Minister with producing a manifesto for the next election; he is dubbed the Minister of Thought, but, of course, he has no ideas, other than a vague, subversive notion that they should 'try to elevate lack of conviction to the status of universal principle'.

Removed from proximity to power, Richard's contrived life unravels, the scar on his neck having become a ritual bloodletting, through 'which all kinds of things might enter'. Far from conjuring thoughts of the manifesto, Richard thus finds himself dwelling on his great-uncle's monograph on the use of horses at the siege of Mafeking, the last knockings of imperial authority, and measuring its assumptions against the present. The parallel also allows the author to weigh, for example, the 'arms race' of toiletries in designer shower-rooms against the bracing certainties of Baden-Powell's cold baths, and to deliberate on the culinary advances that have replaced boiled-beef-and-carrots ethics with a philosophy in which 'the loin shall lie down with the lime'.

This string of smart observation is freighted with an old-fashioned affair of the heart. While Richard is thinking of England, he wishes he could be lying back with Joanna, who is on location in America. A good proportion of the book is spent eavesdropping the repeated words 'I love you' on transatlantic phone calls, a mantra assailed by very contemporary pressures. Richard believes he will find an honesty to cling to in Joanna, but romance is the stuff of clichés and, instead, victims of their times, they end up doing it by the book.

fields.headline: Wenger's worries
fields.trailText: Wenger worries as Arsenal blow it.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger has what he describes as 'a strong sense of humour'. Allowing for some flexibility in language, what the Arsenal coach was trying to convey (I think) was that he did not consider the dominance of Manchester United in the Premiership a matter that would allow any openings for even the mildest joke.

And there was nothing funny about another blown opportunity for Arsenal to dig into that enormous gap between them and Alex Ferguson's team.

It could so easily have been different. In the third minute Robert Pires cut inside Dennis Wise on the left, sidestepped Sam Dalla Bona and shot across a sleeping goalmouth, evading the stationary head of Frank Leboeuf to give Carlo Cudicini little hope as the balled skimmed into the top right corner.

Raid after Arsenal raid followed, amid hardly a semblance of resistance. Thierry Henry was on fire. Twice he wove through the ludicrously thin three-man last barrier that Chelsea had posted in the first half, and was denied only by the athleticism of Cudicini.

Yesterday morning, Paul Merson, who knows a thing or two about Arsenal, said his old team were hinting at a return to form, that the 6-1 Boxing Day slaughter of Leicester City showed they still had the hunger for it. 'We'd be lucky to score six in January,' Merson said of troubled Aston Villa.

Well, the Gunners looked more like Villa in the second half than the team Merson remembered. When John Terry equalised 12 minutes after the break - only his second goal for Chelsea, after last season's effort against Gillingham in the FA Cup - the awful truth about Arsenal's frailties was exposed.

Terry, one of the few Chelsea players to rise above mediocrity in the first half, worked his way into the scrum going up for Dennis Wise's corner from the left and Seaman, worryingly reticent, found himself grasping at air. Terry's header from a rebound bundled its way over the line and Wenger turned his gaze away in acknowledgment that Arsenal had once again thrown away a lead.

'We did it against Sunderland and we did it against Bayern Munich,' he said. Pressed as to how a team capable of machine-gun scoring - the team Merson so admires - could turn to jelly so often lately, Wenger was characteristically blunt.

'I think it is the fear factor, a confidence problem, more psychological than physical. We show great potential and we do not cheat our supporters, but we don't get the necessary consistency.'

The image of a frightened Arsenal is not a familiar one, especially given the pedigree of the squad and the fortitude of the coach. But Wenger knows what everyone else in football knows: Arsenal, 13 points adrift of the lead, are drifting. 'United are out of my mind,' he said. And, he agreed, 'out of sight'.

At least they are in better shape than Chelsea. Despite sharing the points, Claudio Ranieri's side could hardly have looked less like a team. Terry conceded under mild questioning that they were much more relaxed after abandoning the three-man defence for a 4-4-2 shape in the second half. He could hardly disagree with the blindingly obvious, but he would not be drawn into saying the players had bullied Ranieri into the switch.

'Yes, we were better in the second half when we changed our shape. But it was the manager's decision in the end,' he said. 'We just get on with it.'

It says much about Chelsea's form that Marcel Desailly again stood so tall above his team-mates. He was powerful, decisive - and frustrated. Whenever he tried to construct anything from the back in the first half, he was confronted by a rabble in midfield. Gustavo Poyet and Eider Gudjohnsen toiled in bursts; and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink seemed lonely up front, constantly throwing his hands in the air after going forward on his own, only to look around at unpeopled grass behind him.

As for Seaman's comeback, he gifted Chelsea their goal and his England future is surely in the past. He's been out nearly 12 weeks, missing 16 games and, at 37, it showed. He was sharp early on but, under pressure, he cracked. As Wenger said of the team as a whole, it might be 'the fear factor'.

webTitle: Evergreen Merson has moved back into the frame

fields.headline: Evergreen Merson has moved back into the frame
fields.trailText: Sven-Göran Eriksson may turn to Paul Merson - and the Villa man is ready for the challenge.
fields.body:
Paul Merson could be in line for an England recall for the friendly against Spain next month at the Villa Park ground where he plies his club trade - and he says he would 'definitely not turn down the challenge' if the national team's new manager Sven-Göran Eriksson asks him to end his self-imposed international retirement.

After listing the young players on whom he plans to build England's future on his first day in office at the FA's new headquarters in Soho Square, Eriksson also went on to offer hope to those apparently coming to the end of their careers.

'You must take decisions which are good for the team,' added Eriksson. 'That is the only thing that is important. I am not seeing how old or young they are but just seeing if they can do anything good for the team. The future is for young players but you can't only choose young players, you must have players with experience. I don't believe England can win in Germany with only young players.'

Eriksson's assistant Tord Grip watched Merson in Villa's FA Cup tie at Newcastle last Sunday and was impressed by his stylish display. He is thought to have then asked the Villa chairman Doug Ellis how old his No 10 was, before telling Ellis that Merson had 'the best brain' of any English player he had so far seen in his two months scouting Premiership matches; more than 20 of them so far.

'The Aston Villa chairman asked me what I thought of Merson,' said Grip. 'I told him that he was the best mid field player on the pitch. Everybody could see that.'

Merson, 32 and with 21 caps, admits now that he was 'hasty' in announcing his retirement 11 months ago after being omitted from Kevin Keegan's squad for a friendly against Argentina. Then, he said it was time to use international weeks to spend more time with his three young sons now that his access to them was more limited due to his separation from his wife Lorraine. In reality, the disappointment at a time when he was in top form cut deep.

'It was also because I was playing really well and still not getting picked, so I thought my chance had gone,' says Merson. 'It was a hasty decision, I admit, and if I was selected now I would not turn down the challenge. I'm not holding my breath, I have to say, but it's nice that my name's being mentioned again.'

Merson agrees that he has also said it is time for the younger players to be given their chance. 'And so they should,' he now says. 'But I reckon I've still got a lot to offer, like a lot of experienced players. It's all about what's best for the country. I'm fitter than I've ever been and playing more consistently than at any time in my career.'

Indeed, Merson has largely been Villa's saving grace over the past 12 months, shouldering the burden of creativity in a functional, efficient but uninspiring team. His problems with gambling and alcoholism have been well-documented, but he has been in solid recovery for some time now.

His selection would not only be popular with the Villa Park crowd, but also within a squad in need of a tonic. It might even be a signal by Eriksson that England's betting days are over and that it is time for some serious professionalism.

The statements by Eriksson and Grip will also encourage other ageing players, such as Teddy Sheringham and Tony Adams, as a message that there remain places for quality performers. It is surely the only wise course. Youth has its place, and deserves its fling, but England throw out the geriatrics with the bath chairs at their peril.

webTitle: Gregory and Newcastle: The talk of the Toon

fields.headline: Gregory and Newcastle: The talk of the Toon
fields.trailText: John Gregory and his coaching team of Steve Harrison and Ross MacLaren are indicating they will up sticks and quit for Newcastle United, according to sources.
fields.body:
Aston Villa sources close to John Gregory and his coaching team of Steve Harrison and Ross MacLaren are indicating they will up sticks and quit for Newcastle United.

Their whispering campaign has been going on for several weeks, throughout Gregory's uncomfortable stand-off with 'time-warp' chairman Doug Ellis after which Ellis demanded - and received - a grovelling apology.

Newcastle, Villa's opponents in this week's FA Cup replay, have not encouraged the gossip, with chairman Freddy Shepherd telling one reporter: 'Gregory will never manage this club while I am chairman.' But talk of the move has increased in the past week, especially in the Villa dressing room.

So what gives? Gregory might benefit from speculation if it was perceived that he might quit, with fans already calling for the chairman's head. And, while Shepherd has privately rubbished the speculation, his relationship with manager Bobby Robson has been strained by the club's refusal to allow Robson to take temporary charge of England and the board's disquiet over his recent transfer buys.

And there's the rub. Gregory's unease at Villa was caused by the club's lack of spending. Yet Robson has been forced to hunt for cut-price bargains at home and abroad. Add to that Ellis's decision on Friday to reactivate the £9.5m Juan-Pablo Angel purchase and the picture is, at best, clouded by intrigue.

A close friend of Gregory said: 'He wants to work for a club that has passion and ambition. He's finding it harder working with a chairman like Ellis.' Gregory, aware of the gossip, yesterday briefed one reporter, insisting that while he knew of the gossip, he had not instigated it. If Gregory did go, the word in Scotland is that the Hibernian manager, Alex McLeish might replace him. Hibs are resigned to losing McLeish to the Premiership.

fields.headline: Wilson level best
fields.trailText: Wilson level best.
fields.body:
Danny Wilson returned to South Yorkshire for the first time since he was relieved of his duties with Sheffield Wednesday late last season and he was a happier man as he saw his Bristol City team deprive Rotherham of two points with an equaliser a minute from time.

Both teams may be pleasing to the eye with the ball being cherished but the pitch cut up and their rhythm was disrupted.

Indicative of this was a miss by Rotherham midfielder Stewart Talbot after only nine minutes when, after gliding past two City defenders and with time to spare, he pulled his shot wide of the target.

The Second Division rivals were comfortable on the ball but looked happier when making swift counter-attacks. It was hardly surprising that the best opportunities came from set-pieces.

Rotherham defender Dave Artell rose unmarked at the far post from a corner but his header flashed wide and when the opening goal came after 34 minutes the ball didn't touch the ground.

A long throw from Rotherham defender Rob Scott was flicked on by Artell and Mark Robins, the former Manchester United striker, looped his header over City goalkeeper Steve Phillips.

In the second half, doubtless after a few words from Wilson, City were transformed. They pushed wing backs Mickey Bell and Scott Murray further forward and they became increasingly influential as City laid siege to the home goal.

On the hour a Lee Peacock header had to be well saved by Rotherham goalkeeper Ian Gray and Peacock was again foiled by Gray when he saw his free-kick turned round a post.

Rotherham manager Ronnie Moore has assembled a team by shrewd wheeling and dealing in the market and by buying experienced journeymen. While many pundits thought his side would be fighting a relegation battle, they have surprised teams with their grit and determination as well as skill which has taken them into the promotion picture.

However, their battling qualities were undermined by a lack of concentration a minute from time. A corner from Bell found Peter Beadle who rose unmarked to head home the equaliser, his third goal in five games since he returned to the side.

Moore said: 'We were under pressure in the second half, but I never felt my heart pumping away and our keeper didn't really have to make a save. I'm disappointed that we lost concentration from a corner because we would have gone eight points clear of City.'

fields.headline: Valley of the doldrums
fields.trailText: Walsh blunder opens up Bradford.
fields.body:
Life can be cruel, but Manchester United can be so much worse. After Bradford had drawn much of the Champions' sting in a disciplined opening hour, a moment of harsh misfortune gave the favourites a chance they were never going to pass up. What is worse, the culprit was Gary Walsh, the home keeper, who used to play at Old Trafford. He at least ensured himself a generous welcome if ever he should return.

With the match still goalless as it entered its closing stages, Valley Parade was buzzing with excitement. Against the odds and with complete disregard for the form book, United were struggling to create chances and Bradford were hinting at an upset. Walsh, though, had other ideas. As a harmless back-pass rolled its way towards him, Walsh lifted his left foot to clear. In a split-second, 72 minutes of tireless work and a thousand dreams were rendered meaningless as he missed his kick and Teddy Sheringham rolled the ball into an unguarded net.

'I didn't think we were going to win,' said Alex Ferguson, 'but you'd never wish that on a goalkeeper, particularly Gary Walsh, who is such a good keeper. But after that, the game opened up and we finished well. We've worked hard for our points today. We had to.'

Walsh had barely raised his head from his hands when Ryan Giggs burst into the area to smash in a second. A first league goal from Luke Chadwick, who finished with composure from Roy Keane's astute through-ball, gave the scoreline an extremely flattering appearance from United's perspective. Ferguson needed to summon his deepest powers of overstatement to surmise: 'I think it was a decent performance by us. It wasn't a great performance but it's a good, workmanlike way of playing.'

It certainly was not their greatest performance, but there were plenty of positives to be taken from it. Jaap Stam played for an hour and has obviously lost nothing but a little fitness after three months out with an Achilles injury. Sheringham and Andy Cole continued their comebacks, but it was the appearance of Luke Chadwick, a second-half substitute, which offered most encouragement.

Chadwick will never sell many duvet covers, but he is comfortable on the ball and - whisper it - caused Bradford more problems on the right than did David Beckham.

Bradford, too, should gain some encouragement. 'We made them work hard to beat us,' said Jim Jefferies. 'We feel we're starting to perform. We're looking solid, passing well, working hard for each other. But you can't legislate for what happened today. It was a sickener the way it happened. Until then Bradford were comfortable, and had it not been for that blunder we would maybe have taken something from the game.'

United dominated much of the possession, but struggled to create chances. Giggs missed their best of the first half, running from midfield, exchanging passes with Sheringham on his way unhindered through the home defence, but the finish was weak.

In the second period, their threat was limited to Beckham's free-kicks, from which Michael Silvestre and Giggs came close to heading an opening goal. In the end, though, they needed a moment of fortune to gift them an advantage they would never surrender.

For all their resilience, Bradford's opportunities were limited to one in each half. It is not for nothing that they are the Premiership's lowest scorers, but they should at least be applauded for their willingness to try to attack when many sides would have erred towards footballing filibuster.

It says a lot that they came no closer in the first half than a 40-yard shot from Dean Windass, acrobatically and somewhat unnecessarily turned over by Fabien Barthez. Then after an hour Robbie Blake raced through the visiting defence only to roll the ball apologetically into the side netting when only Barthez blocked his route to goal.

And so ends a memorable week for Bradford. Three of their most high-profile signings have been transfer-listed; one, Dan Petrescu, already gone. On Monday, barely 7,000 saw them crash out of the FA Cup. In such times of turmoil, the last team you want to see strolling into the visitors' dressing room are Manchester United. While their performance was better than could have been expected, it will be forgotten long before the result. For in four Premiership games, United's aggregate lead over Bradford is now 17-0. The tide may be turning, but Bradford still have a long way to go.

fields.headline: The blank generation
fields.trailText: The misery continues.
fields.body:
Everton will be kicking themselves for failing to ease their relegation worries. They had enough possession and sufficient chances to have won with something to spare and end a depressing run of just one point from six matches.

Kevin Campbell had a nightmare in front of goal and Neil Sullivan pulled off two jaw-dropping saves to earn his side a draw. In the end the credit was due to Tottenham for a solid if uninspiring backs-to-the-wall performance. As for Everton, they cannot afford to concede too many more points like this.

Before the match the home side paraded some of the players from their championship winning team of 1969-70 before kick-off. They were no doubt disappointed by the poor quality on offer in today's side - injuries not withstanding - even though the first half saw Everton come out on top.

Only two fine saves by Neil Sullivan kept Tottenham in-touch. The goalkeeper swung himself to his left to turn a side a shot on the run by Thomas Gravesen. Then, Sullivan made a one-handed stop from Kevin Campbell, who met Gravesen's centre firmly with his head. This improvement came after the early loss of David Weir, who limped off to be replaced by Alex Cleland. Both sides had chances late in the half from free-kicks awarded just outside the penalty box. Tim Sherwood, assuming the captaincy in Sol Campbell's absence had his effort held under the crossbar by Thomas Myhre. At the other end, from an almost identical position, Stephen Hughes sliced his shot wide.

Everton should have gone ahead when Kevin Campbell released Niclas Alexandersson, who did the hard work by cutting past Stephen Clemence, but Alexandersson could only direct his shot straight at Sullivan. Sullivan also safely dealt with a low shot from Joe-Max Moore and looked on top of his game.

Everton chances continued to fall to Campbell. Mark Pembridge played him into space, and although slightly to the left of goal, Campbell should have done better than clip the far post. Shortly afterwards he came across Gary Doherty to meet Alex Andersson's cross but headed yards wide.

In an effort to stem the tide of constant attacks, Tottenham made a double substitution, bringing on Simon Davies and David McEwen for Willem Korsten and Oyvind Leonhardsen. But it had little real effect with George Graham's team dropping back en masse and leaving Sergei Rebrov increasingly forlorn up front.
