fields.headline: Tel's Boks of tricks
fields.trailText: Tel opens his Boks of tricks.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough's transformation since the arrival of Terry Venables was sustained with considerable ease against an out-of-sorts Derby who were allowed a solitary shot on target.

Middlesbrough are now unbeaten in seven games under Venables, who unsurprisingly considered this their best performance since he took control. 'We kept our clean sheet, played with imagination and finished well,' he said. His verdict and the margin of victory suggest a comfortable success - and so it was in the end - but Boro still needed a 41st-minute penalty to make the crucial breakthrough.

Venables was planning half-time adjustments when Alen Boksic despatched the spot-kick after a foul by Darryl Powell on the Croatian that was spotted by few people other than referee Rob Styles. 'It was a harsh decision,' said County's assistant manager, Colin Todd. 'We feel hard done by. They hadn't looked like scoring and decisions sometimes change the course of a game.'

Todd was even-handed enough to accept his side didn't appear capable of scoring one as Boksic's guile and the assured passing of Australian Paul Okon enabled Middlesbrough to dictate. Okon's chief midfield ally was Paul Ince, energetic enough to suggest he may be right to insist he can still play a part in England's future.

Ince's commitment was admirable and one of his forward breaks in first-half stoppage-time ended in penalty appeals as he went down under a challenge from Horacio Carbonari. This time, Mr Styles shook his head.

Derby finally roused in the 51st minute when Malcolm Christie's shot forced a save from Schwarzer. Little good it did Christie; he was soon substituted, three minutes before Derby conceded another goal. It was a stylish one.

Ince's free-kick was volleyed into the area by Karembeu, presenting Ugo Ehiogu with an easy chance. Ehiogu's header was the prelude to a period of total domination by Boro, who almost added to their lead when Boksic headed Dean Gordon's corner against the bar. He eventually claimed his second with a sublime piece of finishing after collecting a through- ball from Robbie Mustoe while adding to the education of inexperienced defender Chris Riggott in the 81st minute.

Boksic had been substituted by the time Brian Deane was fouled inside the area in the dying seconds, leaving Hamilton Ricard to take the penalty to give Middlesbrough their best win since October 1998.

They are now out of the bottom three after conceding only two goals in seven games - a penalty and an own goal. 'It's very promising, but there's a long way to go,' said Venables. 'Let's hope we can keep it up.'

Todd, dismayed by his players' late capitulation, said: 'We lost our shape and discipline. Now we've got to bounce back.' They must do it with the knowledge that Middlesbrough's impressive emergence will make life more difficult for Derby as the struggle for survival intensifies. Todd undoubtedly believes the club he once managed can escape.

'They shouldn't be in this position,' he said, 'when you look at the amount of money they have spent and the experience of their players.'

fields.headline: Sleepy Stoke
fields.trailText: Reading take best of bore draw.
fields.byline: Michael Prestage at the Britannia Stadium
fields.body:
How the pundits get it wrong. The prediction was that this should have been a high-scoring game given that Reading's appalling away record was allied to a propensity to leak goals, and Stoke had hit a rich seam of form recently. It was not to be, in a disappointing game.

Despite having the worst away record of any side in the top half of the division, the Reading defenders were in miserly mood and limited a lacklustre Stoke to a handful of half-chances. After a seven-point return from their three Christmas matches, this was not a promotion performance for the home fans.

Indeed, the best chances in the first period fell to the visitors. A speculative 50-yard-plus Beckhamesque shot by Phil Parkinson had Stoke goalkeeper Birkir Kristinsson backtracking, but the ball landed on top of the netting to save his blushes. In the dying minutes of the half Tony Rougier out-muscled Brynjar Gunnarsson but Kristinsson comfortably saved the near-post shot.

A 64th-minute tussle between Stoke's Graham Cavanagh and Reading's Darren Gaskey led to an unseemly melee involving half-a-dozen players. When order was restored, it was the visitors who had the free-kick, and the ball pumped into the box provided Rougier with a free header that he should have done better with.

Stoke have produced decisive late goals, but they failed to emulate this feat this time. Their best chance came in the dying minutes when replacement Rikhardur Dadason headed just over.

But Reading will regard this as a point gained rather than two lost against a team one place above them.

fields.headline: Reds turn back clock
fields.trailText: Reds turn back clock against sorry Villa.
fields.body:
Sven-GÖran Eriksson and Tord Grip went to the wrong game. This was vintage Liverpool, as impressive as anything from the Anfield golden era of 20 years ago which the Swedish pair remember so fondly.

Finnish international Jari Litmanen might have been the catalyst for what was only Liverpool's third away win of the season, but Steven Gerrard and Danny Murphy are both English, and the two goalscorers were at the heart of a performance which left Aston Villa as dazed and confused as Juan Pablo Angel, the £9.5m signing they introduced at half-time. The only thing which might have perplexed Eriksson was having to wait 82 minutes to see Michael Owen - and perhaps a lot longer for a glimpse of Robbie Fowler.

Gérard Houllier is not a man to do things by halves, and obviously not a manager to meddle with. When he said Fowler had lost his place in the side and would have to work his socks off to get back, he was not joking. Fowler did not even make the squad, and though Litmanen is still short of match fitness he was given a full debut, with Owen relegated to the bench. 'Robbie travelled with us. He is not being punished,' said Houllier. 'I simply picked the 16 players most ready for this match. We will need Robbie in the future and he'll play. It's just a matter of attitude.'

Litmanen was certainly ready. The former Ajax and Barcelona striker showed up well in Liverpool's opening attacks, displaying a neatness and ability to find space which should come in handy once his team-mates tune in to his wavelength. A single touch from Litmanen set Vladimir Smicer free down the left as early as the fourth minute, only for his cross to sail over the penalty area.

Litmanen was also involved in a clever one-two from a corner which led to Dietmar Hamann hammering a shot narrowly wide after 10 minutes, though Liverpool did not have the early stages all their own way. David Ginola forced the first save with a dipping shot which Sander Westerveld only just reached in time, and a precision pass from the Frenchman gave Paul Merson a rather better opportunity, but his first-time effort flew high and wide.

Although Liverpool were dominating a makeshift Villa midfield, they almost paid for a defensive lapse in the 17th minute, when Sami Hyypia allowed Gareth Barry a shooting chance from the edge of the area. But he missed the target with Westerveld out of position.

Seven minutes later, Villa were regretting that miss and counting the cost of a defensive error of their own. Alpay ignored a call from David James and cleared straight to Murphy, who struck a post with a thumping shot but was able to stroke in the rebound. John Gregory confessed he was 'slightly embarrassed' by the altercation between goalkeeper and centre-half which followed, and indicated Alpay would be disciplined for slapping James in the face.

Liverpool's second was entirely self-created and, ominously for Fowler, was started by Litmanen. The Finn's piercing pass from the centre circle picked out Murphy, who laid it off into the path of Gerrard, for a first-time shot which whistled past James. 'A magnificent goal,' Houllier purred. 'Believe me, Stevie is going to be a player. I think he could be another Vieira or Keane.'

The visitors could have had more before half-time. Litmanen's pass obliged James to race out of his area to tackle Gerrard, then Emile Heskey spotted Litmanen free on his left but was woefully unable to put his pass anywhere near him. Had that situation been reversed, Liverpool would surely have turned round three up. It was not the most auspicious time for Villa to parade their Colombian capture, particularly as he was all-too-predictably greeted with 'Who the ****ing hell are you?' from the delirious Liverpool fans.

Heskey began the second half by missing a sitter off Smicer, and for a couple of minutes Liverpool looked edgy, possibly remembering what happened at Elland Road after they took a 2-0 lead. Villa could not get a toehold on the match, however, despite withdrawing Ginola and Alpay at half-time, and Heskey made amends by laying on the third goal for Murphy to score through Gareth Southgate's legs in the 54th minute. The Villa captain was booked shortly afterwards as the rest of his side assumed the role of spectators. There were no more goals, but the Liverpool manager must have been gratified to hear his name chanted appreciatively at the end. For Gregory, there was just the silent rebuke of empty seats.

fields.headline: Moody mauls Wigan
fields.trailText: Lions increase their lead at the top.
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at The New Den
fields.body:
'Cheer up Mark McGhee,' sang Millwall's biggest crowd of the season, who came hoping to see another Neil Harris hat-trick but instead got one from Paul Moody as their side opened a four-point lead over Wigan at the top of the table.

The Millwall manager was certainly in a brighter mood than last week, when victory at Reading was soured by the personal abuse he received from supporters and even the PA announcer at his former club.

Harris scored three then, but played provider this time as Moody, the unsung half of their double-act, made sure he was given the match ball.

And with 57 league goals so far, Millwall are second only to Fulham in the country and looking an ominous bet not only for promotion but also the title. Ironically Moody used to play for Fulham, and scored a hat-trick in his final game for them on the last day of the 1998-99 season as they won the Second Division title.

McGhee has a side full of young, talented and energetic players who ran up a swift two-goal lead against Wigan, whose hopes of victory effectively ended when striker Simon Haworth was sent off after 31 minutes for trampling on Tim Cahill.

As Bruce Rioch, the Wigan manager, said on his return to one of his former clubs: 'It is hard enough here when you have 11 against 11, but once we were reduced to 10 men at 2-0 down, it was doubly difficult.'

Moody had opened the scoring in the 13th minute when he powered home a header from close range after a right-wing cross from Harris had been inadvertently flicked away from Wigan's goalkeeper Derek Stillie by his skipper Arjan de Zeeuw.

Harris was again the provider when Moody increased the lead in the 26th minute, crossing from the left this time for his partner to hook the ball past Stillie from close range. When Haworth saw red for running all over Cahill after bundling him to the ground, Millwall looked likely to run up a cricket score.

Harris volleyed just over the bar on the turn, Cahill shot just wide and Stillie made a superb save to deny Moody's sliding shot from another Harris cross.

The third goal followed on the hour, when Harris's floated centre following a short corner was flicked on by Joe Dolan and Moody ran the ball over the line from barely a yard out.

He was substituted to wild applause five minutes later, and his replacement, Richard Sadlier, almost added an immediate fourth goal, but Wigan hit back in surprise fashion when Neil Roberts shot home through a crowded penalty area after the ball had rebounded twice off the crossbar following a corner.

fields.headline: Dyer shows his class
fields.trailText: Dyer shows his class.
fields.byline: John Wilford at St James' Park
fields.body:
With Alan Shearer out of action for at least another couple of months Newcastle United's scoring opportunities rely heavily on the pace and invention of Kieron Dyer. And he proved himself up to the task. It was his probing and prompting that led to United's first two goals and he completed a splendid afternoon with an effort that owed nothing to anyone but his own sublime skill in dissecting the City defence. It may well prove to be worthy of consideration when goals of the season are judged.

What a pity then that Dyer will be suspended for United's next two games; the FA Cup replay at Villa Park and the visit to Leeds at Elland Road.

Newcastle will miss him. His ability to link with Nolberto Solano and outsprint defenders was a crucial factor in this comfortable victory. It was after one such early raid that United got a corner in the fourth minute which Solano planted on to Gary Speed's head. The Welsh international glided it home with an exquisite touch.

That was the most memorable act of a mundane first half, but the second provided much more entertainment.

First Dyer set up Solano for a glorious chance that went begging. But it was nothing compared with the catalogue of misses that followed from Coventry. Thompson, Bellamy (three times) and Aloisi could all have found the net, and their profligacy drove manager Gordon Strachan into a touchline frenzy. How he must have regretted the failure to complete the transfer of John Hartson.

Dyer then moved up a gear and settled the issue in the space of eight minutes. Combining yet again with Solano, he rolled the ball across the face of goal for Shola Ameobi to stick out a leg and poke over the line. That was in the 58th minute, and in the 66th Dyer settled all doubts with his wonderful individual effort.

If Coventry couldn't find the net by any known convention, they did gain slight consolation when Stephen Glass put into his own goal.

Newcastle manager Bobby Robson acknowledged the contributions of Dyer and Solano. 'It's going to be a headache playing without them,' he said, adding that Solano had shin splint injuries which are causing considerable concern.

Coventry are not the best travellers in the league and certainly not here, and only Thompson gave them some indication of the old Strachan-McAllister spirit they need to rediscover.

Strachan generously acknowledged Dyer's contribution: 'An exceptional talent. If he'd been on my side we would have won today.'

webTitle: Bottoms up as Crewe and QPR get winning habit

fields.headline: Bottoms up as Crewe and QPR get winning habit
fields.standfirst: League review
fields.trailText: League review.
fields.body:
The most notable First Division performances came from the bottom, with Crewe and QPR asserting themselves with wins over Grimsby and West Bromwich Albion.

Crewe did not look like a team with the worst away record in the section in their 3-1 victory at Blundell Park. QPR were so much on top against West Brom that the visitors could count themselves fortunate to have kept the scoreline to 2-0.

QPR owed their breakthrough to a mistake by Richard Sneekes, whose clearance straight to Peter Crouch led to Chris Plummer getting his first goal for the club. Sam Koejoe secured QPR's first win in five matches with an explosive shot.

West Brom's manager, Gary Megson, who was particularly critical of his defence, admitted: 'I am more worried about my team now than I have been all season. We have a lot of players who are just not performing as they should be.' The other team in the bottom three, Huddersfield, were held to a goalless draw by Stockport, thus emphasising how much they need Peter Ndlovu. The Birmingham striker, who made a big impact during his recent loan period with Huddersfield, was recalled by his club last week, and Huddersfield manager Lou Macari said: 'It is a tricky situation. He will not sign a permanent deal with us because he is out of contract at the end of the season, but I still hope we can get him back here on loan.'

Still, in the meantime, the good news for Macari is that yesterday's result - while not what he hoped for - at least helped lift Huddersfield to the sixth from bottom spot. The team who have replaced them in the relegation zone are Sheffield Wednesday, who were easily beaten 2-0 at Blackburn.

But who can predict what the relegation zone situation will be in the coming weeks? Those bottom six teams are separated by only one point.

Fulham, the leading Nationwide scorers, and also the team who have had the most shots on target (208 at the last count) according to Opta Index, again emphasised their finishing class with a 2-0 win over Norwich.

It needed something special to find the breakthrough against a solid Norwich defence, and Luis Saha provided it by twisting around his two markers and letting fly with a 20-yard shot into the far corner of the net. The goal of the day surely? Louis Boa Morte, the other Fulham player at the top of the individual scoring chart, added the other goal.

With John Hartson opting out of Wimbledon's match against Preston, Jason Euell took centre stage by scoring twice in a 3-1 win. As for the day's misses, Wolves' captain Kevin Muscat failed to convert an 88th minute penalty at home to Portsmouth, who escaped with a 1-1 draw.

One of the more unlikely rivalries in British football was renewed with Bolton facing Tranmere.

The relationship between the two clubs, which started to become less than friendly with Tranmere's win over Bolton in the 1991 Third Division promotion play-off final, reached a lower point than ever last season when they clashed over the long throw-ins of Tranmere's Dave Challinor in the Worthington Cup semi-final ties. Before their match at Tranmere earlier this season, the Bolton team arrived just 30 minutes before the kick-off, already in their kit, and left immediately after the final whistle, still wearing their kit and without even having a shower. 'He [Bolton manager Sam Allardyce] is a peculiar man,' said Tranmere's chairwoman, Lorraine Rogers.

Tranmere's striker, Scott Taylor, a former Bolton player, who still lives in the town, insists: 'The rivalry is between the supporters - it has never bothered the players. We try to play it down.' Maybe so, but yesterday's match - in which Bolton completed the double over Tranmere with a 2-0 win - was a bad-tempered affair. It was certainly a game to try to forget for Tranmere's goalkeeper, John Achterberg, whose mistake helped Bolton take the lead, and their defender Clint Hill, who scored an own goal.

webTitle: Beattie a victim of Carling curse

fields.headline: Beattie a victim of Carling curse
fields.trailText: Beattie a victim of Carling curse.
fields.body:
On the day Sven Göran Eriksson began life as the England manager, Glenn Hoddle - who would probably have still been in the position had he had not imploded almost two years to the day - was overseeing his Southampton side against a Charlton team under the direction of Alan Curbishley, who some people predict may one day replace Eriksson.

In truth, on this occasion neither side displayed any qualities that suggested they were under the influence of international-class managers.

Hoddle had hinted in his programme notes that he felt Kevin Keegan should have been replaced after Euro 2000, writing that Eriksson should have been in place for the start of the World Cup qualifying matches.

England's progress these days is of only passing interest to Hoddle now he is more concerned with Southampton. Thanks to the use of ideas such as psychologists and sports scientists - but not, so far, apparently Eileen Drewery - he has helped the Saints steer a mid-table course for most of the season.

Hoddle's talent for helping players discover hidden depths is best illustrated by the progress of James Beattie under his tutelage. His transformation from goal-shy flop to goal-scoring sensation was recognised before the kick-off when he was awarded the Carling Player of the Month award for December.

With a bit more luck Beattie might have added to his burgeoning reputation. In the 23rd minute, he should have finished better when faced with a one-on-one with Dean Kiely but shot against the Charlton goalkeeper's legs. Fifteen minutes later, when he did beat Kiely with a 20-yard free-kick, Graham Stuart was on the line to clear.

Charlton seemed to be still haunted by the memory of last week's struggles against Dagenham in the FA Cup. The excellent Richard Rufus and Kiely aside, their play was ragged and disjointed.

Afterwards, while Hoddle spoke of missed chances and, perplexingly, 'being disappointed for the right reasons', Curbishley was more realistic. 'It was a scrappy game,' he said. 'But our away record has been so poor we are relieved.'

In the end, they had the crossbar to thank for securing a point. In the game's only real moment of quality, Southampton's Matthew Oakley drove a 35-yard effort against the bar in the 72nd minute. The highlights won't take long for Eriksson to sort through on the video.

fields.headline: Anglo bustle not subtle
fields.trailText: Anglos have an off day as Sven looks on.
fields.body:
The happy Hammers claim they won the World Cup for England in 1966 so maybe that is why Sven-Göran Eriksson chose the home of Hurst, Moore and Peters to watch his first game as England manager.

The crowd appreciated the gesture and allayed fears of a xenophobic outburst by cheering the Swede to his directors box seat with a standing ovation from all corners of the ground. The man with the tan responded with a wave and clenched fist salute. The players showed their appreciation by dishing out a typically English scuffle of a match... big on bustle and low on subtle.

Sunderland's eighth win in 10 games, lifting them into second place in the Premiership table, was the significance of yesterday's match, but was not of much concern to Eriksson. He had come to see some of West Ham's five and Sunderland's four Englishmen in action. First to show was West Ham's Stuart Pearce, still pressing for further international recognition before turning 39 in April.

Now a central defender, the sometime England left-back cleverly used a second-minute corner to display his renowned shooting ability and drove an inswinger that forced Thomas Sorensen to stretch and tip the ball over the bar. When the ball was knocked in again it fell to Trevor Sinclair, another name on Eriksson's watching brief, and he cracked a couple of shots that ultimately produced another save from the Danish keeper. Nice early stuff from the Englishmen, but it was a false dawn and did not mean that skill and entertainment would become a major feature of Eriksson's afternoon.

West Ham, though gaining more possession thanks largely to the outrageous abilities of Joe Cole, were finding it hard to pose any threat to a Sunderland defence well marshalled by their captain, left-back and another trying to catch Eriksson's eye, Michael Gray. Young Cole, however, has already been mentioned in glowing terms by Eriksson and was the only one who really stood out yesterday.

'I briefly spoke to Sven afterwards. It was not the best game to watch, but he was clearly impressed by Joe. He is a special player,' said West Ham manager Harry Redknapp. Sunderland's Peter Reid added: 'Not one for the purists - it was blood and thunder stuff. But I am sure he [Eriksson] has seen a few good things and my lads are just delighted to be second, deservedly so.'

England's new super Swede may have also fancied the Sunderland No 32, who gave the visitors a 23rd-minute lead. But quality Englishmen are spread thinly in the Premiership these days and Stanislav Varga ain't one of them. Not that they care in Sunderland after the giant Slovakian defender firmly headed in his first goal for the club from a Gavin McCann free-kick. Now McCann is an English player, and one to watch. Plucked from the Everton reserves a couple of years ago, he is a competitive midfielder in command of a sweet sense of timing with a dead ball. Cole, meanwhile, continued to impress, but made a hash of his finish when he had an excellent chance to score a 33rd-minute equaliser, having turned superbly on to Frédéric Kanouté's through ball.

Canadian Craig Forrest replaced injured Trinidad keeper Shaka Hislop in the West Ham goal at the break and he was soon pressed into action, making a double point-blank save from Niall Quinn after Kevin Phillips had crossed to the far post. A potential selection for Eriksson's forward line, Phillips, had done nothing to impress before then and did little more of note bar picking up a booking.

After a long quiet spell, Pearce was back in Eriksson's focus when he too was booked for attempting to crunch Hutchison - only to follow through into Darren Williams by mistake. Referee Matt Messias decided not to penalise Pearce's second coming when he appeared to plant an elbow into McCann's face two minutes later.

Cometh the hour, Cole produced a piece of skill that must have made Eriksson's day as the West Ham starlet flicked his left foot behind his right to execute a gem of a pass and put Paolo Di Canio through on goal. The Italian striker drove against the foot of a post and paid dearly as Sunderland's killer blow followed seven minutes later when Hutchison scored from a free-kick, 35 yards out.

Employing a familiar Sunderland tactic, Hutchison struck while Forrest was still arranging his wall, scoring into the opposite corner from the keeper. West Ham threatened once again with a Pearce free-kick that was well saved by Sorensen, but the points were Sunderland's now. And the Swede from Rome? He came, he saw, had a drink with 'Arry and made a swift exit keeping his thoughts to himself - already an Englishman through and through.

fields.headline: Thoroughly reffed off
fields.trailText: Neil Warnock's cool assessment of the Blades' Cup defeat at Southampton.
fields.body:
Not since Kevin Keegan delighted/shocked the nation with his 'I would just love it' speech about Alex Ferguson and his rampant Manchester United in the spring of 1996 has football had a manager's post-match rant worth the name.

Step forward Neil Warnock. His Sheffield United team didn't really get the run of the ball against Southampton in their FA Cup match at The Dell last weekend, and Neil reckoned he knew the reason why. As luck would have it, there was a Sky microphone to hand. Warnock let fly.

Here it is in its glorious entirety. You will notice the dilemma of the interviewer. Once he opens the door to Warnock, the manager takes it off the hinges. The hapless hack then attempts to change the subject, manfully tries to be understanding. But he was as Ginger Rogers to Neil's Fred Astaire, no more than an invisible dancing partner.

Q: At the end, you've gone out of the FA Cup but what was your plan going in, because you survived for so long?

Warnock: We tried to cope with the 11 players. It was difficult with whatever happened with the ref. To say I'm disappointed is an understatement, really. There's no way Southampton would have beaten us without the referee today. It's simple as that and obviously I'm disappointed. But he's a Premier League referee and [you] don't bite the hand that feeds you.

Q: All in a moment you had a penalty conceded and you had a player sent off. What was the verdict on the bench?

Warnock: Well, we wondered why their lad didn't get sent off for deliberate hand-ball when [Paul] Devlin was through on goal. Is it because we're Nationwide League? You know ... It's no wonder they want him [David Elleray] next home match for the third home match on the trot. He's becomin' a regular. They should be safe if they keep gettin' him at home. It's a ridiculous situation. It's got to be the same. The lad deliberately hand-balled, Devlin's through on goal.

[Neil is now building up a healthy head of steam. He spots that his inquisitor has left him a gap. Through he goes.]

Warnock: It's sad. Two tackles in second half, one on George Santos - he never even gave a free-kick. He's cut him off near the waist. It's just two different rules. And [Elleray] says to him, 'I should book ... I should send you off for doing that again.' Come on. It stinks.

Warnock: From where Mr Elleray was positioned, I would think it might have been, because he were that far away he would have needed binoculars. And he couldn't wait to give it. He blew up before he went down! In a game like that, a challenge like that, you don't give those. But he's waiting to give it, he's wanting to give it. You know? You can see that from the sidelines.

Warnock: He said the referee said he'd said words that he did not say. But he shouldn't have said it, because David Elleray loves sending players off for foul and abusive language. [And here comes the insight]. He's a schoolteacher. And he loves it, because he can write it down on Monday morning when he's back at his desk. You know? 'For foul and abusive language, I've sent Bobby Ford off. And I loved it.' And that's what it's all about. To hell with the tackles, the waist-high tackles that went unpunished. Thank you and good night.

But hang on a minute. We might have an epidemic on our hands.

'The better side is not necessarily winning a match these days, because it is being decided by the referee... that is not right. The ref is a major influence and that should not be the case. They have brought in new referees this season to give them experience and it has not worked. They are not up to scratch. The Premiership should not be used as a testing ground. There's a mad rush to find new blood and we have to put up with rubbish in the interim.

'We're talking livelihoods of players and coaches at stake here. We need debate on the matter, not everyone being muzzled. Players are held to account, ripped to bits if they don't perform. I don't see why refs should be any different. How many games have been adversely affected by sub-standard refereeing this season? Too many.

'As for a mandatory code of conduct, I thought I might have seen the end of disciplinary panels now I've almost finished playing. Perhaps not.'

Step forward Dean Ryan, director of rugby at Bristol RFC. The Rugby Football Union's response was to threaten to punish club coaches who criticise referees. They say levels of abuse have risen. According to figures, as many as 200 referees, from a pool of about 5,000, are leaving rugby every year.

'It's getting to be like football,' says the RFU's referees official, Nick Bunting.

What a fuss. Never saw a rugby man - or a football referee - yet who died of an insult.

fields.headline: Be very afraid
fields.standfirst: A triumphant enactment of grisly cautionary tales for children has achieved cult status and arrives in the West End next month
fields.trailText: A triumphant enactment of grisly cautionary tales for children has achieved cult status. Susannah Clapp rejoices in the success of Shockheaded Peter, the most orginal piece of theatre for a decade.
fields.body:
Shockheaded Peter is the two-word answer to people who think that theatre has had its day. Described by its producer as 'a nineteenth-century pop-up video', it projects a dizzy mix of talents: the grisly tales of a nineteenth-century physician; a fringe theatre company whose directors are also designers; a band whose music has been filed in record shops under every section from jazz to folk to rock.

First staged three years ago at West Yorkshire Playhouse, and subsequently at the Lyric Hammersmith, the show has since sold out in Toronto, Wellington, Zurich, Minneapolis... Next month it comes to the West End. The most original piece of theatre of the past 10 years has become a mainstream success.

Much of its power is due to the dark imagination of Heinrich Hoffmann, a Frankfurt doctor who had worked in his city's morgue and with the mentally ill. Unable to find a picture-book for his son, Hoffmann wrote and illustrated a clutch of cautionary tales, in which childish misdemeanours - playing with matches, fidgeting at mealtimes - were horribly punished: a little boy who sucks his thumbs has them cut off by the scissor man. At the centre was Struwwelpeter - Shockheaded or Slovenly Peter - a stocky chap with hair like a bush and terrifyingly long fingernails that curl like briars.

Pretty Stories and Funny Pictures for Little Children was published in Britain in 1848, two years after Edward Lear's Book of Nonsense and 17 years before Alice in Wonderland. In all three books a new vein of writing for children is detectable, in which the ridiculous shades into nightmare, but Hoffmann is by far the most gory.

Freud saw the thumb-sucking tale as an account of masturbation and - 'Snip, Snip' - castration. Marxist historians have read the stories as expressions of mid-nineteenth-century bourgeois culture. In both world wars, the figure of Shockheaded Peter was used in anti-German propaganda: Hitler was adorned in picture-books with nail and hair extensions.

But it took Michael Morris, of Cultural Industry, to see in Hoffmann's work a suitable case for theatrical treatment. Morris, who as a child had been drawn to and scared by the figure of Struwwelpeter, approached Martyn Jacques, accordionist, possessor of an eerie falsetto voice, creator with his group the Tiger Lillies of Low Life Lullabies . Jacques adapted Hoffmann's words and set them to music, introducing one big amendment: in his version all the erring children die; the word 'dead' - often delivered by Jacques as if he were pronouncing something of great sweetness - rings through the show. Morris next turned to Julian Crouch and Phelim McDermott, of the brilliant Improbable Theatre, who wove the songs into a story.

The tale of monstrous Shockheaded Peter - who gets buried under the floorboards by his prissy parents, and proceeds to sprout through them - provided one framing device. The idea of a ramshackle touring theatre com pany, presided over by a fruity actor manager (villainously leering Julian Bleach), struggling to put on a show which was constantly getting out of control, was another. The design became that of a toy theatre, with cardboard props and dimensions so cramped the actors seemed to be struggling to stay inside the set.

I first saw Shockheaded Peter in 1998. It was like learning a new theatrical language, and the memories are still vivid.

The stories are enacted both by enormous humanoid puppets and actors who deploy the puppet-like style of silent movies. There was Harriet who incinerates herself, disappearing into the froth of her flame-coloured petticoats while her cats gloat: 'We told her so', and Fidgety Phil, stabbed to death by cutlery to the accompaniment of a frantic percussion on pots and pans. There was the fleeting moment when a giant fly sweeps over the stage, and the slow minutes when Peter's fingernails start to push up through the floor, and his enormous goggling head lolls above the proscenium arch.

Animated and given voice on the stage, these stories have a far-reaching thrill and chill, talking differently to each audience of buried secrets that will burst out. In Tel Aviv the show proved an intense experience for older watchers familiar with the stories from childhood.

In Australia the show's challenging moment - when the audience is asked: 'What's under your floorboards?' - caused a shiver at the Adelaide Festival, where a debate had raged about opening the Festival Club to Aboriginal bands.

Now Shockheaded Peter is sprouting different lives in Hoffmann's own country. Düsseldorf has seen an entirely new production: a large-scale sci-fi version featuring robots and loads of machinery. And last week in Hamburg I saw a staging mounted by Crouch and McDermott with a German cast. On the wide stage of the beautiful Schauspielhaus, the show was more more imposing, more studied, less explosively funny than the English version.

But the inheritance of Weill-style cabaret was more apparent, largely because of the performance of Wiebke Puls, who sang triumphantly in the Jacques role. So long-limbed that she seemed to concertina when she sat down, she presented herself differently for each number: often in a circus-style corselette; once like a mermaid; once, sitting high above the stage, as a cat, with a long tail draping Rapunzel-style to the floor.

The German audience didn't laugh much, but they applauded like crazy. The man in the ticket office was happy. He'd been given the book for Christmas when he was six, partly as a threat: it was meant to shock him out of being a picky eater.

Shockheaded Peter will be at the Piccadilly Theatre, London W1 from 14 February to 28 April. Instead of a Wednesday matinee, there will be a late-night staging on Thursdays

webTitle: Boys from the Bush are down - but not yet out

fields.headline: Boys from the Bush are down - but not yet out
fields.trailText: Why QPR are both a broken and a broken football club.
fields.body:
Queens Park Rangers are a broke and broken football club. Crippled by debts in the region of £7 million a year, struggling with an injury list as long as Peter Crouch's extraordinarily spindly legs, depressed by the fear of relegation to a division they have looked down upon for more than three decades, it's not surprising that the chirpiest chap at their training ground last week is on his way out of there - fast. Rob Steiner, forced to retire from the game prematurely, dropped into leafy Acton to see a few old friends before disappearing on long and luxurious holiday. Lucky him.

Maintaining passion for an increasingly bleak cause at Loftus Road is a tough task. Gerry Francis, who is starkly realistic about the club's plight, shoulders the responsibility to keep the fire burning because Rangers are in his soul. He grew up there, captained them to their highest ever position - runners up in the top flight - then managed them to their next best finish. Now, in his second spell in charge, the club he calls 'my Rangers' need his dedication more than ever.

Since their 12-year stint in the top flight came to an end in 1996, QPR's potential has shrivelled at an alarming rate. Money has been at the root of their problems. They frittered away a fortune trying to get back into the Premiership on a series of expensive, extortionately paid signings.

The millions that were wasted on the likes of Mike Sheron, Ned Zelic, Vinnie Jones and Mark Hateley - names to make the faithful wince - might as well have been flushed down the gents. Without much in the way of gate receipts to compensate, it leaves them with no more funds, dwindling commercial value, and precious little in the way of floggable assets. These days they are forced to ask players to take salary cuts when their contracts are up and they no longer pay signing on fees.

Francis contemplates the amount of wealthier (though not necessarily bigger) clubs in the division and accepts, sadly, the fact that Rangers are in no position to aim for anything other than survival.

'West Brom, for example, paid £2 million for Jason Roberts, Birmingham bought Geoff Horsfield for £2.5 million, Watford spent £4 million on two players from Tottenham, Preston the other day paid £1.3 million for David Healy from Manchester United. We spent £350,000 on all the players this season.

'I was fortunate to get Clark Carlisle for £250,000, who has since become an England under-21 international - if we can hang onto him he'll be a big asset for the club - and also Peter Crouch, who was only 19 when I took him for £60,000 from Tottenham. Peter has had to be thrown in and he's responded with nine goals - a tremendous achievement for a young kid playing at a very high level.

'Even if we had millions to spend on top-quality players we couldn't afford the wages. But I knew the situation when I took over - I wouldn't have come back for any other club really - and the only way to get out of the situation is to try and work at it to pull through.

'Unless some fairy Godmother or an Al-Fayed comes in with x millions of pounds it's going to be a slow process. You can't give up. You have to roll your sleeves up and make it happen. The most important thing is to make sure we're still a First Division team next year. QPR mean a great deal to me and to see them in this position hurts me. I'm the last person that would ever want to see them relegated.'

The grapple for points has been hampered by an absurd number of draws and a volume of injuries so atrocious it's a miracle Francis puts a team out at all.

'Unfortunately, this season right from the word go people such as Rob Steiner - a player who was influential and has been forced to quit the game - and my captain Danny Maddix have not been able to play a game. Paul Murray broke his leg twice and hasn't played at all. Early in the year we lost Ian Barraclough with a broken leg, Karl Reddy and Gavin Peacock. The following week we lost Chris Plummer with another broken leg. We certainly haven't had the best of luck with injuries.'

Relief from the pressure of basement battles comes with an FA Cup replay on Wednesday. The incentive is massive. Should QPR overcome Luton they will host Arsenal in the next round. It is symbolic of Rangers' current standing that they haven't enjoyed a decent cup run for years.

Francis's contract expires at the end of the season and if he is to extend his 20-year association with the club he needs reassurance that there is light at the end of the tunnel. It needs another renaissance, rather like the transformation he witnessed as a kid when an ambitious takeover made the good times roll.

'The Rangers I grew up with hardly had any seats in the ground, no grass on the pitch, one bath, with a shower over the top of the toilet, old wooden facilities and maybe 3,000 people turned up every week. Our neighbours Brentford were probably a better supported club. That's the QPR I knew before Jim Gregory came along and changed all that. He gave us a major lift, built the stadium, bought players and the club progressed.'

Oh for the days of Rodney Marsh and Stan Bowles, when QPR won the League Cup as a Division Three side and promotions. Glamour and glory cascaded around Shepherd's Bush. Francis still believes that new investment, a new stadium, and new talent will come again. But while pounds and points remain hard to come by he won't be holding his breath.

fields.headline: The cost of injuries: £55m
fields.trailText: English clubs are wasting tens of millions of pounds each year because their outdated training methods cannot keep players fit.
fields.body:
New research has revealed that English clubs are wasting tens of millions of pounds each year because their outdated training methods cannot keep players fit.

The study, which has been carried out in association with Fifa, claims that because teams in both the Premier and Nationwide Leagues haven't done enough to tackle 'avoidable' injuries, they end up paying £55 million in wages annually to players who are unavailable to play.

It comes as the FA and players' union, the PFA, prepare to reveal the results of their own injury audit. It will show that 10 per cent of players with English clubs are missing through injury at any one time.

The Fifa research, which has been carried out at Leicester University, suggests that managers could drastically shorten the queue outside the treatment room simply by insisting that their stars wear shinpads, prepare properly for matches and 'refuel' sensibly afterwards.

But the report's author, Dr Colin Fuller, says that the game is resistant to change. 'Football is a business like any other,' he said. 'Sometimes, even when you highlight what's wrong and how it can be put right, it will insist on its own way of doing things. It's likely that if clubs continue to cut corners, players may take legal action because their careers could be shortened.'

The survey analysed how injuries occur. It found that roughly half of the knocks resulting in lengthy spells out of action happen in training. And yet, despite that statistic, a majority of players still refuse to wear shinpads dur ing training sessions despite being required to do so during a game. fields.headline: Stretford End, Kenny
fields.trailText: Kenny Dalglish has turned his back on football management to join up with a leading football agent.
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish has turned his back on football management to join up with a leading football agent.

Dalglish is to be a director of Paul Stretford's agency, marketing and hospitality business, ProActive Sports Management. Stretford handles the affairs of more than 100 top players worldwide, including the Manchester United striker Andy Cole, his former Old Trafford colleague Peter Schmeichel and Aston Villa's Steve Stone.

Appointing Dalglish to the ProActive board is under stood to be Stretford's latest step in his plans for a stock market flotation in the near future. Stretford told Observer Sport , 'Kenny won't be working as a football agent but we will be looking to use his knowledge and experience to help the growth and development of the company.' Dalglish has several other businesses outside sport but this is his first job back in football since being sacked by Celtic following a disappointing return to Parkhead.

Stretford added: 'I've known Kenny for some time. We've talked about his coming on board for a while but it wasn't until it became apparent that he wanted a change in direction with regards to his own career that the opportunity arose to link up.'

fields.headline: David Hills
fields.trailText: The week in football.
fields.body:
Hanging chads hit Dell

Southampton club officials have launched an investigation into how their online vote for a new kit was sabotaged by Portsmouth fans, thousands of whom voted for one of the worst designs ever launched in Britain. The poll, which took place online and through local paper The Daily Echo , followed the unveiling of the shirt - one of five options - before the club's home game against Spurs. It was met by a chorus of boos. After the Sky match presenter Helen Chamberlain floated the sabotage idea, and hundreds of fans logged on to wreak havoc. Saints officials then promised to check every vote and 'filter out any which arouse our suspicions' - a great image - but, with the vote closing last night, the first signs suggest it could still be close: while 2,317 votes had registered for Shirt 1 - the traditional look - a mighty 2,179 and counting had gone for the hideous Shirt 4 (above). It'll be a tense night in St Marys.

First sex-tryst casualty, 2001

Seven Israeli U21 players exposed in October for making love to the same woman, one after the other, before a match against Bosnia have been handed two-year international bans and 5,000 shekel fines. According to Reuters, the players admitted to 'improper conduct' in a plea bargain. The deal resulted in seven delicately phrased admissions: 'On the eve of the match against Bosnia, while the team was based at the Kfar Hamaccabiah Hotel,' the identical statements read, 'I spent "time out of my room". This contradicted the ethical code.'

Headline of the week

'Coma victim set to hang up boots' (Agence France Press)

Hossam sinks Matthäus

After a year of claiming that football's least popular man Lothar Matthäus was the world's most capped player, Fifa have finally acknowledged what we revealed 11 months ago - that the true record-holder is the slightly less well known Hossam Hassan. The 34-year-old Egyptian was disqualified by Fifa last year because of a 'lack of evidence', a charge which handed the title to the friendless German millionaire just after his retirement. But now, after another game against Zambia last week, Hassan, with 151 formally recognised caps - the first against Norway in 1985 - has officially taken Lothar's title.

Madness sweeps Spain, Italy

Emmanuel Petit - last week named our most unstable player of 2000 - has taken a turn for the worse. 'I train hard and give my best on the pitch but I feel frustrated,' he told the Spanish press last week. 'Then again, what can I do? Get a gun and shoot everybody?' Manu still has to go some, though, to provoke the nervous looks among journalists that an emotional Arrigo Sacchi inspired last week on his return to Parma. 'Footballers are like fiancées,' he told assembled hacks. 'You only find out what they are really like when you take them home and marry them.'

Top stat

447 - the number of days it took Top Man icon and FA chief exec Adam Crozier to wear a tie in his new job. A comforting return for Graham Kelly chic.

Leyton Orient: God, we're sorry

Observer Sport's Leyton Orient v Spurs match report last week claimed that the O's run out to the theme music from It's a Knockout . The track is, in fact, the very similar Tijuana Taxi by Herb Alpert & the Tijuana Brass, and has been for 20 years - thanks for the thousands of letters. To show how sorry we are, we've a copy of the very best of the mighty Herb Alpert, including the track in question, to give away - just answer this: with which song did Barry Hearn try to replace Tijuana Taxi when he bought the club? a) Money Talks b) Whiter Shade of Pale c) We Will Rock You? Write to Herb competition, Observer Sport, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

webTitle: For top earners, the only way is up

fields.headline: For top earners, the only way is up
fields.trailText: Forty years after the first £100-a-week player, the first £100,000-a-week contract is now "inevitable", according to the football analysts Deloitte & Touche.
fields.body:
Forty years after the first £100-a-week player, the first £100,000-a-week contract is now "inevitable", according to the football analysts Deloitte & Touche.

"The Premier League will almost certainly see its first few £100,000-per-week players within the life of the next television contract, which ends in 2004," says Dan Jones, director of sport business at the firm, which publishes an annual report of the sport's financial health.

His belief is shared by John Holmes of FSX Sports Group, agents for David Beckham. "I think wages of £100,000 per week will come fairly soon," he said.

Huge television, sponsorship and marketing deals have propelled football's income to record levels. But with wages increasing by an average of 30% a season, Jones warns that clubs need to keep control of expenditure or face racking up potentially crippling debts.

"As a rule of thumb any club paying less than half of their turnover in total wages and salaries are carefully managing for the long term. Wages of over two thirds of turnover are likely to be unsustainable in the long term and worryingly an increasing number of clubs are spending over that level. This is a crucial benchmark and the red light is already flashing."

Deloitte & Touche figures show that during the 1998-1999 season, 10 of the 20 Premiership clubs were already in the danger band, with Blackburn Rovers, Southampton and Liverpool the worst offenders. Eighty per cent of all English professional clubs now exceed Deloitte & Touche's two-thirds-of-turnover mark.

Blackburn, who were relegated that season, were actually paying their players more than they were making from gate receipts, merchandising and all other commercial activities combined. They were not alone: 13 other clubs across the country including QPR, Fulham and Sheffield United were doing the same.

So how can clubs think about paying players £100,000 a week when many of their finances are so shaky? The players' union believes it is unfair to blame the players for maximising their income.

"The game is enjoying probably its great level of support ever and has become a huge industry," said Brendon Batson, deputy chief executive of the PFA. "A lot of that wealth creation has occurred as a result of players' performances and it is only right that they should share in that. If you look at the sort of money baseball and gridiron players earn in the US you see that footballers here are still a long way behind."

Batson stresses that not all the 2,500 footballers playing professionally earn tens of thousands of pounds a week. "For every Roy Keane there are a lot of members who are earning below the national average male wage. Hundreds are earning only very average livings."

However, the jump in top salaries could cause new problems, Deloitte's Jones argues. Even if David Beckham ends up with "only" around £80,000 a week, it is still a huge jump from the club's current highest earner, Roy Keane, thought to be on around £52,000.

"If Beckham ends up earning twice as much as Keane it could prove a difficult situation to manage," Jones said.

"In the past, when one player has been awarded a better contract, the other players have demanded parity and been nudged up to his level. Now I think there is going to have to be a recognition that there are different types of stars.

"At the top there are the international stars, the ones like Beckham, Figo and Zidane who could go to any club in Europe and demand £100,000 a week. Then there is a tier of regular first-teamers, many of whom will be seasoned internationals, but don't have quite them same allure. Then there are the squad players who maybe get 10 or 15 games a season.

"It will be difficult to keep everyone in the dressing room happy but the change has to be made otherwise player demands will continue to escalate until the last pound note is gone."

Jones thinks a time may come when players are no longer paid according to how many goals they score or shots they save but on how many replica shirts they sell.

When Roma signed Hidetoshi Nakata from Perugia, the Japanese superstar's ability to shift merchandising, attract sponsors to the club and generate television interest in the lucrative Far East market was as important as his playing abilities.

Guaranteeing players a cut of merchandising sales or broadcasting revenues could become a common part of an employment contract. Share options in clubs have also been suggested as a way of linking players' performance to their pay and encouraging long-term loyalty.

The game's traditional power structure had Fifa at the top, with Uefa, the FA, clubs, players and agents all in line behind. Now the players are threatening to turn that order on its head.

webTitle: Need to settle in Sven? Get a title

fields.headline: Need to settle in Sven? Get a title
fields.trailText: Kevin Mitchell on why England's new boss need have no fears.
fields.body:
I know Will Buckley devoted this space to the inanity of footballers' quotes last week, but, if you can bear a few more, there's a point to all this.

'The England team should be managed by an Englishman. We were surprised by Kevin resigning after the defeat by Germany. He had built a good spirit and had the respect of all the England players.' - David Beckham, England vice-captain, The Sun, 13 October.

'I know people wanted an English manager, but he has got a lot of experience and he is a great manager. I think it will be a good thing. We have got many good players and they will become a good team.' - David Beckham, England captain-in-waiting, The Guardian, 18 October.

'It should be good. It will be good. We have got many good players and they will become a good team. He is a great manager.' - David Beckham, England captain-still-in-waiting, The Sun, 1 November.

'Even to think about bringing in a foreign man ager is a joke. It would be an embarrassment for English soccer. Don't even mention it. What would we ask for next: a foreign team instead of an English team?' - Paul Gascoigne. Around about the same time, but any day of the week, really.

One of the liberating consequences of being past it is that you can say what you damn well please. Which is why Beckham - looking forward to a long and wonderful international career, probably as England captain - might have been persuaded to rewrite his own part in the history of Sven-Göran Eriksson. He doesn't want to get the gaffer off-side. Might even invite him around to his Cheshire pad for pasta, remind him of Rome.

S-G should relax. There is a proud tradition of giving outsiders a go in this country. Take His Highness the Jam Sahib of Nawanagar, Cambridge University, Sussex and England, otherwise know as Kumar Shri Ranjitsinhji, or Ranji. Or, at university, Smith. Okay, the title helped. But Ranji was hugely popular in the Golden Age of Cricket, from 1893 to 1920.

Or what about Prince Alexander Obolensky, son of Prince Sergei Alexandrovich Obolensky, a graduate of the Imperial Alexander Lyceum, Aide-de-Camp to the Governor General of Moscow, and Captain in the Horse Guards? Obo scored one of the great tries, at Twickenham for England against New Zealand in 1936, and his legend is secure.

Okay, the title helped. But S-G's hyphen must be worth something.

webTitle: Latvians inspire good times at Palace

fields.headline: Latvians inspire good times at Palace
fields.trailText: The Skonto Riga connection proved the undoing of Liverpool at Selhurst Park on Wednesday, as Palace manager Alan Smith explains.
fields.body:
I suspect there are probably more glamorous places than Latvia, but a few trips I made there earlier this season have certainly paid off.

The two Latvians I signed from Skonto Riga, goalkeeper Alex Kolinko and winger Andrejs Rubins, were key players when we beat Liverpool last Wednesday in the first leg of our Worthington Cup semi-final.

Kolinko was outstanding in goal, while Rubins scored a cracking goal to set us on our way. I was delighted, obviously, for the club and the fans, but especially for the Latvian boys.

They are both very good players and were being considered by a number of other clubs, but I think I managed to get them because I was prepared to go out to Latvia and watch them in action.

They were both recommended by Gary Johnson, who coaches the Latvian national team and is someone I have known for 20 years or so.

He actually played for me a few times when I was reserve team manager at Crystal Palace many years ago. He was a non-League player and guested for us when we were short of numbers, but after one match at Reading, when I really laid into some players and him in particular, he decided he'd had enough.

But our paths crossed over the years, especially when he became academy director at Watford while I was doing the same job at Fulham.

So when he recommended these two players earlier this season, I took him at his word. He was very helpful over the deals and was very positive about them, stressing that he thought they would be perfect for us, and I think he has been proved right.

There were obvious problems at first, because neither of them spoke a word of English when they arrived. But we have set them up with a language coach so they have regular lessons and are coping very well. The club has also done a lot to help their families settle in, finding them houses and looking after them, and they have responded well.

It was similar with Fan Zhiyi when he first arrived at the club two years ago.

He came with a fellow Chinese player, Sun Jihai, who I am trying to sign again, and there is no doubt Fan found it quite difficult when Sun left within a year.

He has a different lifestyle from many of the other lads. He doesn't tend to hang out in bars and nightclubs, but goes home to his family and studies the game - he's almost scientific in his outlook on football.

Foreign footballers certainly bring a different mentality to our game. They think nothing of going away to a training camp for as long as is required and there were no complaints from the foreign players when we went to a luxury hotel two days in advance of our FA Cup game at Sunderland last week, although one or two of the English lads were grumbling about being away from home.

But Fan, for example, was used to spending a month at a time with the national team when he was in China, and he says he cannot imagine any English players being prepared to do that.

The Italians still go away to training camps before games and it is one of things I would like to do more at Palace, because it is no coincidence that we have had some of our best performances after being away together.

It is not just a question of keeping an eye on the players and out of harm's way. Often it is the only time I get to really talk to them, to get my ideas across in a relaxed environment, and to get to know each other.

Around 20 days of our pre-season training will be out of the country. It will not be a holiday, but neither will it be a boot camp - it is simply a chance to prepare properly and intensively, to have good quality training without any distractions.

To be fair to the younger players, most of them accept a lot of these things once the benefits are pointed out to them. Too often in the past managers have been wary of upsetting their players by insisting on having things done in a certain way, but sometimes you have to remind them of their responsibilities.

They are in a privileged position and can earn a lot of money, so it should not be asking too much of them to ask for a little sacrifice now and again.

Of course they are happy now that we are in the limelight. The defeat of Liverpool was our third victory over a top six Premiership side this season, and we have a chance to add another scalp in our FA Cup replay with Sunderland this week.

There is nothing like winning to breed confidence and produce a feel-good factor about the place - quite literally.

We play Nottingham Forest today and for the first time this season I have a fully fit squad, with no injuries or suspensions. Training this week was the best it has been since I returned to the club, because everybody wants to play in these big games.

Both the second leg against Liverpool and the Sunderland game will be really tough, though. Gérard Houllier must be thinking his players cannot squander so many chances again, while Sunderland will be determined to beat us at the third attempt.

It won't be easy in either game - but don't bet against one of the Latvian boys doing it again.

They are both very good players and were being considered by a number of other clubs, but I think I managed to get them because I was prepared to go out to Latvia and watch them in action. They were both recommended by Gary Johnson, who coaches the Latvian national team and is someone I have known for 20 years or so. He actually played for me a few times when I was reserve team manager at Crystal Palace many years ago. He was a non-League player and guested for us when we were short of numbers, but after one match at Reading, when I really laid into some players and him in particular, he decided he'd had enough. But our paths crossed over the years, especially when he became academy director at Watford while I was doing the same job at Fulham. So when he recommended these two players earlier this season, I took him at his word. He was very helpful over the deals and was very positive about them, stressing that he thought they would be perfect for us, and I think he has been proved right. There were obvious problems at first, because neither of them spoke a word of English when they arrived. But we have set them up with a language coach so they have regular lessons and are coping very well. The club has also done a lot to help their families settle in, finding them houses and looking after them, and they have responded well. It was similar with Fan Zhiyi when he first arrived at the club two years ago. He came with a fellow Chinese player, Sun Jihai, who I am trying to sign again, and there is no doubt Fan found it quite difficult when Sun left within a year. He has a different lifestyle from many of the other lads. He doesn't tend to hang out in bars and nightclubs, but goes home to his family and studies the game - he's almost scientific in his outlook on football. Foreign footballers certainly bring a different mentality to our game. They think nothing of going away to a training camp for as long as is required and there were no complaints from the foreign players when we went to a luxury hotel two days in advance of our FA Cup game at Sunderland last week, although one or two of the English lads were grumbling about being away from home. But Fan, for example, was used to spending a month at a time with the national team when he was in China, and he says he cannot imagine any English players being prepared to do that. The Italians still go away to training camps before games and it is one of things I would like to do more at Palace, because it is no coincidence that we have had some of our best performances after being away together. It is not just a question of keeping an eye on the players and out of harm's way. Often it is the only time I get to really talk to them, to get my ideas across in a relaxed environment, and to get to know each other. Around 20 days of our pre-season training will be out of the country. It will not be a holiday, but neither will it be a boot camp - it is simply a chance to prepare properly and intensively, to have good quality training without any distractions. To be fair to the younger players, most of them accept a lot of these things once the benefits are pointed out to them. Too often in the past managers have been wary of upsetting their players by insisting on having things done in a certain way, but sometimes you have to remind them of their responsibilities. They are in a privileged position and can earn a lot of money, so it should not be asking too much of them to ask for a little sacrifice now and again. Of course they are happy now that we are in the limelight. The defeat of Liverpool was our third victory over a top six Premiership side this season, and we have a chance to add another scalp in our FA Cup replay with Sunderland this week. There is nothing like winning to breed confidence and produce a feel-good factor about the place - quite literally. We play Nottingham Forest today and for the first time this season I have a fully fit squad, with no injuries or suspensions. Training this week was the best it has been since I returned to the club, because everybody wants to play in these big games. Both the second leg against Liverpool and the Sunderland game will be really tough, though. Gérard Houllier must be thinking his players cannot squander so many chances again, while Sunderland will be determined to beat us at the third attempt. It won't be easy in either game - but don't bet against one of the Latvian boys doing it again.

fields.headline: Giant-killers are slain
fields.standfirst: Thriving Daggers involved in another upset, but this time it's lowly Weymouth who are celebrating
fields.trailText: Ian Ridley sees Dagenham involved in another upset, but this time it's lowly Weymouth who are celebrating.
fields.body:
The problem with non-League clubs is that none of them really wants to be one; anyone worth their salt wants to drop the 'non' bit and be in the League. And starting soon - perhaps even as soon as next season - more of them are going to fulfil that ambition.

For moves are afoot for three-up, three-down between the Nationwide League and Conference. Talks have already taken place between the two bodies, instigated by the FA, and another meeting is planned for the week after next.

'We are looking at how we can improve the current situation,' says the FA's chief executive Adam Crozier, who believes the present one-up, one-down is restrictive and unfair on a growing number of Conference clubs in better health than many in the Third Division. 'We had a major meeting before Christmas at which all the cards were put on the table and we hope to be seeking an agreement over the next four to six weeks.'

Not surprisingly, the League is dubious about the proposal, one bone of contention being how much relegated clubs should receive as compensation. Surprisingly, it is the League who are worried about 'parachute' payments for those relegated. The FA believe, though, that more TV money is likely to become available and that there should be more ways or generating income, such as a play-off between third bottom in the League and third top in the Conference.

The three-up proposal is a basis for negotiation and it could be that the compromise proposal of two is adopted. At the very least, there should be significant change. The FA have the muscle, as a last resort, of threatening only one up to the Premiership, with that organisation's co-operation.

'I don't know about that,' says Crozier, 'but there are a lot of good clubs in the Conference and we have to look at helping them progress. I think you'll find that the League will reach an agreement.' In place for next season? 'It might just be possible.'

These are heady days for the semi-professional game, reflected in the success of the new Sunday newspaper, The non-League Paper, which is selling a remarkable 42,000 copies a week. Five of their number reached the third round of the FA Cup, and two survived into the fourth round draw.

Kingstonian's win at Southend brought them limited reward with a trip to Bristol City but Dagenham and Redbridge have struck gold after a remarkable 1-1 draw at Charlton that means a replay on Wednesday, with a tie against Tottenham Hotspur awaiting the winners.

Yesterday at Victoria Road it was more about silver, the FA Trophy representing for them a more realistic chance of a trophy, if not glory. Understandably, though, some minds were elsewhere than the third-round tie against Weymouth and two hours before kick-off, a long queue had formed in anticipation of ticket vouchers for the Charlton match going on sale.

Inside the social club that for most non-League clubs produces life-giving revenue, helpful club officials were enjoying all the extra work and media attention, rather than resenting their presence as more arrogant, exalted clubs can. Dagenham and Redbridge, on the border of the Essex badlands, are in West Ham territory and they are clearly enjoying stepping out of their shadow.

For Dagenham diehards, it is a circumstance they have waited a long time for. They had some good times in the Seventies when that golden-haired Tottenham old boy Frank Saul helped them to a Trophy final; they also reached the FA Cup third round, losing at then-big Carlisle. By the early Nineties, though, they found themselves skint and languishing in the Isthmian League.

Redbridge Forest, themselves a merger of Walthamstow Avenue and Leytonstone and Ilford, had reached the Conference but had sold their Greenpond Road ground. They had the money, Dagenham had the ground so they got together. The two-become-one - or should that be five into one? - will be among those heartened by talks of more promotion.

They should be in a strong position to go for it, too; after trousering more than £50,000 from the Charlton game, Wednesday's rematch will bring them £150,000 from Sky for live TV coverage alone. Then there are the gate receipts from a capacity crowd of 5,403 plus the fantasy land of a tie against Spurs, which they are likely to seek to take to White Hart lane. A spin-off benefit was that yesterday's crowd of 1,784, though disappointing, was about 500 above their average.

They saw their players give a performance in an anti-climatic 1-0 defeat that also smacked of pre-occupied minds. It was a tie that reflected football's enduring capacity to turn one week's heroes into the next's saps with Dagenham and Redbridge now the favourites and Weymouth the underdogs, coming as they do from a division below in the non-League pyramid, the Dr, Marten's League (Southern League to us old purists).

Here it is vested interest time; Weymouth - regular, bored readers may be aware - are this correspondent's team. All bias apart though, we murdered them. Well, in a first half, in which the home side were lucky to get nil, at least.

The mighty Terras (nice pun, eh?; after their colours of terra cotta and blue) largely restricted them to long-range shots comfortably dealt with by Danny Potter. Their goal-scoring hero at The Valley, Junior McDougald did look a livewire but this was clearly not the same team now that a burden of expectation - and attention - was on them.

They perked up after the interval, driven on by Steve Heffer in midfield and no doubt inspired by their forthright, even fearsome, manager Garry Hill, who had been presented with a special award for his efforts so far this season from the League Managers' Association before the game. Perhaps it was the introduction of Keen, the substitute Mark, that is. Earlier they had been more like mournful Morrisey's Dagenham Dave.

Their captain Lee Matthews headed a corner over the bar and McDougald came close with a shot on the turn saved by Potter but Weymouth served notice when their promising 20-year-old striker Lee Phillips, on loan from Plymouth, streaked clear only for Tony Roberts, the former Queen's Park Rangers goalkeeper, to thwart him.

Dagenham and Redbridge brought on Mark Janney, the scorer of the goal that won their second round tie at Lincoln, in an attempt to pinch a late goal but that went to Weymouth in the last minute of normal time. David Laws caught the home side on the break and when his shot clipped over Roberts hit a post, Phillips was on hand to tap home the rebound. This time Dagenham and Redbridge were the victims of a cup upset.

Easy peasy. All Alan Curbishley now needs to do is phone the Weymouth director of football Fred Davies, once Wolves' goalkeeper and Shrewsbury's manager, to find out how to come to this bleak setting and pinch a result.

fields.headline: Dossier on Gills 'ignored' by FA
fields.trailText: Allegations of financial irregularities at Gillingham were known by the FA almost a year before they appeared in a national newspaper.
fields.body:
Allegations of financial irregularities at Gillingham were handed to the Football Association almost a year before the file was handed to a national newspaper, Observer Sport can reveal.

Private investigator Royston Pack handed his file to Lancaster Gate 11 months ago with a request to protect the identities of witnesses. He subsequently contacted the FA on several occasions to inquire about progress.

This culminated in a fax sent to the FA's 'enforcer', compliance officer Graham Bean. When Bean replied, the contents shocked Pack. Bean closed a brief, three-paragraph note by saying: 'The Football Association would ask that if you have any evidence to substantiate these allegations, then please forward it to us.'

Pack subsequently contacted public relations expert Max Clifford. A decision was made to sell the file to a newspaper because Pack did not trust the FA to investigate. Pack's dossier allegedly includes evidence of irregular payments to players and manipulation of crowd figures at Gillingham. There are also statements from former players and at least one former director of the club.

If allegations of irregular payments are substantiated then Gillingham could face relegation. Undeclared player payments were a major reason for Swindon's enforced relegation a decade ago after they had won a place in the old First Division. The Wiltshire club also secured players for cheap fees at tribunals where wages were used in a 'multiplier' system of deciding fees.

Clifford said: 'The investigator went to the FA 11 months ago and they had his files. He wanted protection for his witnesses and he contacted them repeatedly about what was happening. When they eventually got back to him in May of last year, they more or less told him to go away. They asked him for evidence when they had already seen his files.'

An FA spokesman maintained: 'Despite allegations made regarding this case, we would welcome evidence to substantiate them. We would then investigate them as thoroughly and as speedily as one would expect. Nothing of substance has been produced to us so far.'

webTitle: Beeb to benefit from England struggles

fields.headline: Beeb to benefit from England struggles
fields.trailText: Why the BBC are hoping England miss automatic qualification for the World Cup.
fields.body:
What will be the most viewed sporting event of 2001? Gary Wilkie, a reader of this column, has already provided a prediction: the World Cup play-off in the autumn in which England attempt to qualify for next year's finals in Japan and South Korea.

No sooner had his email arrived than news leaked out that the Football Association, confident that England would finish second in their group under Sven-Göran Eriksson and so reach a play-off, had earmarked Old Trafford for the home leg.

Certainly the BBC will hope the match happens. Under the terms of the FA's new TV deal, they would share live coverage with Sky of the Old Trafford fixture, which would be a significant addition to their portfolio early in the first season in which they no longer have Premiership highlights (lost to ITV).

At the moment the Beeb have a decent run of live international matches at the start of next season to cushion the effect of losing those highlights. They will show - together with Sky - England's World Cup qualifiers in Germany on 1 September and at home against Albania and Greece on 5 September and 6 October.

If England then went into a two-leg play-off, those matches would be staged in mid-November with the Beeb likely to attract well over 10 million viewers for the home tie.

The BBC remain favourites to televise the Greece v England match on 6 June, the only World Cup qualifier that still hasn't been sold to a broadcaster. Sky and ITV are resisting what they reckon is a fancy asking price for a game that could have lost much of its appeal if England do badly in their March matches against Finland and Albania.

Sky, meanwhile, must be grateful to the FA for fixing up those two home friendlies against Mexico on 25 May and Holland on 15 August, which they get for no additional cost as part of existing contracts. And as they are not classed as competitive games, they don't have to share them with the BBC.

One of the more fanciful reports about the changes in televised football next season was the one that the BBC were hoping to persuade ITV to let them have Premiership footage to sustain Football Focus, Grandstand's Saturday lunchtime show.

For a start, it would contravene the terms of ITV's agreement with the Premier League for the highlight rights. Also, even if the Beeb did ask, they know what the answer would be - the same as they would have given if ITV had ever wanted Premiership footage for On the Ball.

Football Focus will keep going next season with less recorded action and with more features. And as the season gets into its stride they will have access to clips from FA Cup matches and England's home internationals.

Although the BBC will lose commentator Jon Champion to ITV next season, his departure marks the end of defections from Match of the Day , which have also included senior producers Tony Pastor and Paul McNamara. Gary Lineker and Alan Hansen have decided to stay put, which means ITV are expected to complete their line-up of presenters for their enhanced football coverage next season with an in-house appointment.
