fields.headline: Owen's misses inspire my strikers
fields.trailText: By missing all those chances, Owen is bound to have made other strikers feel better about themselves.
fields.body:
Any striker who is suffering from a lack of confidence will surely have been lifted by the agony that Michael Owen experienced in Liverpool's 2-1 Worthington Cup semi-final first-leg defeat at Crystal Palace on Wednesday.

In missing chances that he would usually have taken with his eyes closed, Owen is bound to have caused other strikers going through a bad patch to have felt a little better about themselves. I can relate to this through my assessments of myself as a manager.

In order to keep a sense of perspective about yourself when things are not going well, it does help to be able to look at managers with a better record or a bigger reputation than me who have landed in the same situation.

In that context, the players who might have derived the biggest boost through watching Owen's uncharacteristic mistakes on TV are those at Coventry. It is no secret that scoring goals has been a big problem for us this season. Generally, we have not had the results we have deserved on the possession we have had and the number of chances we have created.

During my time as manager, the Coventry team that posed the biggest scoring threat was the one with Dion Dublin and Darren Huckerby together up front three seasons ago. Dion, with his physical strength and ability in the air, and Darren, with his pace in getting behind defenders, complemented each other perfectly. They scored 38 goals between them, with Dion finishing the joint top scorer in the Premiership - alongside Michael Owen - on 23.

I felt that we had potentially another top-notch scoring duo in Robbie Keane and Cedric Roussel. But there was no way we could afford to turn down Inter Milan's £13.5 million bid for Robbie and Cedric has been hampered by injuries. Not surprisingly, the fact that we have struggled in the scoring department this season has put Craig Bellamy, the Welsh international signed as a replacement for Keane for a club record fee of £6.5m, under a lot of pressure.

This is unfair - not least because he has not had a lot of help from players in other positions. However, the harsh reality for strikers is that, no matter how much good work they might do with regards to their team's overall play, it is their scoring records on which they are assessed.

In our training sessions, I always stress that the strikers' first thought should be to get into a scoring position. Dropping deep, and setting someone else up for a scoring attempt, should always be the second option. But when a striker is going through a bad time, it is not the easiest advice to take on board.

To me, one of the most intriguing aspects of the scoring art is that the best strikers tend to come in all shapes and sizes. In one category, for example, there are the will-o'-the-wisp types such as Owen, Robbie Fowler, Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke. In the other, there are the big men such as John Hartson and Niall Quinn, who might not look particularly stylish but are nevertheless very effective.

As reflected by Coventry's bid to sign Hartson from Wimbledon, I have admired him for some time. People tend to concentrate on his physique and combativeness; as his former West Ham boss, Harry Redknapp, pointed out: 'He is the closest football equivalent to a rugby union front-row forward.' But there is more to Hartson than just physical power. He has a good knowledge of the game - he knows how to find space - and, in addition to his ability in the air, he is an excellent striker of the ball.

The other attraction about him for Coventry, of course, is that he operates with Bellamy in the Welsh team.

At this stage, I do not want to get carried away by the prospect of him in a Coventry shirt. There are so many potential hitches in transfer deals and those concerning this one include the player-exchange element involving Roussel, and Hartson's previous knee problems. However, our chairman, Bryan Richardson, who is dealing with the finer points of the deal, is confident it will go ahead.

Quinn, experiencing a new lease of life at Sunderland at the age of 34, is another big striker whose appearance is deceptive. It is difficult to avoid looking ungainly and clumsy when you are 6ft 5in tall. But, like Hartson, he has acquired a tremendous football knowledge; and his partnership with Kevin Phillips is as good as any in the Premiership.

Still, that does not mean they are above missing apparently simple chances. As we saw on Wednesday, no one is. In the second leg of the Liverpool-Palace tie, we might also see how dramatically a striker's fortunes can be transformed.

I still remember Mark McGhee's response after he and I had been guilty of amazing misses in Aberdeen's 2-0 European Cup Winners' Cup defeat by Ujpest Dozsa in 1984.

In his book on his Aberdeen experiences, the manager, Alex Ferguson, described them as 'the worst goal attempts I have ever seen'.

Mark, whose miss was even worse than mine - he fired wide of an open goal from a yard out - scored a hat-trick in the return to give us a 3-0 win.

In that context, the players who might have derived the biggest boost through watching Owen's uncharacteristic mistakes on TV are those at Coventry. It is no secret that scoring goals has been a big problem for us this season. Generally, we have not had the results we have deserved on the possession we have had and the number of chances we have created. During my time as manager, the Coventry team that posed the biggest scoring threat was the one with Dion Dublin and Darren Huckerby together up front three seasons ago. Dion, with his physical strength and ability in the air, and Darren, with his pace in getting behind defenders, complemented each other perfectly. They scored 38 goals between them, with Dion finishing the joint top scorer in the Premiership - alongside Michael Owen - on 23. I felt that we had potentially another top-notch scoring duo in Robbie Keane and Cedric Roussel. But there was no way we could afford to turn down Inter Milan's £13.5 million bid for Robbie and Cedric has been hampered by injuries. Not surprisingly, the fact that we have struggled in the scoring department this season has put Craig Bellamy, the Welsh international signed as a replacement for Keane for a club record fee of £6.5m, under a lot of pressure. This is unfair - not least because he has not had a lot of help from players in other positions. However, the harsh reality for strikers is that, no matter how much good work they might do with regards to their team's overall play, it is their scoring records on which they are assessed. In our training sessions, I always stress that the strikers' first thought should be to get into a scoring position. Dropping deep, and setting someone else up for a scoring attempt, should always be the second option. But when a striker is going through a bad time, it is not the easiest advice to take on board. To me, one of the most intriguing aspects of the scoring art is that the best strikers tend to come in all shapes and sizes. In one category, for example, there are the will-o'-the-wisp types such as Owen, Robbie Fowler, Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke. In the other, there are the big men such as John Hartson and Niall Quinn, who might not look particularly stylish but are nevertheless very effective. As reflected by Coventry's bid to sign Hartson from Wimbledon, I have admired him for some time. People tend to concentrate on his physique and combativeness; as his former West Ham boss, Harry Redknapp, pointed out: 'He is the closest football equivalent to a rugby union front-row forward.' But there is more to Hartson than just physical power. He has a good knowledge of the game - he knows how to find space - and, in addition to his ability in the air, he is an excellent striker of the ball. The other attraction about him for Coventry, of course, is that he operates with Bellamy in the Welsh team. At this stage, I do not want to get carried away by the prospect of him in a Coventry shirt. There are so many potential hitches in transfer deals and those concerning this one include the player-exchange element involving Roussel, and Hartson's previous knee problems. However, our chairman, Bryan Richardson, who is dealing with the finer points of the deal, is confident it will go ahead. Quinn, experiencing a new lease of life at Sunderland at the age of 34, is another big striker whose appearance is deceptive. It is difficult to avoid looking ungainly and clumsy when you are 6ft 5in tall. But, like Hartson, he has acquired a tremendous football knowledge; and his partnership with Kevin Phillips is as good as any in the Premiership. Still, that does not mean they are above missing apparently simple chances. As we saw on Wednesday, no one is. In the second leg of the Liverpool-Palace tie, we might also see how dramatically a striker's fortunes can be transformed. I still remember Mark McGhee's response after he and I had been guilty of amazing misses in Aberdeen's 2-0 European Cup Winners' Cup defeat by Ujpest Dozsa in 1984. In his book on his Aberdeen experiences, the manager, Alex Ferguson, described them as 'the worst goal attempts I have ever seen'. Mark, whose miss was even worse than mine - he fired wide of an open goal from a yard out - scored a hat-trick in the return to give us a 3-0 win.

fields.headline: Who's a popular team then?
fields.trailText: Crowds for domestic football in England are now the biggest in Europe.
fields.body:
I hate to say it, but I have spent the past few days hooked on a statistics website. The best thing about www.football.sportsites.co.uk is the attendance figures it provides for almost every football league in Europe (though not, sadly, for Albania). These give surprising insights and answer the question of which European country is maddest about the game.

Crowds in England are now the biggest in Europe. It was not ever thus. Ten years ago the average match in the old English First Division drew 20,776 people. In the Premier League so far this season it's 32,553. England has thus come from miles behind to overtake Italy, where average crowds in Serie A have hovered about 30,000 for most of the decade (or 29,499 so far this season).

German attendances have also jumped, but they did so earlier than in England, with the rise starting in the mid-Eighties and more or less peaking in the mid-Nineties. The average Bundesliga match now draws 29,897. German, Italian and Spanish crowds have all declined this season, while Premier League attendances are up 6.2 per cent.

But the country where fandom has truly come into fashion is France. Ten years ago the average crowd in the Championnat was 10,226. This season it's more than double that, at 22,190. As far as I can ascertain, this is by far the highest average in French history.

Aha, you might say, that's because the French won the World Cup and Euro 2000. Indeed, the average gate has jumped by 7,000 since the World Cup, and a sign of how quickly the French have caught on is that the final of Euro 2000 was watched on TV by four million more people (a total of 25 million) than saw the World Cup final.

However, it should be noted that the latest rises merely accelerated a trend. In the eight years before the World Cup, the average French attendance rose 50 per cent.

All this proves how fickle football fans are. It's not that they come running when a team does well. Rather, it seems that football can quickly become fashionable across a whole country. All teams then profit, but particularly those that build nice, large new stadiums. That would explain why the three English clubs whose crowds grew fastest over the Nineties were Manchester United, Sunderland and Newcastle. (The club that lost most spectators, incidentally, was Sheffield Wednesday, which shed 8,953 during the decade.)

In other nations, clubs such as Ajax and Celtic have drawn huge new crowds to their new grounds - in Ajax's case, even though their football has spontaneously combusted. Chants of 'Where were you when you were shit?' miss the point. It should be, 'Where were you when your ground was shit?'

Fans are more swayed by comfort, safety and fashion than by glory. If they were so worried about winning, then silverware-free operations such as Inter Milan, Borussia Dortmund, Newcastle and Olympique Marseille would not be among the 12 European clubs with the largest crowds.

Brian Clough once spoke of the great hordes of people not going to football matches. Indeed, grounds in most European countries are empty. Only in eight leagues does the average match draw more than 10,000 people. In Greece, supposedly a football-mad place, the average top-division crowd is 4,648.

But most pathetic are attendances in eastern Europe. This is a post-Communist phenomenon. In 1989, Nicolae Ceaucescu's last year in power, the average crowd at a Romanian first-division match was 17,000, almost as many as in England at the time. Now it's 7,307. In Poland, which has nearly 40 million inhabitants, the average has sunk to 4,523, and even given that Russian men are dying at such a startling rate, it's disappointing that only 11,820 (or less than one in 10,000 Russians) on average turn up to matches there. In Ukraine, Dynamo Kiev average 6,429 spectators. But the least popular league in Europe is Lithuania's, with an average attendance of 398.

It is also clear that few Europeans care about little clubs. The English are the exception. The Premiership club with the smallest crowds, Southampton, still pulls in 15,106, which is more than six clubs in Spain's Primera Liga.

The Nationwide Division One is easily the best-supported lower league in Europe, with average crowds of 13,943 per game. That is almost double the Italian Serie B , and nearly three times larger than the average in France's second division.

The Champions League was invented by the big western clubs. But it is their fans who like it least. Bayern Munich's average attendance in Europe so far this season is 22,750, or less than half their average Bundesliga crowd. Real Madrid, Lazio, Juventus and Paris St Germain also draw fewer fans than for domestic games.

The Champions League has most appeal in countries where domestic football is unpopular. Among the eight clubs with the largest average crowds in the competition are Olympiakos Piraeus, Dynamo Kiev, Panathinaikos, and, in first place, Spartak Moscow with 69,250. That's almost four times what they get for domestic matches.

None of this reveals which European country is nuttiest about football. England may have Europe's largest attendances, but as a percentage of its population the numbers are modest. In which country does the highest proportion of inhabitants go to games?

You might think it was Scotland. The average Scottish Premier League match draws a crowd of 15,991, more than the Russian average - pretty good for a country of 5.1 million people. If the English went in equal proportions, even taking into account the fact that the English Premier League game has eight more teams than Scotland's, the average English match would draw a crowd of 90,000.

Nor is the Scottish phenomenon simply an Old Firm effect. The average attendance for the 10 other clubs in the Scottish Premier League is 8,400, far more than for any other European country of similar size.

Yet the Scots are not the most football-mad Europeans. Icelanders are marginally more fanatical, but they don't win either. Instead, the honour goes to Cyprus. The average Cypriot match draws just 2,789 people, but that amounts to an excellent one in 287 of the country's 800,000 inhabitants.

fields.headline: Stop the world
fields.standfirst: Places to refresh your body and your mind from a headhunter's hut to a Japanese farm
fields.trailText: Places to refresh your body and your mind from a headhunter's hut to a Japanese farm.
fields.body:
2001 has finally begun and memories of Christmas and New Year are already drifting away, so it's time to start making plans for trips to recover from it all, maybe even time to start travelling with a new, fresh outlook. Call it what you like - recharging batteries, getting away from it all, just chilling out - there are many destinations that offer more than just a holiday. They are somewhere to restore your well-being, physically and mentally, places to which you definitely don't need to bring along your cell phone, Wap, portable computer or Palm. On these travels you might have a massage by a swirling whirlpool, go hiking up a mountainside, or take part in a mass meditation ceremony. You may end up staying in a luxury, expensive hotel, or cheap, spartan accommodation - and it could be thousands of miles away or just the other side of the Channel.

Rejang River, Sarawak, Malaysia

Sarawak is in the middle of the world's oldest rainforests in Borneo, and before becoming part of modern Malaysia was the private fief of Britain's Brooke family, known as the Land of the White Rajahs. Running through the jungle is the Rejang River, on whose banks live the Iban people, who were headhunters until half a century ago.

Why there? The Ibans live in communities of longhouses, where several hundred people share the same building, where only the sleeping quarters are kept private. The Ibans are friendly and welcoming to visitors, though don't be surprised to see skulls hanging from the ceiling, as they are still used for animist ceremonies.

Auroville, Pondicherry, India

A hundred miles south of Madras lies Auroville, the City of Dawn, a community of followers of the Sri Aurobindo ashram, a mystical, idealistic movement. More than 1,000 people live in Auroville, and over two-thirds are foreigners, including Brits and other Europeans.

Why there? Whether you find it a fraud, a rip-off or the recipe for surviving the future, a visit to Auroville - and especially its meditation centre, the Matramandir, a vast windowless globe - is a unique experience that may start you asking questions about your life.

Where to stay It is possible to stay in the utopian city of the future. Alternatively you can relax in nearby quaint Pondicherry, staying in the delightful hotel, Villa Helena, set in a luxurious old colonial bungalow. Auroville Guest Programme, Visitors Centre, 605 101 Auroville. Villa Helena, 14 Rue Suffren, Pondicherry. Tel: 00 91 413 226789, fax: 227087

Ubud, Bali, Indonesia

Forget the claim that Bali has been ruined by tourism because with a little effort anyone can find their own corner of paradise on this island where art and culture, religion, music and dance remain inextricably woven into people's daily lives.

Why there? If the island's cultural capital, Ubud, seems too busy and touristy, then head for nearby Sayan valley, Bali's most beautiful hidden vista of terraced rice fields. Spend your days having long, languid massages, witness trance dances and strange animist rites that cover Balinese life from birth to death.

Where to stay You can stay in a simple wood-carver's cottage in Sayan, but if budget is no problem, don't miss one of the world's ultimate luxury hotels. Four Seasons Resort at Sayan Ubud, Gianyar, Bali 81571. Tel: 00 62 361 977 577, fax: 361 977 588

Venice in winter

Discover why this city can still be called La Serenissima. Don't bother with the carnival, which has turned into a tacky circus; choose November, January, February or March and pack Wellington boots for the Aqua Alta floods.

Why there? Venice in the rain, the thick, enveloping winter fog, is Venice as it was centuries ago - silent, eerie, incredibly beautiful, and most importantly, inhabited mostly by locals rather than the thousands of tourists that flood in each day during the rest of the year.

Where to stay Avoid spending a fortune at the overpriced palace hotels but equally don't end up in a depressing one-star dive with loo and bathroom down the corridor. Book months in advance, and bag a room in Locanda Ai Santi Apostoli, a small elegant palazzo with a view over the Grand Canal. Locanda Ai Santi Apostoli, Strada Nuova 4391, Cannaregio. Tel: 00 39 0415 212 612, fax: 212 611

Little Palm Island, Florida Keys, US

Leave behind mainstream America and hit the road from Miami on the Overseas Highway, a silver ribbon that streaks southward through the Florida Keys, a long coral necklace of 40 islands, surrounded by the turquoise waters of the Gulf of Mexico. The Keys have an eccentric, independent island mentality.

Why there? Though most visitors here can't resist the lure of Key West, Key Largo, or the romantic Matekumbe Key, head for one of the idyllic private islands.

Where to stay In Little Palm Island you'll be deprived of telephones and TV but find yourself in total luxury. Little Palm Island, 28500 Overseas Highway, Little Torch Key, Florida 33042. Tel: 00 1 305 872 2524, fax: 872 4843

Kuda Huraa, Maldives

The Maldives remain one of the world's fundamental 'get-away-from-it-all' destinations. The perfect plan is to organise a combined trip, where you take in the marvellous Buddhist temples of Sri Lanka - Kandy, Polonnurawa, Anuradhapura - then escape to a faraway tropical island.

Why there? The unique tiny atolls of the Maldives are seriously threatened by the effects of global warming, and although they're not going to disappear into the Indian Ocean just yet, staying on one of these fragile desert islands is an experience better planned sooner than later.

Where to stay There are dozens of luxury resorts dotted around the coral reefs and blue lagoons of the Maldives, but covering an entire island, Kuda Huraa has the added attraction of an ideal state-of-the-art spa, with a vast range of relaxing, imaginative massages and aromatherapy Kuda Huraa Reef Resort, North Male Atoll, Maldives. Tel: 00 960 444888, fax: 960 441188

Mont-Saint-Michel, France

Mont-Saint-Michel holds the rather dubious honour of being France's most visited tourist site, but it is certainly one of the greatest religious buildings in Europe.

Why there? Millions of tourists flock here in summer, but the Mont - known as God's Pyramid - is virtually deserted in winter and there is a strange magical feeling each time the sea swirls in and covers the dangerous sands that separate the island from the French mainland.

Where to stay It is crucial to stay inside the confines of the Mont, to experience the isolation as the high tide cuts off the abbey. Hotel Saint-Pierre is open all the year round and offers rooms with views overlooking the sea. Hotel Saint-Pierre, BP 16, 50116 Le Mont-Saint-Michel. Tel: 00 33 2 33601403, fax 33 2 33485982

Shirakawa-Go, Honshu, Japan

To discover the authentic Land of the Rising Sun head for the picturesque mountains of the Japanese alps near Nagoya, and in particular, the idyllic, unspoilt Shokowa valley.

Why there? You'll discover huge, four-storey traditional thatched roof farmhouses - gassho zukuri - transformed for the most part into welcoming inns, known as minshuku . In one night you'll be transported back into ancient rural Japanese life, where the evening begins with a steaming hot bath, then all guests eat together, graciously served by the lady of the house who makes sure everyone tries the lethal home-made sake .

Where to stay The Japanese Tourism Office in London can provide a list of minshukus in Shirakawa-go, or even the nearby ski resort of Hakabu. Try Minshuku Matsuhei, Shirakawa-go, Nagoya. Tel: 00 81 576961500

St Catherine's Monastery, Sinai, Egypt

Set in the wild, arid desert of the Sinai peninsula, the monastery of St Catherine is both one of the most important and visually stunning sites of the Christian world.

Why there? The monastery is overshadowed by the towering Mount Sinai, where pilgrims from all over the world come to retrace the steps of Moses on his climb to receive the Ten Commandments. The walk begins in the pitch darkness of the night, arriving at a tiny chapel on the summit as dawn breaks over the mountain range.

Where to stay The best plan is to actually stay in the hostel of the monastery itself. To reserve, contact the administrative office of St Catherine's: 18 rue El Zaher , Cairo. Tel: 00 20 2 482 8513. The nearest main hotel is St Catherine Tourist Village, Wadi el-Raha, tel:062 77 04 56, fax 062 72 02 21

Scilly Isles, England

Imagine over 100 tiny islands, reefs and atolls, surrounded by a turquoise, crystal clear sea. Brilliant white sand beaches stretch for as far as the eye can see. The Seychelles or Caribbean come to mind, but this paradise is in fact the Scilly Isles, just 50 kilometres off the rocky coast of Cornwall.

Why there? Go to the tiny island of Tresco, where you'll discover the wonderful botanical centre, the Abbey Gardens which are filled with extravagant, exotic plants from all over the world. Smell the deep fragrances of musk, cinnamon or eucalyptus, then pinch yourself to remember that this is actually England.

Where to stay If Tresco is the jewel of the Scillies, then the Island Hotel is the ideal spot to base yourself, understated luxury, fine gourmet cuisine, with a laid-back atmosphere more like the Hamptons than the West Country. Island Hotel, Tresco, Scilly Isles. Tel : 01720 422883 . Fax : 01720 423008

Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe and Zambia

Situated on the boundary between these two African nations, the Victoria Falls remains one of the unspoilt wonders of the world, a rare sight that is even more breathtaking than you'd expected.

Why there? Explore the quiet, wild parkland on the Zambian frontier, which has even better views than the more frequented Zimbabwean side. There's a hair-raising, footbridge across the gorge that takes you to Knife Edge Point.

Where to stay Although the best views may be from the Zambian side, nothing can compare with staying in Zimbabwe's grand old relic from colonial times, the Victoria Falls Hotel, PO Box 10, Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe. Tel: 00 263 13 3211, fax: 263 13 3205

Sukhothai, Thailand

Avoid Thailand's congested, polluted modern capital, Bangkok, and hop on an old-fashioned train to the centre of the country and visit the country's first capital, Sukhothai, a peaceful, meditative centre of Buddhist temples.

Why there? Explore the 45 square kilometres of old city ruins that represent the Golden Age of Thai civilisation and religious art. You'll see more yellow-robed Buddhist monks on pilgrimages here than foreign tourists, especially around the colossal statue of Buddha in Wat Mahathat.

Where to stay There's plenty of cheap and cheerful budget accommodation in 'new' Sukhothai, but it can be worth splashing out on one of the luxury hotels in the countryside, with spas, traditional massage and lotus-filled lakes. Sukhothai Resort Hotel, 99 Moo 7 Tambol Sarmruen, Amphur Srisamrong Sukhothai 64120. Tel: 00 66 55 681698, fax:681697

Monte Alban, Oaxaca, Mexico

The ancient capital of the Zapotec Indians, this eerie ceremonial site resembles a lunar landscape. It is literally an artificially flattened mountain top, whose origins go back to around 500BC.

Why there? Less visited than the classic Mayan sites of Mexico's Yucatan peninsular, Monte Alban is a much more spiritual centre, and local Indian shamans still gather here to take part in mystic rituals.

Where to stay Oaxaca is one of the most charming cities in all Mexico. The Camino Rail Hotel was a convent in the sixteenth century, and is just off the main square, the Zocalo. Camino Real Hotel, Calle 5 de Mayo 300, 68000 Oaxaca. Tel: 00 52 951 60611, fax: 951 60732

North Cape, Norway

What better place to get away from it all than the most northern point in all Europe, deep in the heart of the Arctic Circle. You won't see more than a few Lapp farmers herding their reindeer, or hardy fishermen out to catch the few elusive cod still left in these icy waters.

Why there? The North Cape is flooded with tourists in summer, but during the dark winter months when twilight stretches for most of the day you can explore this isolated, snow-covered outpost and scarcely meet another soul.

Where to stay The ideal solution is to book a few days' passage on Norway's coastal steamer, the Hurtigruten, where in winter prices are discounted and the boat is mostly deserted. To book directly on the Hurtigruten Ferry, telephone Norwegian Coastal Voyage on 020 7559 6666. A small hotel near the North Cape itself is the Rica Hotel, Honningsvag. Tel: 00 47 7847 2333, fax: 7847 3379.

Spend your days having long, languid massages, witness trance dances and strange animist rites that cover Balinese life from birth to death. Where to stay You can stay in a simple wood-carver's cottage in Sayan, but if budget is no problem, don't miss one of the world's ultimate luxury hotels. Four Seasons Resort at Sayan Ubud, Gianyar, Bali 81571. Tel: 00 62 361 977 577, fax: 361 977 588 Venice in winter Discover why this city can still be called La Serenissima. Don't bother with the carnival, which has turned into a tacky circus; choose November, January, February or March and pack Wellington boots for the Aqua Alta floods. Why there? Venice in the rain, the thick, enveloping winter fog, is Venice as it was centuries ago - silent, eerie, incredibly beautiful, and most importantly, inhabited mostly by locals rather than the thousands of tourists that flood in each day during the rest of the year. Where to stay Avoid spending a fortune at the overpriced palace hotels but equally don't end up in a depressing one-star dive with loo and bathroom down the corridor. Book months in advance, and bag a room in Locanda Ai Santi Apostoli, a small elegant palazzo with a view over the Grand Canal. Locanda Ai Santi Apostoli, Strada Nuova 4391, Cannaregio. Tel: 00 39 0415 212 612, fax: 212 611 Little Palm Island, Florida Keys, US Leave behind mainstream America and hit the road from Miami on the Overseas Highway, a silver ribbon that streaks southward through the Florida Keys, a long coral necklace of 40 islands, surrounded by the turquoise waters of the Gulf of Mexico. The Keys have an eccentric, independent island mentality. Why there? Though most visitors here can't resist the lure of Key West, Key Largo, or the romantic Matekumbe Key, head for one of the idyllic private islands. Where to stay In Little Palm Island you'll be deprived of telephones and TV but find yourself in total luxury. Little Palm Island, 28500 Overseas Highway, Little Torch Key, Florida 33042. Tel: 00 1 305 872 2524, fax: 872 4843 Kuda Huraa, Maldives The Maldives remain one of the world's fundamental 'get-away-from-it-all' destinations. The perfect plan is to organise a combined trip, where you take in the marvellous Buddhist temples of Sri Lanka - Kandy, Polonnurawa, Anuradhapura - then escape to a faraway tropical island. Why there? The unique tiny atolls of the Maldives are seriously threatened by the effects of global warming, and although they're not going to disappear into the Indian Ocean just yet, staying on one of these fragile desert islands is an experience better planned sooner than later. Where to stay There are dozens of luxury resorts dotted around the coral reefs and blue lagoons of the Maldives, but covering an entire island, Kuda Huraa has the added attraction of an ideal state-of-the-art spa, with a vast range of relaxing, imaginative massages and aromatherapy Kuda Huraa Reef Resort, North Male Atoll, Maldives. Tel: 00 960 444888, fax: 960 441188 Mont-Saint-Michel, France Mont-Saint-Michel holds the rather dubious honour of being France's most visited tourist site, but it is certainly one of the greatest religious buildings in Europe. Why there? Millions of tourists flock here in summer, but the Mont - known as God's Pyramid - is virtually deserted in winter and there is a strange magical feeling each time the sea swirls in and covers the dangerous sands that separate the island from the French mainland. Where to stay It is crucial to stay inside the confines of the Mont, to experience the isolation as the high tide cuts off the abbey. Hotel Saint-Pierre is open all the year round and offers rooms with views overlooking the sea. Hotel Saint-Pierre, BP 16, 50116 Le Mont-Saint-Michel. Tel: 00 33 2 33601403, fax 33 2 33485982 Shirakawa-Go, Honshu, Japan To discover the authentic Land of the Rising Sun head for the picturesque mountains of the Japanese alps near Nagoya, and in particular, the idyllic, unspoilt Shokowa valley. Why there? You'll discover huge, four-storey traditional thatched roof farmhouses - gassho zukuri - transformed for the most part into welcoming inns, known as minshuku . In one night you'll be transported back into ancient rural Japanese life, where the evening begins with a steaming hot bath, then all guests eat together, graciously served by the lady of the house who makes sure everyone tries the lethal home-made sake . Where to stay The Japanese Tourism Office in London can provide a list of minshukus in Shirakawa-go, or even the nearby ski resort of Hakabu. Try Minshuku Matsuhei, Shirakawa-go, Nagoya. Tel: 00 81 576961500 St Catherine's Monastery, Sinai, Egypt Set in the wild, arid desert of the Sinai peninsula, the monastery of St Catherine is both one of the most important and visually stunning sites of the Christian world. Why there? The monastery is overshadowed by the towering Mount Sinai, where pilgrims from all over the world come to retrace the steps of Moses on his climb to receive the Ten Commandments. The walk begins in the pitch darkness of the night, arriving at a tiny chapel on the summit as dawn breaks over the mountain range. Where to stay The best plan is to actually stay in the hostel of the monastery itself. To reserve, contact the administrative office of St Catherine's: 18 rue El Zaher , Cairo. Tel: 00 20 2 482 8513. The nearest main hotel is St Catherine Tourist Village, Wadi el-Raha, tel:062 77 04 56, fax 062 72 02 21 Scilly Isles, England Imagine over 100 tiny islands, reefs and atolls, surrounded by a turquoise, crystal clear sea. Brilliant white sand beaches stretch for as far as the eye can see. The Seychelles or Caribbean come to mind, but this paradise is in fact the Scilly Isles, just 50 kilometres off the rocky coast of Cornwall. Why there? Go to the tiny island of Tresco, where you'll discover the wonderful botanical centre, the Abbey Gardens which are filled with extravagant, exotic plants from all over the world. Smell the deep fragrances of musk, cinnamon or eucalyptus, then pinch yourself to remember that this is actually England. Where to stay If Tresco is the jewel of the Scillies, then the Island Hotel is the ideal spot to base yourself, understated luxury, fine gourmet cuisine, with a laid-back atmosphere more like the Hamptons than the West Country. Island Hotel, Tresco, Scilly Isles. Tel : 01720 422883 . Fax : 01720 423008 Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe and Zambia Situated on the boundary between these two African nations, the Victoria Falls remains one of the unspoilt wonders of the world, a rare sight that is even more breathtaking than you'd expected. Why there? Explore the quiet, wild parkland on the Zambian frontier, which has even better views than the more frequented Zimbabwean side. There's a hair-raising, footbridge across the gorge that takes you to Knife Edge Point. Where to stay Although the best views may be from the Zambian side, nothing can compare with staying in Zimbabwe's grand old relic from colonial times, the Victoria Falls Hotel, PO Box 10, Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe. Tel: 00 263 13 3211, fax: 263 13 3205 Sukhothai, Thailand Avoid Thailand's congested, polluted modern capital, Bangkok, and hop on an old-fashioned train to the centre of the country and visit the country's first capital, Sukhothai, a peaceful, meditative centre of Buddhist temples. Why there? Explore the 45 square kilometres of old city ruins that represent the Golden Age of Thai civilisation and religious art. You'll see more yellow-robed Buddhist monks on pilgrimages here than foreign tourists, especially around the colossal statue of Buddha in Wat Mahathat. Where to stay There's plenty of cheap and cheerful budget accommodation in 'new' Sukhothai, but it can be worth splashing out on one of the luxury hotels in the countryside, with spas, traditional massage and lotus-filled lakes. Sukhothai Resort Hotel, 99 Moo 7 Tambol Sarmruen, Amphur Srisamrong Sukhothai 64120. Tel: 00 66 55 681698, fax:681697 Monte Alban, Oaxaca, Mexico The ancient capital of the Zapotec Indians, this eerie ceremonial site resembles a lunar landscape. It is literally an artificially flattened mountain top, whose origins go back to around 500BC. Why there? Less visited than the classic Mayan sites of Mexico's Yucatan peninsular, Monte Alban is a much more spiritual centre, and local Indian shamans still gather here to take part in mystic rituals. Where to stay Oaxaca is one of the most charming cities in all Mexico. The Camino Rail Hotel was a convent in the sixteenth century, and is just off the main square, the Zocalo. Camino Real Hotel, Calle 5 de Mayo 300, 68000 Oaxaca. Tel: 00 52 951 60611, fax: 951 60732 North Cape, Norway What better place to get away from it all than the most northern point in all Europe, deep in the heart of the Arctic Circle. You won't see more than a few Lapp farmers herding their reindeer, or hardy fishermen out to catch the few elusive cod still left in these icy waters. Why there? The North Cape is flooded with tourists in summer, but during the dark winter months when twilight stretches for most of the day you can explore this isolated, snow-covered outpost and scarcely meet another soul. Where to stay The ideal solution is to book a few days' passage on Norway's coastal steamer, the Hurtigruten, where in winter prices are discounted and the boat is mostly deserted. To book directly on the Hurtigruten Ferry, telephone Norwegian Coastal Voyage on 020 7559 6666. A small hotel near the North Cape itself is the Rica Hotel, Honningsvag. Tel: 00 47 7847 2333, fax: 7847 3379.

webTitle: Romantic getaways: Ten ways to leave your lover... breathless

fields.headline: Ten ways to leave your lover... breathless
fields.standfirst: Don't say we didn't try to help - you now have exactly one month to plan a Valentine's Day to set pulses racing,  Joanne O'Connor  offers advice
fields.trailText: Don't say we didn't try to help - you now have exactly one month to plan a Valentine's Day to set pulses racing, Joanne O'Connor offers advice.
fields.body:
Parisian encounter

Nul points for originality but top marks for romance. Eurostar Holidays Direct (0870 1 676767) has a short break departing for the city of lovers on 13 February for £143 per person. The price includes two nights accommodation at the two-star Hotel de France and return Eurostar travel. For £66 per person you can prebook a gourmet dinner cruise along the Seine with champagne and musical accompaniment.

Rural retreat

Escape to your very own nineteenth-century cottage which comes with its own duck pond, rose garden, wood-burning stove and Victorian brass bed. The cottage, near Knighton in Wales, is available for a week from 10 February at a cost of £179. Search through a database of more than 3,000 properties around the UK, northern France & Ireland by visiting www.easycottages.com or by telephoning 01756 70 80 90.

Play Romeo and Juliet

The perfect destination for star-crossed lovers, Verona is the city of Romeo and Juliet. Stay in the comfortable three-star Hotel de'Capuleti and pay a visit to Juliet's balcony. The house to which the balcony belongs was once owned by the Cappello family, the model for the fictional Capulets. Inntravel (01653 629010) has a two-night break departing 8 February for £198 per person including accommodation and return BA flights from Gatwick to Verona.

Disneyland Paris

Take your Prince (or Princess) Charming to Disneyland Paris (0870 5030303). Prices start at £223 per person for one night in the fairy-tale themed Disneyland Hotel, two days in the theme park and return travel on Eurostar. Visit Sleeping Beauty's Castle, go ice-skating outside the Hotel New York and enjoy a French meal at the romantic Auberge de Cendrillon.

Champagne and roses

Champagne on arrival and a red rose on the pillow are just two of the romantic touches promised by Tylney Hall (01256 764881) in Hampshire for guests arriving the weekend before or after Valentine's Day. The knot garden, entwined dolphins fountain and log fires set the tone at this Tudor country house hotel. Prices start at £245 per person for two nights, including dinner on Friday and aperitifs and a black-tie gourmet dinner on Saturday night with musical accompaniment.

Ballet and chocolate in Vienna

Go one step better than chocolates with a visit to the Hotel Sacher in Vienna whose café is home to the original Sachen Torte, a deliciously rich chocolate cake. A two-night stay at the five-star hotel with Thomson Breakaway Cities (0870 606 1476) costs £964 per couple in February, including flights, arrival transfer and a guide book. The hotel is opposite the Opera House, which will be staging the most romantic of ballets, Swan Lake, on 14 February.

Stay in an Irish castle

If the Scottish castles are all booked up for Valentine's look across the Irish Sea where there are plenty of historic properties offering a romantic getaway. One such is Dromoland Castle. Surrounded by acres of private park and woodland, the castle's bedrooms are decorated with antique furnishings. A three-night break in February costs from £685 per person including flights from London, accommodation with breakfast and private transfers. Book with Seasons in Style on 0151 342 0505.

Moroccan magic

With its jugglers, magicians, storytellers, shady courtyards and heaving souks set against the backdrop of the Atlas mountains, Marrakesh offers up a potent brew for romantic souls. The Riad Kaiss hotel has rooftop terraces, a flower-filled patio and four-poster beds in most rooms. A three-night break departing on 12 February with Simply Travel (0208 541 2212) costs £464 per person, including bed and breakfast accommodation, return flights with British Airways, transfers and roses on arrival.

Classic driving tour

Cruise the country lanes of East Anglia with your loved one in an Aston Martin DB6 or a Jaguar E-Type Roadster. Grand Touring Club (01449 737 774) offers a range of self-drive breaks in classic cars. Prices start at £250 per person for a three-night midweek break and include car hire, insurance and breakdown cover, advice line and area route books. Accommodation can be arranged on request, along with other extras including champagne, concert tickets or even a gourmet winter picnic.

Spanish spa break

Indulge in life's sensual pleasures on a Valentine's spa package at the Marbella Club Hotel & Spa in Spain. Priced from £555 per person, the package includes three nights accommodation, flights, a candlelit dinner for two and a two-day Thalasso spa programme which includes treatments such as algae baths and full-body massages. Book with the Mediterranean Experience on 020 8445 6000.

webTitle: No otters. Still, I've got a loch to be thankful for

fields.headline: No otters. Still, I've got a loch to be thankful for
fields.trailText: 'Every morning, when I woke up on the Island of Danna, I looked out of the bedroom window in amazement.'
fields.body:
Every morning, when I woke up on the Island of Danna, I looked out of the bedroom window in amazement. If I lived there for years, I don't think I'd get used to the view of the waters of Loch na Cille, a few metres from the cottage. Sometimes they lapped peacefully at the shore, while at others they charged furiously up the channel between our island and the next peninsula, beyond which the Paps of Jura were occasionally visible. Every morning I scanned the water for the otters we'd been promised by the cottage's owner, Miss Pollock. They must be the shyest otters in Scotland.

James and I decided months ago that we would spend a low-key New Year in a remote corner of the British Isles. It occurred to us that a cottage would be much cheaper and more fun than any hotel. Extensive enquiries among everyone we knew produced three other takers: Charlotte from London, Neil from Newcastle, and Jeff from New York. We searched the internet for properties and were surprised at the vast array of websites out there. The best site, in our opinion, was run by Country Holidays; it let us put in requests such as 'open fire', then listed page after page of gorgeous looking houses. We settled on one near Ullapool.

It was not, however, as straightforward as we'd hoped: the day before our departure, we suddenly had to choose a different Country Holidays cottage, because the whole country except for our hometown, Brighton, was covered in snow, and the people who had spent Christmas in our original choice had (opportunistically, in our opinion) declared themselves unable to leave.

Thus we arrived, on a crisp and snowy Saturday, on the Island of Danna. It is not a place that should be anybody's second choice. From Glasgow, the drive was spectacular, skirting Loch Lomond and Loch Fyne before meandering through the village of Tayvallich and over a causeway.

'There'll be a ceilidh tomorrow night,' Miss Pollock told us, (she was surely Judi Dench's twin sister). 'I don't expect anyone would mind if you came. Just ask in the pub whose house it's at, and bring plenty of bottles.' The idea of celebrating Hogmanay at someone else's house when we weren't really invited, and the roads were icy and any expedition meant that one of us couldn't drink, was not, ultimately, as appealing as staying in making our own entertainment; which we did in some style, thanks to six magnums of champagne left over from James's brother's wedding, and a roaring fire.

Despite good intentions, we began the New Year with a day of collective televisual sloth. We had a brief moment of self-awareness when Charlotte pointed out that we were slumped indoors on a beautiful Scottish island, watching people leaving a beautiful Scottish island, and marvelling at how beautiful it was. Looking out of the window would have been more effective. Jeff received a thorough grounding in British television, and for the rest of the week impressed us by saying things like 'Isn't that Judy Finnegan?' and, 'How did Mark Fowler get HIV?' We, in return, emerged depressingly well-informed about the iniquities and the corruption of the American election.

Once the hangovers wore off, there was an immense amount of sightseeing to be done. Kilmartin Glen was nearby, with its standing stones and ruined castles. Skies were often blue. The fresh air hit our lungs and made us happy, and having an American on hand ensured that we appreciated how old everything was (and also led us to visit numerous establishments that offered fish and chips). One day we drove to Oban and caught a boat to Mull and then to Iona, where we saw John Smith's grave. The abbey and the ruined nunnery alone were worth the holiday, and the sense of isolation was tempered only slightly by the fact that we were far from the only tourists on the boat.

We left Danna sadly, a bit calmer, and a lot fatter. As well as seeing in the New Year in some sort of style, we'd remained friends throughout. The only thing I could have asked for would have been the briefest glimpse of an otter.

 The Country Holidays website is at www.country-holidays.co.uk. Miss Pollock's cottage's reference number is 6775

fields.headline: Height of luxury
fields.standfirst: While the snows last, make the most of a Rockies resort that lives up to the hype, advises  Stephen Lee
fields.trailText: While the snows last, make the most of a Rockies resort that lives up to the hype, advises Stephen Lee.
fields.body:
The work may define the man, but in western Canada you are defined by your sport. A quick tour of Whistler, regularly voted top ski resort of the Americas, will tell you why. It has the 'largest ski area, one of the greatest vertical drops, the longest season, 1,500 instructors, sumptuous on-slope accommodation, the mellowest apres-ski and nightlife - all within two hours of Vancouver, itself a superb vacation city'. Could any resort really be this good?

A 10-hour flight should be exhausting, but not if you stay at the just-opened Fairmont Vancouver Airport Hotel. The luxurious Entrée Gold hotel within a hotel is 30 seconds from Arrivals. A massage, a light meal and a good night's sleep banished jet lag and we were ready for the road.

And what a road. We crossed the Lion Gate Bridge, Vancouver's Golden Gate, and headed up the stunning seal-dotted Howe Sound to Squamish (Indian for Big Wind). Here some 5,000 Bald Eagles spend the winter fishing for salmon. The last hour was a scenic mountain travel delight; Whistler almost came too soon.

Our hotel, Chateau Whistler, dominates the upper village, at the base of the Blackcomb slopes. The Whistler and Blackcomb massifs are two inter-linked ski areas that offer a possible 7,000 skiable acres. You would be pushed to ski each run once in three days, assuming you had the legs to do it.

Last summer the resort invested $2.3 millon on snowmaking, to some local scepticism, since they normally have 100 per cent coverage from November to May, with an average 12 metre annual snowfall. But this autumn was the driest for a decade. With a mere 3,000 acres on offer in early December, the snowmaking was put to good use.

One of the best ways to enjoy Whistler is to join the Ski Esprit instruction programme. Fresh-faced Phil Gordon soon had us enjoying Whisky Jack, the Dave Murray Downhill and Harmony Express. He boosted our confidence on Jersey Cream and Burnt Stew trails. Serious teaching was regularly interspersed with humour and inspiration.

The Horstman glacier provided exhilarating ski scenery. At 7,000ft, it is another of Whistler's bonuses - glaciers are usually at lung-crushing altitudes. We marvelled at the Black Tusk panorama and looked askance at the Couloir Extreme, a dou ble black-diamond shute that is the start of skiing's reputedly steepest GS race.

As to the après-ski, there are plenty of bars in which to rub shoulders with couloir extremists and restaurants with great ambience. Whistler Village is also a shopper's paradise - international names, quirky local outlets and mellow internet cafes - all affordable given the current exchange rate.

It would be easy for this blue-chip resort to rest on its laurels, but the expansion and aspiration continue. The Blackcomb snowboard Terrain Park is groomed with the latest 17ft radius-arm Super Pipe Dragon. New for 2001 is the rejuvenated Whistler Creek Village, with rapid access to the slopes.

Whistler facts

Until 21 Jan, World Freestyle Championships.
2-3 Feb, Peak to Valley Race.
4-11 Feb, Annual Gay Ski Week.
13-22 April, Ski and Snowboard Festival.
Weekly throughout the season, Kokanee Ski Races.
www.tourismwhistler.com

Crystal Holidays (0870 848 7000) offer seven nights at the five-star Chateau Whistler from £635 per person, based on four sharing a room, including return flights and transfers

Fairmont Chateau Whistler/Fairmont Vancouver Airport Hotel; www.fairmont.com

Our hotel, Chateau Whistler, dominates the upper village, at the base of the Blackcomb slopes. The Whistler and Blackcomb massifs are two inter-linked ski areas that offer a possible 7,000 skiable acres. You would be pushed to ski each run once in three days, assuming you had the legs to do it. Last summer the resort invested $2.3 millon on snowmaking, to some local scepticism, since they normally have 100 per cent coverage from November to May, with an average 12 metre annual snowfall. But this autumn was the driest for a decade. With a mere 3,000 acres on offer in early December, the snowmaking was put to good use. One of the best ways to enjoy Whistler is to join the Ski Esprit instruction programme. Fresh-faced Phil Gordon soon had us enjoying Whisky Jack, the Dave Murray Downhill and Harmony Express. He boosted our confidence on Jersey Cream and Burnt Stew trails. Serious teaching was regularly interspersed with humour and inspiration. The Horstman glacier provided exhilarating ski scenery. At 7,000ft, it is another of Whistler's bonuses - glaciers are usually at lung-crushing altitudes. We marvelled at the Black Tusk panorama and looked askance at the Couloir Extreme, a dou ble black-diamond shute that is the start of skiing's reputedly steepest GS race. As to the après-ski, there are plenty of bars in which to rub shoulders with couloir extremists and restaurants with great ambience. Whistler Village is also a shopper's paradise - international names, quirky local outlets and mellow internet cafes - all affordable given the current exchange rate. It would be easy for this blue-chip resort to rest on its laurels, but the expansion and aspiration continue. The Blackcomb snowboard Terrain Park is groomed with the latest 17ft radius-arm Super Pipe Dragon. New for 2001 is the rejuvenated Whistler Creek Village, with rapid access to the slopes. fields.headline: Choices
fields.standfirst: Meet your makers
fields.trailText: Meet your makers.
fields.body:
If you've bought the product, why not meet the producer. Traidcraft, the independent fair trade organisation, is organising a holiday to India to allow supporters to meet the people behind the goods in the catalogue. Most of the Indian products are crafts such as natural dyed textiles, but the tour - in the second half of October - will focus on a new food supplier at Cochin, South India. This EU-funded project, 70 per cent owned by local farmers, produces candied fruit for cereals and stem ginger for cookies. An Indian guide, Ranjith Henry, a specialist in alternative travel will lead the tour to 12 places. The trip will cost around £2,500. For details contact Catharine Howe at Traidcraft, Kingsway, Gateshead, Tyne and Wear NE11 0NE 0191 491 0591, email comms@tradecraft.co.uk.

Grown-up child discounts
Teenagers often miss out on child discounts but not with Planos (01373 824201), the company that only features the Ionian island of Paxos. Planos offers discounts of 20 per cent to all children under 18 and extends the deal to any family dependant in full-time education - school, college or university. Studios, apartments and villas are featured across the island, which has remained unhurried, thanks perhaps to the two-hour ferry connection necessary to reach the airport in Corfu.

Going native
Take a step back into American history with Bear Print, the only company to specialise in Native America. There are four tours this summer offering a chance meet traditional medicine men at their campfires, spend time with Steve Reevis, the star of Dances With Wolves, eat feasts with Blackfoot tribal people or stay in teepees at a hidden Indian encampment. Prices are from £1,495 for a 14-day Buffalo Nation which starts in South Dakota. This is for accommodation and internal transport only: international flights are extra. Details from 01924 840111 or email bearprint@bun.com.

Separate tables
Princess Cruises has joined the move to a more informal style of life afloat. Personal Choice dining has been introduced on Caribbean cruises this winter aboard the Grand Princess. Instead of eating at designated tables in one of two sittings, passengers may dine at any time between 5.30pm and midnight without a reservation and can sit at tables for two if they wish. This option will be available in two of the three main dining rooms as well as the two speciality restaurants. The scheme, which follows the 'freestyle cruising' concept introduced by the Norwegian Cruise Line. Princess hope to extend the scheme across the fleet by the end of the year. (0870 5664422)

fields.headline: Health check
fields.trailText: An outbreak of Ross River Virus in the south of Australia has totalled 60 cases on the west coast, Kangaroo Island and near Lake Albert. Ross River Virus is a febrile viral disease characterised by arthritis, primarily in the wrist, knee, ankle and small joints of the extremities, lasting from days to months. The onset of arthritis is often followed by a rash which affects the trunk and limbs and resolves within 7-10 days. A small percentage of people will take more than a year fully to recover. Ross River Virus is transmitted by mosquitoes that bite during the day and the night. Travellers should take extra measures to avoid mosquito bites while in the area. Using repellents on exposed skin is recommended. The state government has launched an awareness campaign.

webTitle: Could global warming put an end to skiing?

fields.headline: Meltdown
fields.standfirst: Snowfall may be good in Europe this weekend, but global warming could put an end to skiing altogether - and soon
fields.trailText: Snowfall may be good in Europe this weekend, but global warming could put an end to skiing altogether - and soon.
fields.body:
The broiling heat of Florida's Orlando might seem incongruous for the annual convention of North America's ski operators. Last year, however, the shorts-and-sandals weather was uncomfortably appropriate. Top of the agenda was what delegates had voted the biggest threat to skiing worldwide: the insidious encroachment of global warming. Delegates arriving in Orlando had every reason to be worried. After three bad snow years the gossip in the convention centre was about the resorts that had suffered yet another disastrous year, prominent among them the unfortunate Snow Bowl resort near Flagstaff, Arizona. High temperatures and low snowfall meant last season only lasted a few weeks.

And it is not just North America that is suffering from the threat of rising temperatures. Wherever local economies are dependent on skiing - from Europe to the Antipodes - they are facing the same nightmare scenario: the end of skiing as we know it, and with it the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs in some of Europe's and America's poorest regions.

For tourists it poses another kind of nightmare: of muddy denuded slopes and crumbling mountains; of ski-lift pylons made unsafe by the defrosting of the very foundations on which they stand; a future in which skis and snowboards are curious museum pieces.

'There was a survey done recently that showed what the impact would be on North American skiing,' says Auden Schendler, director of environmental affairs at the Aspen Skiing Company in Colorado, one of the world's most famous resorts. 'It showed that in 100 years our climate could be similar to that of Santa Fe. That is the equivalent of chopping the top 2,000ft off our mountains.

'It is,' he admits, 'a worst-case scenario. But what we are seeing without doubt is heavier snow, wetter weather and warmer nights, which has a clear implication for artificial snowmaking.' And it matters to Aspen. It really does. For despite its public face as a chi-chi resort for the rich and famous, many of those servicing the resort are from the most vulnerable end of the economic spectrum.

According to Schendler, Aspen's economy is almost entirely dependent on skiing and winter tourism. Each dollar spent on skiing brings in almost a dollar in revenue to restaurants and other outlets. In the bad snow years, income has dropped by up to 20 per cent.

It is a story horribly familiar in the world's most famous resorts, especially after the experiences of the Nineties - the warmest decade since records began. It is also an issue some ski operators believe the industry has been slow to wake up to. Schendler's predecessor Chris Lane was one of those who, for years, had been warning about the danger. 'When I brought up global warming just two years ago,' he told the US Ski Magazine earlier this month: 'I was laughed at.'

Now nobody's laughing. A tranche of new scientific research has revealed that the snow once taken for granted by resorts is increasingly under threat.

Last week it was the turn of Dr Chris Harris to turn the heat up on the ski business, revealing that the very fabric of Europe's mountains, the frozen permafrost that holds the Alps together, was melting. Work by the Cardiff University academic revealed that temperatures in the icebound soil above Alpine villages such as Zermatt, St Moritz and Murren, had risen by as much as a degree in the last 15 years, a phenomenon that is also being repeated from Scandinavia's mountain ranges, through the Pyrenees down to Spain's high mountains of the Sierra Nevada.

It may be news to most skiers, but is something that has been noted with growing alarm by mountaineers for well over a decade. Alpine ice climbs first ascended in the summer months even until the Sixties are now climbed in mid-winter, or not at all, trans formed in the summer into rocky rubble chutes. Across the globe glaciers are in retreat. Indeed, since 1850 the glacial area of western Europe has reduced by almost a half. And the loss of permafrost has serious implications for the Alps themselves. The spectacular collapse of a massive rampart on the Petit Dru, an imposing and beautiful rock pillar that towered over the French Alpine resort of Chamonix, has been blamed on the melting of the deep and ancient ice that glued it together.

And it is a threat that could bring economic meltdown to many mountain communities, as well as endangering their very existence through the avalanches, landslips and floods that have come to be associated with the changing mountain weather patterns.

A 1996 model of snowfall in the European Alps created by the Centre for Snow Studies in Grenoble in France calculated that at an altitude of 1,500 metres in the French Alps, a rise of 1.8C would reduce the period of snow by 20 per cent in the north and by 40 per cent in the south, with the greatest impact in the Maritime Alps. For Mont Blanc, Europe's highest mountain, it would mean half a metre less snow each year.

It has been more than just theory. According to the same report, the predicted shrinking of the ski season at lower altitude resorts has been happening for a decade. Satellite imaging in the Nineties of the lowlands around the Alps in Germany, Switzerland and Austria and the plains of the river Po showed they were receiving between three and four weeks less snow cover than in previous decades.

The threat to the European ski industry was laid out in apocalyptic terms by Bruno Abegg, a researcher at Zurich University in the mid-Nineties, when he warned that a rise in temperature of 3C would devastate the European mountain environment and economies, leading to a rise in the snowline of the Central Alps of 300m, threatening a third of Switzerland's resorts with the prospect of insufficient snow to ski.

But it is at the lower altitude resorts - particularly in Austria - that the alarm bells are ringing most loudly. Three-quarters of Austria's ski-lifts are situated below 1,000 metres; 69 per cent of all winter tourist nights are also spent below this level.

Austria, indeed, is typical of many mountainous regions of the world where skiing and mountain tourism has been established in the last half century as an alternative to low intensity agriculture. Austria too, is unusually dependent on its ski industry which generates 4.5 per cent of the country's gross national product. That figure - high as it is - hides an even higher level of economic dependence in the mountain regions themselves on winter tourism. Research commissioned by the Austrian government from Meinhard Breiling, a scientist at the Laboratory of Land Resource Sciences at the University of Tokyo, makes for chilling reading. Breiling has calculated both the possible loss of snow cover for Austria and, significantly, the economic impact it would have on theindustry.

For like many other ski operators (Aspen included) Austrian operators, faced with a flattening of growth in the ski market, have borrowed heavily to fund improvements in their resorts they hope will give them the edge on their competitors.

And if Austria's resorts are vulnerable, then their populations are doubly so, for reasons echoed in mountain communities around the world where work is seasonal and low paid. Incomes in some ski areas - according to Breiling's research in the Hermagor region - are 80 per cent lower than the national average. 'No industrial country in the world is as dependent on tourism as Austria, which has a share between 4 and 5 per cent of world tourism,' Breiling said in a presentation to the Japanese Snow and Ice Society at Niigata. 'Fifty per cent of tourist income derives from the winter season. A couple of bad winter seasons with poor snow cover, similar to those experienced at the end of the Eighties may ruin a population dependent on winter income.' The worst-case scenario has already been spelt out for Austria by a 1994 government report which warned that a rise of just 1C, combined with a decline in snowfall, could reduce the duration of snowcover over 1,500m by half.

While Breiling challenges such worst-case scenario calculations he does, however, believe that the Austrian economy has already been damaged by global warming, perhaps accounting for as much as a 1.5 per cent of potential national earnings. Breiling bases his calculations on a rise in temperature of 1.5C over the next few decades. The impact of this, he calculates, would be devastating, seeing a loss of 15 days from both ends of the winter season, and damaging the profitable Christmas and Easter periods.

The vulnerability of the Austrian ski industry was also highlighted by a report last year by the World Wide Fund for Nature on the impact of global warming on international tourism that focused on the threat to the top resort of Kitzbuhl, none of whose mountains is much above 2,000m.

'There is obviously going to be a problem in somewhere like Kitzbuhl,' says Dr Ute Collier, the head of WWF's climate change campaign. 'The local people there will say: "No, no, we haven't got a problem" and point to annual variations in snowfall, but the trend is clearly for warmer winters. We have also seen a change in the winter weather patterns with snowfall patterns changing so that there are long periods of stable sunny weather with short very heavy falls of snow that bring their own kind of problems like the avalanches we have seen in Austria, Switzerland and France. I think that it is also clear that we are going to see more starts to the ski season like this year's, where low-lying resorts had no snow at all.'

If Austria is contemplating a nightmare future without sufficient snow for skiing, the same concern is being amplified several-fold in ski areas with marginal profitability like Vermont, New Hampshire's White Mountains, California's Sierra Nevada (which includes Hollywood's resort of choice, Lake Tahoe) and Australia's Snowy Mountains, whose viability is at best close to the knuckle. In Scotland the situation is best regarded as being hopeless.

Vanessa Haines, of the Ski Club of Great Britain, has noted the changes with concern but remains open-minded about how much temperatures will finally rise and cautious about the most pessimistic predictions for the sport. 'The research has been contradictory but temperatures do seem to have been rising. We have already seen summer glacier skiing being restricted. It is also true that Austria has had some very bad years, but last winter Austria had some amazing snow.'

One thing she has noticed is the way in which snowfall patterns have changed away from steady snowfall throughout the season to heavy falls during wild storms.

And on the slopes themselves ski guides and instructors are painfully aware of what is going on. Last Thursday The Observer caught up with British instructor Mark Jones as he was leading an off-piste party above the resort of Val D'Isère. Despite abundant snow last week, he has noticed a marked change in the 10 years he has been based in the Alps.

'Global warming comes up a lot in conversation in the resort,' he said.'Now when there is any unusual weather people immediately blame global warming. But what has been very noticeable is the way in which all the glaciers have been retreating, even in a decade. Where there was once snow and ice there are just steep rocky slopes. The other thing that I have noticed is how unpredictable the weather has become. Once you could have a pretty good idea what kind of weather you could expect in each month of the winter.'

If it all sounds like terrible news, there is at least one straw of hope to cling to for dedicated skiers horrified by the prospect of their sport being consigned to the history books. For as well as heavier snowfall predicted for northern latitude locations such as northern Scandinavia and Alaska, at least one climate model for global warming would see Northern Europe's temperature rise and then just as quickly decline as cold water from the northern polar ice cap displaces the Gulf Stream and creates a Polar Stream cooling Europe's climate.

Don't throw away those skis just yet.

The chilling facts

 Satellites show vast areas of the Alps already losing up to four weeks snow cover compared to a decade ago.

 Mountain communities face the threat of avalanches, landslips and floods as the snow melts.

 Defrosting of the ground is likely to make ski-lift pylons unsafe.

 Hundreds of thousands of workers in the ski industry could lose their jobs.

 4.5 per cent of Austria's gross national product could be lost.

webTitle: Where to find the white stuff this weekend

fields.headline: Where to find the white stuff this weekend
fields.standfirst: Nigel Lloyd's snow reports
fields.trailText: Nigel Lloyd's snow reports.
fields.body:
Despite gloomy long-term predictions, Austria has been getting some of the snow it needs. Italy and the southern French Alps are excellent. After good early snow many Americans would welcome new falls and the snowmakers have been busy.

Andorra: Not good. Arcalis with 40cm on lower slopes and 70cm higher up, and Pal (35/60cm) had hard pistes, while Soldeu (15/30cm) and Pas de la Casa (20/30cm) were cold and miserable midweek.

Austria: Mayrhofen (20/120cm) was excited at the arriving snow. 'Pistes are good and off-piste there is 30cm of powder.' Up at Hintertux there has been 75cm of fresh powder. St Anton (50/160cm) was reasonable on and off the higher pistes. Lech (50/80cm) too had improved higher up. Kitzbuhel (15/48cm) was better but needs more. Obergurgl (66/200cm) was fine with powder off piste, while Ischgl (30/ 130) was coming good. February may be best in Austria, when it is less crowded during school half-terms than France.

Bulgaria: Borovets (5/10cm) and Pamporovo (0/10cm) struggled to open a little skiing while, in Romania, Poiana Brasov (50/60cm) wasn't happy.

Canada: A 30-year-old woman was killed by a cougar near Banff. At nearby Lake Louise (45/81cm) conditions were reasonable on and off piste. Whistler (153/180cm) was also good. In the East, Mont Tremblant (95/113cm) has more snow but is cold.

France: Most runs have been open in Megeve and St Gervais (15/80cm) though conditions were disappointing. The weather was expected to improve this weekend. It was the same in Chamonix (30/130cm) where the best skiing is high up. Courchevel (15/70 cm) had good if packed pistes, the off-piste was 'great if you know where to go'. Weather variable. 'The snow is much better over towards Val Thorens' (50/150cm). Les Arcs (50/103cm) had hard pistes despite some snow and very mixed off-piste. In Val d'Isère (50/110cm) bad weather brought some snow. Tignes (60/190cm) was slightly better off. Alpe d'Huez (40/210cm) again was cloudy with best runs higher up. Its little neighbour Vaujanay (18/80cm) had bare and patchy pistes. The further south you go the deeper the snow. Isola (105/365cm) only 90min from Nice looks to be having bumper snow depths.

Italy: Great enthusiasm from Courmayeur (80/220cm) after some snow. The pistes were 'top notch' and the off-piste 'bottomless though a little heavy on lower slopes'. At nearby Pila (60/105cm) in the Aosta Valley conditions were 'excellent' and the snowboard park 'great'. Conditions are generally good in the Dolomite resorts and along the great Milky Way. Elsewhere midweek depths speak for themselves, Passo Tonale (160/180cm), Bormio (35/270cm), Santa Caterina (100/300cm) and Madesimo (120/580cm), Cervinia (90/200cm) Livigno (115/300cm) and Cortina (20/250cm).

Switzerland: After early week snow most resorts were reporting good pistes and resort runs, while off-piste was described as powder. Weather has been variable. Davos (30/140cm), Klosters (40 /130cm), Arosa (95/110cm), Verbier (50/120cm) Zermatt (35/160cm) had improved. Wengen (50/100cm) and Murren (55/95cm) were pleased, while St Moritz (100/260cm) and SaasFee (60/165cm) also offered fine skiing.

US: The cold East Coast resorts are doing well. Killington (75/175cm) had excellent piste skiing and powder off-piste while Stowe (55/95cm) was good on piste and varied off it. From California came news that there was a serious shortage of snow in Mammoth (30/60cm) and around Lake Tahoe. Heavenly (35/80cm) and Squaw Valley (43/90cm) were making snow while still needing dollops of the real stuff. In Colorado they have even been seeding clouds, but depths are still impressive even though most pistes are hard packed. Steamboat (95/115cm), Vail (79/112cm) Aspen (60/85cm), Breckenridge (76/190cm) and Winter Park (115/125cm). Utah hadn't had any fresh snow since the new year.

On the slopes: Julie Walters was out with an instructor in Les Houches. Robbie Williams was snowboarding in Courchevel but keeping a low profile off the slopes.

Best skiing: Killington, where Ski Safari (020 7740 1221) has a week's B&B in the Pico Mountain Inn, with Virgin flights from Gatwick to Boston and self-drive hire car for two people sharing at £499. This special offer is valid from 20 January to 7 February.

The AITO directory of ski operators, whose reps help with this report, is available free by calling 020 8607 9080

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Claire
fields.trailText: I can really recommend Zeck Travellers Inn if you go to Kota Bharu It's basic but extremely friendly; I felt more relaxed there than anywhere else. They will organise all sorts for you. Say hello from me if you get there.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

In the summer of 1999 I was 50, and celebrated with a month travelling on my own in Malaysia. It was the first time I had done this since my early twenties. I found Kuala Lumpur rather intimidating (watch out for the fact that taxis only stop at special places, like bus stops).

Flying is dirt cheap. I can really recommend Zeck Travellers Inn if you go to Kota Bharu (telephone 09 7431613, or email ztraveller_inn@hotmail.com). It's basic but extremely friendly; I felt more relaxed there than anywhere else. They will organise all sorts for you. Say hello from me if you get there.

The Perhentian Islands are beautiful and I learnt to dive there, but you can't go at this time of year. If you like bird watching there is a mad guy called Durai who works for the World Wide Fund for Nature at Frasers Hill who will take you out endlessly and for free (telephone 019 918888 0514 or email dure@rocketmail.com.

I think the jungle trekking is best left to the young or very fit, and I don't think you really see that much.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Fethi Gucluer, chief concierge at The Ciragan Palace Hotel, Istanbul
fields.trailText: Fethi Gucluer, chief concierge at The Ciragan Palace Hotel, Istanbul.
fields.body:
Is it a real palace?

Yes. The Ciragan Palace was originally built of wood at the end of the sixteenth century. It was rebuilt in marble in 1857 and was home to the last of the Ottoman sultans. It was badly damaged by fire in 1910 and abandoned until 1986. Kempinski purchased it in 1991 and it is now the only five-star property in Istanbul on the shores of the Bosphorus.

So, plenty of famous guests?

Since our opening in 1991 we have hosted many kings, presidents, artists and famous faces, including President Clinton, Princess Margaret, Claudia Schiffer, Luciano Pavarotti and Giorgio Armani.

Any unusual requests?

There have been many, but the most memorable involves a young couple who said that the hotel's breathtaking location had inspired them to get married there and then. Within days we had made all the necessary arrangements, organised the reception and ensured their dream could come true.

What about a night out?

The most popular restaurants and by definition the hardest to book are Tike, Vogue, Korfez for seafood, Papermoon and Tugra for fine Ottoman cuisine. The hottest nightspots are Laila and Havana, and for Turkish entertainment with belly dancers, singers and a traditional banquet we have our own Sultan Night. It's very popular so I'd advise booking in advance.

And sightseeing?

The most important historical sights are located in the old town on the European side of Istanbul and no visitor should miss Topkapi Palace, the Blue Mosque or Aghia Sophia. Also you must visit the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market and wander the backstreets to get a real feel of the city's nerve centre. Lesser-known attractions, which I personally love, are a stroll among the beautiful old buildings of the Galata and Fener residential area and the surrounding areas of Beyoglu and Pera are extremely interesting. If possible, a performance by the whirling dervishes at Galata Mevevihanesi is unforgettable. However, as this is only held on the last Sunday of each month not everyone is lucky enough to witness it.

Kempinski reservations: 00 800 426 313 55, www.kempinski.com

Rooms at the Ciragan Palace Sea-view rooms from £250 per room in low season; from £290 in high season.

fields.headline: French Motorail cuts midweek prices
fields.trailText: French Motorail has cut prices on its midweek departures this summer to encourage more first-time users to take their car to southern France by train.
fields.body:
French Motorail has cut prices on its midweek departures this summer to encourage more first-time users to take their car to southern France by train.

The new off-peak fares, for Monday to Wednesday departures, are up to 15 per cent cheaper than last year. A one-way fare from Calais to Brive, gateway to the Dordogne, for a car and up to six people travelling between 3 and 14 June, now leads in at £219. Reduced fares will also be available on Motorail routes from Calais to Avignon, Nice, Toulouse and Narbonne.

There are no plans to resume Motorail services to Italy this summer. The company's Italian routes were axed last summer because of a shortage of suitable rolling stock.

Passengers wishing to take their car to Italy by rail must now disembark at Nice and drive across the border.
