fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Charlotte
fields.trailText: Good to hear you had a excellent time skiing in Aspen and got off the tourist track in Fiji. If you come to Wellington, I'd be happy to give you a city tour from a local's perspective. Tourists often bypass Wellington, but I think it's worth the visit.
fields.body:
Hi Sam,

I was that Kiwi staying in Simpkins bed and breakfast in Washington when you were there. I was flicking through my DC photos and wondered if that English guy who won that Guardian newspaper competition ever made it to New Zealand. Well, I see you have!

Good to hear you had a excellent time skiing in Aspen and got off the tourist track in Fiji. If you come to Wellington, I'd be happy to give you a city tour from a local's perspective. Tourists often bypass Wellington, but I think it's worth the visit. You should also visit the Marlborough Sounds, one of my favourite places in New Zealand. Hope you are not too sick of old hostels, strange beds and shared bathrooms!

fields.headline: Riding high on Bull's Blood
fields.standfirst: Robert Poulton finds the Hungarians singing rhapsodies about their food, drink and horses, but just who is the Nice Lady?
fields.trailText: Robert Poulton finds the Hungarians singing rhapsodies about their food, drink and horses, but just who is the Nice Lady?
fields.body:
Crack! A horse chestnut cluster bomb exploded as it hit the table. Around me, a thousand gleaming chestnuts already littered the paving stones, left there by the hotel staff - not neglectfully, but as a warning to guests to stay under cover of the verandah.

Why anyone allowed such an arboreal arsenal to blitz the hotel terrace was not the question to ask in Eger (pronounced Egg-air), a fortress town in eastern Hungary. The local people have been subjected to almost continuous bombardment for centuries. Being conked by a conker is the least of their worries.

Eger's hero, whose story is taught to all Hungary's 12-year-olds, is the bathetically named Istvan Dobo (as in Dobson). Unlike Frank Dobson, however, Dobo was a natural winner. He repelled a vastly superior Turkish army in 1552 by arming his womenfolk with rocks to throw from the castle battlements and goading his men into a rage fuelled by the local red wine. The teetotal Moors, seeing the wine stains on the Hungarians' shirts, attributed their ferocity to drinking bull's blood and fled. The name Bull's Blood endured - but victory didn't. The Moors returned a few years later, captured Eger and ruled it for 91 years.

Before them, the town had already been overrun by the Mongols; after them, it was taken by the Hapsburgs, the Nazis and the Soviets. Which means the Hungarians have been under the yoke for almost all their 1,000-year history. Despite that - or perhaps because they are at last tasting the fruits of peace and self-determination - they are open and welcoming to strangers.

To pay homage to the valiant Dobo, I headed off to Szepasszony-Volgy, signposted in English as Nice Lady Valley, to drink Bull's Blood. After a short cab ride, a gold-painted figure of a maiden and a statue of Bacchus astride a barrel came into view. The strains of a fiddle band filled the air; women in traditional bonnets and full skirts and men in trilby hats were whirling in an open-air dance. So who is this Nice Lady, I asked. Sheepishly, the answer came back that 'nice lady' had a double meaning in Hungarian; far from being nice, she ran a bawdyhouse in one of the wine cellars cut into the hill.

Noting a cave still sporting a red light, I headed in a different direction and entered a limestone vault where the vintner, Attila ('No, there aren't any Huns in Hungary any more; they came and went in the fifth century,' assured my guide), served me Bull's Blood and sweet red medina and white leanyka in small tumblers at the equivalent of 75p a litre. Two Gypsy fiddlers scraped away. A drunken clarinettist who tried to form a trio was sent packing. Voices and strings mingled in merriment. Only a stack of empty Tesco Value Lemonade bottles spoilt the effect. Oh well, the price of embracing capitalism.

Next day, Rosza, my guide in Eger, invited me to help harvest her family's grapes. When I arrived, she pressed homemade meatballs and walnut cake into my hands, followed by a pair of rusty secateurs. All the precious violet-blue Zweigelt grapes had to be gathered into buckets, then wheelbarrowed to a skip, where they were stomped on by the youngest member of the family. Rosza said she and her husband had seized the chance at the end of the Communist era to work a piece of land and sell the produce. Later they were allowed to become property owners.

Despite poverty, Eger is a fine town, rebuilt in baroque style in the eighteenth century after the departure of the Turks. It's a couple of hours' drive from Budapest. A solitary Turkish bath and minaret remain as reminders of Moorish domination. The castle houses exhibitions and Dobo's tomb. The baroque Minorite Church in Dobo Square with many-coloured marbles and elaborate altars and the Lyceum with its frescoes are spectacular. Thermal baths from natural hot springs are favoured by Polish and Slovak visitors and the Hungarians, though the English are more timid about bathing in strange minerals and radioactive radon gas.

For most of my stay, Hungary looked and felt like western Europe - then occasionally someone or something would give it away: the staff at a motorway toll who weren't collecting because there was 'too much traffic'; the waitress at a café gathering in dead pot plants at closing time; the Fifties radio in my hotel room that was larger than the modern television; the two-stroke Trabants bombing down the streets; the cloying aroma of paprika, Hungary's national spice. This sense of not quite having shaken off a bleak past is part of Hungary's melancholic charm.

Travelling out of Eger, there's a choice: the mountains to the north; the interminable Great Hungarian Plain plain to the south. I had time to do both. I took the low road to the Puszta, a world heritage site where Gypsy horsemen showed off their riding skills and herded their animals.

From there to Lake Tisza, an eerily empty expanse where our party was taken in small aluminium boats through open water, flooded tree stumps, reed beds and willow swamps. We emerged into the river Tisza, which last February was devastated when tonnes of cyanide sludge at a gold mine upstream in Romania escaped into the water. Had the Tisza recovered, I asked the boatman. Yes, he said, fish were back to three-quarters of former levels, thanks to restocking and a flood that purged the river. Recently a catfish more than two metres long had been caught.

Northwards from Eger, at Szilvasvarad in the Bukk mountains, I rode in a carriage pulled by Lippizaners from the Hungarian national stud and was allowed on a trusty steed for a plod round a field. It was much like a donkey ride on a British beach, although the photos were more impressive.

Final stop was the mediaeval hill village of Holloko, another world heritage site. After a demonstration of traditional dress, our guide explained that this was a living community, not a monument to a lost lifestyle. To prove it, he took us to meet an elderly couple, Lajos and Erzsebet, who treated us to lunch. We later discovered they had been paid £25 to serve six of us four courses interspersed with pear and plum brandy. The first course was steaming bowls of chicken noodle soup and sliced paprika rings; the second was more soup and paprika with the addition of pieces of cooked chicken and vegetables. The beaming Erzsebet then presented the third course, a cauldron of chicken pieces in, guess what, paprika sauce with more pasta. But never mind the width, I felt the quality. I had had a taste of Hungary that left me hungry for more.

Fact file

Robert Poulton travelled with Inghams (020 8780 4433) and stayed at the baroque three-star Hotel Park in Eger, where prices start at £349 for seven nights including half-board, transfers and scheduled flights from Heathrow. All the excursions described can be pre-booked.

Travelling out of Eger, there's a choice: the mountains to the north; the interminable Great Hungarian Plain plain to the south. I had time to do both. I took the low road to the Puszta, a world heritage site where Gypsy horsemen showed off their riding skills and herded their animals. From there to Lake Tisza, an eerily empty expanse where our party was taken in small aluminium boats through open water, flooded tree stumps, reed beds and willow swamps. We emerged into the river Tisza, which last February was devastated when tonnes of cyanide sludge at a gold mine upstream in Romania escaped into the water. Had the Tisza recovered, I asked the boatman. Yes, he said, fish were back to three-quarters of former levels, thanks to restocking and a flood that purged the river. Recently a catfish more than two metres long had been caught. Northwards from Eger, at Szilvasvarad in the Bukk mountains, I rode in a carriage pulled by Lippizaners from the Hungarian national stud and was allowed on a trusty steed for a plod round a field. It was much like a donkey ride on a British beach, although the photos were more impressive. Final stop was the mediaeval hill village of Holloko, another world heritage site. After a demonstration of traditional dress, our guide explained that this was a living community, not a monument to a lost lifestyle. To prove it, he took us to meet an elderly couple, Lajos and Erzsebet, who treated us to lunch. We later discovered they had been paid £25 to serve six of us four courses interspersed with pear and plum brandy. The first course was steaming bowls of chicken noodle soup and sliced paprika rings; the second was more soup and paprika with the addition of pieces of cooked chicken and vegetables. The beaming Erzsebet then presented the third course, a cauldron of chicken pieces in, guess what, paprika sauce with more pasta. But never mind the width, I felt the quality. I had had a taste of Hungary that left me hungry for more. Fact file Robert Poulton travelled with Inghams (020 8780 4433) and stayed at the baroque three-star Hotel Park in Eger, where prices start at £349 for seven nights including half-board, transfers and scheduled flights from Heathrow. All the excursions described can be pre-booked.

fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Hest Bank Nature Reserve | Geffrye Museum | Clumber Park's Fairytale Quest
fields.body:
Watch hundreds of wading birds gather on the saltmarshes of Hest Bank Nature Reserve in Lancashire during high tide (01524 701601). 1.30pm. Adults £3, children £1.

Visit the Geffrye Museum (020 7739 9893) in London which is paying tribute to the style of Oscar Wilde with the recreation of aesthetic period interiors. Noon-5pm. Free.

Hunt for treasure on bicycles at Clumber Park's Fairytale Quest, Nottinghamshire. 10am-2.30pm. Cycles for hire. £1 per question sheet (01909 476592)

Revisit post-war London at the Museum of London's exhibition of photographs by Henry Grant. (020 7600 0807) Noon - 5pm. Adults £5, children free.

Explore depictions of the family by artists such as Degas, Hogarth and Gainsborough at Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery (0117 922 3571) 10am - 5pm. Free.

Browse the stands at London's largest Antique and Collectors' Fair, Alexandra Palace, London (0208 883 7061). 11.30am-5pm. Adults £4, children free.

Admire Indian sculpture at Southampton City Art Gallery's Human and Divine exhibition. 10am-4pm. Free. (02380 832277)

Go for a two-hour guided walk through Strathclyde Country Park starting at 2pm in the Plantation Car Park. (01698 266155)

Share the visionary outlook of poet and artist William Blake at Tate Britain (0207 887 8000), London. 10am - 5pm. Adults £8, children £5.

Join a guided bird walk around RSPB Rye Meads Nature Reserve (01279 793720) in Hertfordshire. Prizes for the family that spots the most birds. 11am and 2pm. Free.

webTitle: Don't leave it too late for your pet

fields.headline: Don't leave it too late for your pet
fields.trailText: Pet owners planning on taking a dog or cat abroad with them this summer should start making preparations now or risk having to leave them behind.
fields.body:
Pet owners planning on taking a dog or cat abroad with them this summer should start making preparations now or risk having to leave them behind. The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food warns that it takes at least seven months from the initial insertion of a microchip and rabies injection to receiving the all-clear and a PETS 1 re-entry certificate from the vet, writes Natasha Blair .

'We strongly advise people thinking about taking their pets on holiday this summer to call our helpline now to avoid disappointment,' said a MAFF spokesman.

More than 12,500 animals successfully crossed the Channel in the first year of the pet travel scheme, but 1,500 pets failed to meet the criteria and were delayed or put into quarantine. The most common reasons for delay were incorrect paperwork or having to repeat the mandatory tick and tapeworm treatment before returning home.

Taking your animal abroad is not cheap. Prices vary depending on where you are, but as a guideline expect to pay £30 for the microchip, £50 for the rabies injection, £70 for the blood test and £20 for the 'tick and tape' treatment. There is also the additional cost of travel insurance for your pet to be considered.

The scheme has been evolving since it started last February. Previously an Export Certificate was required to take your animal to France; now your vet can issue a PETS 5 certificate.

The Pet Travel Scheme will be extended on 31 January to include a number of rabies-free islands. Countries that participate in the pet passport scheme are listed on the MAFF website

 For further information telephone the PETS helpline on 0870 241 1710.

fields.headline: Go for it
fields.standfirst: Late bargains, by Desmond Balmer
fields.trailText: Cuba | New York | Jordan
fields.body:
Holidays

Cuba

Explore the roots of Afro-Cuban music and dance on a two-week trip to the Cuban town of Guantánamo with Dance Holidays (01206 57 7000). The trip, departing from Heathrow on 3 February, costs £1,295 including flights from Heathrow, half-board at a three-star hotel and 20 hours of dance and drumming instruction.

New York

Book by 29 January and travel by 28 February for a three-night break for £377 (saving £82) with Funway Holidays (020 8466 0222). Includes British Airways flights from Gatwick, three nights room-only at the New Yorker Hotel in Midtown. Weekend supplements apply.

Jordan

A seven-night Jordan Connection itinerary, combining the highlights of Jordan with a visit to Egypt, costs £699 with The Imaginative Traveller (020 8742 8612). Includes flights (from Heathrow on 22 January) and mainly half-board accommodation.

Amsterdam

Go clubbing in Amsterdam for £76 with STA Travel (0870 160 6070). This offer is valid for students and the under-25s and includes a Saturday night flight from Stansted to Schipol, rail transfers, entry into either Chemistry or Time dance clubs, and return flight on Sunday morning. Regional flights start at £90 from Birmingham.

Antigua

Depart before 31 January for seven nights at the Jolly Harbour Villas for £549 with British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 245). Includes flights from Gatwick, transfers and room-only accommodation.

Hong Kong

Celebrate the Chinese new year on 24 January on a five-night stay at the four-star Newton Hotel for £669 with the Online Travel Company (0870 887 0100) Includes flights from Heathrow on 23 January, transfers and room-only accommodation.

Flights

Singapore

Trailfinders (020 7938 3939) offers return British Airways or Qantas flights from Heathrow for £396 up to 31 March. Book by 29 January. Must stay Saturday night, maximum stay three months.

New York

Book by 29 January with Travelbag (0870 737 7866) to fly British Airways from Heathrow until 28 February. Must stay a Saturday night. Maximum stay one month.

fields.headline: The Gump grows up
fields.standfirst: Is there more than meets the eye to the saccharine-sweet Hollywood hero tipped for the Oscar? Well, according to the saccharine-sweet Hollywood hero, the answer is yes... and he'll beat up any trucker to prove it
fields.trailText: Is there more than meets the eye to the saccharine-sweet Hollywood hero tipped for the Oscar? Well, according to the saccharine-sweet Hollywood hero, the answer is yes... and he'll beat up any trucker to prove it.
fields.body:
Does Tom Hanks symbolise something less than manly? Ford's US advertising people apparently think so: they built a recent ad around the idea that no truck driving man would be caught dead watching Hanks's 1998 romantic comedy, You've Got Mail. Hanks's reply came in surprising vigorous language. 'You know what? I could kick the butts of all those guys driving their trucks. Come by me, man, and I'll tear you apart. And you know what? I've only got one good shoulder.'

The idea that Hanks is a wimp is blown away by the story of the making of his latest film, Cast Away. To play the Federal Express employee stranded on a Pacific island he managed to lose 40 pounds, not to mention surviving a dangerous leg infection. Nor is this the first time that Hanks has indulged in this kind of De Niro-like preparation: he gained 30 pounds for A League Of Their Own, lost 20 for Philadelphia, learnt to play the violin for The Man In The Red Shoes, did comedy open mic slots for Punchline and convinced his younger co-stars not to give in as they were all put through the gruelling boot camp for Saving Private Ryan.

Yet Hanks has no ideological commitment to Method acting. And the last thing the audiences who have made Hanks one of the two biggest film stars in the world want is for him to disappear into the role. What they are seeking from him is reassurance that there is goodness in the world. Hanks, Steven Spielberg has said, is 'the most moral man I have ever known'. Of Forrest Gump, veteran US film critic Roger Ebert wrote: 'Tom Hanks may be the only actor who could have played the role. I can't think of anyone else as Gump, after seeing how Hanks makes him into a person so dignified, so straight-ahead.' Hanks's own take is: 'I think what I am is that I am not cynical.'

This expresses itself most prominently in a yearning for a better, past America: the obsession with the Space Race (Apollo 13, the Hanks produced mini-series, From The Earth To The Moon ) and World War II (Saving Private Ryan, the forthcoming Hanks/Spielberg mini-series, Band Of Brothers). Like an increasing number of Americans, Left and Right, Hanks is obsessed with 'the greatest generation', the men who fought the Good War.

He's far from stupid, though. Everyone who meets him insists that Hanks - this is rare for an actor - is brighter than the characters he plays. Despite the straightforward moral world of most of his films - including his directorial debut, That Thing You Do - he cites Alexander Payne's corrosive high school satire, Election, as his favourite recent film, and American Beauty as the film he most regrets missing out on.

And behind the slightly stolid persona lies a turbulent childhood. He was born in Concord, California, in 1956, son of Amos and Janet Hanks. When he was five, his father - normally known as Bud - left his mother and took the kids with him. This was the start of a nomadic life with Bud, trying to make his way as a cook. Hanks lived in at least 10 towns as a child, and had two step-mothers and three step-fathers. He has claimed that he can't remember the names of some of the 11 or so step-siblings he had along the way. At one point he found himself being referred to as 'number eight'.

However, the experience didn't traumatise the young Hanks. 'I liked a new school, a new neighbourhood. I wasn't worried about being the new kid on the block.' In time-honoured fashion, he ingratiated himself at his new schools by being the class clown.

He did, however, adopt a strict moral code that could be seen as a reaction to the chaos. He was involved with Christian youth groups, and arrived at Chabot College a virgin for ideological reasons. He started acting in high school, when it became clear that he wasn't that good at sports. And it was to pursue acting that he dropped out of Chabot and moved to California State University at Sacramento. There he discovered girls, and dropped out when his girlfriend - soon to be wife - Samantha Lewes became pregnant.

Meanwhile, he had started taking part in the Great Lakes Shakespeare Festival. He continued appearing at the festival after leaving California State, and then headed off to New York. He made his big screen debut in a 1980 slasher movie called He Knows You're Alone.

In so far as the Tom Hanks wild years existed, this was the time. He took coke - not excessively - and dropped in from time to time at the local Times Square porn dives. And then he got his first shot of stardom in the sitcom Bosom Buddies. It was typical of the dreadful TV comedy of the early Eighties, all situation and no comedy. The set-up has two young men trying to find a cheap place to live, and resorting to drag to get into a women-only hostel. It lasted two seasons, which was enough to establish Hanks's rubbery faced comedy skills. His next break came when he met Ron Howard, who invited him to audition for a supporting role in Splash!, and then reconsidered and made him a star.

As the not excessively handsome, slightly bumbling and essentially likable hero of a romantic comedy, Hanks in Splash! had the template for much of his later success. But things didn't progress so smoothly from there. He had mixed success with the films he made in the Eighties, got divorced, and then on the set of Volunteers met his second wife, Rita Wilson.

The second definitive Hanks film was Big (1988), the one where he plays a young boy temporarily inhabiting an adult's body. It began the split between the people who found Hanks charming - the larger group of film goers - and those who found him the essence of schmaltzy Hollywood. And yet Big was followed by more flops: Joe Versus The Volcano - which failed despite the first outing of the Meg Ryan-Hanks pairing - and The Bonfire Of The Vanities , when Hanks was catastrophically miscast as the nasty and ambitious Sherman McCoy.

The fully formed Tom Hanks, the Everyman superstar with the rambling, over-emotional Oscar speeches, dates from 1993. That was the year he combined the romantic comedy success of Sleepless In Seattle with Philadelphia , his first big drama, for which he won an Oscar. It summed up something else about Hanks: although Hollywood insiders talked it up as a daring project - the first big Aids movie - the criticism came mainly from gay groups, unhappy with the sanitised, nonsexual saintliness of Hanks's character, rather than the Christian right.

In fact, despite his financially generous support for the Democrats, Hanks has been frequently accused of being a reactionary. He is certainly a fervid patriot: that first Oscar speech concluded with 'God bless America'. And despite starring in the death row drama The Green Mile , he doesn't oppose the capital punishment. Then there is the awkward question of Forrest Gump (for which he picked up the second Oscar), seen by some as a wholesale critique of the countercultural America. In fact, what Hanks is is a pre-Vietnam liberal - one of his sons is even named Truman - unhappy to see the country in the hands of either Nixon or Abbie Hoffman, the Bush family or the philandering Bill Clinton, who he regretted giving money to.

Cast Away - in which Hanks is alone on screen for 75 minutes - is something of an attempt by Hanks to stretch himself as an actor; he thought up the idea of the film, and nurtured it into existence. But he knows that the men he is most often compared to - pillars of decency such as Jimmy Stewart and Henry Fonda - took big risks later in their careers: you can't stake a claim to greatness simply by reassuring people.

Which begs the question, is Hanks ready to do anything as ambitious as Vertigo or Rear Window ? Would he be willing to be seen on screen gunning down a little boy (Fonda in Once Upon A Time In The West)? Hanks's only real competitor for the title of the world's biggest film star - Tom Cruise - has shown an increasing daring with Eyes Wide Shut and Magnolia.

Hanks finally looks willing to give it a try. His next role is in Road To Perdition, a revenge thriller set in the Thirties and directed by Sam Mendes. Hanks will play a hitman known as the Angel Of Death. Hanks is still the hero - his character is out to deal with the men who have killed his wife and son - but this hero is nevertheless a cold blooded murderer. On paper, it is the most adventurous move of his career.

The question is whether he has the guts to make the film as tough as the plot outline suggests. If it is, it would be a Tom Hanks film the truck drivers could watch without shame - along with those of us who don't believe America ever had an innocence to lose.

Tom Hanks

Married to: Rita Wilson (two children); two children from previous marriage

Forebear: Direct descendant of Nancy Hanks, Abraham Lincoln's mother

Education: Skyline high school, Oakland, California; California State University

Film debut: He Knows You're Alone (1980)

Oscars: Philadelphia, Forrest Gump

fields.headline: Fleming Funds Isa
fields.trailText: Contact 0800 204020 or www.chaseflemingam.co.uk
fields.body:
Contact 0800 204020 or www.chaseflemingam.co.uk

Aim To enable people to invest tax-free in a selection of up to 17 of Chase Fleming's specialist funds.

Bells & whistles Investors can choose from a technology or European portfolio or construct their own portfolio from the 17 funds. These range from the low- to medium-risk UK Enterprise fund to the high-risk Asian and Global Life Sciences funds. Chase Fleming says its funds benefit 'from the knowledge and experience of over 300 investment professionals throughout the world'. The Isa capitalises on Chase Fleming's stock-picking skills using a 'bottom up' process, complemented by global research and analysis.

How it works Fleming Funds is the name of the investment firm's Luxembourg-based SICAV, an open-ended investment fund which offers many 'sub funds' investing in different sectors. Ten of the funds are new, while the other seven have been available to UK investors for several years, but not tax-free through an Isa. The two portfolios will each invest equally across four areas. webTitle: Now Met's staff say force is racist

fields.headline: Now Met's staff say force is racist
fields.standfirst:
Confidential survey shows 56 per cent think ethnic minorities are treated differently

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Confidential survey shows 56 per cent think ethnic minorities are treated differently.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest police force is racist, according to its own staff. The disclosure, which will cause acute embarrassment to London's Metropolitan Police, is contained in a confidential staff survey.

More than 56 per cent of employees reported that 'people are treated differently in the Metropolitan Police according to their ethnicity' - almost two years after an independent report found evidence of institutional racism in the force.

Ahead of a week of intense controversy about the issues of race and crime - reports out on Thursday will reveal the 'ethnicity' of drug offenders and the numbers of black people in jail - confirmation that the Met is racist will fuel the debate about endemic racial problems in Britain's police.

In another blow to the Government, crime figures out on Tuesday are expected to show a rise in violent crime, undermining Labour's claim to be 'tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime'.

Police advisers on race expect the Met results to be reflected around the country. Cultural audits are being carried out in police forces nationwide to test their acceptance of minority groups.

Sergeant Ravi Chand, chair of the National Black Police Association, said: 'I've never known a time when we've had so many black and Asian police staff taking their forces to industrial tribunals across the country. It's a terrible state of affairs.

'Forces claim to be putting change into practice, but we don't see that being demonstrated on the ground. Too often the approach is a gimmick. A black face on a recruitment poster doesn't address community confidence in the police.'

The Met has been hit by a series of high-profile claims of racist treatment from staff during the past five years. Last month Sergeant Gurpal Virdi was awarded £150,000 by an employment tribunal for race discrimination. After being accused of sending racist emails to himself and 12 other officers, he had been sacked in March last year.

Paul Bailey, a black PC with the Greater Manchester Police, said: 'This problem certainly isn't confined to London. In the 11 years I've been with the service I've repeatedly heard racist comments both about officers and members of the public, someone described as a 'half-nigger', things like that.

'I've been stopped on several occasions in my car by other officers. The last time, two police motorcyclists drove quite dangerously to catch up with me, even though I was in uniform. They claimed I wasn't wearing my seatbelt, which I was.'

In the wake of the Macpherson Report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, which accused police of 'institutional racism', home secretary Jack Straw ordered police across Britain to recruit a further 8,000 officers from ethnic minorities over 10 years. All the major forces involved have so far failed to reach their annual targets.

A Home Office source confirmed yesterday that the Metropolitan Police had included officers classified as 'White Irish' in its tally of minority ethnic officers published last month. The figure, used for the first time, helped give a much better impression of the force's recruitment position among black people and Asians than is actually the case.

Eighteen thousand of the Met's 36,270 employees, both officers and civilian staff, took part in the survey. Five per cent of respondents, equivalent to 1,800 officers, said they witness racism very often or sometimes and 36 per cent had witnessed it at some time. One per cent of Met staff, or almost 400 officers, said they still witness racism in their unit 'very often'.

A Metropolitan Police spokesman said: 'We're committed to maximising the potential of all our staff and to eradicating harassment. We're committed to building an organisation which reflects the diverse communities of London.'

The new survey also reveals that only half of Metropolitan Police staff believe that homosexual and heterosexual staff are treated fairly. Last week the Met began an investigation into the harassment of gay officers at West End Central police station.

fields.headline: Lorna Sage 1943-2001
fields.trailText: Lorna Sage, who died last week, was one of the final links to some of the golden years of The Observer's literary pages under the editorship of Terence Kilmartin.
fields.body:
Lorna Sage, who died last week, was one of the final links to some of the golden years of The Observer's literary pages under the editorship of Terence Kilmartin. A lifelong academic, with a string of influential critical books on women's writing and important studies of both Doris Lessing (1983) and Angela Carter (1994), she brought to her book reviewing a writer's sensibility and a perceptive generosity that made an important and lasting contribution to the tone of our books pages. First novelists who were lucky enough to receive one of her reviews found their work exposed to a searching literary intelligence of great force and integrity.

Former literary editor Tim Adams remembers that: 'In her reviews Lorna achieved a rare and highly personal admixture of rigour and surprise; each one of her sentences, peculiar constructs of this beady individual attention, bore the unmistakable fingerprint of her unique critical DNA.' Another former colleague, Kate Kellaway, who commissioned much of Lorna's work, writes: 'She had wonderful poise and heart, a light touch and a wry wit. She could make an ordinary moment feel suddenly convivial, as though a party might suddenly grow out of her presence. And she was incapable of writing a dull word about anything.'

I met her shortly after I joined The Observer to discuss the renewal of her reviewing, a meeting notable for the intervention of much lager and many cigarettes. Sadly, a sabbatical in Florence and the travails of ill-health prevented a real collaboration. For her readers, however, it was not a wasted year. She completed the editing of her landmark Cambridge Guide to Women's Writing in English (1999) and, more importantly, wrote her prize-winning Bad Blood, a brilliant and characteristically fearless investigation of her family's dark, Dickensian secrets.

The Observer's review of this remarkable book identified Lorna Sage as 'the odd one out - the teenager who loves Latin and Elvis; the university student with the husband and baby daughter... determined to break the rules and get away with it.'

Bad Blood has now become hot favourite to win this year's Whitbread Prize. Lorna Sage, a doughty veteran of English literary life, would have been the first to appreciate the irony.

webTitle: Express way with web highlights paper chase

fields.headline: Express way with web highlights paper chase
fields.trailText: It is, in the most precise sense, a derelict site. Visit www.express.co.uk. Suspended until further notice. 'Please note that we are no longer employed by Express Newspapers and are unable to answer any questions or queries about the Daily or Sunday Express .' Don't even think of asking.
fields.body:
It is, in the most precise sense, a derelict site. Visit www.express.co.uk. Suspended until further notice. 'Please note that we are no longer employed by Express Newspapers and are unable to answer any questions or queries about the Daily or Sunday Express .' Don't even think of asking.

There goes Richard Desmond again, slyly passing over his newly acquired web presence for a pittance, and watching 46 uncompensated jobs go bump overnight. The carnage continues. But this time Desmond, however rancid his tactics, is not alone.

The New York Times, apostle of the net, axed 69 staff from its digital operation the other day. Rupert Murdoch, as ever, went 131 better. He closed News Corporation's umbrella new media organisation in the States. There were, naturally, immediate rumours here in Britain: that the Times and Sunday Times would merge on the net, that the Sun was getting out of the game entirely. They were denied. The sites survive, but the collywobbles linger on.

Seven years ago, if you clicked your way round the world, you could only find a couple of dozen newspapers on the web. Today, that is well over 5,000 - growth as phenomenal as the internet itself. When growth slows, however, questions begin to be asked: and the most penetrating question of the lot is starkly simple. What is this (or that) site for?

We can, perhaps, guess (from his record) how Rupert Murdoch might answer. The enterprises he buys or begins are intended, over time, to make money. He wants to see profit on every horizon. But the net has a febrile way with five-year forecasts.

Last year (a good one, with the US still booming) the American Journalism Review ran an audit of newspaper net profitability. It found under a quarter of papers claiming to have turned a positive dollar; and much of that was down to distinctly animated accounting, adding in revenues but taking a soft view of costs. It was possible, occasionally, to make money. The depleted Thomson chain did that by charging for everything. Little makes little. Financial journals could work the same trick to far better specialist effect.

At core, however, this was not great business. The intensity of the competition made it difficult to levy subscription fees (even on hand-crafted web magazines such as Salon); the build-up in site advertising was slower than prophesied. And that, remember, was when the good times were still rolling. A gloomy Yahoo! thinks they've stopped.

Richard Desmond was never going to be impressed by such figurings. Porn may be big bucks on the net, general news of the kind he inherited from Lord Hollick isn't. None of the other reasons for persevering have weighed with him for a second.

Those reasons aren't negligible, though. Every one of them can be argued cogently in particular circumstances. There is the defensive case for securing your (print) classified advertising on screen, before electronic rivals spirit it away - a huge factor for many papers.

There is the vital task of ensuring that your views and news will have any kind of long-range future in cyberspace. Already nearly 50 per cent of college graduates under 30 look to the net for their news.

There is the aggressive defining and sustaining of a brand image, a batting back and forth between newsprint and computer screen which uses the strength of the old medium to open windows in the new medium. Hollick was very keen on that until he swallowed his last announcement.

But now comes the time of test. As hundreds of dotcom companies fall by the wayside, philosophy and motivation come under scrutiny. Just being there because everybody else is there clearly isn't good enough any longer. After all (Desmond might add) the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday, which continue to take his papers to the cleaners, aren't on the web at all in any conventional sense. Even the Evening Standard (at This is London) hides its light under other labels.

Associated - ploughing in £15 million investment again last year - has preferred to start more targeted, theoretically commercial sites such as Charlotte Street (for women) or Big Blue Dog (for job seekers). No branding arguments, no long-term transition to electronic news there. Different horses ride totally different courses. It is by no means axiomatic, with precious few classified ads to defend, that the redtop tabloids have to blow millions on the net - unless they can turn their Page 3 or Megastar sites into vendors of nudie posters and frilly knickers.

So where, as even the New York Times cuts back, do we go from here? What of Knight Ridder and the Chicago Tribune, who have invested hundreds of millions of dollars without breaking through yet? Is Murdoch, having discovered the future rather late, about to undiscover it again?

As always in all affairs of the web, it's best not to get carried away. The rise in net usage and PC ownership continues, blip or no blip. When the New York Times estimates that its sites have three million people registered who have never bought a copy of the paper, potential beckons.The threat to newspaper classified ads hasn't gone away. The synergies of brand promotion are manifest every day as new dotcommers take print space to announce they've arrived. Some newspaper sites (like Guardian Unlimited, declaring an interest) are steaming away; some are stalled. Competition, as ever, has losers and winners. But that, in its way, is a salutory lesson - which 46 dispossessed Express souls are having to learn a very hard way.

fields.headline: Another fine mess
fields.standfirst:
With its shambling naturalism, The Low Down does for British slackers what
The Sopranos does for New Jersey hoods. Sean O'Hagan met the film's director
fields.trailText: With its shambling naturalism, The Low Down does for British slackers what The Sopranos does for New Jersey hoods. Sean O'Hagan met the film's director.
fields.body:
On a recent South Bank Show, the artist Marlene Dumas, touching on the thorny topic of relationships, observed that many young people today are 'so sensitive that they seem to be allergic to each other'. Watching Jamie Thraves's debut feature film, The Low Down, you cannot help feeling Dumas may have a point. If, as some reviewers have suggested, The Low Down is a portrait of a generation, it is a singularly undynamic one; where once we had angry young men parading their pent-up frustrations about class and identity, we now have moping late twentysomethings fretting about their career trajectories and imminent mortgage payments.

The film tracks the meandering fortunes of Frank (Aidan Gillen), a gauche and inarticulate prop-maker with vague artistic ambitions who moves - at times as if sleepwalking - through a social and romantic obstacle course all of his own making. Frank is not so much insecure as almost inert, confused to the point of paralysis by his sudden urge to own a flat, and by the appearance of the beautiful and relatively carefree Ruby (played to perfection by Kate Ashfield) in his life. Down these mean streets, I guess, a modern man must go, but, unsurprisingly, these personal traumas do not make for comfortable or particularly dramatic viewing. It is to Thraves's credit, then, that he has crafted a small but curiously hypnotic film that, in a wealth of incidental detail, becomes much more than the sum of its wilfully meandering parts.

'I never wanted to make a slow film,' Thraves explains, choosing his words with a caution that suggests he might well share his character's unwillingness to be pinned down, 'simply one that was light and funny and observational. There are bits of information in every scene which, if I have done my job right, should add up to a portrait of someone almost paralysed by low-level anxiety. I suppose the film's message is more in the gestures, in the things that aren't said. But,' he adds, looking visibly pained, 'I can see why that might be seen as a bit wanky.'

If Thraves has an abiding theme, it is the insecurity and inarticulateness of his contemporaries, as well as their lack of anything tangible to rebel against. On one level, he provides a very English variation on the American 'slacker' ideal, except here it is not so much an attitude as an unregistered collective dilemma. This is not so much a Zeitgeist film as one that highlights the lack of a Zeitgeist. There is, though, a shambling, stilted naturalism on display that has struck a chord with the late twenty/ early-thirtysomething festival audiences who obviously recognise traces of their own hazy, uncertain adult lives.

How much you like the film may well depend on how much you sympathise with the characters - most of whom are, it has to be said, pretty unlikeable - and how much time and energy you want to invest in what at another time would have been called their petit bourgeois predicaments. Ironically, given that it lays bare the neuroses of a particular generation, this is a film that may well divide audiences along generational lines: the two people I know who have hailed the film as a small masterpiece are both roughly the same age as Thraves, who is 31; older viewers of my acquaintance have been less kind, one mid-thirtysomething dismissing it as 'self-obsessed and self-indulgent'. Whatever, it certainly says something truthful about its subjects, about their suppressed desires, dreams and longings.

'There is definitely a sense of suppression in the film that, I suppose, is crucial to understanding it,' says Thraves. 'Even in Frank's sexuality; you're never quite sure if he's enjoying being with this beautiful girl. There's the sense that he has given up slightly - which is ironic because when I was writing it, I didn't feel I was a good enough writer. In many ways, I felt I was drowning this character in order to stay afloat.'

Despite, or maybe because of its skewed narrative and dysfunctional characters, The Low Down is unique among recent British films insofar as it pertains to the tug and sway of real life, the messiness and myriad unresolved narratives of everyday existence. It's as far away from the current vogue for faux gangster chic and souped-up kitchen sink dramas as it is possible to go without making an all-out art-house movie. That said, as well as The Sopranos, Seinfeld and The Larry Sanders Show, Thraves namechecks Godard and Fellini as formative influences. 'They're not conscious presences but I am drawn to that expressive style of storytelling. I tend to shy away from the idea of the traditional narrative, but there is a story there. You just have to look for it a bit more closely.'

There are certainly echoes of early Godard in the seemingly random vignettes used to map out Frank's singularly unexciting life and, in certain key scenes, echoes of Cassavetes's claustrophobic human conflicts wherein no one ever says what it is exactly that makes them so physically pent-up, so emotionally dislocated. It is difficult, at times, to know whether Frank's inability to articulate his feelings feeds his anxiety or vice versa.

'That's something I wasn't quite sure of myself,' admits Thraves, 'but in the end it doesn't seem to matter. There's an anxiety in Frank that feeds on itself and makes every decision he makes bigger than it needs to be. Five Easy Pieces [directed by Bob Rafelson, starring a young Jack Nicholson] was a definite influence; that whole idea of someone who's really talented but thinks he's not good enough. Just the simplicity of that storyline, and the fact that by the end of the film nothing has changed that much. That seemed much more true-to-life to me than a classic linear narrative.'

Thraves studied film at the Royal College of Art, then made pop videos for the likes of Mansun and, more revealingly, Radiohead. His promo for the latter's 'Just' framed a typically intense performance with an intriguingly surreal narrative that could easily have stood alone as a short film. His own short films are equally compelling: Scratch is a grotesque and feverish vignette about a young man who won't stop scratching his head, while The Take-Out, The Hackney Downs and I Just Want To Kiss You, all garlanded at film festivals here and abroad, seem like dress rehearsals, thematically and stylistically, for his debut feature.

'Jamie has a definite signature,' elaborates Jim Wilson who, as deputy head of production at FilmFour, sought out the young director after seeing the 'Just' video. 'He has a singular way of looking at the world which is rooted in natural observation but undercut with this almost surrealist vision. What struck me most about him is that he didn't fit into the aggressive, obvious styles of filmmaking that hold sway in Britain today. He homes in on the tiny details in people's lives, in the odd ways people behave, particularly when they are under pressure. His films are full of hints and clues, nothing is overstated.'

That said, I had heard rumours that The Low Down, which Thraves describes as 'semi-biographical', had been a source of some discomfort to certain of his acquaintances who, for all his understatement, had recognised themselves on screen and were less than thrilled. There is an even longer than usual pause. 'Well, I don't want to be specific, but people came out of the film recognising characters, especially one character, which surprised me because I was concerned that I hadn't really caught their traits at all.' Has the film affected his friendships? 'Oh yeah. Definitely. Put it this way, I wouldn't do it again. I think I was a bit naive. I mean, there are some truths in there, and some false truths. I've overplayed some scenes. The part where Frank starts hitting his annoying friend, that never happened. That's more wish fulfilment, what I'd like to have done.'

Next up, Thraves is working on another self-written script called The Pushover which, smiling, he describes as 'another very quiet little film'. It's theme is the power of subtle suggestion and manipulation. When I push him for more information, he tells me it hinges on 'a character who is weak-willed', but almost immediately pulls himself up short, saying, 'No, that's not accurate, it's actually about someone who is concerned that they're weak-willed.' Which, of course, is a different dilemma altogether; more subtle, more low-level, more - dare I say it? - Thravesian. I wait with almost bated breath.

Watching Jamie Thraves's debut feature film, The Low Down, you cannot help feeling Dumas may have a point. If, as some reviewers have suggested, The Low Down is a portrait of a generation, it is a singularly undynamic one; where once we had angry young men parading their pent-up frustrations about class and identity, we now have moping late twentysomethings fretting about their career trajectories and imminent mortgage payments. The film tracks the meandering fortunes of Frank (Aidan Gillen), a gauche and inarticulate prop-maker with vague artistic ambitions who moves - at times as if sleepwalking - through a social and romantic obstacle course all of his own making. Frank is not so much insecure as almost inert, confused to the point of paralysis by his sudden urge to own a flat, and by the appearance of the beautiful and relatively carefree Ruby (played to perfection by Kate Ashfield) in his life. Down these mean streets, I guess, a modern man must go, but, unsurprisingly, these personal traumas do not make for comfortable or particularly dramatic viewing. It is to Thraves's credit, then, that he has crafted a small but curiously hypnotic film that, in a wealth of incidental detail, becomes much more than the sum of its wilfully meandering parts. 'I never wanted to make a slow film,' Thraves explains, choosing his words with a caution that suggests he might well share his character's unwillingness to be pinned down, 'simply one that was light and funny and observational. There are bits of information in every scene which, if I have done my job right, should add up to a portrait of someone almost paralysed by low-level anxiety. I suppose the film's message is more in the gestures, in the things that aren't said. But,' he adds, looking visibly pained, 'I can see why that might be seen as a bit wanky.' If Thraves has an abiding theme, it is the insecurity and inarticulateness of his contemporaries, as well as their lack of anything tangible to rebel against. On one level, he provides a very English variation on the American 'slacker' ideal, except here it is not so much an attitude as an unregistered collective dilemma. This is not so much a Zeitgeist film as one that highlights the lack of a Zeitgeist. There is, though, a shambling, stilted naturalism on display that has struck a chord with the late twenty/ early-thirtysomething festival audiences who obviously recognise traces of their own hazy, uncertain adult lives. How much you like the film may well depend on how much you sympathise with the characters - most of whom are, it has to be said, pretty unlikeable - and how much time and energy you want to invest in what at another time would have been called their petit bourgeois predicaments. Ironically, given that it lays bare the neuroses of a particular generation, this is a film that may well divide audiences along generational lines: the two people I know who have hailed the film as a small masterpiece are both roughly the same age as Thraves, who is 31; older viewers of my acquaintance have been less kind, one mid-thirtysomething dismissing it as 'self-obsessed and self-indulgent'. Whatever, it certainly says something truthful about its subjects, about their suppressed desires, dreams and longings. 'There is definitely a sense of suppression in the film that, I suppose, is crucial to understanding it,' says Thraves. 'Even in Frank's sexuality; you're never quite sure if he's enjoying being with this beautiful girl. There's the sense that he has given up slightly - which is ironic because when I was writing it, I didn't feel I was a good enough writer. In many ways, I felt I was drowning this character in order to stay afloat.' Despite, or maybe because of its skewed narrative and dysfunctional characters, The Low Down is unique among recent British films insofar as it pertains to the tug and sway of real life, the messiness and myriad unresolved narratives of everyday existence. It's as far away from the current vogue for faux gangster chic and souped-up kitchen sink dramas as it is possible to go without making an all-out art-house movie. That said, as well as The Sopranos, Seinfeld and The Larry Sanders Show, Thraves namechecks Godard and Fellini as formative influences. 'They're not conscious presences but I am drawn to that expressive style of storytelling. I tend to shy away from the idea of the traditional narrative, but there is a story there. You just have to look for it a bit more closely.' There are certainly echoes of early Godard in the seemingly random vignettes used to map out Frank's singularly unexciting life and, in certain key scenes, echoes of Cassavetes's claustrophobic human conflicts wherein no one ever says what it is exactly that makes them so physically pent-up, so emotionally dislocated. It is difficult, at times, to know whether Frank's inability to articulate his feelings feeds his anxiety or vice versa. 'That's something I wasn't quite sure of myself,' admits Thraves, 'but in the end it doesn't seem to matter. There's an anxiety in Frank that feeds on itself and makes every decision he makes bigger than it needs to be. Just the simplicity of that storyline, and the fact that by the end of the film nothing has changed that much. That seemed much more true-to-life to me than a classic linear narrative.' Thraves studied film at the Royal College of Art, then made pop videos for the likes of Mansun and, more revealingly, Radiohead. His promo for the latter's 'Just' framed a typically intense performance with an intriguingly surreal narrative that could easily have stood alone as a short film. What struck me most about him is that he didn't fit into the aggressive, obvious styles of filmmaking that hold sway in Britain today. fields.headline: Romney Bay House,  Kent
fields.trailText: This sparkling white confection - built in the Twenties by Sir Clough Williams-Ellis for the Hollywood gossip columnist Hedda Hopper - has to be one of the snuggest places in the country to spend a wintry weekend.
fields.body:
Aren't seaside hotels just for high summer?
Think again. This sparkling white confection - built in the Twenties by Sir Clough Williams-Ellis for the Hollywood gossip columnist Hedda Hopper - has to be one of the snuggest places in the country to spend a wintry weekend. If weather permits, you can walk along the beach to Littlestone and, if you're feeling very energetic, on to Dungeness. But if seaweed is being tossed into the garden, take refuge in the sitting room as the windows mist with salt.

That close to the sea, eh?
Across a private road and down a shingle bank.

Sounds a bit draughty
Not at all, even when gales keep the fishing boats in port.

What are the rooms like?
They feel like guest bedrooms rather than hotel rooms: cosy, warm, and crammed with stuff (naive art, old jugs, dried flowers). Room 9 has a four-poster, red-check armchairs and two big windows from which you can watch the lost section of the Mulberry Harbour (which ran aground before it could be towed to assist the Normany landings) rising and receding beneath the Channel.

What's worth seeing locally?
The churches of Romney Marsh (especially Fairfield, and St Mary's in the Marsh, where E. Nesbit is buried). Dungeness, where you can wander past Derek Jarman's garden or climb the lighthouse. In the summer, catch the Romney-Hythe-Dymchurch railway, a tiny steam railway with its own pint-sized dining car, and collar a lobster lunch in Hythe.

Atmosphere?
Easygoing, and slightly chaotic. I'm told the food, cooked by the owners, is terrific. However, they'd forgotten we were coming and had gone away for the weekend. Oh well, any excuse for another visit...

· Romney Bay House, Coast Road, Littlestone, New Romney, Kent TN28 8QY (01797 364747, fax 01797 367156). Rooms from £75 to £130, including breakfast.

fields.headline: How to erect a marquis
fields.standfirst: Philip  Kaufman's flamboyant new movie about the last days of de Sade has been acclaimed by the critics. He tells  Mark Morris why he's so interested in sex
fields.trailText: Philip Kaufman's flamboyant new movie about the last days of de Sade has been acclaimed by the critics. He tells Mark Morris why he's so interested in sex.
fields.body:
If you have never actually read the Marquis de Sade, you might not know that he layered beatings, deflowerings and buggery with long stretches of philosophy: the Marquis wanted to enlighten his readers as well as turn them on.

Which is why it seems so appropriate that the fascinating new film about De Sade, Quills, should be directed by Philip Kaufman. Kaufman, on the evidence of his sprawling, erotically-charged epics The Unbearable Lightness Of Being and Henry And June, is a man interested in the places where serious art, the politics of liberation and lots of sex coincide. In short, you could call him the highbrow sex guy.

Kaufman chuckles. 'The highbrow sex guy! I think my wife enjoys me being the sex guy. She gets a laugh out of that - and we've been married over 40 years.

'I only do films that interest me, and I'm interested in sex. Everybody is interested in sex. I would like to see more sex movies, not with slapstick sex, but explorations of sexuality and ambiguity of sexuality. But I never go about a movie saying I'm going to make a "sex movie".'

Sex is a major part of Quills, a flamboyant black comedy about the last days of the Marquis. Set in the feverish atmosphere of the Charenton asylum, it has a brilliantly unrestrained and occasionally naked Geoffrey Rush as De Sade, Michael Caine as his persecutor, Joaquin Phoenix as an idealistic priest and Kate Winslet as a buxom laundrymaid. It is very funny, very theatrical and enjoyably lurid.

And despite being openly provocative it has featured heavily in US end-of-year polls, picked up Best Film at the prestigious National Board Of Review awards, and Rush looks a good bet for an Oscar nomination.

But all that has happened since I spoke to Kaufman. Then he was still anxious about the way it was going to be received. 'Disney movies are always advertised as "films for children of all ages". I would say this film is definitely not for children of all ages, not even for grown-ups who are looking for the Hollywood ending.'

He worries whether audiences these days are too literal, whether they can only accept people doing fantastical things in movies if they talk in an everyday way. In Quills, which embraces its origins as a play (by Doug Wright), the dialogue is theatrical; the performances, like the extra-large sets, are not meant to be lifesize. And it isn't intended as a historical account of the Marquis de Sade. 'By the end,' Kaufman explains in a deep, slow voice, 'the actual boring biopic approach has been forsaken, and in a way it's as though the Marquis has been brought to his end by a character who has risen out of his own literature, the perfect Sadean hero, the hypocrite who acts like he is doing good but will behave in the most abominable way. I wanted the film to have certain Grand Guignol qualities because he was a writer, he was a director, his life was about storytelling, about myths.'

On the day we met, Kaufman could have been forgiven for not wanting to talk about films, sex or anything else. He had had food poisoning, and hadn't eaten in two days. But sitting back on a plump sofa at the Dorchester Hotel in London, he seemed to be enjoying himself. He has a decadent elegance to him, very much a match with his films. At 64, the longish hair and trimmed beard are mainly grey. Chicago-born, he has spent nearly four decades living in bohemian San Francisco.

For a well-known director, Kaufman doesn't make a lot of films: Quills is only his fifth since 1980. This isn't due to any Kubrick-like perfectionism, he claims, it's just that the people with the money won't let him make the films he wants to make. 'Sometimes you get to the point where the producers say to you, "you can make it, but only if you get one of four stars". I've had that happen.'

Kaufman doesn't much like working with stars, especially American stars. 'There is a certain spoilt quality about them. They get used to living like millionaires, and acting like millionaires, and there is often a lot of bad behaviour associated with money.' Kate Winslet, Kaufman allows, is an exception and he gratefully acknowledges that her presence in the film was the main reason Quills made it to the screen.

Kaufman isn't one of those film-makers who always wanted to be a director, not a Spielberg type, making ambitious short films when other kids were in the playground. He studied history at the University of Chicago, tried Harvard Law School, dropped out, and went back to study more history. It shows in his early films, which examine American history and its big myths: The Great Minnesota Raid (1972), which told the story of Jesse James; The White Dawn (1974), about whaling; The Wanderers (1979) and The Right Stuff (1983). He also wrote the script for Clint Eastwood's The Outlaw Josey Wales (1976). 'I was thinking of being a history professor at one point, and I thought I could redo history the way it might have been.' He revisited a modern American myth in his 1978 remake of the Invasion Of The Body Snatchers, and helped create one by working on the story for Raiders Of The Lost Ark.

It was in Europe in the early Sixties, teaching English and trying to be a writer, that he decided he wanted to make films. 'I was really inspired by European films. I loved American movies but round the time I lived in Europe in the early Sixties you had the new wave. So I went back inspired by Godard and Truffaut.'

His first film, Goldstein, released in 1965, picked up a prize in Cannes and the praise of Jean Renoir, who said it was the 'best American film I have seen in 20 years'. And his reputation was transformed when he found his way back to Europe in 1988 with The Unbearable Lightness Of Being. Its author, Milan Kundera, was at the peak of his reputation, as was the film's male star, Daniel Day-Lewis. And the film made Juliette Binoche's name for an international audience.

Already in his fifties, Kaufman was abruptly immensely hip. The film he made on the back of that breakthrough, Henry And June, gained notoriety rather than critical acclaim. The plentiful sex, including lesbian scenes, caused the film to run into trouble with the US ratings board. The fight over its release eventually led to the creation of a whole new ratings category in the US, the No-Children Under 17 (NC-17). 'Blockbuster [the video rental chain] to this day refuses to stock Henry And June in the US, even though they do porno films, which are not rated,' Kaufman notes. 'Hypocrisy: that's what I like about the Marquis de Sade - he railed against hypocrisy.'

Greil Marcus, a long-time Kaufman supporter, describes Quills as 'a horror movie about the Rights Of Man'. Kaufman nods. 'It is about freedom of expression. That's our First Amendment. You'd think the kind of conservatives who've criticised Quills would be the first to defend the Constitution.'

 Quills is released on Friday.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.trailText: Jesus' Son | What Planet Are You From? | Maybe Baby
fields.body:
Jesus' Son
(2000, 15, High Fliers, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)
The long-awaited second film of New Zealand director Alison Maclean (her first was Crush in 1992). This harrowing movie (based on short stories by Denis Johnson) centres on a kindly, dim-witted heroin addict (Billy Crudup) living by his wits in Iowa during the 1970s and eventually finding a form of salvation as a mental hospital orderly. Samantha Morton is wonderful as a self-destructive fellow addict, and there are brief appearances by Holly Hunter, Will Patton and Dennis Hopper.

What Planet Are You From?
(2000, 15, VHS/rental, DVD/Retail)
The teaming of director Mike Nichols with cult television comedian Garry Shandling for the latter's first major film fails to fulfil its promise and goes straight to video here. Shandling and his three fellow-writers have come up with the hackneyed idea of a bemused alien from an advanced planet that has forgotten about procreation being sent by its leader (Ben Kingsley) to impregnate an earth woman in Arizona and take over our world. This is Mork and Mindy with added sex (Shandling is equipped with an artificial penis that makes buzzing noises), and the flaccid result resembles a hard-core movie with the porn scenes trimmed. Annette Bening, Greg Kinnear and Linda Fiorentino are largely wasted, and such comedy as the film generates comes from John Goodman as a Federal Aviation Agency agent who's rumbled the alien plot but can't get anyone to believe him.

Maybe Baby
(2000, 15, Warner, VHS/Rentail, DVD/Retail)
Like Nichols's latest effort, Ben Elton's directorial debut (adapted from his novel Inconceivable ) is a sad affair about getting pregnant - in this case a yuppie couple in London who resort to IVF. But hubby Hugh Laurie, a BBC producer, secretly draws on the diary kept by his wife (Joely Richardson) to write what turns out to be an acclaimed movie, and troubles ensue. The heavy handed picture we're watching is in effect the sensitive comic masterpiece that ruthless Scottish director Tom Hollander is making within the movie. The acting is coarse with unfunny little comic turns from Dawn French, Rowan Atkinson and John Fortune, the humour is childishly lewd, and the tone is embarrassingly self-congratulatory.

webTitle: Stalker fear haunts Courtney on film set

fields.headline: Stalker fear haunts Courtney on film set
fields.standfirst: Rock's bad-girl widow claims she lives in fear of deranged fans and vindictive enemies. Real or not, her nightmares are affecting her film career, reports Vanessa Thorpe
fields.trailText: Rock's bad-girl widow claims she lives in fear of deranged fans and vindictive enemies. Real or not, her nightmares are affecting her film career, reports Vanessa Thorpe.
fields.body:
Fears for the personal safety of rock widow Courtney Love led to the introduction of elaborate security procedures on the set of her new film about the lesbian awakening of two suburban housewives.

The Observer has discovered that Love, lead singer of the rock band Hole, worked on the picture amid high levels of secrecy and was not referred to by name in any production papers.

Julie Johnson, which premieres at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, next week, stars Love and Lili Taylor as lovers who leave their husbands to set up home together. The film has already secured another prestigious opening run at the Berlin Film Festival later in the year, and so looks set to turn the dissatisfied couple into a Thelma and Louise for the new century.

But the making of this feminist film, which celebrates the bond between two downtrodden women, has been dogged by Love's concern to protect herself from other women.

'The daily call sheet was never allowed to carry her name,' said an on-set source. 'She was always described by some facile codename, such as Mary Black or Sharon White.'

Julie Johnson is based on the play of the same name by Wendy Hammond and is set in Hoboken, among New Jersey's blue-collar workers. Love plays the part of Johnson's best friend, Claire, who moves in when she eventually kicks out her abusive husband. The director and co-screenwriter, Bob Gosse, shot the film on location in the commuter belt around New York and he ensured that the crew covered up all evidence of Love's involvement at all times.

The star's primary worry is thought to concern the activities of a so-called 'stalker', Lesley Barber, who Love claims has been following her in 'a 20-month campaign of stalking and harassment'. In a lawsuit launched earlier this month Love argued that the woman, who is the ex-wife of her boyfriend, Jim Barber, prevented her from taking part in the Gothic horror movie Ghosts of Mars, to be made by John Carpenter.

Barber has denied all charges, including that she ran over Love's foot with her car and that she threatened to burn down the singer's house.

But those who worked on Julie Johnson with Love were aware of a secondary threat. 'She is often shouted at or abused by fans of Kurt Cobain,' said one. 'They call out things like "Yoko" and accuse her of having taken over his life.'

Cobain, the late lead singer of Nirvana, was Love's husband and the father of her child, Frances Bean. He shot himself in the head in 1994 in the Seattle home they shared. Recently Love has legally challenged the unconventional documentary-maker Nick Broomfield over his film Kurt and Courtney, which touched on the idea that some Cobain fans still blame her for his death.

Since the suicide, Love has been determined to launch a subsidiary career for herself as a film actress and made a strong early impression in The People vs Larry Flynt with Woody Harrelson. More recently she starred alongside Jim Carrey in Man On The Moon.

Those who have worked with Love on more than one film have commented on her growing concern for privacy and security on set. In an interview with The Observer in 1998 Love was already indicating that she was becoming more and more protective of her young daughter's life. She said she would continue to move house - 'even go to Montana, if I have to' - every time the more aggressive fans found her home and upset Frances by staring up at the windows.

'There were no problems with security on this movie in the end,' said a spokesman for The Shooting Gallery, who made Julie Johnson. ' We were filming in public places and there was no sense of threat. I think she did have problems, though, that prevented her making the horror movie she was going to make.'

The spokesman went on to deny the suggestion that Love had frequently been late on set for Julie Johnson. ' We had no regular problems that upset shooting,' he said.

But the technician who worked on the movie remains convinced that the actress was troubled. 'It is my job to stand around waiting a lot, but she kept us waiting for hours. She often turned a 12-hour day into a 16-hour day,' he said.

Love, a former addict who once admitted taking heroin while pregnant, is also currently in dispute with her band's label, Geffen Records.

The original play, Julie Johnson, was written by Wendy Hammond, a teacher of dramatic writing at the University of Michigan. At the opening of her story, Julie, who is married to an abusive cop, cries out 'I don't want to be stupid no more', and begins a journey towards both education and lesbianism.

The film, which is co-written by Hammond, is due to go on general release in the United States in the autumn and come to Britain before the end of the year.

fields.headline: Empathy with the devil
fields.standfirst: What drives someone to batter his wife to death, shoot his son and daughter, then have lunch with his parents before killing them too? Gaby Wood meets the man who spent seven years finding out
