It is late on Friday evening and Yamani is tired. He has flown in from his home in Saudi Arabia's seaside city, Jeddah, to address the Royal Institute of International Affairs on the future of the oil market. As ever he had barely spoken what was on his mind before his words were flashing around the world's newswires. The man who dominated the oil market as oil minister of Saudi Arabia in the Seventies is no longer a decision-maker at Opec, but he still has it in his power to captivate market traders, executives, politicians - even presidents - with his views. His presence in London comes at a fragile time for the world economy, as concerns mount that further jumps in the oil price could tip slowdown in to global recession. So, yes, we did want to talk about oil. As it happens Yamani does not believe that his commodity was directly responsible for the US economy putting on the brakes: 'The slowdown in the US cannot really be attributed to the high price of oil. The reason we have a problem now within the US economy is corporate earnings, which are shrinking.' However, he believes higher energy costs are a significant factor in slowing US corporate earnings: 'The corporates are paying more for their energy bills. It is not a direct reflection on industry - but it is on corporate earnings.' Against this backdrop he questions the wisdom of Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries taking steps to shore up the price of oil by making cuts in production of up to 2 million barrels per day when it meets on Wednesday in Vienna. He believes increasing the price could worsen the economic situation in the US - with knock-on effects in the Far East and Europe - to the long-term detriment of producers, as industrialised nations seek other sources of oil, and of power. In this, he has remained consistent for 30 years: in the Seventies he was not persuaded of the benefits to Opec of hiking crude prices by the 400 per cent that came about in 1973. The importance of North Sea oil and the fall in Opec's contribution to global production, from 70 per cent to less than 30 per cent, are testimony to his wisdom. Nevertheless, Yamani is only too aware that Opec has the power to influence events in the current climate. He thinks there is a 50 per cent chance that Opec will follow Saudi Arabia's lead and agree to cuts of 1.5 million barrels per day (bpd). However he has made it clear that a cut now would be unwise, because Iraq has reduced its own production from around 1.2million bpd to around 600,000. Yamani is especially concerned about the hawkish role played by Venezuela since the arrival of Hugo Chavez as its President. Chavez and his Oil Minister - new Opec Secretary-General Ali Rodriguez - have galvanized the cartel over the past two years in a successful attempt to treble an oil price that had slumped to less than $10. He believes this policy derives from Venezuela's moves to cut investment in new production. 'In Venezuela it is a new government with a new philosophy. When they came they stopped investment in upstream and the capacity of Venezuela came down. Instead of having 800,000 barrels a day surplus, it disappeared. Now it cannot produce any more [than it is currently].' Yamani believes that if hawkish tactics are employed, they will have seriously detrimental implications both for Venezuela and for Opec as a whole. 'There are countries which want to extract every last barrel. They are part of a group who would like to have a higher oil price - Venezuela, Libya, Algeria and Iran.' As a result of pressures between these countries and 'core' states with huge reserves such as his own Saudi Arabia, he believes Opec itself may begin to unravel.He says candidly: 'Opec will be less in number.' By when? 'Probably by the end of the decade. Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Iran, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela will be there in future.' The sheikh says he does not miss the day-to-day cut and thrust that characterised the Seventies oil crisis. However, it is with a smile that he adds: 'When you deal with oil you have to take so many other things into consideration.' The suggestion is that politics, rather than economics, is the key. And the fascination of oil diplomacy clearly animates him more than the numbers, which he can rattle effortlessly off the top of his elegant head. The key political question in his mind now is the same as it was in 1973 - relations between Israel and its Arab neighbours. 'It is very worrying,' he says. 'Barak is cornered. He brought back his Foreign Minister from Paris, met him in the airport and said "Go and talk to the Palestinians." The man is desperate.' He singles out the period between 20 January, when President Clinton leaves office, and 6 February, the date of Israeli elections, as especially sensitive times, given recent Middle Eastern history. The implications for oil prices are unquantifiable. But Yamani ventures: 'Perhaps people will panic and think they have to buy oil.' However, he is at pains to point out that the global polit ical backdrop is now very different. His voice quickens further when he reminisces about the era of great oil diplomacy in the Seventies and his contemporary, former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger. At this point he makes an extraordinary claim: 'I am 100 per cent sure that the Americans were behind the increase in the price of oil. The oil companies were in in real trouble at that time, they had borrowed a lot of money and they needed a high oil price to save them.' He says he was convinced of this by the attitude of the Shah of Iran, who in one crucial day in 1974 moved from the Saudi view, that a hike would be dangerous to Opec because it would alienate the US, to advocating higher prices. 'King Faisal sent me to the Shah of Iran, who said: "Why are you against the increase in the price of oil? That is what they want? Ask Henry Kissinger - he is the one who wants a higher price".' Yamani contends that proof of his long-held belief has recently emerged in the minutes of a secret meeting on a Swedish island, where UK and US officials determined to orchestrate a 400 per cent increase in the oil price. These extraordinary insights come as US/Opec relations once again return to the spotlight: President-elect George W Bush last week warned Opec of the implications of a price hike. When asked whether oil had proved to be a blessing or a curse for oil-producing countries, the Sheikh smiled enigmatically: 'I am worried about the future. If you get money so easily, you relax and you lose your muscles.' He believes that the oil age will end not for lack of oil, but because of technology. His concern for the long-term economic prospects of his people is clear. For him, that cut on Wednesday may be the first step in the wrong direction. Fast facts 'Yamani or your life,' cried one headline during the oil crises of the Seventies. That reflected Sheikh Ahmed Zaki Yamani's role as the public face of the Opec oil-producer's cartel. Yamani was Saudi Oil Minister from 1962 to 1986. During that time he escaped the assassin who killed King Faisal, and survived kidnapping by Carlos 'The Jackal'. He now chairs the respected Centre for Global Energy Studies, famous for its exhaustive knowledge of world trends. He also runs the Al-Furqan Islamic Heritage Centre in south London. Last year Yamani said that the oil prices were destined to crash in the long term and, the world would never use up the last drop of oil, because it would not need to: 'The Stone Age did not come to an end because we had a lack of stones, and the oil age will not come to an end because we have a lack of oil.'

fields.headline: Yamani fears world slump
fields.standfirst:
Oil production cuts likely this week, says former Opec chief  Be very careful, EU warns cartel

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Sheikh Yamani, the world's most respected practitioner of oil diplomacy, has predicted that if oil prices rise as a result of this week's Opec summit in Vienna, the economic slowdown in the US could blow up into a world recession.
fields.body:
Sheikh Yamani, the world's most respected practitioner of oil diplomacy, has predicted that if oil prices rise as a result of this week's Opec summit in Vienna, the economic slowdown in the US could blow up into a world recession.

The warning, from the Saudi minister who was at the centre of the oil crisis in the Seventies, comes at a time of increasing tension between the West and the Opec cartel.

The incoming Bush administration in the US and the European Union Energy Commissioner have warned of the impact of higher prices on Western economies.

Bush spokesman Ari Fleischer said on Friday that production cuts would result in higher prices for US consumers. The EU cautioned: 'Producing nations should be extremely careful about cutting production, and should consult with countries that will feel the greatest impact.'

Saudi Arabia, traditionally the moderate fulcrum within Opec, has been calling for a cut of 1.5 million barrels per day in oil production; more hawkish countries, led by Kuwait, have called for a 2 million bpd cut.

Saudi Arabia has said it is already preparing to cut deliveries for February. Crude futures in New York rose to $30 a barrel on Friday for the first time since December.

Sheikh Yamani believes there is a more than 50:50 chance that Opec will cut production, and is concerned that, because Iraq last month halved its 1.2 million bpd production, this will fuel a steep rise in prices - perhaps to as high as $35. The danger arises if Opec cuts without Iraq reversing its position.

In an interview with The Observer, Sheikh Yamani said: "If there is a recession in America in the first two quarters, it will have an impact on the economy in the Far East and also in Europe. The increase in the price of oil will have an impact on the world economy. If it is going into recession, this will push it down.'

Yamani also warned that a rise would not be in the interests of Opec or of Saudi Arabia, suggesting that within 10 years the cartel of 11 members could fall apart.

Yamani insisted that since the Seventies he has been wary of countries that have attempted to raise the price of oil, and says he remains concerned.

He pointed to a group 'who would like to have a higher price - Venezuela, Libya, Algeria and Iran'.

Looking forward, he said: 'Opec will be less in number. Probably by the end of the decade. Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Iran, United Arab Emirates and Venezuela will be the future.'

Yamani indicated that he believed the importance of oil in the world economy had diminished: 'In the past we used to use the energy co-efficient. For every one percentage point rise in the rate of growth, there would be another one-point rise in the oil consumption. Then that factor came to 0.5 to 1. But in Europe in the year 1999/2000 you have a rate of growth averaging around 2.5 per cent and the rate of energy growth is below zero. In the US they had a rate of growth of 4.9 per cent with consumption up only about 50,000 bpd.'

Oil is still crucial, he says. But the growth of alternative forms of energy and exploration of new oil fields means that influence will subside.

fields.headline: Dennis Hopper: American psycho?
fields.standfirst: He's acted in more than 50 films, been married five times and raised hell in Hollywood since 1955. But Dennis Hopper, 64, has no plans to retire. Lynn Barber met him in his LA fortress home to talk art, drugs and posterity
fields.trailText: He's acted in more than 50 films, been married five times and raised hell in Hollywood since 1955. But Dennis Hopper, 64, has no plans to retire. Lynn Barber met him in his LA fortress home to talk art, drugs and posterity.
fields.body:
Paranoia is a great theme of Dennis Hopper's work, and his house is Paranoia Central. It must be one of the few houses in the world where you could be run over by a truck while sitting watching television. It is in Venice Beach, a notoriously dangerous part of Los Angeles, and designed as a fortress. It presents a blank, windowless wall to the street with entry via a steel door and you need to know a special code even to ring the doorbell. Inside, the compound consists of two artists' studios designed by Frank Gehry, which Hopper bought 18 years ago, and another building he added later, linked by steel walkways and stairs. The patio has a steel mesh roof in case anyone tries to lob a grenade in from the street.

A maid lets me in through the steel door, into a sort of auditorium with a large broken sculpture on a stage. It is a Dennis Hopper work called Bomb Drop currently awaiting repair. The seats of the auditorium are all piled high with framed photographs, again by Dennis Hopper, and there is a hologram of a sinister man in silhouette (Dennis Hopper?) overlooking the stage. This auditorium leads into a hangar-like room which has a giant flat-screen television and furniture made of crinkled cardboard. Across the room are several sliding screens for storing paintings, and a steel staircase going up to a walkway above. On the walls all round there is a stunning collection of contemporary American art - an Andy Warhol Chairman Mao, a Basquiat, a Haring, a David Salle, a Julian Schnabel, a Cindy Sherman - several million dollars' worth of prime museum fodder housed in one of the highest-crime areas in the USA.

A young woman introduces herself as Hopper's assistant and asks me to wait. An older woman in running shorts glides through the room and introduces herself as Hopper's mother-in-law. Next, a tiny childlike woman in jodhpurs and riding boots appears from nowhere and nervously introduces herself as Victoria - the current Mrs Dennis Hopper, the fifth. She says that she is sorry she can't stay but she is going to Topanga Canyon to train her horses. So saying, she walks to the far end of the room where a huge Land Cruiser is parked in the distant gloom, gets in and starts the engine. A steel wall rolls up, revealing a corridor of metal gates sliding open, and off she drives. It is an incongruously James Bondian exit for such a tiny, fragile-looking woman.

After she has gone and the steel wall has clanged down again, I get seriously spooked. The acoustics of the house are most peculiar - the whole place clangs and throbs like a ship's engine room, there is a constant whispery static from the intercom, and voices and footsteps seem to advance and recede overhead, echoing along the steel walkways and pipes. It is a paranoiac's castle but it also seems designed to induce paranoia - sitting in this blind fortress, it is easy to imagine the Mad Max tanks rolling up the street with their battering rams poised, the advance troops of crazies throwing grappling hooks over the roof, the wirecutters and oxyacetylene torches getting stuck into the steel doors.

By the time Dennis Hopper finally appeared, I was fully expecting some gibbering Blue Velvet character in a gasmask, and for a moment failed to recognise the small, neat elderly man (he is 64) in navy blue sweater and grey slacks. For the supposedly 'scariest man in Hollywood', he seemed disappointingly quiet. His assistant brought us tea but then he decided he wanted to do the interview upstairs, and led me up a clanking staircase across a walkway to another even stranger room, perched on a sort of ledge high up. It had a conventional Christmas tree and a rather kitsch cocktail bar with swirly coloured glasses -an incongruously sub-urban touch in this all-throbbing, all-clanging hi-tech setting.

It took me a while to notice that there was a woman lying under a blanket on the sofa. Hopper sat down beside her and introduced her as his eldest daughter, Marin. She uttered a feeble 'Hi!' and said she had rung the doctor and was waiting for him to call back. She seemed to have flu, so I offered her an Anadin from my handbag. Marin examined it closely and asked me to name the ingredients. Of course I couldn't, so we both struggled to read the small print on the packaging. Luckily her doctor rang soon afterwards and Marin asked if it was OK to take Anadin, and he reassured her that it was. I suppose if you are Dennis Hopper's daughter, you are brought up to be wary of strangers bearing pharmaceutical gifts.

It was distinctly odd trying to interview Hopper with his sick daughter lying on the sofa beside him. Once or twice, when I was asking about his drugs and his drinking and his failed marriages, I suggested that we might move elsewhere but he said no, it was fine. But when I got back to London there was a message saying, 'Delete all references to Marin.' No way, José. He imposed Marin on me - we could have done the interview downstairs and I need never even have met her. Or she could have stayed in bed where she belonged. Actually, she perked up after a bit, maybe thanks to my Anadin, and chatted while he took phone calls. She is 38 (five years older than her current stepmother), and till recently worked for Elle magazine in New York. But I found it tiresome that whenever he laughed - a particular sort of heh-heh Aren't-I-a-wacky-drug-monster cackle - she would do it too, louder, and then he would do it louder still, and they would set each other off into a ghastly hyena antiphon.

Heaven knows Dennis Hopper is quite difficult to interview anyway, partly because he has certain set-piece riffs that he does for every journalist, but also because his career is so large and so diffuse you hardly know where to begin. He has acted in more than 50 films, including classics such as Blue Velvet and Apocalypse Now, and directed half a dozen, starting with Easy Rider. FilmFour's recent retrospective, Dennis Hopper - Hollywood Rebel, showed a good range of his filmwork, but only a fraction of it.

He also has a secondary career as an artist and photographer (some of his photographs can be seen at www.eyestorm.com and also in a monograph published in 1988 called Out of the Sixties). And then, as we have seen, he is a serious collector of contemporary American art, now on to his third collection, having lost the first two to divorce. He has been married five times and has three children, ranging in age from 10 to 38. All this, despite having blown away a large chunk of his life with drugs and alcohol.

He has been around so long - he was in Rebel Without a Cause with James Dean in 1955. He was discovered as a teenager acting Shakespeare at the San Diego Old Globe Theater, and signed on a three-year contract to Warner Bros. But in 1958 he had a stand-off with director Henry Hathaway on a John Wayne movie called From Hell to Texas and was told he would never work in Hollywood again. So he went to New York, worked as a photographer, got in with the art crowd (he bought one of Andy Warhol's first soup-can paintings for $75), and studied Method acting under Lee Strasberg. He married Marin's mother, Brooke 'Haywire' Hayward, the daughter of film star Margaret Sullavan, and through her met her childhood friend Peter Fonda, with whom he made Easy Rider in 1969.

Easy Rider is the film by which he must stand or fall. He says it is his masterpiece, his pitch for posterity, and it is his, all his. He wrote, directed, acted in it. No matter that the writing credits read Peter Fonda, Dennis Hopper, Terry Southern - 'Terry Southern never wrote one fucking word of Easy Rider. Only the title Easy Rider came from him. He broke his hip; he couldn't write. I used his office and I dictated the whole fucking thing in 10 days.' Surely Peter Fonda made some contribution? 'He did. He had a name. He had a credit card. And he loved motorcycles [Hopper hates them]. But Jack Nicholson was the one who put the deal together, he went in and told them there was no way they could lose money on a motorbike picture.'

Rashly, I mention Peter Biskind's book Easy Riders, Raging Bulls, which purports to tell the background story of the film, and it is like lighting the blue touchpaper. 'Total horseshit! I read one chapter and decided it was a good thing I was homicidal rather than suicidal - except I didn't know who to kill, there were so many people up for it. My brother-in-law, Bill Hayward, said I was the worst editor he'd ever seen - as if he'd know an editor if he saw one. And then Peter Fonda called me a fascist punk. And Buck Henry said there was no director on that movie - the movie directed itself! Oh really! Great! These are really good friends, nice people, people you just want to have over and cuddle. With your gun at their heads, heh heh!' And he and Marin go into one of their hyena fits.

Well, I said, according to Biskind he was out of his head most of the time and he certainly didn't sound like a fun drunk. 'I was a productive one! And they were a bunch of pussies. I went out and made a movie and put it together and they posed a lot and afterwards took a lot of credit for doing absolutely nothing. I was hellbent to make a movie - I mean, talk about obsession. I didn't give a fuck if I ran over people in the street: if they got in the way, then they'd better get out of the way - that was my objective and that's what I did. And at the end of it there were a lot of people standing there wondering what had happened and thinking that I'd ruined this great masterpiece they were going to make. And then when they suddenly realised I'd gone and made the masterpiece, they all started talking about how much they'd done on it.'

Right, right, I say soothingly, noticing that Marin has gone quite rigid under her blanket, whether from fear or boredom I'm not sure - I suspect she has heard this rant 900 times before. Anyway, at the time he certainly got the credit for making Easy Rider - he was on the cover of Time magazine and the studio gave him carte blanche to make his next project, The Last Movie. According to Biskind again, it was a disaster - first the filming in Peru, which attracted every freak and cokehead on the continent, and then the editing in Taos, which dragged on for a year and 'kept growing, like a malignancy'. When Universal executives finally saw the movie, they released it just long enough for the critics to pan it, then buried it. But Hopper is still very proud of it. 'It won the only award given at the Venice Film Festival in 1971 - it would be nice for people to look at it.'

But The Last Movie effectively ended the brief bankability he'd gained from Easy Rider - no major studio would back him again. 'I didn't direct again for 12 years and during that period Spielberg, Lucas, Francis [Ford Coppola] all went on and had tremendous success while I was watching it all happen.' Anyway, by this stage, he was deep into drugs and alcohol, drinking half a gallon of rum and up to 27 beers a day, then using 3g of cocaine - 'lines the length of a fountain pen every 10 minutes' - to sober up. He didn't bother to hide it, either - one director told Biskind he went through a script with Hopper, working out which drugs he'd take for which scene and marking them on the call sheets. And yet even in the 70s - his lost decade - he still delivered some great performances, for instance in Wim Wenders' The American Friend, and possibly the greatest of all as a drug-crazed war photographer in Apocalypse Now, though most of his scenes were cut.

He cleaned up in the mid-80s and says that one of his best acting years was the year he turned sober, 1986, when he made three very different films, Blue Velvet, Hoosiers and River's Edge, back to back. Since then his performances have gone up and down - he was great in Waterworld and Basquiat, but terrible by his own admission in Super Mario Brothers. He chooses roles purely on the basis of when he's available, because he'd rather be working than not - hence the wildly variable quality of his filmography.

Perhaps this is why he's never won an Oscar, and thinks now he never will. 'You know, I've been scraping the bottom of the creative bowl here in Hollywood for so long that I don't really get any of the roles that one gets nominated for. I'm not on their A list at the studios, nor on their B list nor their C list nor their D list. So I have to go out and do independent films that most of the time never see a theatre, go directly to video or Home Box Office. Some of them turn out very well, but you don't win Academy Awards for things that go straight to television. I was in a producer's office the other day with a script he wanted to do of mine and he said, "Now if you can get these actors" - and he gave me a list - "I can get you $90m; if you can get these actors, I can get you 70; these 40, and these 15 to 20." And my name wasn't even on the list! I'm not bankable on any level.' So is he bitter about it? 'No! Just because I'm green and look like The Grinch! No. I'm too old to be bitter. And it's been that way for my entire career, except for one moment after Easy Rider.'

So he works as a jobbing supporting actor and, between films, gets on with his art. He has spent most of the past two years assembling a big retrospective of his artwork for the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam. It opens in mid-February, and goes on to Vienna at the end of May. It consists of 'photography, painting, sculpture, light machine, billboard, sets, video, digital work - just about everything'. He has no hopes of making money from his art. 'I do it totally out of an ego problem, that's all.'

The ego problem - this is the crux of Dennis Hopper, but what is it exactly? It's something to do with coming from nowhere - an alfalfa farm in Kansas - and having a huge ambition - nothing less than to be a genius. His determination to be a genius was, perhaps still is, total, but he never quite decided what sort of genius he would be. Joanne Woodward remarked when he was in his twenties: 'Dennis is a genius. I'm not sure of what, and I'm not sure Dennis knows of what. Certainly not acting. But he is a genius.'

Unfortunately he made the common mistake of studying the lifestyles of geniuses rather than the work - what one might call the If-I-cut-off-my-ear-I-will-paint-like-Van-Gogh delusion. He observed that great actors were often drunks, so he started drinking, and then he observed that some of them also took drugs, so he did that too - 'It was all like part of the creative process to me.' And in the beginning, he insists, it was creative - all the energy from the drugs went into his filmwork. But eventually it became just boring old addiction. 'We were all going to hold hands, take LSD, find God - and what happened? We ended up at the drug dealer's door, carrying guns and in total madness.'

The madness finally overcame him when he was making a film in Mexico and ran off naked into the jungle - 'I thought the Third World War had started. I masturbated in front of a tree and thought I'd become a galaxy - that was a good mood!' he roars, going into a fit of the heh-hehs with Marin obligingly heh-hehing along. He loves telling this story - he tells it to every interviewer. He ran about in the jungle all night and was eventually picked up by the police and put on a plane back to Los Angeles, but he thought the plane was on fire and tried to climb out of the emergency exit. Pause for more heh-heh-hehs.

Anyway, the upshot was not so funny - he was put in a psychiatric hospital and given an antipsychotic drug which gave him all the symptoms of Parkinson's disease. 'It lasted for three months without them knowing what had happened. I was in lockup cleaning toilets and shaking so badly I screamed: "I can't do it" and the guard said, "You're going to do it!" but I couldn't hold the rag. I couldn't make a gesture, I couldn't speak, and I was taken to three meetings a day and they'd say, "This is what happens if you use drugs and alcohol." And this went on for a long time, but finally I got through all that. Quite honestly, I was in such bad shape that to survive and to come out with a mind and to have a second chance was really an amazing thing.'

Meanwhile three marriages had come and gone and two children - Marin and another daughter, Ruthanna, by his third marriage - had grown up barely seeing him. This was a subject I didn't want to raise in front of Marin, but he insisted, 'No it's fine. Go ahead.' OK, I said, the Biskind book claimed he was violent to his wives. 'Well, I didn't read it, so can you tell me what it said?' 'It said you threatened Brooke Hayward so much that she ran away.' 'I don't know about threatened. I hit her. There was a moment when I became violent with her. And she was probably afraid of me after that. That was a very young and stupid mistake because I didn't understand her illness.' Her illness? 'Yes. She had an illness. She was manic depressive and I couldn't cope with it. So that was that one. What was the next one?'

Wife number two, Michelle Phillips of the Mamas and Papas. According to Biskind, 'Hopper terrified her and her daughter Chynna by firing guns in the house, and handcuffing her to prevent her from running away, saying he thought she was a witch.' 'Oh Michelle,' Hopper says wearily. 'Well, we were married for eight days and we did everything we could possibly think of. Then she went off to sing with Leonard Cohen and she said, "I've decided music is my life and I never want to see you again." So. When I was young, was I aggressive towards women? Yes. If we had an argument and they physically attacked me, I didn't have any problems treating them much as I would a male. I slapped a few women. But that, very honestly, ended with alcohol. I've never threatened my current wife and we've been together nine years.'

What about his last wife, Katherine La Nasa, whom he married when she was 20 and by whom he has a 10-year-old son, Henry Lee? 'No, I didn't use violence on Katherine La Nasa, even though she used it as an excuse in court. I was sober and I used no violence on her.' Why does she say you did? 'Because she could. Why do people say I didn't write Easy Rider? Because they can.' He and La Nasa divorced in 1991 when their son was only one and he has been fighting for equal custody ever since. At present the boy lives with him five days a fortnight - Hopper showed me his room, which featured a Julian Schnabel crockery painting among all the normal schoolboy clutter. 'I missed my daughters' upbringing and I tried to be so involved in this one, but karma has dealt me the same kind of hand again - it's been hard on me.'

Karma indeed. Anyway, his current marriage seems to be surviving, though it is still childless. He has been with Victoria Duffy nine years, since she was 24, and is very proud of the fact that she is a champion three-day eventer who trains her own horses. But she is younger than his daughter and he admitted when they married that the age gap scared him. Has it been a problem? 'Well, I mean, so far, so good. It's a problem when I look in the mirror, not with my mind.'

His mind is still bent on being a genius, on leaving something for posterity. 'I'd like to establish a place in time. I went to a party the other night - Nic Cage and Francis Ford Coppola had a party -and I said, "This house is really familiar" and they said, "Well, it's Dean Martin's house." They didn't say it was Coppola or Nic Cage's house; it was Dean Martin's house. And David Lynch said, "Yes, and he's gone and we're standing here now and just in a flash there'll be another group standing here and we'll be gone." The only reason you go into art is that you hope you can cheat death a little by leaving something that's going to last a little bit beyond your own time.'

Will he succeed? He's pinning his hopes on Easy Rider, but even if he gets all the credit, it's not exactly Citizen Kane. By any normal standards, he's had a good film career and an immensely long one - almost half a century - but not by the genius standards he sets himself. Perhaps that's why he's awkward about being interviewed - perhaps that's why he needed Marin for support. He told me, 'I'm an introvert by nature. Social things are not my best. I would prefer sitting quietly rather than thinking that I have to make some sort of conversation to prove myself, advance some philosophies. I was always unbearably shy. That was probably one of the reasons that I drank and took drugs. And also because of the roles that I played, and people expecting me to be those roles or they were disappointed.'

I wasn't disappointed exactly, but I found it terribly oppressive to be in his company - or maybe it was just the house. When I left, he came to the door to see me off, and actually stepped outside for a minute and I thought: 'How brave of him, to come outside!' And then I almost skipped across the street, taking deep breaths of freedom, while he went back inside his castle and clanged the steel door shut.

fields.bodyText: Paranoia is a great theme of Dennis Hopper's work, and his house is Paranoia Central. It must be one of the few houses in the world where you could be run over by a truck while sitting watching television. It is in Venice Beach, a notoriously dangerous part of Los Angeles, and designed as a fortress. It presents a blank, windowless wall to the street with entry via a steel door and you need to know a special code even to ring the doorbell. Inside, the compound consists of two artists' studios designed by Frank Gehry, which Hopper bought 18 years ago, and another building he added later, linked by steel walkways and stairs. The patio has a steel mesh roof in case anyone tries to lob a grenade in from the street. A maid lets me in through the steel door, into a sort of auditorium with a large broken sculpture on a stage. It is a Dennis Hopper work called Bomb Drop currently awaiting repair. The seats of the auditorium are all piled high with framed photographs, again by Dennis Hopper, and there is a hologram of a sinister man in silhouette (Dennis Hopper?) overlooking the stage. This auditorium leads into a hangar-like room which has a giant flat-screen television and furniture made of crinkled cardboard. Across the room are several sliding screens for storing paintings, and a steel staircase going up to a walkway above. On the walls all round there is a stunning collection of contemporary American art - an Andy Warhol Chairman Mao, a Basquiat, a Haring, a David Salle, a Julian Schnabel, a Cindy Sherman - several million dollars' worth of prime museum fodder housed in one of the highest-crime areas in the USA. A young woman introduces herself as Hopper's assistant and asks me to wait. An older woman in running shorts glides through the room and introduces herself as Hopper's mother-in-law. Next, a tiny childlike woman in jodhpurs and riding boots appears from nowhere and nervously introduces herself as Victoria - the current Mrs Dennis Hopper, the fifth. She says that she is sorry she can't stay but she is going to Topanga Canyon to train her horses. So saying, she walks to the far end of the room where a huge Land Cruiser is parked in the distant gloom, gets in and starts the engine. A steel wall rolls up, revealing a corridor of metal gates sliding open, and off she drives. It is an incongruously James Bondian exit for such a tiny, fragile-looking woman. After she has gone and the steel wall has clanged down again, I get seriously spooked. The acoustics of the house are most peculiar - the whole place clangs and throbs like a ship's engine room, there is a constant whispery static from the intercom, and voices and footsteps seem to advance and recede overhead, echoing along the steel walkways and pipes. It is a paranoiac's castle but it also seems designed to induce paranoia - sitting in this blind fortress, it is easy to imagine the Mad Max tanks rolling up the street with their battering rams poised, the advance troops of crazies throwing grappling hooks over the roof, the wirecutters and oxyacetylene torches getting stuck into the steel doors. By the time Dennis Hopper finally appeared, I was fully expecting some gibbering Blue Velvet character in a gasmask, and for a moment failed to recognise the small, neat elderly man (he is 64) in navy blue sweater and grey slacks. For the supposedly 'scariest man in Hollywood', he seemed disappointingly quiet. His assistant brought us tea but then he decided he wanted to do the interview upstairs, and led me up a clanking staircase across a walkway to another even stranger room, perched on a sort of ledge high up. It had a conventional Christmas tree and a rather kitsch cocktail bar with swirly coloured glasses -an incongruously sub-urban touch in this all-throbbing, all-clanging hi-tech setting. It took me a while to notice that there was a woman lying under a blanket on the sofa. Hopper sat down beside her and introduced her as his eldest daughter, Marin. She uttered a feeble 'Hi!' and said she had rung the doctor and was waiting for him to call back. She seemed to have flu, so I offered her an Anadin from my handbag. Marin examined it closely and asked me to name the ingredients. Of course I couldn't, so we both struggled to read the small print on the packaging. Luckily her doctor rang soon afterwards and Marin asked if it was OK to take Anadin, and he reassured her that it was. I suppose if you are Dennis Hopper's daughter, you are brought up to be wary of strangers bearing pharmaceutical gifts. It was distinctly odd trying to interview Hopper with his sick daughter lying on the sofa beside him. Once or twice, when I was asking about his drugs and his drinking and his failed marriages, I suggested that we might move elsewhere but he said no, it was fine. But when I got back to London there was a message saying, 'Delete all references to Marin.' No way, José. He imposed Marin on me - we could have done the interview downstairs and I need never even have met her. Or she could have stayed in bed where she belonged. Actually, she perked up after a bit, maybe thanks to my Anadin, and chatted while he took phone calls. She is 38 (five years older than her current stepmother), and till recently worked for Elle magazine in New York. But I found it tiresome that whenever he laughed - a particular sort of heh-heh Aren't-I-a-wacky-drug-monster cackle - she would do it too, louder, and then he would do it louder still, and they would set each other off into a ghastly hyena antiphon. Heaven knows Dennis Hopper is quite difficult to interview anyway, partly because he has certain set-piece riffs that he does for every journalist, but also because his career is so large and so diffuse you hardly know where to begin. He has acted in more than 50 films, including classics such as Blue Velvet and Apocalypse Now, and directed half a dozen, starting with Easy Rider. FilmFour's recent retrospective, Dennis Hopper - Hollywood Rebel, showed a good range of his filmwork, but only a fraction of it. He also has a secondary career as an artist and photographer (some of his photographs can be seen at www.eyestorm.com and also in a monograph published in 1988 called Out of the Sixties). And then, as we have seen, he is a serious collector of contemporary American art, now on to his third collection, having lost the first two to divorce. He has been married five times and has three children, ranging in age from 10 to 38. All this, despite having blown away a large chunk of his life with drugs and alcohol. He has been around so long - he was in Rebel Without a Cause with James Dean in 1955. He was discovered as a teenager acting Shakespeare at the San Diego Old Globe Theater, and signed on a three-year contract to Warner Bros. But in 1958 he had a stand-off with director Henry Hathaway on a John Wayne movie called From Hell to Texas and was told he would never work in Hollywood again. So he went to New York, worked as a photographer, got in with the art crowd (he bought one of Andy Warhol's first soup-can paintings for $75), and studied Method acting under Lee Strasberg. He married Marin's mother, Brooke 'Haywire' Hayward, the daughter of film star Margaret Sullavan, and through her met her childhood friend Peter Fonda, with whom he made Easy Rider in 1969. Easy Rider is the film by which he must stand or fall. He says it is his masterpiece, his pitch for posterity, and it is his, all his. He wrote, directed, acted in it. No matter that the writing credits read Peter Fonda, Dennis Hopper, Terry Southern - 'Terry Southern never wrote one fucking word of Easy Rider. Only the title Easy Rider came from him. He broke his hip; he couldn't write. I used his office and I dictated the whole fucking thing in 10 days.' Surely Peter Fonda made some contribution? 'He did. He had a name. He had a credit card. And he loved motorcycles [Hopper hates them]. But Jack Nicholson was the one who put the deal together, he went in and told them there was no way they could lose money on a motorbike picture.' Rashly, I mention Peter Biskind's book Easy Riders, Raging Bulls, which purports to tell the background story of the film, and it is like lighting the blue touchpaper. 'Total horseshit! I read one chapter and decided it was a good thing I was homicidal rather than suicidal - except I didn't know who to kill, there were so many people up for it. My brother-in-law, Bill Hayward, said I was the worst editor he'd ever seen - as if he'd know an editor if he saw one. And then Peter Fonda called me a fascist punk. And Buck Henry said there was no director on that movie - the movie directed itself! Oh really! Great! These are really good friends, nice people, people you just want to have over and cuddle. With your gun at their heads, heh heh!' And he and Marin go into one of their hyena fits. Well, I said, according to Biskind he was out of his head most of the time and he certainly didn't sound like a fun drunk. 'I was a productive one! And they were a bunch of pussies. I went out and made a movie and put it together and they posed a lot and afterwards took a lot of credit for doing absolutely nothing. I was hellbent to make a movie - I mean, talk about obsession. I didn't give a fuck if I ran over people in the street: if they got in the way, then they'd better get out of the way - that was my objective and that's what I did. And at the end of it there were a lot of people standing there wondering what had happened and thinking that I'd ruined this great masterpiece they were going to make. And then when they suddenly realised I'd gone and made the masterpiece, they all started talking about how much they'd done on it.' Right, right, I say soothingly, noticing that Marin has gone quite rigid under her blanket, whether from fear or boredom I'm not sure - I suspect she has heard this rant 900 times before. Anyway, at the time he certainly got the credit for making Easy Rider - he was on the cover of Time magazine and the studio gave him carte blanche to make his next project, The Last Movie. According to Biskind again, it was a disaster - first the filming in Peru, which attracted every freak and cokehead on the continent, and then the editing in Taos, which dragged on for a year and 'kept growing, like a malignancy'. When Universal executives finally saw the movie, they released it just long enough for the critics to pan it, then buried it. But Hopper is still very proud of it. 'It won the only award given at the Venice Film Festival in 1971 - it would be nice for people to look at it.' But The Last Movie effectively ended the brief bankability he'd gained from Easy Rider - no major studio would back him again. 'I didn't direct again for 12 years and during that period Spielberg, Lucas, Francis [Ford Coppola] all went on and had tremendous success while I was watching it all happen.' Anyway, by this stage, he was deep into drugs and alcohol, drinking half a gallon of rum and up to 27 beers a day, then using 3g of cocaine - 'lines the length of a fountain pen every 10 minutes' - to sober up. He didn't bother to hide it, either - one director told Biskind he went through a script with Hopper, working out which drugs he'd take for which scene and marking them on the call sheets. And yet even in the 70s - his lost decade - he still delivered some great performances, for instance in Wim Wenders' The American Friend, and possibly the greatest of all as a drug-crazed war photographer in Apocalypse Now, though most of his scenes were cut. He cleaned up in the mid-80s and says that one of his best acting years was the year he turned sober, 1986, when he made three very different films, Blue Velvet, Hoosiers and River's Edge, back to back. Since then his performances have gone up and down - he was great in Waterworld and Basquiat, but terrible by his own admission in Super Mario Brothers. He chooses roles purely on the basis of when he's available, because he'd rather be working than not - hence the wildly variable quality of his filmography. Perhaps this is why he's never won an Oscar, and thinks now he never will. 'You know, I've been scraping the bottom of the creative bowl here in Hollywood for so long that I don't really get any of the roles that one gets nominated for. I'm not on their A list at the studios, nor on their B list nor their C list nor their D list. So I have to go out and do independent films that most of the time never see a theatre, go directly to video or Home Box Office. Some of them turn out very well, but you don't win Academy Awards for things that go straight to television. I was in a producer's office the other day with a script he wanted to do of mine and he said, "Now if you can get these actors" - and he gave me a list - "I can get you $90m; if you can get these actors, I can get you 70; these 40, and these 15 to 20." And my name wasn't even on the list! I'm not bankable on any level.' So is he bitter about it? 'No! Just because I'm green and look like The Grinch! No. I'm too old to be bitter. And it's been that way for my entire career, except for one moment after Easy Rider.' So he works as a jobbing supporting actor and, between films, gets on with his art. He has spent most of the past two years assembling a big retrospective of his artwork for the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam. It opens in mid-February, and goes on to Vienna at the end of May. It consists of 'photography, painting, sculpture, light machine, billboard, sets, video, digital work - just about everything'. He has no hopes of making money from his art. 'I do it totally out of an ego problem, that's all.' The ego problem - this is the crux of Dennis Hopper, but what is it exactly? It's something to do with coming from nowhere - an alfalfa farm in Kansas - and having a huge ambition - nothing less than to be a genius. His determination to be a genius was, perhaps still is, total, but he never quite decided what sort of genius he would be. Joanne Woodward remarked when he was in his twenties: 'Dennis is a genius. I'm not sure of what, and I'm not sure Dennis knows of what. Certainly not acting. But he is a genius.' Unfortunately he made the common mistake of studying the lifestyles of geniuses rather than the work - what one might call the If-I-cut-off-my-ear-I-will-paint-like-Van-Gogh delusion. He observed that great actors were often drunks, so he started drinking, and then he observed that some of them also took drugs, so he did that too - 'It was all like part of the creative process to me.' And in the beginning, he insists, it was creative - all the energy from the drugs went into his filmwork. But eventually it became just boring old addiction. 'We were all going to hold hands, take LSD, find God - and what happened? We ended up at the drug dealer's door, carrying guns and in total madness.' The madness finally overcame him when he was making a film in Mexico and ran off naked into the jungle - 'I thought the Third World War had started. I masturbated in front of a tree and thought I'd become a galaxy - that was a good mood!' he roars, going into a fit of the heh-hehs with Marin obligingly heh-hehing along. He loves telling this story - he tells it to every interviewer. He ran about in the jungle all night and was eventually picked up by the police and put on a plane back to Los Angeles, but he thought the plane was on fire and tried to climb out of the emergency exit. Pause for more heh-heh-hehs. Anyway, the upshot was not so funny - he was put in a psychiatric hospital and given an antipsychotic drug which gave him all the symptoms of Parkinson's disease. 'It lasted for three months without them knowing what had happened. I was in lockup cleaning toilets and shaking so badly I screamed: "I can't do it" and the guard said, "You're going to do it!" but I couldn't hold the rag. I couldn't make a gesture, I couldn't speak, and I was taken to three meetings a day and they'd say, "This is what happens if you use drugs and alcohol." And this went on for a long time, but finally I got through all that. Quite honestly, I was in such bad shape that to survive and to come out with a mind and to have a second chance was really an amazing thing.' Meanwhile three marriages had come and gone and two children - Marin and another daughter, Ruthanna, by his third marriage - had grown up barely seeing him. This was a subject I didn't want to raise in front of Marin, but he insisted, 'No it's fine. Go ahead.' OK, I said, the Biskind book claimed he was violent to his wives. 'Well, I didn't read it, so can you tell me what it said?' 'It said you threatened Brooke Hayward so much that she ran away.' 'I don't know about threatened. I hit her. There was a moment when I became violent with her. And she was probably afraid of me after that. That was a very young and stupid mistake because I didn't understand her illness.' Her illness? 'Yes. She had an illness. She was manic depressive and I couldn't cope with it. So that was that one. What was the next one?' Wife number two, Michelle Phillips of the Mamas and Papas. According to Biskind, 'Hopper terrified her and her daughter Chynna by firing guns in the house, and handcuffing her to prevent her from running away, saying he thought she was a witch.' 'Oh Michelle,' Hopper says wearily. 'Well, we were married for eight days and we did everything we could possibly think of. Then she went off to sing with Leonard Cohen and she said, "I've decided music is my life and I never want to see you again." So. When I was young, was I aggressive towards women? Yes. If we had an argument and they physically attacked me, I didn't have any problems treating them much as I would a male. I slapped a few women. But that, very honestly, ended with alcohol. I've never threatened my current wife and we've been together nine years.' What about his last wife, Katherine La Nasa, whom he married when she was 20 and by whom he has a 10-year-old son, Henry Lee? 'No, I didn't use violence on Katherine La Nasa, even though she used it as an excuse in court. I was sober and I used no violence on her.' Why does she say you did? 'Because she could. Why do people say I didn't write Easy Rider? Because they can.' He and La Nasa divorced in 1991 when their son was only one and he has been fighting for equal custody ever since. At present the boy lives with him five days a fortnight - Hopper showed me his room, which featured a Julian Schnabel crockery painting among all the normal schoolboy clutter. 'I missed my daughters' upbringing and I tried to be so involved in this one, but karma has dealt me the same kind of hand again - it's been hard on me.' Karma indeed. Anyway, his current marriage seems to be surviving, though it is still childless. He has been with Victoria Duffy nine years, since she was 24, and is very proud of the fact that she is a champion three-day eventer who trains her own horses. But she is younger than his daughter and he admitted when they married that the age gap scared him. Has it been a problem? 'Well, I mean, so far, so good. It's a problem when I look in the mirror, not with my mind.' His mind is still bent on being a genius, on leaving something for posterity. 'I'd like to establish a place in time. I went to a party the other night - Nic Cage and Francis Ford Coppola had a party -and I said, "This house is really familiar" and they said, "Well, it's Dean Martin's house." They didn't say it was Coppola or Nic Cage's house; it was Dean Martin's house. And David Lynch said, "Yes, and he's gone and we're standing here now and just in a flash there'll be another group standing here and we'll be gone." The only reason you go into art is that you hope you can cheat death a little by leaving something that's going to last a little bit beyond your own time.' Will he succeed? By any normal standards, he's had a good film career and an immensely long one - almost half a century - but not by the genius standards he sets himself. Perhaps that's why he's awkward about being interviewed - perhaps that's why he needed Marin for support. He told me, 'I'm an introvert by nature. Social things are not my best. I would prefer sitting quietly rather than thinking that I have to make some sort of conversation to prove myself, advance some philosophies. I was always unbearably shy. That was probably one of the reasons that I drank and took drugs. And also because of the roles that I played, and people expecting me to be those roles or they were disappointed.' I wasn't disappointed exactly, but I found it terribly oppressive to be in his company - or maybe it was just the house. When I left, he came to the door to see me off, and actually stepped outside for a minute and I thought: 'How brave of him, to come outside!' webTitle: David Blunkett: No hiding place for fraudsters

fields.headline: No hiding place for fraudsters
fields.standfirst:
The New Deal has virtually ended long-term youth unemployment. Now it will be compulsory for all

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The New Deal has virtually ended long-term youth unemployment. Now it will be compulsory for all.
fields.body:
Snaking dole queues and boarded-up high streets were the Tories' nightmare. My biggest worry is whether we have enough skilled people to meet the demands of a booming Britain.

After years of economic instability and unprecedented levels of unemployment, Britain is working again: more than a million more people are in work since we won the election, and unemployment is at its lowest for 20 years. Three out of four people of working age are in a job. And of those who aren't, many are parents caring for their children or people who simply can't work.

But who's been getting the jobs? New Deal has helped more than a quarter of a million young people into work, virtually eradicating long-term youth unemployment and giving many youngsters opportunities that they had never dreamt of. Cynics said it wouldn't work, but New Deal has changed lives.

Now the focus must turn to older workers. There are still many people over 25 who, being unemployed for a long time, find the thought of going back to work scary. Information technology is dizzying and daunting. New Deal helps. Not by getting any old job, but by them the skills they need in the modern workplace. And it gives them the motivation they need to get out of bed in the morning and get the job done.

Jobs are there for the taking in most parts of the country. We will always give people the support that they need to get back to work, but we expect something in return. As we have consistently said, our welfare policies are about rights and responsibility - the right to help and to benefit, and in return the responsibility to look for work and train for work when needed. The something-for-something approach has stuck a chord with young people on the New Deal.

And that is why we have decided to make the New Deal compulsory later this year for those aged between 25 and 50. We want to ensure that everyone has the opportunity to develop new skills, but we also want them to accept the responsibilities they have towards society. Those who genuinely want to work will receive all the support and practical help they need from us - those who are taking tax payers for a ride will soon find that there is no hiding place.

We know that there are people out there who work and claim benefit at the same time. As far as the Government is concerned, they are quite simply thieving from everyone else. It is time to get even tougher with those people who steal public money - money that could be spent on schools, hospitals, and other vital services.

I have always been struck by a story the Employment Service tells of problems with the post in one city just before a holiday period. Worried that some families might not have their Giro cheques in time to buy food, Employment Service staff decided to phone unemployed people at home to tell them how they proposed to get their money to them. Phone call after phone call was met with the answer: 'Oh, he's out at work.'

So there will be a lot of people receiv ing a phone call in the months ahead. We will contact anyone we suspect of a fraud and call them in for an interview. If they are working, they will be found out. We know how these fraudsters operate - they will devise excuses for not coming in to see us, they will always be out when we call. We'll ask them in so frequently that their employer will become suspicious. If people are genuine job seekers, we will help them. If they are benefit cheats, we will find them. Quite simply, we're getting streetwise.

It used to be thought that the number of jobs in the economy was finite. Households were happy if one person had a job. Older workers would retire early to make way for the young and many worked short time to string out contracts. What we now know is that it simply doesn't work like that. The more people available to work with the right skills, the more jobs that are created. The more people in work, the more they have to spend, and the more people we need working to produce the goods they want to buy.

The doom and gloom merchants claim that British industry is sinking into a permanent decline. Yes, there are fewer jobs in the traditional industries that were once the bedrock of our economy and we should be concerned.

But as the demand for those traditional skills falls, the demand for new skills in new industries is growing rapidly and for the first time in generations we have the real prospect of full employment in Britain. In every area of the country employers have jobs to fill, and people who are looking for jobs are able to get them.

Of course there are still problems. That is why we are introducing a Job Transition Service, matching new skills with the needs of expanding employers, particularly in areas of major structural change. It is also why we are providing new bonuses and incentives for small employers to take on long-term unemployed men and women, including a training allowance to help equip them for the new tasks.

And some people lack the skills they need in order to get into work and get on in work. Others require immediate help with the challenge of rapid change and dislocation to their lives. That is why we are working so hard to ensure that our schools and colleges equip our young people with the skills they need for the future. It is why we are working so closely with employers to ensure that the workforce they need is the workforce they get. In the last four years we have made the virtual eradication of long-term youth unemployment a reality. Our intention now is to make full employment a reality too.

 The Rt Hon David Blunkett MP is Secretary of State for Education and Employment.

The more people in work, the more they have to spend, and the more people we need working to produce the goods they want to buy. webTitle: Fashion shoots and death camps don't mix. Do they?

fields.headline: Fashion shoots and death camps don't mix. Do they?
fields.standfirst: Lee Miller went from salon snapper to front-line reporter, taking in surrealism along the way. No wonder she needed a bath
fields.trailText: Lee Miller and Erwin Wurm Photographers' Gallery, London, WC2
fields.body:
Lee Miller and Erwin Wurm Photographers' Gallery, London, WC2

Lee Miller's early life looked like a discrete series of impossible stolen moments; as a result, perhaps, she intuited that photography might have been invented just for her. She got her break as a Vogue model one day when she fell into the path of an oncoming car in New York. Her life was saved by the publisher, Condé Nast, who, passing by, pulled her from under the car's wheels, and was so struck by her wide-eyed beauty that he put her on the cover of the next issue of his magazine.

Not content to be a subject for long, Miller determined to be a muse and an artist, too. In 1929, she introduced herself to Man Ray in a Paris café by informing him she was his new and only pupil; they left later that day to holiday in Biarritz, and subsequently lived together for three years, a relationship which produced the classic images of surrealist photography.

During the war Miller transformed herself from committed salon snapper into the most glamorous of front-line reporters, capturing the bombardment of St Malo from the honeymoon suite of a five-star hotel for Vogue; personally liberating Picasso's studio in Paris. Her war ended in Munich, where she lodged briefly in Hitler's abandoned house, soaped herself in his bath, and later slept, 'comfily and creepily', up the road in Eva Braun's bedroom.

Her photographs, surprising, fugitive geometries captured from this extraordinary life, look like the wedding album from a no-expense-spared marriage of heaven and hell. A small selection of them, mingling fashion shoots and death camps - Miller was among the advance guard that arrived at Buchenwald and Dachau - are on display upstairs in the Print Room of the Photographers' Gallery. It is a measure of how far she travelled that, for all the disparities of their subject matter, each is so insistently hers. The formal game-playing experiments of her years with Man Ray, (including the 'solarisation' technique Miller discovered by accident when a mouse ran over her foot in the dark room and she momentarily switched on the light), equipped her to deal, photographically at least, with all the horrors that followed.

A regular star of surrealist costume balls, Miller could bring an unmistakable sense of iconic shock to both her portraiture - here, of Meret Oppenheim, the creator of the fur-lined teacup, and of Man Ray shaving in his bathroom - and to her landscapes. At the Great Pyramids, the backdrop to her ill-fated first marriage to an Egyptian millionaire in the Thirties, she found a landscape to counterpoint her sense of comedic alienation; 'Portrait of Space', one of her desert compositions, framed by the torn accident of a flyscreen, became a dislocating inspiration for Magritte when he saw it in London. Along the way, though her heart was perhaps not quite in it, Miller boldly revolutionised fashion photography, too, taking her models outside the studio for the first time. Her coutured subjects, collected on one wall, lean towards planes, trains and automobiles, holding - superfluously - onto the sharp lines of their hats.

These tailored vignettes of escapism were war photos of a kind, but Miller found in herself a characteristic hunger to be at the centre of conflict. Only a few of her war pictures are here - more will be on display at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art in May - but there are enough to delineate the unerring lightness of her eye when faced with the darkest of subjects. Miller could make bleary firewatchers look like morning-after survivors of a masked ball; she was equally adept at capturing the incongruous pathos of Henry Moore sketching people asleep during an air raid at Holborn Underground, at the charged mortality of a German prison guard dead under water, suspended as if in formaldehyde. Her great surrealist coup de thétre , though, was captured not by her but by her friend, the Life photographer Dave Scherman. It shows Miller washing away the filth of war in the Führer's neatly grouted bathroom, the ultimate in grotesque readymades.

It is perhaps a little unfair to Erwin Wurm, an Austrian conceptualist, to have his own provocatively small-scale absurdities on show at the same time in the gallery downstairs, but he survives the juxtaposition.

There is a likeable DIY quality to Wurm's precarious human statuary. The photographs of his One Minute Sculptures - of a man who has made his torso 'disappear' into a foreshortened polystyrene box, of a friend spreadeagled on the kitchen floor, balanced on four teacups - come complete with instructions as to how the effects can be achieved. They are Blue Peter Magrittes that you can, theoretically, make in the comfort of your own home.

The more of these pictures you see, of a man holding a huge apple in his mouth, or another clutching half a dozen gherkins between his toes, or a third bending over and balancing toilet roll on his backside - the more precarious the physics of our lives comes to seem. They celebrate the moment before the world comes tumbling down around us.

In one of the video pieces, 'Memory', gravity is hung out to dry by shifting vantage points: sandwiches fly sideways off a plate, a kind of three-dimensional Jenga is played with fruit-juice cartons that never spill; sleights of hand-held cameras make water flow upwards. All too quickly the viewer cannot tell arses from elbows.

In this way, and by the repetition of simple actions, Wurm quietly demonstrates some of the awkwardnesses of the body. On another telly at floor level, a man with an authentic Bruce Nauman look of incontrovertible rationality, puts on a series of jumble-sale sweaters, each tighter than the last growing, as you watch, from an L to an XXL.

Like Miller, Wurm takes his models out to the streets, or finds them there. For no good reason, these are exclusively the streets of Cahors and Taipei. In the former, a suited and booted leg appears halfway up a graveyard wall; a bank manager stands outside his bank with a pair of asparagus spears in his nostrils, a buttoned-up Walrus; and a museum director disappears head first into a silver metal bucket.

In Taipei, meanwhile, a woman balances a knife and four forks between her fingers and her chin, as good a metaphor as any for the pointless dexterity that animates Wurm's eye.

webTitle: Focus: Human rights in northern Ireland

fields.headline: Tale of two tribunals
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Two tribunals were held in Northern Ireland last week, one partially in camera, the other in absolute secrecy. In one hearing, the defendant had legal representation; in the other the prisoner had to defend himself.
fields.body:
Two tribunals were held in Northern Ireland last week, one partially in camera, the other in absolute secrecy. In one hearing, the defendant had legal representation; in the other the prisoner had to defend himself. Cross-examination in one case was verbal with legal arguments between defence lawyers, senior police officers and NIO officials; the second involved the use of blunt instruments, boots, fists and knives.

The setting for the first trial was a heated room in a prison hospital, and food and drinks were no doubt available. The location for the other was a squalid back room of a pub whose thick walls could soak up the screams from the detainee. Both of the accused belonged to the same terrorist movement - the Ulster Defence Association. One was fighting to overturn a decision to keep him in jail for a further 22 months; the other was pleading for his life.

The Northern Ireland Human Rights Commission, set up to defend civil liberties in the North, had plenty to say about the first case and nothing at all regarding the latter. Brice Dickson, the NIHRC's chairman, expressed his concern that the human rights of UDA commander Johnny Adair were compromised. The muscular, heavily tattooed loyalist leader was seeking to challenge Peter Mandelson's ruling in August last that Adair be re-arrested and incarcerated in Maghaberry prison. The Northern Ireland Secretary's patience had snapped following intelligence and media reports linking Adair to sectarian tensions at Drumcree, the interfaces of north and west Belfast, and his role as prime mover in last summer's UDA-UVF feud. Adair, in Mandelson's mind, had broken the terms of the early release scheme set up following the Good Friday Agreement.

Clearly, there are civil liberty concerns regarding what some see as the selective targeting of Adair last August. Paramilitaries have been engaged in terrorist activities, and particularly so-called punishment attacks. Brice Dickson is correct to focus public attention on the use of police intelligence rather than hard evidence to convict (or in this instance, re-convict) someone of a crime. Everyone who wants to see the new Northern Ireland embrace a human rights culture should support the basic principles on which the NIHRC was founded.

None the less, the Commission's silence on the torture killing of UDA member George Legge raises the wider issue of human rights' groups and their attitudes to paramilitarism. Legge was so badly beaten and slashed that the RUC could not establish whether he had been shot. His throat was cut so severely that he was almost decapitated. He died as a result of a UDA turf war over drug-running.

But like Adair, Legge had the right to a fair trial free from torture or coercion. The glaring contrast between Adair's legal rights and the spine-chilling way Legge lost his life should concentrate the minds of the human rights' community in the North. They must accept that the state is not the only party guilty or potentially guilty of human rights abuses.

When Amnesty International changed its policy in the mid-Nineties and decided to investigate abuses not only by the state but also by illegal armed groups, some in the North's civil liberties lobby were reluctant. The NIHRC now offers a fresh start, a chance to create a human rights culture in Northern Ireland. The Commission deserves support and encouragement. But it must be prepared occasionally to step on the bovver boots of the paramilitaries as well as the shoes of the state, otherwise people will lose faith in its ability to defend our basic freedoms.

Meanwhile, when is the RUC going to name the organisation orchestrating the pipe bomb attacks on vulnerable Catholic families in Larne and Coleraine? If, as most suspect, the UDA is behind this sectarian intimidation, then surely it is time for the authorities to say so? And if they have the backbone to do so, will they re-arrest any recently released UDA prisoner engaged in these Nazi-like activities?

webTitle: Martin McGuinness on school league tables

fields.headline: Why I ditched a divisive system
fields.standfirst:
This year's school league tables will not be published in Northern Ireland. The Minister explains why

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: This year's school league tables will not be published in Northern Ireland. The Minister explains why.
fields.body:
When I took office as Minister of Education in December 1999, I knew what my first task had to be. It was to listen, and look, and find out what people thought of the education system, what the strengths and weaknesses were, what they thought could be improved.

In the last year I have visited a great number of schools and talked with a great many people from all walks of life: teachers, parents, pupils, representatives from the education authorities and business people.

The education system I found was not perfect. However, it is a system where there is great optimism and enthusiasm, and where teachers and those who work with them and support them are doing the best they can for the pupils and their communities. The results are good - Northern Ireland traditionally out-performs England and Wales, for example, by several percentage points on all the main indicators at A level, GCSE and key stage tests. We also have a lower percentage of young people leaving school with no qualifications.

But when I asked people what they would like me to do to improve the education system, one answer kept coming back: 'Do something about the league tables'. (This was second only to 'do something about the 11-plus', so I decided to look more closely at both.)

Over and over, school heads and teachers, particularly in socially disadvantaged areas, would tell me how unfairly the tables portrayed their school: that the tables took no account of the ability of their pupils on entry or the circumstances in which they worked; that all the hard work they and their pupils had put in over the year was made to look like poor performance when their school was ranked against more affluent schools in the leafy suburbs.

It annoyed and frustrated them that the things their schools did well - the arts, sports, pastoral care, provision for special needs, personal and social development, community work, careers preparation, after-school clubs - were not reflected in the tables. They felt that all this wider education was regarded as unimportant, that only exam results mattered. Their pupils felt it too.

They felt this even though the annual performance tables listed schools alphabetically and never in rank order, and showed grammar and secondary schools in separate sections. However, our local press had a passion for reorganising the tables into ranked lists and, for many schools, their ranking had become a matter of dissension. Teachers found this demoralising and unfair. I felt I had to look at whether the objectives we had for the performance tables could be met in other ways.

The main point of publishing the tables is to enable parents, particularly the parents of pupils transferring to secondary school, to compare performance. As far as the schools are concerned, my department also publishes each year a set of 'benchmarking' information for both primary and post-primary schools, which enables each school to judge its own performance against the full range of performance of schools of a similar size, or with similar proportions of pupils on free school meals. This provides a better basis than the league tables to set targets for improvement.

There are many reasons why a system that suits England might not be appropriate to Northern Ireland. Outside Belfast and Derry, we do not have the major conurbations that are typical of England. We have a selective post-primary system, although this is now under review. By parental choice, we have a school system that is largely segregated by religion. In addition, parents in Northern Ireland are less willing to have their children travel long distances to school. Ten miles would be the outside limit and most would want far shorter journeys. So, for most parents outside Greater Belfast, the choice is limited to a couple of schools ... and for some there is just one option. Examination performance and comparison among schools are not, therefore, deciding factors for most parents when it comes to choosing a secondary school.

So I decided to see if teachers' views on the tables were widely shared, and in the autumn my department consulted a wide range of bodies on three options: to keep the tables (but do whatever was possible to improve the indicators); to have schools publish their own results in their prospectuses; or to have the five Education and Library Boards publish the information in their 'Transfer Booklets' (annual compendia of information about post-primary schools compiled for parents of children at 11-plus stage).

In addition to schools, churches, district councils, voluntary organisations and teacher unions, the options went to the Education Committee of the Northern Ireland Assembly and to the parents of all pupils in the first year of their post-primary schools - Year 8 - who would have received a copy of the tables when they were choosing their schools.

More than three-quarters of the responses were opposed to the continued publication of the tables. This was true not only of the responses from teachers and boards of governors, but also from parents (who made up three-quarters of the respondents). Many respondents took the opportunity to condemn the tables as divisive and uninformative.

More than half the responses favoured the second option - publishing performance information in prospectuses - and that is what I decided to do.

This year's tables, due at the end of this month, will not now be published.

Schools here are already required to publish information about examination performance in their prospectuses, and will make this available to parents at open nights or on request. We will now carry out a review of this information and consult schools and others about the form it should take from next year. I want to make sure that schools publish what is of most value to parents.

Parents will be able to get relevant information about any school from a single source and form a more rounded picture of what the school provides. Schools can set their examination performance in the fuller context of school life as a whole and show how they are working on behalf of their pupils.

I believe this is right for our schools and for parents. Judging by the response over the past few days to my decision, many others share my view.

 Martin McGuinness is Northern Ireland Education Minister
