webTitle: America finds its soul in music

fields.headline: America finds its soul in music
fields.standfirst: It's got sex, it's got drugs, but a new TV series which has captivated America by reflecting its history through its music hasn't got rock'n'roll. Why? Because it's about jazz
fields.trailText: It's got sex, it's got drugs, but a new TV series which has captivated America by reflecting its history through its music hasn't got rock'n'roll. Why? Because it's about jazz
fields.body:
Ken Burns says he feels like a presidential candidate. He has been doing 24 interviews a day, flying from city to city and facing television exposure for two hours for the past three nights. The chances are that, if he really was running for office, he would probably have been elected comfortably without any need for recounts.

But Burns is not a politician - not in the strict sense of the word anyway - but a filmmaker. Over the past week, his new epic, 10-part, 17-hour, $13 million documentary series, Jazz, has become one of the cultural talking-points in the United States, seen by some critics as a chance not only to examine the social and racial overtones of jazz and to ponder on the future of the documentary but nothing less than an examination of the state of the American psyche and its possibilities of redemption.

In case you miss the two-hour programmes unravelling seductively on public TV (to be shown later in the year by the BBC), there is a fat, glossy book on the series, a five-CD boxed set - which Starbucks is playing in coffee houses across America, teaching aids on the subject have been provided to 75,000 teachers through the sponsorship of General Motors and there is an agreement with the National Basketball Association to play jazz during half-time breaks in games.

Jazz, which accounts for less than 5 per cent of CD sales in the US, has never been so honoured by the mainstream. But Burns and his collaborators say their aim is set higher than merely introducing the hip-hop generation to the magic of Louis Armstrong and Ethel Waters, the stories of Benny Goodman and Bessie Smith - who confronts a band of Ku Klux Klanners at one of her concerts and chases them off with a cry of: 'You just pick up those sheets and run!' What the series aspires to do, with its 2,000 archival clips and its 500 pieces of music, is much, much more.

As far as Wynton Marsalis, the gifted trumpet player, enthusiastic cheerleader for and teacher of jazz and one of the series's linchpins is concerned, it is about hope: 'That's the thing in jazz that got Bix Beiderbecke up out of his bed at two o'clock in the morning to pick up that cornet and practise with it into the pillow for another two or three hours. Or that would make Louis Armstrong travel around the world for 50 years non-stop, just get up out of his sickbed, crawl up on the bandstand and play. The thing that would make Duke Ellington, Thelonius Monk, Miles Davis, Charlie Parker... give their lives. And they did give their lives for it; because it gives us a glimpse into what America is going to be when it becomes itself.'

And it is this aspect of jazz and its relationship with the US - the series is sub-titled 'A History of America's Music' - that Burns feels is so important, an opportunity to tell America its own history obliquely but educationally in the hope that it may help the nation 'become itself'. This is, after all, the third and final part of Burns's American trilogy, the first and most famous being his 1990 series The Civil War, the second, lesser known in Britain for obvious reasons, Baseball made in 1994, and now this.

It all goes back, says Burns, to a conversation he had with the writer Gerald Early while working on the baseball series. Early had said to him: 'When they study our civilisation 2,000 years from now, there will only be three things that Americans will be known for: the Constitution, baseball and jazz.' Burns says that part of the resonance of jazz lies within its improvisational quality, just as the framers of the Constitution improvised with their aspiration to 'the pursuit of happiness... improvisation is our genius'. And he feels jazz, America's one original major art form, encapsulates that genius.

Not that this is an unremittingly celebratory series; far from it. While Burns does tell the history of jazz, it is also the story of the darker side of America: of segregation and discrimination, of the Depression and war, of civil rights struggles and drugs, of Prohibition and addiction, of sexual politics and the exploitative side of the entertainment industry. But he has chosen to use the canon of jazz to tell a story that manages to encompass everything from the First World War to Freud and Einstein. History with a musical accompaniment.

'I'd go to hell to hear a good band,' Beiderbecke wrote to his brother from boarding school, whither his parents had dispatched him to stop him playing his infernal jazz. And, on the musical side of the documentary, it is this infatuation with the music itself that the series seeks to celebrate.

Burns himself came to jazz as an outsider. He had worked throughout his high-school years at a record store in Ann Arbor, Michigan, but his tastes were the typical ones of a young white boy, of rock'n'roll and rhythm'n'blues. When he embarked six years ago on Jazz, he had no more than half a dozen 'jazz' records of his own. 'I had 'Girl from Ipanema', Glenn Miller's greatest hits, John Coltrane's A Love Supreme and André Previn and Shelly Manne's My Fair Lady,' he says. All that has changed with the epiphanous discovery of the music's roots: 'I listen to jazz all the time - old and new, straight-ahead and avant-garde and fusion, swing and bop and cool. I play it night and day.' And he clearly hopes that his excitement will be infectious. He is thrilled that the series has had a (mainly) rapturous reception even as he turns his attention to his current task of a film biography of Mark Twain.

Certainly few TV series in recent years in the United States have been awaited with such anticipation or greeted with such reverence. This is partly due to Burns's record and reputation - he has been winning Emmys and Oscar nominations since his first documentary, Brooklyn Bridge, in 1981. But it is also an indication of the decline - mirrored in Britain - of 'serious' big-budget television and its replacement with big-budget 'reality' television.

There could have been no neater contrast for the American television viewer at 9pm last Wednesday than Burns's exploration of the Twenties, of Sidney Bechet and Earl Hines, and the offering on Rupert Murdoch's Fox network of the first episode of Temptation Island, in which the commitment of four couples is tested by a team of coquettish singles of both sexes on a Belize beach.

The exploration and celebration of jazz and what it means also comes at a particularly apt moment in American popular music history when the nomination of Eminem for a Grammy for his last album has sparked anger because of its misogynistic and homophobic tone. It is as if there is a subconscious subtext that compares the respectful documenting of the nobility of jazz's history - the battle against segregation, the police raids, the 'jungle music' derision - with what Burns calls the 'execrable voyeurism' of reality TV and the casual misanthropy of a rich white rapper.

Eleanor Earl, professor of communications studies and humanities at Pepperdine University in southern California and herself a jazz singer, says the series is significant in placing jazz in its proper place in history. 'It is very important that people finally understand the importance of jazz as an American art form and one that was never recognised as such. Jazz was in danger of being pushed out of the picture. Generations grew up without knowing how important it was.' She feels it is particularly relevant now to remind people how jazz had once desegregated social lives. 'Jazz allowed you the freedom to experiment and with that came the freedom to experiment socially.'

The great scrutiny to which the series has been subjected is understandable. TV critics welcome an epic that helps to restore the image of the medium as something more than a purveyor of sitcoms, sport and cable laddishness. Burns said that after his Civil War series, there was a perceptible increase in the number of documentaries being made, although he agrees that the big networks now look too often for the quick fix for their schedules. He is delighted that, for a few days this month anyway, every night is Burns Night.

Not that Burns has met with universal applause by any means. He has been criticised by some jazz lovers for using the televisual equivalent of the concertina on the past 40 years of jazz, giving the period from 1960 to the present day just one programme, the same amount of time as, for instance, the period from 1924 to 1928 merits.

Part of this sensitivity among some jazz writers is because there is a recognition that no one is going to get another shot at the subject on the same scale for probably another couple of generations, and the programme by its sheer weight will define jazz for the lay person.

Ben Ratcliff wrote in the New York Times of the series: ' Jazz will fix in the minds of millions of Americans a particular set of notions when the word jazz is uttered: a serious and heroic undertaking. An art of erotic depth and trigonometric accuracy. An entirely American invention mirroring the ideals of democracy. A kind of moral endeavour to make black and white worlds intersect in America. A responsible accounting of the shared history of the races. A welcoming gesture to all Americans, no matter their cultural background. A means of coming into one's own maturity.' Phew.

But Ratcliff and others have criticised the series for leaning too heavily on the 'great man' theory of history, focusing on a few heavyweights such as Armstrong, Ellington, Goodman, Parker and Davis and in so doing downplaying the collegiate nature of the music. Some suggest it is 'a' history of jazz not 'the' history.

The Guardian's jazz critic John Fordham sees the complexities of such an endeavour and notes the way the once forbidden and twilight world of jazz has now won the stamp of corporate approval. 'High-profile, serious exposure for jazz in the media has been pretty rare, so an in-depth study like this with a big budget behind it has to be a good thing if it helps people realise how crucial jazz has been to so much of the music we hear every day,' says Fordham. 'But I don't think it's a coincidence that all that corporate money has gone to a history that concentrates mainly on the period before 1960. In Britain, business people wanting to entertain clients have become increasingly likely to take them to a Sonny Rollins concert at the Barbican as to the opera now, because after decades of marginalisation, the earlier forms of jazz are becoming a classical music.'

Burns defends the involvement of General Motors and the like on the grounds that unless such partnerships are made the message of the films disappears 'like sky writing' as soon as the films are shown. Six million schoolchildren will now have a chance to learn about an important and often ignored part of their culture, he feels. He has also responded to criticisms of the truncation of the history in the American media magazine, Brill's Content, by saying: 'I'm a historian; I'm not in the business of telling the present.'

He sees further nuances to the series which he explains in the companion book: 'Jazz is about sex, the way men and women talk to each other and conduct the complicated rituals of courtship - a sophisticated and elegant mating call that has all but disappeared from popular music in recent times. It is about drugs and the terrible cost of addiction and the high price of creativity. It's about solitude, loneliness and the nearly unbearable burden of consciousness.'

But while there may be disagreements about just how much such a series can hope to accomplish in lifting the burden of consciousness and whether the spotlight has been shone on all the right people, the moment that Armstrong starts playing 'West End Blues' or that Ellington appears on stage, any viewer with blood in their veins must surely be transported. And that really is reality TV.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: When Paul Hedge and Paul Maslin set up Hales Gallery in a derelict undertaker's in Deptford they spent most of their time making pasta. Now, Charles Saatchi is a customer and Tomoko Takahashi sleeps there
fields.trailText: When Paul Hedge and Paul Maslin set up Hales Gallery in a derelict undertaker's in Deptford they spent most of their time making pasta. Now, Charles Saatchi is a customer and Tomoko Takahashi sleeps there.
fields.body:
Paul Hedge Paul and I got to know each other in the early 80s when we were both working with the local church on an anti-drugs programme. I had left Goldsmith's in 1983 and was working as a postman and Paul was about to go to Cambridge to study economics. He's a Deptford boy and I got the impression he felt a bit isolated there.

After Cambridge, he spent a year in Senegal digging ditches and doing school maintenance. When he returned he got a good job with Swiss Bank. I think he was drinking too much and feeling miserable because he didn't enjoy the job. I suggested he give it up and come and work with me.

I worked as a postman for nine years. The post office was like a refugee camp for creative people. After I left Goldsmith's I had found it difficult to survive financially as an artist. So I worked at the SW1 post office, delivering a lot of mail to galleries in the St James's area. I would regularly quiz the gallery staff about their exhibitions. I don't think they expected it. As a postman you are sort of invisible. I hated it all the time I was there because I wanted to run a gallery.

When the church was bequeathed a derelict undertaker's building in Deptford High Street, it had neither the funds nor energy to do anything with it. I convinced them to let us convert it. It was to be an art gallery for people like Paul and me. We weren't aiming at the upper social set. Galleries can be very snooty and unwelcoming. We decided to open a café because we wanted the gallery to be more socially inclusive. People would come in and have to walk past the art on the way to the toilet. We'd be there in our chefs' outfits to answer questions.

Paul's talents are organisational. He's excellent at sorting out the accounting, computers, even the plumbing. But he's also a fantastic troubleshooter. Mostly he's happy to stay in the background while I travel the world linking artists with galleries and selling their work.

We've got to the point where my wife refers to Paul as my second partner. We know each other so well we can tell each other anything.

Paul Maslin When we were younger Paul was like an older brother. He was always one step ahead of me. Leaving my job in the City to set up the gallery with Paul was a rather insane thing to do. I had never been interested in art. I thought more about being a vicar. But Paul had a tremendous vision and I was won over by that. He was so passionate that when we had to dig the undertaker's basement out by 2ft he'd have done it with a teaspoon.

In 1992, we started the café which generated some cash, but we struggled for five years. We always felt that credibility was key, and Paul has always run a curatorial programme that couldn't be ignored. We held the first show of Jake and Dinos Chapman, and Charles Saatchi came down to Deptford - although at the time he thought he was going to Dartford - and bought some John Frankland works.

We were still trying to build the business in 1995 when I fell in love with an old college friend who was living in Prague. They say if you want to keep your friends, then don't put them to the test. But I was so often in Prague during what was a difficult time for the business that it was a real test. But Paul didn't resent me not being around, which meant so much to me.

In 1997, things started to take off. We hired staff and started to concentrate on representing artists rather than making cappucinos and pasta sauces. Paul spotted Tomoko Takahashi in a competition in Norwich and she came down to Deptford, saw the gallery and liked the atmosphere. When she made her show here, she often slept in the gallery. We would come in early and find loud opera music blaring and have to step over her.

Paul is a great observer of people and a great empathiser and conversationalist. I don't have any input into the curatorial process, but I will say when I think something is rubbish. We are equal partners, but he puts more time and effort into it. I am a Labour councillor for Lewisham and prefer to put spare time and energy into that. It's Paul's dream and I've just helped him realise it.

fields.headline: The 2001 house
fields.standfirst: Bare floorboards and halogen lights are now  so 90s. Tamsin Blanchard predicts this year's design classics
fields.trailText: Bare floorboards and halogen lights are now so 90s. Tamsin Blanchard predicts this year's design classics.
fields.body:
It seems like it was only five minutes ago that Ikea was urging us all to chuck out the chintz. But a lot has happened on the home front since then. Ikea's campaign of five years ago was so successful that even the most traditional British homes have come over all, well, Swedish. As we creep into the first few weeks of 2001, we do so along varnished, blond-plywood floors. We relax on plain, neutral-coloured, no-nonsense sofas, rest our feet on square poufs made of suede, and enjoy the soft, flickering light of scented candles. There's a wall made of glass bricks between living room and kitchen, where the electric kettle - designed to look like the good old-fashioned variety which is heated up on the stove - boils up little ceramic bowls of green tea. The halogen lights, suspended from the ceiling on wires, illuminate the shiny stainless steel worktop and splashback with a cool glow. It's all very minimal, very domestic-industrial, so very turn of the century.

For many of us, our homes and interiors have become more fashionable than our wardrobes. Priorities have changed for both the consumer and the designer. Ralph Lauren was one of the first to focus on bedlinen and paint ranges. Now everyone from Calvin Klein to Benetton has moved into 'homeware' - even if that just means producing pyjamas and towels. For the Dublin-based designer John Rocha, a talent for interior decoration has opened up a whole new world that spans Waterford crystal, an award-winning hotel in Dublin, and loft conversions in Liverpool.

But are we really ready for our homes to become battlegrounds for trends, colourways, fabrics and chair silhouettes? Up until the 80s, decoration was a generational thing. Our parents lived in homes that were relatively unchanged since they moved in 20 years previously. Our grandparents would find that the odd piece of furniture - a family heirloom, or a Utility chair left over from the war years - would drift in and out of fashion, but their homes would just remain their homes. The walls would be given a lick of paint every few years, or perhaps a new coat of paper. Over the decades, rooms evolved, rather than experienced drastic makeovers. Now, before we can say Laurence Llewelyn Bowen, we've got the dream kitchen we've always wanted.

Over the past five to 10 years, interiors trends seem to have accelerated from changing every decade or so to changing every month. Magazines such as Elle Deco and Living etc offer new ideas each issue - the look might be minimal in January and flowery in February. Of course, nobody actually changes their decor that frequently, because who wants to live in a home that dates as quickly as a pair of bell bottoms?

Before we've even completed the first month of 2001, there are some clear indications of what the fashionable home should and shouldn't be 'wearing' this year. Start with the floor. Bare floors are so 90s. How about a deep, shagpile carpet wall-to-wall (just in the bedroom, perhaps)? Sheepskin rugs are a less permanent option. Or, if you're really flash, you can invest in a hand-tufted rug, designed by the Italian fashion house Marni. There's a choice of two designs: Cube (£1,350) and Kimono (£1,750). The rugs have been adapted from prints by Marni's designer Consuelo Castiglioni.

If you're in the market for a coffee table, you can't go wrong with Robin Day's Alpha system, in shiny red laminate or minimal glass. Robin Day, who gave the world the utility polypropylene stacking chairs that we sit on everywhere from doctors' waiting rooms to our own kitchens (thanks to their introduction to the Habitat range as part of its Living Legends series last year), is the subject of a major retrospective at the Barbican next month, alongside his wife, the textile designer Lucienne Day. Both are veterans of modern design, who began redesigning our worlds over 50 years ago.

The consumer is only just catching up. The north London furniture showroom twentytwentyone is manufacturing a handful of pieces by Day, including his three simple coffee tables and the Tri Tray, a triangular plywood tray that can be attached to a steel base to make it into a little table. (A similar idea has been utilised by Jasper Morrison at Tate Modern's chic member's bar on Bankside.)

It seems as though it will be a good year for the UK design group Gusto too. The small, three-person company became a finalist in the Peugeot Design Awards last year with Sticklebook, a shelving system for paperbacks that uses fine teeth to hold the pages of the book. Sticklebook was voted 'the people's choice' in a touring exhibition, and has gone into limited production at a recommended retail price of £49.95 plus carriage (if you order direct from Gusto).

If you want to get ahead and set the trend for 2002, put in an order for the company's Altitude Light, which they describe as 'a lighting concept which uses the raising or lowering of the lamp to adjust the brightness'. To see the light in action, pay a visit to the Craft Council's new show, Industry of One, which opens 1 February. For instant millennial illumination, there is the Bubble by Mathmos (£39.95; enquiries 0207 549 2743), which was developed from an original concept by Aaron Rincover. Made from tactile silicon, it's sold with a recharger so that it can apparently light up of its own accord, without the need for wires or batteries, wherever you care to roll or juggle it.

For the serious fashion victim, however, the 2001 home will not be complete without a visit to Armani Casa, currently only at the recently opened, fluorescent-lit Armani department store on Milan's Via Manzoni. Who's counting the price of an airfare when the dinky Conversation Sofa costs £2,500? There's also a choice of dining tables, writing desks, dining chairs and beds, as well as bedlinen (wool and spun cashmere blankets, hand-dyed in Tibet, no less), and a whole collection of vases, plates, cutlery and Murano glass. Armani has taken the 'home' collection very seriously and even won praise from the highly critical eye of Blueprint magazine. Perhaps the world of interiors will belong to Armani for 2001. For a whole 12 months at least. By then it will definitely be time to get out the chintz again. I can't wait.

fields.headline: Inner beauty
fields.standfirst: Don't judge a lychee by its rough exterior. Its pure white, fragrant flesh is a revelation
fields.trailText: Don't judge a lychee by its rough exterior. Its pure white, fragrant flesh is a revelation.
fields.body:
Lychees are a costermonger's dream - not because they are especially rare or expensive any more, but because their name, being a transliteration of Chinese characters, means you can spell them any which way you like (darlin'). So that's litchis to you, leechees to him. They could be litchees to me, as long as they're not longans, which taste similar but, like rambutans, are only distant, inferior relations.

But most consumers are naturally less interested in the orthography than in the pleasures of the flesh. Is any other fruit quite so perfumed, so delicate and juicy? Europeans often compare the lychee's flavour to that of muscat grapes, but this is to deny the fairy-tale shock of the rough, rosy skin, which cracks open like eggshell to reveal flesh as white as snow. Only prior knowledge of the fruit's heavenly taste saves us from some awkward associations: clean-peeled, a lychee is alarmingly like a witchetty grub; leaking juice, it could double as an eyeball.

The common assumption that these two states - dry and wet - are a reflection of the peeler's dexterity is useful in one way; it's a good excuse to practise the art. Yet the truth is that dry-fingered success depends on the variety of lychee, which is why you seem better at it some days than others. Nor is it a question of luck when the shiny, mahogany-coloured seed is atrophied inside the fruit, providing more delicious flesh. These are so-called 'chicken-tongue' lychees, prized since the Song dynasty in China.

The successful cultivation of lychee trees in South Africa and Florida has extended the season to four or five months of the year, but lychees are still far more seasonal than most fruits. The relative scarcity makes them all the more desirable, just as the arrival of the first, pink-tinged clusters on market stalls in January seems to herald Chinese New Year - this year on 24 January. Chinese traders still insist the best fruits come from Kwantung province - a traditional preference dating back to the first century AD, when the imperial court in northern China had a horse-drawn courier service to transport the coveted lychees from the south.

Then as now, no serious lychee fan thought of cooking the fragrant flesh. An American grower of my acquaintance recommends 'broiling' the fruit with nuts, bacon, soy sauce and brown sugar, but I suspect eyeballs would do just as well in this recipe. A Chinese friend endorses the widely held British view that fresh is best, but says Chinese medicine cautions against eating too many, since overindulgence 'heats' the body and causes spots and ulcers. The effect can only be countered, apparently, by drinking beer. Now if you believe that, you'll believe anything.

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: cultivating your creativity, quashing herpes, and the art of knitting bones
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: cultivating your creativity, quashing herpes, and the art of knitting bones.
fields.body:
When you hear mention of creativity, do you automatically think of some new marketing fad or team-building concept? Or do you see struggling artists in frayed knitwear on the Cornish coast? Perhaps it conjures images of art-therapy sessions or amateur photography classes. In short, does the idea of creativity elicit a response of, 'Oh, creativity, that's something for other people who haven't got more important things to do'? In fact, everyone is an artist or potential artist of some kind. The artistic or creative faculty is built into the circuitry as a preset in your DNA. That you may not yet have found the relevant command to activate it, or perhaps found it only to lose it again, is probably down to faulty conditioning by those in charge of your education.

The expression of the creative urge as some form of artistic offering to be enjoyed by others was considered by the ancient Orientals to be vital to one's wellbeing, not just emotionally, spiritually and psychologically, but also physically and energetically. They adhered to a concept known as mastering the 'five excellences', which comprised the arts of meditation, self-defence, healing, composition and presentation skills. A well-rounded, masterful individual was seen as one who was conversant in all five. The benefits of the first three are self-evident, but how, you'd probably wonder, would composition and presentation skills be beneficial to your health?

During the act of composing a piece of art, whether visual, filmic, sonic, literary, performance-oriented or indeed any other creativity-carrier of your choice, you ideally enter a quasi-meditative or contemplative state. When composing a painting, for instance, you gaze at the blank canvas until it reveals a subliminal shape, then, with mind emptied of preconceptions and with your energy extending through to the tip of the brush, you simply interpret the given shape, allowing yourself to get in the way as little as possible. If, say, you are approaching the composition of a piece of music, let the instrument or recording studio reveal the piece to you and proceed to interpret the information revealed according to your taste, allowing the music to play itself. You could call this the Tao or Sen of composition.

The necessary ego-voiding process involved allows your local mind precious moments of repose from the pressures of daily responsibilities, which helps slow your pulse and is generally good for energy flow and, by extension, immune response.

This process also implies a certain degree of conscious union with the a-priori creative force, which tends to deepen your moment-by-moment experience of life in much the same way as does meditation, yoga or t'ai chi.

In the execution or presentation of the piece, you take a risk that others may deride you or your work. It requires courage to risk rejection and humiliation, making the act of carrying something through to this stage subtly exhilarating and self-esteem-building. It implies that you love or at least like yourself enough to spend time nurturing yourself. Moreover, it is at these times during which your overworked mind takes a brief holiday that some of your most original, important and life-changing ideas will emerge.

To enhance the creative flow, the ancient Taoists, who first developed the 'five excellences' concept, also devised certain meditative exercises, which if practised on a daily basis for 30 days or so, will yield positive results.

Visualise a clear tube or channel of approximately 1in diameter beginning in the centre of the forehead between your eyebrows, running back along the mid-line of your skull, over the top of your brain to the medulla oblongata at the base of the skull where it meets the back of your neck.

As you breathe in, imagine you can feel the breath enter the channel through your forehead and travel backwards over the brain to the back of your head. As you breathe out, feel the breath return through the tube to the forehead. You can augment the exercise by mentally imbuing the breath with bright, clarifying light.

Repeat this cycle up to nine times each sitting. Don't make a big deal over it. Do it while watching TV or sitting on the train. As well as stimulating and enhancing creativity, this exercise brings great mental clarity, increases your ability to focus and tends to make you feel cheerful.

If you're of the persuasion that creativity is visited upon you by your muse or from the divine or heavenly realms, it also helps to visualise the top of your head opening up to receive or download information as if from above.

The biggest block to healthy and healing creative expression is the belief in an imaginary internal critic, who sits poised like a monkey on your shoulder ready at all times to tell you what you're doing is worthless and wrong. There's no point trying to argue with the critic. The best approach is either to use a stun gun or simply to ignore whatever negative messages you receive. Either way, overriding the critic is essential not only for bringing works of art to completion, but also for ensuring peace of mind in general.

The other block you'll have to surmount is impatience. It takes a long time and consistent application to develop a reliable creative channel and the skill to interpret and shape the information coming through into a form worthy of sharing.

Finally, remember creativity can be applied to every aspect of your life including the way you relate to yourself and others, the way you organise your timetable and the places you choose to spend your time in. However, pay attention lest the creative urge runs away with you and you end up a compulsive content-spewer like this barefoot doctor.

Your questions

Dear Barefoot, I broke my ankle a few weeks ago and though the cast is off, it still causes pain and looks out of shape. The hospital assures me it's fine but it doesn't feel fine. Any ideas?
Danielle Spears, email

Dear Danielle, The two most effective ways of getting the bones to reset properly and realign the fascia are cranio-sacral therapy for the bone and deep connective-tissue massage for the fascia. Of these, the cranio-sacral therapy is more important, as it can often accelerate the bone knitting process. As with IT, it's all a matter of getting all the relevant bits and pieces in the area to talk to each other.

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I contracted genital herpes three years ago. Conventional ointments don't seem to prevent attacks. I've stopped eating chocolate and nuts or drinking coffee and tried taking L-lysene, but that doesn't seem to do anything, either. I always seem to be on the verge of an attack. Is there anything you can recommend?
Name withheld, email

Herpes responds to stress levels as well as causing its own stress. Consider taking a short course in biofeedback training to help you monitor stress levels. Learn to regard the herpes as a useful stress barometer. Visit an acupuncturist occasionally, as the liver meridian runs through the genital region and there are acupuncture points on the inside thigh which can help diffuse the build-up before an outbreak. A mixture of essential oils of tea tree and lavender applied daily may also serve as a useful preventative.

 If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com

webTitle: Health: Oh! What a lovely diet

fields.headline: Oh! What a lovely diet
fields.standfirst: How a wartime diet unexpectedly worked wonders for the Hymers family, in Channel 4's 1940s House
fields.trailText: How a wartime diet unexpectedly worked wonders for the Hymers family, in Channel 4's 1940s House.
fields.body:
There can't be many people who would willingly return to the days of food shortages and rationing, but that doesn't usually stop our mums and grans fondly recalling the stodgy puddings, bread and dripping and shepherd's pies of their wartime diet. Today, as we tuck into ready-made curries and lasagne, it's tempting to smile smugly and think we all know what's good for us now. But as nutritional experts believe - and the Hymers family from Otley in Yorkshire can confirm - it may well be that Mum knows best.

Dieticians have long argued that wartime rationing provided the healthiest diet the British population has ever eaten, leading to dramatic post-war improvements in the nation's health. But now that ration books are consigned to museums, nutritionists still believe there are valuable lessons we can learn from the 40s diet that could help us beat the biggest threats to health today.

The proof of the pudding lies in the experience of the Hymers family who volunteered to go back in time and spend nine weeks surviving on austere rations for the series The 1940s House , currently showing on Channel 4. Not only did all the adult Hymers lose weight and show modest health improvements by the end of the experiment but, six months after filming has ended, grandmother Lyn Hymers has stuck with her wartime regime and insists her health has benefited.

'I feel so much better,' says Lyn, 50. 'It really has become a way of life for me.'

Taking up the wartime challenge was no easy option for the Hymers. The family - Lyn and husband Michael, their daughter, Kirstie, 29, and grandsons Ben, 10 and Thomas, seven - previously ate a typical modern British diet. Their staple fare consisted of ready-made meals, tinned and frozen convenience foods and takeaways. Lyn rarely cooked, had no idea how to bake a cake and enjoyed smoking and drinking. Not surprisingly, both she and Michael, 52, were overweight and unfit.

After nine weeks of spartan rations and, without the benefits of modern time-saving conveniences, heavy physical labour, it is hardly surprising the adult members of the family lost weight. But after just nine weeks, medical tests also showed their cholesterol, blood pressure and bodyfat levels had fallen moderately and their muscles grown stronger.

More significantly, despite returning to their 21st-century home comforts, Lyn and Michael have continued their wartime regime, complete with Spam fritters and home-made cooking. While Michael feels more ambivalent about the benefits of his revolutionary lifestyle change, Lyn has now lost more than a stone, feels healthier, fitter and more energetic than ever before and has given up both alcohol and coffee, without the aid of any weight-reduction programme or exercise regime.

Instead of driving to the supermarket for weekly shopping, she now walks daily to her local bakery, grocer's and butcher's shops to buy fresh produce. She no longer buys convenience foods or ready-made meals, but cooks everything from basic ingredients. And while previously she threw away vast quantities of food each week, she now wastes nothing. One day for lunch she may make soup with fresh peas and the following day a broth from leftover pea pods. She is even converted to the delights of Spam, and although she still smokes, she has given up coffee and alcohol because she simply doesn't want them any more.

To her amazement, she has not regained the weight lost during the 40s experiment and feels healthier all round. 'I have battled weight all my life with different diets and going to Weight Watchers,' says Lyn. 'But whatever I did, the weight always yo-yoed back to its old level. This time it is just staying off and I am not hungry.'

In addition, she says, her teeth are whiter, her gums no longer bleed, her eyes are no longer bloodshot, she rarely becomes breathless and her skin is as clear as ever, without the aid of expensive creams.

The fact the Hymers lost weight and their short-term health improved confirms nutritionists' faith in the benefits of combining exercise with a diet high in carbohydrates and low in fat. But more importantly, nutritional experts also argue that a return to aspects of the wartime diet could, for all of us, be the secret to surviving modern-day killers such as cancer, heart disease, stroke and diabetes.

At first sight, the typical 40s meal of tiny meat portions, mounds of potatoes, carrots, cabbage and bread, followed by a stodgy pudding, may not sound like the pathway to true health. Yet, at the start of the war, the average British diet, with its higher carbohydrate and lower fat content, was closer to modern recommendations than today's diet, explains Susan Jebb, head of the Medical Research Council's human nutrition research unit, who advised on the television series. When war brought food shortages and rationing, the diet improved further, as people relied more on carbohydrates while fats and sugar were severely restricted.

British people derived 32 per cent of their calories from fat in the 40s - almost spot on the 33 per cent level now recommended by government - compared to 40 per cent today, says Dr Jebb. Although we are now more likely to spread polyunsaturated fats, such as margarine, on our bread than the butter or dripping of the war years, overall fat consumption is still too high, she says. Similarly, whereas war families consumed 55 per cent of calories as carbohydrates, the figure today is down to 45 per cent. We now eat about half the potatoes and a third of the bread typically consumed during the 40s. And although we partly compensate with pasta and rice, this is still insufficient, she argues.

These two major shifts in British diet are held partly to blame for our high incidence of several killer diseases. Nutritionists agree that too much fat can lead to raised cholesterol and obesity, which put us at risk of heart disease, stroke and diabetes. Eating more carbohydrates provides essential fibre, which can protect against some cancers. It is also more likely to fill us up without making us resort to unhealthy biscuits, cakes and other bad habits. Higher vegetable consumption also protects against certain cancers.

Experts estimate that up to a third of all cancers are caused by dietary factors. Since 1950, cancer deaths have grown from 17 per cent to 25 per cent of all mortality, and while treatment has improved survival in many cases, incidence is still rising. Diabetes and obesity have also both increased significantly and although deaths from heart disease are now falling, they have not dropped as fast as many experts believe feasible.

'Many people ate a lot better during the war,' says Dr Jebb. Ironically, although we now enjoy more choice and variety in what we eat, diet has generally worsened. 'It is certainly possible to eat more healthily now than then, but not all of us choose to do it.'

There were other health advantages to the wartime diet, too. Although fruit was a rarity, there were free supplies of fruit juice, milk and vitamins for children. The standardised wartime national wholemeal loaf contained far more fibre than traditional white bread and was fortified with calcium, while vitamins A and D were added to margarine. At the same time, fair shares meant many poorer families ate a better diet than before. The difference in death rates between rich and poor reached its narrowest gap in the 20th century after the war, before widening to its current gulf.

'It was the best diet we have ever had in Britain,' declares Aubrey Sheiham, professor of dental public health at University College London. The government based rationing on sound nutritional principles, while equal shares ensured the benefits were enjoyed by all. After the war, there were dramatic reductions in diabetes and dental decay, which can both be linked to better diet, he points out.

Obviously, health trends have not all moved in one direction. We now live longer than ever before and have largely seen off infectious diseases such as TB, measles and polio. Yet the greatest increases in life expectancy during the last century happened during the war decades, according to Richard Wilkinson, professor of social epidemiology at Sussex University.

From 1911 to 1921 and again from 1940 to 1951, life expectancy increased by between six and seven years - more than double the rise in other decades, he says. In the 40s, deaths from many causes, including heart disease, diabetes, flu and pneumonia, fell significantly. He believes full employment, higher earnings, more equality and social cohesion all played a part in this dramatic health improvement. The wartime diet was clearly another factor. 'Food certainly is part of the more general picture.'

On the home front

Rationing was introduced in 1940 and lasted 14 years. For most of that time, meat, cheese, butter, cooking fats and sugar were heavily restricted, but potatoes, other root vegetables and bread were freely available. People ate a diet much higher in carbohydrates and lower in fats. After rationing ended, people rushed to buy butter, sugar and white bread. The National Food Survey, conducted since 1950, shows our consumption of fruit has slowly risen over the past 50 years, but that consumption of bread, cereals, potatoes and other vegetables has steadily fallen. We eat fewer visible fats, but consume hidden quantities in processed foods, takeaways and restaurant meals.

fields.headline: Restoration drama
fields.standfirst: New Year, new Jane Clarke. So that our popular dietician can cover a wider range of nutritional issues and respond to your questions, we've introduced a more helpful format. This week: energy boosts and soft cheese during breastfeeding
fields.trailText: New Year, new Jane Clarke. So that our popular dietician can cover a wider range of nutritional issues and respond to your questions, we've introduced a more helpful format. This week: energy boosts and soft cheese during breastfeeding.
fields.body:
Having spent the festive period with my family, I take my hat off to my sister, Ann Marie, the busy mother of two boisterous boys. I don't know how she copes with the demands of caring for young children, but if you're in a similar position, be aware that there are certain steps you can take to energise yourself through nutrition.

Ann Marie finds that skipping meals has disastrous consequences for her wellbeing, and if you tend to pick at your children's leftovers rather than make yourself a proper meal, you would do well to make a point of finding a few minutes to nurture yourself. Something simple will do: a bowl of soup accompanied by a slice of wholegrain toast and a chunk of cheese, or pasta sprinkled with grated Pecorino cheese and a little olive oil, will both reap dividends in terms of boosting your energy reserves.

You may find keeping a record of everything that you eat and drink over a week and then analysing the results an illuminating exercise. A regular dose of fructose (fruit sugar) can be an effective energiser, but if you find that you're not eating enough fruit and vegetables, buy a supply of the fruits that you enjoy and set yourself the target of eating them between meals. Staying ahead of the game helps, as it's frequently the 'no good food around but desperate for something' moments that can get you into trouble; you might try slicing up an orange or two in the morning and keeping it covered in the fridge for a fuel boost later in the day. Since feeling physiologically replete usually makes you feel psychologically satisfied, increasing your intake of satiety-prompting fibre by eating plenty of fruit and vegetables will also help you to feel, if not ready for anything, at least better able to cope.

Finally, as I often point out, it is also important to drink lots of water. Also bear in mind that although caffeine can energise if drunk in moderation - more than two to three cups a day will drain your energy reserves. If, however, coffee helps to get you through the day, either try switching to a decaffeinated brand or limit yourself to just a couple of regular cups a day. You can make your daily caffeine ration go further by mixing your coffee with hot milk, which will also provide you with extra nourishment.

Nutrition news: The benefits of oily fish

You may recently have been concerned by reports about toxic residues found in oily fish. If so, fear not, as it appears that as long as you eat a 90-120g portion of oily fish once a week as part of a well-balanced diet, you shouldn't consume enough pollutant residues to cause any health problems. In fact, there are many reasons (including their heart-protecting qualities) why you should eat salmon, tuna, sardines, mackerel and pilchards, all of which contain the beneficial oil omega-3 fatty acid.

Some interesting new research carried out at the University of Cincinnati suggests that omega-3 fatty acids may have a positive effect on our minds as well as our body. According to their scientists, omega-3 fish oil, aka eicosapentaenoic acid, may prove efficacious in various psychiatric conditions, including mood disorders. Several other treatment studies are also being carried out into whether increasing our intake of omega-3 fish oils, either through eating more oily fish or taking an omega-3 fatty acid supplement (cod liver oil contains eicosapentanoic acid and is usually cheaper than other omega supplements), can have a beneficial effect on major depression, dementia and schizophrenia. If you're pregnant, there is even more reason to eat your quota of oily fish, as new research suggests that omega-3 fatty acid encourages the development of your unborn baby's brain. If the thought of eating fish turns your pregnant stomach, consider taking either a supplement containing omega-3 oil or a slightly cheaper cod liver oil supplement. Before doing so, however, be sure to check the packaging to ensure that it doesn't contain more than 3,000 micrograms of retinol (vitamin A), excess quantities of which may compromise your baby's health.

Your questions answered

I gave up soft cheeses during pregnancy. Is it safe for me to eat them now that I'm breastfeeding?
Lynn Scott, Birmingham

Being a cheeseaholic myself, the prospect of having to avoid soft and blue cheeses for nine months seems tough, but abstinence is a small price to pay for reducing the risk of contracting listeriosis, the strain of food poisoning that can either prompt a miscarriage or damage your unborn baby. All soft, moist, blue-veined cheeses, whether pasteurised or unpasteurised, are likely to harbour listeria bacteria, as are ptés, soft-whip ice cream, chilled ready-made meals that haven't been reheated according to the manufacturer's instructions and pre-washed, packaged salads (rinse them in cold water before eating them). Once you've given birth, however, you can tuck into any cheese you like. Indeed, if you are breast-feeding, a piece of Stilton as a mid-meal snack can provide you with some much-needed calories, calcium and energy.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. If you would like her to answer any questions, please write to Jane Clarke c/o Life Magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email her at life@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Head over heels
fields.standfirst:
All Miranda Sawyer ever wanted to be was a gymnast. From the age of seven she wore her
hair like Olga Korbut's, trained three times a week and thought nothing of throwing a back somersault from standing. Here, she travels to the Gymnastics World Cup Final in Glasgow to relive the rough and tumble of her youth
fields.trailText: All Miranda Sawyer ever wanted to be was a gymnast. From the age of seven she wore her hair like Olga Korbut's, trained three times a week and thought nothing of throwing a back somersault from standing. Here, she travels to the Gymnastics World Cup Final in Glasgow to relive the rough and tumble of her youth.
fields.body:
In July 1976, Nadia Comaneci won the overall gold medal for women's artistic gymnastics at the Montreal Olympics. She also won gold on the beam, gold on asymmetric bars, bronze on floor and a silver medal with her fellow Romanians in the team event. Even more astonishingly, during the five-day competition, she scored a perfect 10 out of 10 seven times - four times on bars, three on beam - an achievement which remains unbeaten to this day. In July 1976, Nadia Comaneci was 14 years old.

It's December 2000, and photographer Zed Nelson and I are wandering around an out-of-town shopping centre outside Glasgow, trying to find a World Cup Final. The International Federation of Gymnastics World Cup Final 1999-2000, no less. You'd think it would be easy to spot, but somehow, among the Sainsbury's and the Salisbury's, the C&A and the M&S, we just can't seem to track the thing down. It's meant to be in an arena and the arena is meant to be near. We check the map, traipse along miles of glinting arcade, our eyes bleeding in the air conditioning. Is the World Cup buried beneath Beaverbrooks? Is it taking place around us, secretly, in the aisles? I start looking carefully at small children in tracksuits, to see if they're gymnasts in disguise. You know how little those Russkies are.

Eventually we spot an arrow stuck to a wall near McDonald's, which we follow to the press area. And finally, we find our World Cup. Through double doors into a bright-lit hall which jumps with silent, wild activity, its floor alive with teeny-tiny people swinging around bars, somersaulting on the beam, screaming along the ground like noiseless Formula Ones before chucking their bantam bodies into the air as though propelled from a car crash. The air boils with energy, but the only sounds are the squeak of the bars, the muffled thud of feet on matted floor.

I start babbling to Zed: 'Look, there's Andreea Raducan, she won the gold but had it taken from her, and see the one with the ponytail, that's Simona Amanar, she won the silver but took the gold, and that one is the Russian who won floor and vault...'

Zed is unimpressed. Our press passes only allow us into the front row of the audience. As far as he is concerned, this is not near enough. It's training day, the only one before the competition, and he was hoping for intimate close-ups. He isn't happy.

As for me, the mere fact of breathing the same recycled air as these athletes has made me quite ecstatic. Imagine how excited you'd be to walk into a church and find Zinadine Zidane, Steve Redgrave and Tiger Woods all hanging out at the altar. That's how this feels for me. I am a big gymnastics fan. During the Sydney Olympics, I set my alarm in order to watch the 5 am shift. I followed every twist and turn, every stumble and fall, and I bored everyone I knew with the drama. So, to have some of the principal players running through that same theatre - in real life! right next to me! - makes me gulp.

Also, I think I'm experiencing my first-ever Proustian rush. This world of French chalk and springboards and sprung floors and crashmats, of stomach strengtheners and stretching exercises and standing on your hands, is familiar yet long-forgotten. From the age of seven until I moved to London at 21, I spent up to three nights a week practising gymnastics. Why, I don't know: I was pretty good at it, but never strong enough to make Stockport, my county team. Though, on one occasion, I trained at Lilleshall, in the national gymnastics centre. I can still remember it: the tumbling floor was so highly sprung, I threw a back somersault from standing.

I gave up at 21, because, well, every gymnast gives up around then. Your body won't do what you tell it any more. Worse, your mind won't tell your body to do it any more. Adulthood brings fear, and gymnastics is impossible if you're afraid. Concentration is essential; consideration - of snapped neck, ripped ears, shattered ankle - spoils everything. When I was 11 and so shortsighted I could barely see my feet, I thought nothing of hurtling at full speed towards a vault that only clicked into focus when I slammed on to the springboard. At 14, I was flinging myself from one uneven bar to another, wrapping my pelvis around a fibreglass pole with no thought for a child-bearing future. Drunk at 17, I'd throw free - no-handed - cartwheels around concrete town centres, chuck flips on park benches, handsprings on dark paths. I was brave. My body was all mine.

Until I left home at 18, I trained at Bramhall High, just south of Manchester. It was just a school sports hall, nothing special, with those long ropes that pulled out from the ceiling and wooden climbing bars on the walls. Every session, we'd set up and take down the equipment; click the asymmetric bars into place, French-chalk them, angle their uprights, tighten the steel ropes; lug out the beam, push the mats underneath, the crashmat at the end; set the vault and springboard; lay the floor, its strips held together with Velcro. I look at the beam in the Glasgow arena, and I know its texture - smooth moleskin wrapped around cold, dense wood. I know its height - 4ft, its width - 4in, I can feel it between my fingers - and I know how heavy it is to carry back into a storeroom. It has 'Continental' stamped on its side. All gymnastic equipment is made by Continental.

A cameraman squeezes past me. He gestures with his head towards a tumbling tot and says: 'Few whiskies and I could do all this.' Except, of course, he couldn't. And neither could I, not even when I trained so hard that gymnastics danced through my dreams. Actually, neither could the all-conquering Nadia Comaneci, at the very height of her powers. If she were to perform her 1976 perfect-10 routines in front of today's judges, she'd be lucky to get above 8.5. Gymnastics has moved on.

I watch the Romanian Andreea Raducan perform a full twisting back somersault on the beam. When Comaneci was Olympic champion, only the top girls could manage such a move on the floor. Raducan did her first triple twist on that apparatus seven years ago. When she was 10. Andreea has grown since, but not much: she's 4ft 7in and weighs 5st. During the Sydney Olympics, a male commentator said, wistfully, 'She has lovely sparkling eyes.' Which she has, and dimples, and a dark, flippy ponytail. She also had the all-around individual Olympic gold medal, Romania's first since Comaneci, for seven whole days, until she was disqualified for failing a drugs test. The Romanian team doctor had prescribed her two Nurofen Cold & Flu tablets for a sniffle; the resulting pseudoephedrine in her urine cost her the gold.

Andreea is a superstar now: after the Olympics, when she arrived home on her 17th birthday, she was welcomed into Bucharest's airport by a crowd of thousands, including Romania's prime minister Mugur Isarescu. She received all the privileges traditionally given by her country for winning an Olympic title - a car, an apartment - plus £20,000, twice the money usually awarded. A jeweller made her a replica medal, out of 18ct gold. Someone wrote 'A Song For Andreea Raducan'. And she became the gymnastics fans' darling, worldwide. Every time she takes a rest near the arena barrier, scores of little girls rush up to ask her for her autograph.

Little girls, little girls: gymnastics' life-blood and its most dedicated disciples. I started gymnastics in its mad post-Korbut heyday, when every girl under ten wanted to be Olga. I was five when she exploded into the 1972 Olympics, scooping gold on floor and beam, silver on bars. Olga Korbut was the first gymnast ever to perform a back somersault on the beam; I wore my hair like her, in two bunches.

In the early to mid-70s, with ambassadors like Korbut and Comaneci, gymnastics was at its popular peak. Even now, when I meet women of my age working in the music business, or in magazines, or PR, or telly, as far from a sporting life as can be imagined, you'd be surprised at how many are ex-gymnasts. We all tried it. Most dropped out, usually in their teenage years; exams took over or boys came along or bodies grew too big, too womanly. The more immature, like me, stuck it out. There was nothing I found that I enjoyed more. Why would I have given up?

By the late 70s, though, the image of gymnastics was suffering. Partly because its greatest legend was suffering, too. In 1978, Nadia Comaneci reappeared, post puberty, a stone heavier and, at 5ft 3in, three-and-a-half inches taller than in 1976. By the end of 1979, she'd lost all her weight and was shockingly gaunt, suffering from a bad wrist and blood poisoning. Articles accused her of bulimia, and the 'gymnastics is bad for your health' rumours started. It stunts your growth. You'll never have babies. The champions are only good because they take steroids.

Then, in 1989, Nadia suddenly turned up in the States, fat, sluttish, unresponsive. 'See what happens when you stop taking those Eastern European drugs?' crowed the papers.

But she recovered eventually and married Bart Connor, a US gymnast, in 1995. Thousands of well-wishers turned up. Soon after, she was named one of the 100 athletes of the century. Nadia appeared at Andreea Raducan's side during her Sydney appeal: she looked slim, blonde, glamorous. Andreea looked very pale and small.

Today, though, Andreea's perky, chatting to her rivals as she waits for her turn on the bars. She's wearing a black Lycra swimsuit-style leotard and black Lycra shorts. In my day, the fashion was for long sleeves with contrasting V necks, or stripes up the inside of the arm. We wore footless tights, with leg warmers; never shorts.

The only girls in footless tights here are the modern rhythmic gymnasts down the far end, the long-limbed girls with the ball and the ribbon and the hoop, gymnastics' ballet dancers. Zed is photographing them and I go down to join him. He's focusing on one razor-boned poppet who snaps her ribbon with elegant disdain. 'It doesn't take much imagination to have her dressed in leather and turn that into a whip,' he muses.

Gymnasts always score highly in the male fantasy league. It's the bendy sex thing. Whereas once your dad had a choice of curvy beauties to sigh over: Ludmila Tourischeva, Elvira Saadi, Nelli Kim...

Unmistakable, even 26 years on, Eurasian cheekbones, lovely smile, the only true challenge to Comaneci in the late 70s, she's clicking across the arena floor surrounded by elderly women in fur coats. 'Ten out of 10 for the body,' says the other, and they collapse into giggles.

The atmosphere today is far more serious; even Andreea has stopped smiling. The coaches are more evident, arms folded, ignoring each other, barking instructions. There are few women coaches. And the men, it seems, all have Freddie Mercury moustaches.

The top eight performers on each apparatus are due to compete today, although, post-Olympics, some haven't bothered to show, including Russia's Number One Svetlana Khorkina, who's off taking the Yankee dollar in an exhibition tour across the States.

Yesterday, though, we spotted her in her civvies - Puffa jacket, tracksuit bottoms, hair scraped back into straggly ponytail - and this, combined with her razor cheekbones, led us to nickname her (perhaps unfairly) Crack Ho.

There are plenty jostling for top position at the moment. Which might explain gymnastics' dormant popularity. 'Andreea says she nearly to stop to do gym because she don't trust the adult people who made her guilty. But she was very impressed by her support, from the people and from important places, and maybe she get a big help from God to be strong. She don't cry or ask for pity. She says: I want to finish with the nightmare in Sydney,' says her coach. 'She says: I want to show what I am able to do.'

Andreea looks straight ahead as he speaks. Her medals flash under the lights, but her dark-circled eyes are unreadable.

fields.headline: Young fogeys
fields.standfirst: One foot in the groove
fields.trailText: One foot in the groove.
fields.body:
Last Friday, sitting in a lounge with a bunch of twentysomething friends, we started chatting about what we were up to over the weekend. Much to the surprise of the rest of us, one pair mentioned they were going to Fabric the following evening. Why, we wondered, would anyone want to spend Saturday night, or indeed any night, going clubbing? Especially at a dreary corporate superclub.

Obviously it could be said that nightclub dread and disco depression are an essential by-product of growing up. Still, most twentysomethings I know, unfettered by children and mortgages and still considered young, are bored rigid by clubbing and indeed by much of what passes for youth culture.

In the not-so-distant past it was all so simple. Kids would listen to unfathomable music, take drugs and dance. Over-thirties would react with outrage and indignation and try to outlaw whatever it was the kids were into. Everyone knew their place in the great scheme of things.

Then, as these things are wont to do, it all changed - what had been the subculture became the mainstream, and suddenly underground activities were the new orthodoxy; clubbing mums appeared in documentaries about Barnsley; taking drugs and dancing the night away became government endorsed; it was regarded as almost unpatriotic not to go to Ibiza, and Britain became one big happy-clappy post-rave safe dancing nightmare full of dance music awards sponsored by Ericsson, Tory MPs fessing up to youthful indiscretions with marijuana and Jamie Oliver. With some minor tinkering over the past decade, youth culture slowed down, stood still, got sickly and is currently seriously unstable, jerking spasmodically to the latest Seb Fontaine remix.

Which is why a growing number of youths are reacting against it by indulging in stuff that is self-consciously not youth culture - revelling instead in a restrained and particularly English style of hedonism in whichever form most appeals, seeking out the illicit pleasures of gardening, listening to Radio 4, eating marmalade and reading The Pickwick Papers as a reaction to the idea that the only recreation available is to force oneself to go to boring clubs, 'lose' the plot and hug sweaty gurning strangers.

The difference in attitude goes some way to explaining why the most popular TV programmes among twentysomethings are not the ones targeted at them. Look at the resounding failure of Frontal - you remember, that much-hyped 4Later programme which appeared last autumn promising 'stuff you've never seen on TV before; sex! drugs!! the internet!!!' Two episodes in, it disappeared from the schedules (and, Stalinist revisionist-style, from the Channel 4 web archive). Meanwhile, programmes like Watercolour Challenge achieve cult followings.

It should be pointed out that while there have always been young people thrust into fogeydom before their time, this is different. The leisure pursuits of a growing number tend to be an interesting mix of the old and the new; drugs, for example, are not absent from the new schedule of fun, it's just that the location you take them has changed. It's a way of enjoyment nodded to in the forthcoming film adaptation of Martin Amis's Dead Babies, where the twentysomething characters spend a weekend at a Hertfordshire retreat indulging in darts, badminton, web terrorism, sexual deviancy and casual murder. Take away the murder and you've got the rough idea.

Youth culture mags have started catering for these eclectic tastes. Once rigidly split into music and fashion pages, with the odd interview with an actor and some grungy Corinne Day/Juergen Teller shoots, these days the pages are more likely to be running Martin Parr's gently satirical pics of prize-winning marrows and ladies in floral dresses alongside articles extolling the virtues of gardening, Great British days out and other ephemera.

Recently, The Guardian asked, Is Bingo the New Clubbing? While I think the answer to that is an emphatic no , I have noticed that down the local pub there are numerous twentysomethings indulging in the pub quiz, a pastime originally intended for corduroy-clad CAMRA members. The pursuit of trivia obviously holds some appeal for what was after all the Trivial Pursuit Generation.

It's hardly the new black. But while those who indulge in quizzes, reading or watching TV, rather than forcing themselves to hang round the DJ box long after the appeal has worn off, may look to the casual observer as if they're just old before their time, beneath their fogeyish exteriors lurk fearless experimenters who have shaken off the pressures of conforming to a boring 'youth' culture and instead chosen to do what is the prerogative, nay the duty, of any young person - the unexpected.
