Then, as these things are wont to do, it all changed - what had been the subculture became the mainstream, and suddenly underground activities were the new orthodoxy; clubbing mums appeared in documentaries about Barnsley; taking drugs and dancing the night away became government endorsed; it was regarded as almost unpatriotic not to go to Ibiza, and Britain became one big happy-clappy post-rave safe dancing nightmare full of dance music awards sponsored by Ericsson, Tory MPs fessing up to youthful indiscretions with marijuana and Jamie Oliver. With some minor tinkering over the past decade, youth culture slowed down, stood still, got sickly and is currently seriously unstable, jerking spasmodically to the latest Seb Fontaine remix. Which is why a growing number of youths are reacting against it by indulging in stuff that is self-consciously not youth culture - revelling instead in a restrained and particularly English style of hedonism in whichever form most appeals, seeking out the illicit pleasures of gardening, listening to Radio 4, eating marmalade and reading The Pickwick Papers as a reaction to the idea that the only recreation available is to force oneself to go to boring clubs, 'lose' the plot and hug sweaty gurning strangers. The difference in attitude goes some way to explaining why the most popular TV programmes among twentysomethings are not the ones targeted at them. Look at the resounding failure of Frontal - you remember, that much-hyped 4Later programme which appeared last autumn promising 'stuff you've never seen on TV before; sex! drugs!! the internet!!!' Two episodes in, it disappeared from the schedules (and, Stalinist revisionist-style, from the Channel 4 web archive). Meanwhile, programmes like Watercolour Challenge achieve cult followings. It should be pointed out that while there have always been young people thrust into fogeydom before their time, this is different. The leisure pursuits of a growing number tend to be an interesting mix of the old and the new; drugs, for example, are not absent from the new schedule of fun, it's just that the location you take them has changed. It's a way of enjoyment nodded to in the forthcoming film adaptation of Martin Amis's Dead Babies, where the twentysomething characters spend a weekend at a Hertfordshire retreat indulging in darts, badminton, web terrorism, sexual deviancy and casual murder. Take away the murder and you've got the rough idea. Youth culture mags have started catering for these eclectic tastes. Once rigidly split into music and fashion pages, with the odd interview with an actor and some grungy Corinne Day/Juergen Teller shoots, these days the pages are more likely to be running Martin Parr's gently satirical pics of prize-winning marrows and ladies in floral dresses alongside articles extolling the virtues of gardening, Great British days out and other ephemera. Recently, The Guardian asked, Is Bingo the New Clubbing? While I think the answer to that is an emphatic no , I have noticed that down the local pub there are numerous twentysomethings indulging in the pub quiz, a pastime originally intended for corduroy-clad CAMRA members. The pursuit of trivia obviously holds some appeal for what was after all the Trivial Pursuit Generation. It's hardly the new black. But while those who indulge in quizzes, reading or watching TV, rather than forcing themselves to hang round the DJ box long after the appeal has worn off, may look to the casual observer as if they're just old before their time, beneath their fogeyish exteriors lurk fearless experimenters who have shaken off the pressures of conforming to a boring 'youth' culture and instead chosen to do what is the prerogative, nay the duty, of any young person - the unexpected.

fields.headline: Dealing with infertility
fields.standfirst: Fertility treatment is an expensive and often futile lottery. But for thousands of childless couples it's their only chance of having what everyone else takes for granted - a baby. Nicci Gerrard describes the misery and desperation of infertility
fields.trailText: Fertility treatment is an expensive and often futile lottery. But for thousands of childless couples it's their only chance of having what everyone else takes for granted - a baby. Nicci Gerrard describes the misery and desperation of infertility.
fields.body:
Every year in Britain, about 27,000 couples receive fertility treatment, although only one in six is successful. There are babies who are born who were not planned or wanted. There are babies who are born after medical help, and for their parents they seem like a miracle. And then there are the babies who are not born who are desperately wanted and struggled for; whose absence is felt as a deep loss and mourned like a bereavement.

According to Child, the National Infertility Support Network, infertility now affects one in six couples, and the number that seek help is up by 55 per cent in the last five years. An awful lot of hope and misery is hidden under this statistic. Yet those of us who are lucky, who don't have any reproductive problems, who spend the early part of our sexual life avoiding pregnancy, the next part having the number of children that we want, and who can take our fertility and the invisible workings of our body for granted - how much do we actually care, after all?

A survey was recently carried out in Oregon, in which people were asked to assess how important they thought different health services were, and how important to the community as a whole - their responses were married to costs, thus giving a crude assessment of health priorities. If something was not very important, but cheap, it moved up the table; if something else was important but exorbitant, price pushed it down. The responses were not entirely predictable; some of them were heartening. People cared more about Aids and Alzheimer's, say, than had been expected. But the one thing that scored surprisingly low was infertility. Perhaps this is because we don't know what to think about childlessness in general, either enforced or voluntary, or how to place it.

Until a few decades ago, it was regarded as a woman's function and duty to bear children if she married. To be a woman was to be a mother. Men sow and women bear fruit. The present gives birth to the future. If a woman had no maternal longings, that was her problem. On the other side of the coin, there was nothing a couple could do about problems in having children. It wasn't really a health issue, but a rough hand dealt by fate. 'Let nature take its course'; 'What will be will be.' And it was also a secret. A stigma. A failure. Unnaturalness and incompleteness. Men who had low sperm counts were, somehow, less of a man (in rather the same way that today, young boys who become teenager fathers see it as a sign of their macho virility: sure evidence that they've 'done it'). Women who failed to conceive were barren, empty, useless; the seed was falling on stony ground. It used to be a ground for divorce. For many couples, it remains a reason.

Even now, when one in 80 children are born with medical help, we are ambivalent about fertility treatment. It raises such ethical dilemmas and poses such large, spooky questions. Who should be helped? How old is too old; how desperate is too desperate; when is unnatural too unnatural? When we hear of a 60-year-old woman giving birth, or a man selling eggs on the net, of embryos being swapped by mistake, a collective shudder goes through us. Germaine Greer, in her angry book The Whole Woman , wrote about the women who are delivered of child after they have been brain-dead for months; the women who are long post-menopausal but who manage to give birth with a little help from scientists. 'Every time this happens,' she writes, 'women's grip on motherhood lessens.' What's more, she adds, it is men who are in charge of women's childlessness. Women are reduced to objects.

Our ambivalence towards treatment is reflected in its availability on the NHS. Most couples do not qualify for NHS treatments - especially where the woman is above 35 (which is often the age at which a career woman will start trying). Some authorities spend £500,000 a year on fertility; others nothing.

When Alan Milburn pledged to make help equally available across regions, getting rid of the postcode lottery couples now face, there was a great deal of hostile comment in the press. Some talked about the premature rush to treatment and dashed the hopes that IVF represents, which makes it more difficult for couples to 'come to terms' with childlessness; others shuddered at the culling of embryos, the cold science of it all. Pregnancy was widely called a 'consumer choice' or a matter of 'destiny' - many critics agreed that help, if available at all, should certainly not be freely available. It is weirdly easy for people with children to write rather blithely about childlessness. It is oddly common for men and women, whose own lives have been changed by becoming parents, to think that infertility doesn't matter that much; it's just one of those things. Life's unfair.

When I raised the question of costs with Professor Winston, infertility guru and New Labour peer, he responded furiously, saying it was 'stupid, fatuous'. 'Infertility,' he says, 'is like a pain in the chest. It is a symptom of something wrong. It covers a range of problems; it might be genetic; it might cause a miscarriage; it might be something serious or trivial.' And, of course, he says emphatically, help should be available on the NHS, in the same way that a tumour or an arthritic hip should be investigated and the pain healed or eased. 'It is essential in a civilised society, with access to a free health service.' What's more, he says, we talk about equality yet punish women who, because they work, are now trying to have children later; and we applaud family values, and yet don't support women who are trying to have much-wanted children; 'Ironic, don't you agree?

'Do you have any idea at all,' he asks, 'of the pain that infertility causes? What cruelty leads us to label it a lifestyle choice?'

Do I? I have four children, so of course I don't. Do you? Have you ever thought about it properly? Most of us come to the story either as people who do not want children (yet, or ever), or as people who have successfully managed to do so. Those who have not felt broody (and that soft, clucking word doesn't begin to evoke the fierceness and urgency of the desire) find it impossible to imagine the pain of not getting pregnant. And for those of us who've managed - been randomly lucky - a certain complacency sets in. I think that many women, even those who conceive naturally and swiftly, feel the little shudder of doubt and dread as they wait for the period they don't want. But we forget it - just as we later manage to forget the pain of giving birth - and the thought of infertility quickly blows away, a little ripple of cold wind. For whereas cancer (or strokes or heart attacks or BSE or a bolt of lightning out of a blue sky) might always be waiting round the next corner, waiting to ambush us, infertility only matters during a certain passage of our life, and after we give birth becomes something that we do not need to fear or think about.

Yet for men and women trying to have a baby, the clock ticks like a time bomb. It ticks away their hopes. The year is divided brutally into periods. The mood swings between hope and despair, hope and despair. Around them, they see pregnant women, babies in prams. They see the birth of the future. They feel they are outcasts from the only life that they really wanted and that other people so easily have. They deserve to be listened to.

Fertility facts

One in 80 children born in Britain today was conceived as a result of IVF.

One in six couples try infertility treatment.

Denmark has the highest proportion of test-tube babies in Europe - 2.6 per cent of all live births (it is 1.2 per cent in the UK).

IVF can produce high rates of multiple births because up to three embryos can be implanted in the uterus. 27 per cent of all IVF births produce two or more babies, compared to 1.4 per cent of all babies conceived naturally.

47 per cent of individual babies born as a result of IVF came from a multiple pregnancy.

One third of all infertility is caused by male fertility difficulties, one third by female factors and another third is unaccounted for.80 per cent of infertility treatment is carried out privately.

 Some names have been changed.

fields.headline: Perfect design
fields.standfirst: Alberto Alessi
fields.trailText: Alberto Alessi.
fields.body:
People usually say that something is perfect because it is beautiful, but this is too narrow a definition. Perfection is what we feel when we face small masterpieces. Every good designer is looking for perfection. There's no reason to design another tray or teapot, but the search for perfection is what spurs people on to keep trying. Bowls and forks and everything else for the house are actually thousands of years old, so from a functional point of view they are at the very end of their development cycle.

What brings household objects closer to perfection is the struggle to capture the essence of the object. Heidegger calls it the object's 'thing-ness'. This is to do with the real essence of the design, the reason for it to be born, the purpose of it being there, which revolves around why we humans use each article.

The initial purpose of a jug is to keep liquid inside. If it does it effectively, it's a good design, but that's not the real essence of it, which is as a tool to repeat a ritual: serving a drink. Though a coffeepot such as Rossi's La Conica (right) can be beautiful, what it's really for is the ritual of offering coffee to someone as a way of communicating. A breadbasket by Sottsass might be useful because it's made from stainless steel and holds bread, but what brings it closer to perfection is something more. Its woven form, reminding us of old-fashioned breadbaskets passed around the family dinner table, helps with the ritual of breaking bread.

These designs are pure acts of poetry, but at the same time accessible. Philippe Starck's products are 70 per cent surprise. People are immediately attracted to them; he plays with the attention-grabbing elements of his designs. The real goal for a design for objects in the house is not just to be understood by aficionados, but to be popular and to have a real effect on people's lives.

 Alberto Alessi is head of the Alessi design group.

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Sexy lectures
fields.trailText: Sexy lectures.
fields.body:
Those interminably dull monologues on particle physics, given by tweedy dandruff-ridden Open University types with leather elbow patches, the only fit response to which is to doodle stick-people engaged in baroque acts of torture in the margins of one's rough book? That's right. But crank up that overhead projector and get with the beat, Daddy-o: standing at a lectern and talking for quite a long time is the new rock'n'roll.

How so? It started with last year's reading tours with Julian Cope dispensing gaudily clad transcendental wisdom from The Modern Antiquarian , and Duke of Dope Howard Marks, just visible through the fug as he extrapolated from Mr Nice . Then the Dimbleby Lecture was given by torrid Tate director Sir Nicholas Serota on the joys of modern art, and the resulting controversy meant the disquisition-you-need-a-strong-cigarette-after had come of age.

And now? London's South Bank Centre (020 7960 4242) is striking while the iron's hot with two titillating series: Team GB? In Search of a British Identity (23 Jan-13 Feb) and Sorting the Men from the Boys: Masculinity Today (15 Feb-27 Mar). The former gets off to a less-than-priapic start with Rankin' Roger Scruton mourning England's passing, but quickly builds up a head of steam when Late Review stalwart Ekow Eshun chairs a debate on multicultural society with Billy Bragg, among others. The latter, meanwhile, sprints out of the blocks with Anthony Clare looking at male insecurity, gets clammier as Joe Jackson discusses masculinity in the music business, and climaxes with Beryl Bainbridge probing the male urge to explore. All this and Hanif Kureishi - the lecture circuit's answer to Ricky Martin - to boot.

Lectures we'd like to see: New Perspectives on Bernoulli's Principle of Fluid Dynamics, by Geri Halliwell; I Wouldn't Say My Mother-In-Law Was Fat, But... - Contextual Irony in the Age of Hypermedia, by Bernard Manning.

fields.headline: The golden oldies
fields.trailText: 'I wake up to discover that my wife has already broken my New Year resolution not to introduce more than eight children into the house before a male parent has had the chance to think up a plausible reason to vacate it.'
fields.body:
I wake up to discover that my wife has already broken my New Year resolution not to introduce more than eight children into the house before a male parent has had the chance to think up a plausible reason to vacate it, but how else is she supposed to offer free unlimited crèche facilities to anyone she has ever met in the supermarket on the grounds that you never know when we might have enough money left to go to the Comet sale one year, and where would we be without a few morally indebted neighbours to have our four miscreants round at their house for a few short hours running riot and eating them out of Penguin biscuits?

But then I suddenly remember I have my own alternative pressing engagement, owing to my mum ringing up on Wednesday to give me five minutes' notice that it's their golden wedding anniversary and dad is being rushed out of hospital for the occasion, so if I do just fancy popping hundreds of miles up the motorway and back the same day at the drop of a hat maybe I could find room in the car for the old sofa that John and Fiona didn't want but which will go nicely in the dining room where dad has to sleep, it being just the right green to go with the cushion on his commode. But golden wedding! It doesn't seem 25 years since I missed their silver one. Naturally I'm quite keen to make an early departure from this temple of chaos but my wife is making such a banquet of taking all the seats out of our Fiat people carrier and unscrewing the legs off the sofa and carrying it single-handedly downstairs in grudging deference to my poor left arm, which has done itself a mischief trying to keep up with the right one on the rowing machine in our local gym, where they are offering injury holidays throughout January for people who can't afford to go skiing.

'Hurry up,' I suggest, unnecessarily holding the tailgate up while she opines that there is indeed something to be said for observing the ritual of congratulating married couples on having gone another year without killing each other. Which is all very amusing but did it cross her mind to get a card? The answer is no. Apparently they are, after all, my parents. But luckily we do have a bottle of Asti spumanti that just needs the raffle ticket taking off, plus a giant box of chocolates with only one layer missing left over from Christmas, and the children have cobbled together a set of unstable golden candlesticks out of clay and glitter so that my mum can set the curtains on fire when the electric meter runs out.

Ten minutes later I'm thundering up the M11, with just the eldest to keep me entertained with his monologue on the endless variety of 007's novelty weaponry in the Nintendo 64 version of The World Is Not Enough and the arm of a Habitat three-seater clomping into the back of my head every time I put the brakes on. The journey seems very long, but at last we are pulling up outside Mum's and putting CrookLocks on all the wheels. I am slightly concerned about my dad having to drag the sofa up the icy path on his Zimmer frame - he is quite active for someone who has had four strokes - but my brother and sisters are here with all their towering grown-up sons and daughters, and I'm sure they won't mind coming out to push in eight different directions at once as soon they have finished admiring my new I, Claudius haircut, which according to Bunny, my barber, is just the thing to avoid waking up one day to find Arthur Scargill staring out from the bathroom mirror.

My dad is thrilled with the chocolates. Unfortunately, he is not allowed to eat any of them. Mum says if he has too much sugar he gets up in the middle of the night and starts getting dressed for work and she has to run down and remind him that he retired 11 years ago. 'That's what you think,' he says. Though it is lovely to have him home, Mum says. There are sausage rolls and quartered pork pies and cups of tea and fruitcake, and the house full of children. Happily, nearly all of us are over 21.

'Hurry up,' I suggest, unnecessarily holding the tailgate up while she opines that there is indeed something to be said for observing the ritual of congratulating married couples on having gone another year without killing each other. Which is all very amusing but did it cross her mind to get a card? The answer is no. Apparently they are, after all, my parents. But luckily we do have a bottle of Asti spumanti that just needs the raffle ticket taking off, plus a giant box of chocolates with only one layer missing left over from Christmas, and the children have cobbled together a set of unstable golden candlesticks out of clay and glitter so that my mum can set the curtains on fire when the electric meter runs out. Ten minutes later I'm thundering up the M11, with just the eldest to keep me entertained with his monologue on the endless variety of 007's novelty weaponry in the Nintendo 64 version of The World Is Not Enough and the arm of a Habitat three-seater clomping into the back of my head every time I put the brakes on. The journey seems very long, but at last we are pulling up outside Mum's and putting CrookLocks on all the wheels. I am slightly concerned about my dad having to drag the sofa up the icy path on his Zimmer frame - he is quite active for someone who has had four strokes - but my brother and sisters are here with all their towering grown-up sons and daughters, and I'm sure they won't mind coming out to push in eight different directions at once as soon they have finished admiring my new I, Claudius haircut, which according to Bunny, my barber, is just the thing to avoid waking up one day to find Arthur Scargill staring out from the bathroom mirror. My dad is thrilled with the chocolates. Unfortunately, he is not allowed to eat any of them. Mum says if he has too much sugar he gets up in the middle of the night and starts getting dressed for work and she has to run down and remind him that he retired 11 years ago. 'That's what you think,' he says. Though it is lovely to have him home, Mum says. There are sausage rolls and quartered pork pies and cups of tea and fruitcake, and the house full of children. Happily, nearly all of us are over 21. phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

webTitle: The cost of... Cooking like a pro

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... Cooking like a pro
fields.trailText: ... Cooking like a pro
fields.body:
There are more celebrity chefs out there than you can shake a spatula at. Although these people are unnaturally accomplished - chef, restaurateur, author, journalist and television presenter in one svelte package - don't be shy about competing for a piece of the action. Not only should your kitchen be spacious enough to accommodate people wielding TV cameras and boom mics, a food stylist and a group of friends ostentatiously enjoying themselves, but your equipment should appear suitably professional. A large chef's knife, such as one from the Global range (£79), is essential and will account for some authentic scars, too. Le Creuset's cast-iron cookware is a sound investment, with sauté pans, for instance, costing up to £70.

Agas are the curvaceous pinnacle of cooking technology: four ovens, two hotplates and a sturdy bar to which you can tether small, muddy children while they thaw or dry after a day outdoors. There are those who will tell you that buying an Aga is lunacy. They will cry that there are no temperature controls, that these £6,000 iron hulks weigh more than an elephant. However, these people have obviously never used one.

Bear in mind that an oil-fuelled Aga will burn at least £500 of oil each year and that you will also have to pay for any building work. A cheaper option is a gas range, at £3,000. Of course the most important point is to sound convincing. A good cookbook, like Leith's Cookery Bible , should explain where to start with a sabayon and how to spatchcock a bird. But rather than enrolling at Leith's famous school, take it easy with a five-day residential course at Raymond Blanc's Manoir aux Quat' Saisons for a mere £1,675.

Finally, you won't get far without an idiosyncrasy, or if you prefer, a Unique Selling Point - it can be something as simple as an irritating catchphrase ('pukka'), an absurd haircut, a flamboyant temper or a drink problem.

Four-door oil-fuelled Aga £6,275
Gas range £3,000
Cook's knife £79
Cookery course from £1,200
Le Creuset pans from £40
Total from £8,000

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.body:
If posters are no longer enough to decorate your walls, it's time to buy some art. Which can be harder than it sounds for first-timers. Galleries can be intimidating for new buyers, and there are so many of them in London, it's hard to know where to start. You can take days wandering from gallery to gallery without ever spotting anything you like.

The answer is ART2001, the London Contemporary Art Fair. Britain's largest and most important art fair has been running for 13 years now, and attracts more than 100 galleries from all over the world. It offers the chance to see a wide range of work in the relatively compact setting of the Business Design Centre in north London, enabling you to start to discover what you like - and what you don't. The atmosphere is friendly, and even daft questions are welcomed (I know, I've asked plenty of them). Some of the 40,000 visitors just come to browse, but everything is on sale, at prices ranging from £100 to £150,000.

The organisers say that this year's event has a particularly strong showing from cutting-edge British galleries, with several new exhibitors. There is also work from new online galleries, such as Counter-Editions and BritArt.com. The Contemporary Art Society is there to provide advice for buyers, and there's even a Personal Shopper Service.

But when you're starting out, don't get too hung up on buying art as an investment. Instead concentrate on getting something you really, really love. After all, you're the one who's going to have to live with it.

 ART2001 runs from 17-21 January, with late-night shopping to 9pm on Thursday, at the Business Design Centre, 52 Upper Street, London N1 (information 020 7288 6005; ticket hotline 0870 739 9500). Tickets £8.50 in advance, £10 on the door. This week's 'Life Support' features Paul Martin and Paul Hedge, who started Hales Gallery together and who will be showing at ART2001.

fields.headline: Love for sale
fields.trailText: 'How long will it be, I wonder, before it becomes de rigueur for single men and women to hire publicists for their personal lives?'
fields.body:
How long will it be, I wonder, before it becomes de rigueur for single men and women to hire publicists for their personal lives? Someone to do the hard sell, let the world know that they are on the market, and how superb, 'available', unmissable they are. Certainly, it's a fact of romantic life that, subconsciously or not, we all use what we've got. Our looks, our brains, our wits, our accomplishments, our friends, anything, really, to make ourselves seem more attractive than the next person. Just as in professional life, the mating ritual is increasingly less about self-expression than self-promotion. The only difference being that sooner or later your clothes are going to come off.

Some people find this self-aggrandising process good sport, the spice of life, the point - others, like myself, find it slightly sickening. Somehow, within me, behind the cynical frozen layers of modern femininity, there seems to be this wild-eyed fairy woman, dancing about, waving a flower, holding out for the kind of love that doesn't necessarily look good on paper. Depending on your view, that's either sweetly romantic or idiotically naive, maybe a combination of both. These days, the pressure seems to be on, for all of us, but especially women, to 'shop' wisely, cold bloodedly, for a suitable mate, just as one would for any other commodity. Moreover, how 'well' you do seems to depend entirely on how romantically ambitious you are.

The weirdness doesn't stop there. Maybe you saw the latest study about human attraction which claimed that, subconsciously, good-looking women chose impressive mates on the strength of how fabulous their babies were going to be. Plainer women were said to be attracted to less impressive men, on the grounds that they'd be less likely to stray. So this would be the psychosexual version of cutting your coat according to your cloth. Good-looking, confident girls get the good-looking, successful guys, and the Plain Janes with low self-esteem get the boring jerks who can't get laid to save their lives. The bottom line being that romantic ambition, or lack of it, on the part of the woman dictates the state of play at every stage of the game.

All of which sounds very convincing until you remember that the vast majority of women have mutable self-esteem, with a twin capacity for self-deprecation and delusion. It's entirely possible for the same woman to feel like one of the the ugliest freaks in the world one second, and borderline-beautiful the next. Which somewhat makes a mockery of the argument that how beautiful a woman feels she is dictates which mate she will end up with. In reality, it's always been more a case of how beautiful he thinks she is. The good-looking man choosing the good-looking woman, rather than vice versa. On a similar note, it is becoming clear that, whatever we like to think, women, especially when young and even in these post-ladette times, still tend to be the 'chosen' rather than the 'choosers,' in the sexual arena.

There are exceptions, obviously, but women seem to spend the bulk of their romantic lives not so much choosing a mate from all the men available on the planet as automatically selecting the one they like the best from the exclusive pool of men who have already presented themselves as interested. So, in reality, female 'choice' is limited to those men who have already chosen them. Certainly, when I think about my own life, I don't recall hunting aggressively for men I might like. Like most women, I've tended to just sort of mooch about, quasi passively, making yes/no decisions about the ones who liked me. Which, when you think about it, is absolutely bizarre, like being told you're allowed to choose any outfit you like for the evening, but then volunteering to be locked in one shop where the style of clothing has been dictated by someone else's taste.

It's a turning point for any woman when she twigs that these self-imposed restrictions have been in place for her entire adult romantic life. All of a sudden, she realises that her 'type' might not be her type at all, but merely the type who is attracted to her. Suddenly, whether she feels beautiful, plain or both, she can start making her own decisions about the sort of person she wants to be with, and stop putting herself at the mercy of the whims of others. Simultaneously, it becomes clear that while men have traditionally hunted for partners, it's not only because they have to, the poor biologically tortured lambs, but also because they want to, because they end up with someone better that way. The point a woman realises this is probably where real romantic ambition kicks in.

fields.headline: Donizetti on a Lambretta
fields.trailText:
The Elixir of Love Opera North, Leeds
Park Lane Group New Year Series Purcell Room, London SW1
fields.body:
The Elixir of Love Opera North, Leeds
Park Lane Group New Year Series Purcell Room, London SW1

Donizetti's The Elixir of Love, premiered in Milan in 1832, had a roughly contemporary setting. Daniel Slater's Opera North production relocates the action to the Fifties and in the symbolic code of opera stagings, 'Fifties Italy' means heat, sensuality, a little light skulduggery, bright skies and even brighter people. So it is here. It doesn't matter whether that's what the Fifties were really like in Italy; this is a magical place where the sort of things that go on in nineteenth-century Italian comic opera might really happen.

So Slater's choice of location works well enough, and Robert Innes Hopkins's designs radiate everything that we northern Europeans might think of as Mediterranean warmth. The risk is that we spend too much time spotting authentic period detail when we should be attending to the drama. Sure enough, there's the Gaggia espresso machine, and here comes an echt-Fifties scooter.

Donizetti labelled The Elixir not an opera buffa but an opera comica, which suggests a certain distance, albeit short, from standard knockabout. Our hero, Nemorino, may not be a sophisticate, but through drinking Dulcamara's bogus elixir (plain old wine) he learns a little about himself and about his beloved Adina. Nor is Dulcamara simply a travelling quack - he's a peddler of dreams.

Of buffoonery there's little trace, yet Slater misses few opportunities to introduce a bit of slapstick, mainly via the chorus. At least one of the ladies, drunk in premature celebration of Adina's marriage to the wrong man, vomits in her handbag, while Dulcamara gets so excited talking to Adina that he has to exit concealing his erection. Nothing wrong in adding extra humour, but these are the wrong gags in the wrong opera.

I saw last Tuesday's performance so perhaps I was suffering a curmudgeonly bout brought on by the lunar eclipse; the rest of the audience found it funny enough. Certainly, musical values are high. David Parry works well in the bel canto repertoire, knowing when to temper refinement with a hint of vulgarity. He has the orchestra right inside Donizetti's style, even when the vocal characterisation isn't wholly idiomatic.

Running counter to the overall tendency, Richard Whitehouse makes Belcore more subtle than usual; he is less the preening dullard, more a genuine contender for Adina's hand, the kind of sailor that all the nice girls were at one time supposed to like. Christopher Purves renders Dulcamara so smooth-tongued that he comes to believe his own sales pitch, and if Paul Nilon's Nemorino is always very British in timbre, his 'Una furtiva lagrima' is a properly ardent expression of hope against the odds.

As for Mary Hegarty, she looks and sounds every inch the part of Adina. Bossy one minute, vulnerable the next, she has the whole town wrapped around her finger. Why, even Dulcamara perks up at sight of her. Hegarty attacks her music with real gusto, occasionally missing true centre but with the skill to carry her through. It's a performance to win over even such a sourpuss as this.

Setting Donizetti in the Fifties counts as modernising. For the annual Park Lane Group Young Artists New Year Series, the Fifties are vieux jeu . In 10 concerts over five days, this year's performers offered 61 pieces, only two of them pre-dating the Seventies, and including eight world premieres. Commendable, but it doesn't bring in the crowds, even though the programming favours the well-behaved over the unruly. Minimalism and electro-acoustics might never have happened.

Still, there were rewarding performances, none more impressive than the solo violin recital that kicked things off last Monday. So-Ock Kim is 18 years old and knows no fear. She played Brian Ferneyhough's Intermedio alla ciaconne as if it was an ecstatic cadenza she was improvising on the spot, spraying vertiginous glissandi and expansive flourishes in all directions. The range of colours at her disposal is dazzling, from the siren wail that opened the Ferneyhough to the breathy harmonies of Nicholas Maw's Solo Sonata. Throw in some Elliott Carter for good measure and you have a genuine risk-taking performance.

Later that evening, the saxophonist Sarah James premiered Philip Cashian's Songs From a Still World, a spacious, slow piece that grows from three carefully placed notes, hauntingly woody of tone. Accompanied by Grace Huang's piano, James found the right cocktail hour nonchalance for Richard Rodney Bennett's Sonata, and something earthier in Brian Elias's Pythikos Nomos.

On Wednesday, the chamber group Chroma became a quintet for Diana Burrell's Double Image, a work that starts piercingly high for every instrument before the piano gradually pulls things down to earth. Burrell uses the instruments less as a unit, than as a set of combinations she permutates restlessly. One moment, flute and clarinet combine eerily, the next, the pianist is pounding away at the low strings that Burrell has tampered with so as to produce a mighty thunder.

Chroma was followed by Alexandra Wood, a fiery violinist who, in company with pianist/composer Huw Watkins, gave a wonderfully assured account of Hugh Wood's Poem. Here the piano provides a kind of emotional support for the overwrought violin, and Alexandra Wood does overwrought very well indeed. Earlier, she negotiated the pitfalls of David Matthews's Three Studies, producing a wild rush of sound that any folk fiddler would have been proud of.

I may have problems with the range of repertoire that the Park Lane Group concerts offer, but there's nothing wrong with the emerging talent for which they are such a valuable showcase.

The Elixir of Love at the Grand Theatre, Leeds, 19 Jan - 6 Feb, (0113 222 6222), then touring.

webTitle: Quiet please, I can't hear myself think

fields.headline: Quiet please, I can't hear myself think
fields.standfirst: The new wave of US bands are loud, but just as introspective as the UK soft rockers
fields.trailText: The new wave of US bands are loud, but just as introspective as the UK soft rockers
fields.body:
The choice facing the British rock fan in 2001 is, on the face of it, distinct.

In the blue corner: the homegrown troubadour, acoustic guitar in hand, extolling the virtues of classic songwriting. The success of soft-rockers Coldplay last year has helped spawn a dozen more artists in the same introspective, semi-acoustic mould. Up-and-coming bands such as Alfie and Starsailor are happy to eschew the electric dynamics of rock for something more folky and pastoral.

'Right now,' says Andy Ross, head of Food Records and the man who signed Blur, 'we've got this post-Coldplay hangover where British record companies are signing anything with acoustic guitars because Coldplay sold a lot of records.'

In the red corner: an energetic bunch of rockers who represent the first serious American challenge to Britpop since the pulsating pomp of grunge at the start of the Nineties.

In the States, nu-metal bands such as Queens of the Stone Age, At the Drive-In, (And You Will Know Us By the) Trail of Dead and Amen have challenged the muscle-bound MTV dominance of rap-rockers such as Limp Bizkit and Kid Rock by creating a less macho and more thoughtful, angst-ridden alternative. There's no real stylistic link between these four leading groups, beyond their determination to provide an original rock alternative to the corporate rap-rock homogeneity of recent years. It's an attitude that should enable them to sell lots of units over here, too.

Amen look like the band most likely to succeed. They peddle a loud, angry punk sound, but do it fronted by one of the most beguiling singers in recent memory - Casey Chaos. Chaos is a veteran LA punk who suffers from a serious lung condition induced by teenage drug abuse, and uses songs such as 'Piss Virus' and 'Dead on the Bible' to rail against perceived injustices. He underlined his tortured artist credentials at Amen's most recent London gig by slowly slicing his arm open with a broken bottle.

If that's a long way from jocular chart-toppers Limp Bizkit, it seems further still from the bucolic yearnings of the new Brit groups. It's the aggression and volume of nu-metal that has seduced American fans, and its bands are about to enter the battle for the souls and wallets of British teenagers.

'There are a lot of 15-year-old kids who are into these new American bands,' says Ross. 'It's like two parallel musical universes, because there doesn't seem to be any middle ground between that new semi-acoustic British stuff and the new heavy American rock.'

Curiously, though, some industry observers actually believe the opposite, that there is, in fact, a transatlantic consensus brewing, despite the musical chasm. That theory should be tested on the NME Brats Tour later this month, with a bill that has Amen appearing directly after the folk jangle of Mancunians Alfie and the group most tipped for Coldplay-ish success, Starsailor.

According to NME deputy editor James Oldham: 'Both Amen and Starsailor are going for the same emotional response, they're both trying to hit the same buttons.'

Paul Fig, guitarist in Amen, says: 'In America, it's very easy to do that rap-rock thing: get a DJ, throw in some heavy guitars and get on MTV heavy-rotation. You can make a lot of money that way because kids have figured out they like to jump up and down to it. But what you're seeing with bands like ourselves and At the Drive-In, and I guess these British bands... is something with a lot more soul and passion, something deeper.'

Ross Robinson, producer of Amen and At the Drive-In, also sees a definite connection: 'Amen project their feelings, their angst, out wardly, and it is extreme. But those British bands are the inner part of that same shell; they're soft, but the songs and emotions are just as valid and moving. Amen aren't any different from my favourite British band, Doves. Playing Doves is like having God in the room. Playing Amen is like him blowing the house down.'

According to Robinson: 'These honest, pure groups could destroy all this terrible corporate rock that's polluted music recently. It reminds me of when Nirvana and Oasis both came out and destroyed all those horrible stadium groups in the early Nineties.'

Perhaps, then, we'll look back on this period as the dawn of a new era, a time when a fresh consensus took hold of new guitar groups on both sides of the Atlantic - only at different volumes.

Young British musicians realise they just can't rock as well as the Americans, says Oldham: 'There are a lot of ripe new American groups breaking through and trying to add substance to rock, and a lot of exciting new British acts with similar aims.

'I don't think music buyers should be scared of the choice. They should be excited.'

The NME Brats Tour featuring Amen, Starsailor and Alfie starts on 21 January in Glasgow

Rival band Slipknot, who keep a rotting bird in a jar, which they inhale before vomiting over each other on stage.

What are they like? Clean-cut, melodic Radio 1 stalwarts. Favour acoustic guitars and plaintive lyrics.

Famous for Outselling Radiohead last year. They avoid traditional rock star behaviour. 'Pretending to be "a bit mad" would just be sad,' says guitarist Jon Buckland.

webTitle: Film of the week: Cast Away

fields.headline: And your one luxury item is...
fields.standfirst: Some desert island castaways choose a piano or golf clubs to take with them. Others have a TV crew recording their every move. All Tom Hanks gets when he's washed up is a volleyball called Wilson
fields.trailText: Some desert island castaways choose a piano or golf clubs to take with them. Others have a TV crew recording their every move. All Tom Hanks gets when he's washed up is a volleyball called Wilson.
fields.body:
Cast Away (144 mins, 12) Directed by Robert Zemeckis; starring Tom Hanks, Helen Hunt, Nick Searcy

From Shakespeare's The Tempest and Daniel Defoe's Robinson Crusoe to William Golding's Lord of the Flies and the 1964 science-fiction movie Robinson Crusoe on Mars, writers have been intrigued by the notion of people cast ashore on desert islands. Audiences share this fascination and every week since Roy Plomley devised Desert Island Discs in 1942 several million listeners have tuned in to hear how various celebrities would cope with loneliness and privation, and what eight gramophone records they'd take with them to ease the pain.

The latest exercise in the Crusoe genre is Cast Away, which reunites Robert Zemeckis and Tom Hanks, the director and star of Forrest Gump, which was, of course, an updating of another eighteenth-century moral fiction, Voltaire's Candide.

Hanks plays Chuck Noland, a workaholic FedEx systems engineer who spends his time flying around the world trying to make his company's parcel delivery service faster than that of its rivals. We first meet him a couple of blocks from Red Square trying to imbue FedEx's Moscow branch with the Stakhanovite spirit. 'We live or die by the clock,' he tells them.

Back home in Memphis, Tennessee, he has a fiancée, Kelly (Helen Hunt), a research scientist working on her doctorate and, except for a nagging tooth, all seems well with his life. After a pre-Christmas dinner, he promises to be home for New Year and possible nuptials, after he's accompanied a Fed-Ex cargo plane to the Antipodes. Unfortunately, the plane loses radio contact with Tahiti in a storm and in a superbly extended crash sequence that leaves you searching for a seat belt, Chuck is washed up on a small island, the only survivor.

Robinson Crusoe actually had it lucky with a wrecked ship from which to salvage for rifles, gunpowder, tools, clothes, timber and so on. He also had a rather grand island to explore, to map and to colonise. Chuck Noland, whose name suggests someone dumped in no man's land, has wound up on a hard place as inhospitably rocky as the one that provided the briefest of sanctuaries to the eponymous hero of William Golding's brilliant and remorseless Pincher Martin.

Chuck has nothing except for a few random parcels, containing a woman's party dress, a pair of ice-skates, a volleyball, some VHS cassettes and a document annulling a marriage. When the body of his dead pilot is washed up, he keeps the man's boots but can't bring himself to remove the belt. Crusoe managed to retrieve some of the ship's instruments; Chuck has a fine pocket watch, a family heirloom given him by his fiancée, whose photo is in the cover.

The first days on the island are well managed - the discovery of coconuts, the shaping of tools, the hope of imminent rescue, the descent into despair. The film's colour is cold, unromantic, quite unlike the gorgeous Technicolor hues of the 1949 (British) and 1980 (American) versions of The Blue Lagoon, both shot in the same area of the South Seas.

There are neat details here. The retrieved volleyball is given a face painted in blood, named Wilson after its manufacturer, and becomes a cross between a mute companion and a fetishist Cargo Cult object. An ice skate becomes a primitive dental tool for the most painful exercise in sadomasochistic orthodontics since Marathon Man.

Unlike Crusoe, Noland defecates (hiding behind a bush) and urinates boldly into the sea, and it's during a moonlight slash that he spots a distant light which raises rapidly dashed hopes of rescue. Of his sexual yearnings, we hear nothing and, unlike Crusoe, he has little in the way of larger social or spiritual experiences.

There's no frisson like the solitary footstep on the sand. No modern Man Friday appears. In fact, there are no unforgettable images that lodge in the mind like those scenes in Luis Buñuel's Robinson Crusoe, where the hero climbs a hill to shout out the Twenty-third Psalm as a defiant challenge to an indifferent universe, or where Friday innocently puts on a woman's dress and throws Crusoe into a perverse crisis of revulsion and attraction.

Cast Away, in fact, jumps four years from the first terrible weeks to the final period, when Noland has adapted to his new environment, but is preparing to escape on a raft. The big change is not internal (we never discover his religion, his politics or his aesthetic interests other than his love of Elvis Presley) but purely physical.

Tom Hanks spent 18 months getting into condition for the second part of the movie under Dr Paul McAuley, credited as 'Weight Loss Adviser', and the American Humane Society saw to it that in the scenes involving the skewering of crabs and other foodstuffs 'no animal was harmed'.

To reveal that Hanks makes it home is merely to acknowledge that this is a big-budget Hollywood picture, produced by its star, and there is a drawn-out, sentimental coda that more or less re-enacts Tennyson's 'Enoch Arden', that great Victorian poem about a desert-island survivor returning to discover that life has changed and his wife has remarried.

Weirdly, however, this finale turns into a tribute to Noland's employers, and the real-life boss of the organisation, Paul Smith (billed 'As Himself'), turns up to welcome Chuck back to 'the FedEx family'. Unlike FedEx, however, Cast Away finishes up delivering a neatly wrapped, somewhat disappointing package rather slowly.

webTitle: Foreign language films: A tiger burning bright

fields.headline: A tiger burning bright
fields.standfirst: Ang Lee's martial arts masterpiece is not just a critical smash; crowds are queuing to see it and it could change forever the fortunes of foreign films
fields.trailText: Ang Lee's martial arts masterpiece is not just a critical smash; crowds are queuing to see it and it could change forever the fortunes of foreign films.
fields.body:
It is the foreign language film that is more than just threatening to break the mould - it has karate-chopped right through convention in the opening week of its run. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon refutes all the pessimists who believed that a mass audience would never pay to see a subtitled feature, let alone one about troubled identities in Qing dynasty China.

Ang Lee's film has taken £970,000 in less than a week in British cinemas and has seen queues winding round cinemas across the country. It may even win an Oscar nomination for best picture, the first time a film made in a language other than English has ever been recognised in this way.

'I saw it in a huge multiplex,' said Rupert Preston, the managing director of the British independent distributor Metrodome. 'It was absolutely packed. And it really wasn't the kind of audience you would expect to see at a foreign language movie.'

The martial arts action and fast tempo of Crouching Tiger have obviously helped it bridge the genre gap and experts now confidently expect it to be the biggest grossing foreign language film ever.

Box office like this puts it in a different league to the usual 'crossover' fare. True, we may have sobbed in large numbers at Cinema Paradiso and Il Postino, and we may have savoured the mordant humour of Life Is Beautiful, but, let's face it, none of these Italian offerings featured a fight staged atop a giant bamboo forest. As a result, they stayed inside the repertory cinema and the arthouse, grossing £1.02 million, £1.27m and £3.03m respectively.

However, according to Daniel Battsek, managing director of Buena Vista International, British audiences may be about to change for good.

'When you get a movie like this, it acts as a vanguard for all foreign language films,' he says, while admitting that his own market research has always underlined the fact that audiences don't generally like to 'read' their movies. Buena Vista's Life Is Beautiful managed to overcome the subtitle prejudice in 1998, but not on the scale of Crouching Tiger 's victory.

'This time many of those queueing will not have seen a film with subtitles before and suddenly this will not seem such a bad thing to them,' says Battsek.

Britain, he notes, has always been gratifyingly reluctant to accept dubbed films.

'In Europe, they are used to it because they see it all the time on television, too. In this country, it is completely different. We released Nikita in a dubbed version and a subtitled version and nobody came to see the dubbed film.'

The main point about the arrival of Crouching Tiger, as Battsek stresses, is that it exposes the silliness of the idea of 'foreign language' as a genre category. After all, would someone who enjoyed the French comedy Les Visiteurs necessarily enjoy Ingmar Bergman?

The future lies, as ever, in the hands of the distributors, who may well have been emboldened by the success of this Mandarin blockbuster.

The trouble is, if you call for a wider release for every single foreign language film, then you have fallen into the enemy trap and lumped them all together. What is needed, instead, in this fight is a 'strong but supple' weapon, rather like the 400-year-old sword, Green Destiny, at the centre of Lee's story.

Regardless of language, the subject of a film is still the key factor for distributors. They should be mindful, though, of the meaning of the old Chinese proverb from which Crouching Tiger takes its name - often in life, the real nature of things remains hidden.

fields.headline: Happily after everything
fields.standfirst: You've got money, perfect breasts and the man of your dreams - feeling confident?
fields.trailText: The Secret Life of Happiness | Living By The Book: The Rules | Perfect Breasts
fields.body:
The Secret Life of Happiness BBC1
Living By The Book: The Rules C4
Perfect Breasts C4
To Diet For C4
Confidence Lab BBC2

New Year, New You. Out with the old, in with the firm and shiny, taut and trim... this was TV's designated National Inadequacy Week. 'Happiness is something we all want,' warned Nigel Planer's voiceover at the start of BBC1's The Secret Life of Happiness. So, will more money make us happy? Well, here was media-friendly, Schadenfreude-inducing Lottery winner Karl Crompton (£10.9 million) to tell us why it won't: 'The main problem has been jealousy!' Karl gave a million pounds each to his mum, dad and brother and now flies helicopters, drives fast cars, sponsors a motorbike team and is 'project managing' the completion of the obligatory Lottery dream home.

Unfortunately, he has also lost his best friend - the friend who thought £100,000 was a tangible measure of their mateship. But Karl had told him: 'If I give you £100,000, do I give £80,000 to someone else I've known for less time? Do I put a price on all your heads?' Personally, I think, Karl might succeed in dampening some of this envy if he avoided appearing quite so often on television.

The best advertisement for happiness seemed to be Kelly Holmes, thrilled with her Olympic 800m bronze simply because she hadn't expected a medal at all (tip: set yourself relatively low goals and then accidentally exceed them). Or perhaps happiness might come as part of the DNA package, especially if one was born as half of a pair of irritatingly giggly identical twins: 'What makes you laugh most, Daphne?' asked Barbara. 'You!' replied Daphne, laughing. This year, then, I shall enter the London marathon in the expectation that I will pass out with cramp long before I've waddled a mile. Imagine my joy, laughter and the accompanying serotonin-high if I were to complete two miles. Weak with happiness just thinking about it - maybe I'll just carry on thinking about it after all.

My word, I'm feeling optimistic now. Got a bad track record when it comes to relationships? Never fear: Ellen Fein and Sherrie Schneider are two terrifyingly thin and fearsome Manhattanites - a cross between party-scene extras from Sex And The City and Channel 5's no-nonsense House Doctor, Ann Maurice - who wrote a book called The Rules which promises to bludgeon the man of one's dreams into marriage, whether he wants it or not. On hand to test The Rules, in C4's Living By The Book, were three women, including Karen, 28, a divorced mother of one, who tended to be just a wee bit needy 'and wifey' with boyfriends.

'I'm shocked,' said Ellen as she watched a video of Karen preparing an elaborate dinner for David, a man she'd known only a month. 'You only make dinner on his birthday,' agreed a disapproving Sherrie. 'She sounds desperate.' 'No man marries you because you're making a perfect whatever-she's-making. This is a Monday ? This is so not meant to be happening. He's getting a frightened look on his face,' raved Ellen.

Soon, however, thanks to at least some of 'the rules' (Karen ignored 'wear short skirts and get a nose job', but went along with 'always end a phone call first', 'don't accept a Saturday night date after Wednesday' and 'be a creature unlike any other') she had David wrapped around her little finger; emotional foreplay that would, apparently, result in her getting something even shinier wrapped around another finger. Then David invited Karen away for a week in Tunisia, discovered her copy of The Rules and they argued non-stop. Karen dumped him a month later which, for a former serial dumpee, was presumably a victory of sorts.

There had been so much press surrounding Channel 4's Perfect Breasts that, to be honest, I was feeling desperately inadequate long before I saw the show. Unlike all my female columnar peers, not only had I not yet written a thousand frothing words about the tragedy of teenage girls wanting breast implants but I was still a pathetically unfashionable 36B. Obviously, something had to give and bigger boobs could well be the key to my elusive happiness. After all, having lived with these ones most of my life, they're starting to bore me - and what self- respecting woman wears the same shoes they were wearing 20 years ago?

'Life's tough when you've got no boobs,' intoned several serious, doll-faced young women. While 19-year-old Laura's floppy funbags were getting her down so much she was starting to scowl like Patsy Palmer. 'I thought swimming might do it,' said Laura's dad, Gill, 'but Laura can't swim. 'How would you feel if you had a small penis?' said Laura. 'It's not the same thing at all,' said Gill. 'Yes it is.' 'No it isn't...'

Happily, however, Laura's mum had the full measure of her daughter's misery and took her off to Harley Street where Laura gently fondled 350 cubic centimetres of silicone. I was poised to make the call myself - at least until the operation, which was both hilarious and horrific by turns. No, fresh perky breasts might well bring me considerable joy, but I am not ready to have my fleshy scatter-cushions restuffed quite so brutally. Apparently, they need replacing quite often, too, but if you can't buy the pads in the John Lewis sale and do it yourself, I'm really not interested.

Perhaps a New Year diet will do the trick? 'Dieting's like being with Liz Taylor,' said Arabella 'Does my bum look big in this?' Weir, in Channel 4's To Diet For. 'You must know from the start that it's not going to work...' From flat-chested flappers to Twiggy and Kate Moss, a century of skinny-minnies were paraded for our envious delectation: 'Women look better slim,' said an unrepentant Mary Quant, 'and clothes look better if some of the bones show'. Sadly, I don't think she was talking about underwiring.

This was an amusing programme, with a pithy commentary from Mel Giedroyc, but, so keen was it to trash the concept of faddy diets - something ghastly from the 1960s called The New Sego Spoon-Up from Pet, to SlimFast, the F-Plan, the Cambridge and The Zone - in favour of witty soundbites from Ms Weir, that even when it came across a diet that works, it didn't dare spoil the fun. Last year, reader, I lost a stone in three weeks thanks to Dr Atkins' high protein, low-carb Diet Revolution and felt great, even before I'd found out that Jennifer Aniston, Anna Wintour and Nigella Lawson were all devotees. Nigella was featured on To Diet For but they weren't about to let a cute documentary idea get in the way of the truth: that you really can eat, as Ms Lawson admitted, 'egg and bacon for breakfast... butter sauces with steak... and as much fat and protein as you like', and lose weight. Perhaps the best short-term advice, though, came from Weir: 'Never eat in the nude.'

Fully dressed (with a smile), abdominals rippling and a packet of trusty macadamia nuts to hand, perhaps it is only my unhappy head that still needs fixing? Time to check into groovy country hotel, Babington House, with BBC2's Confidence Lab (and, in a very good week for resting comedians doing voiceover work, Dawn French).

The first episode in this new series concentrated on instilling confidence into Nigel the 'lazy-minded' chef and Maria, a charity worker who is so terrified of public speaking that she vomits and pulls out her hair.

Coached and coaxed by a battalion of therapists - psychiatrists, business psychologists, body language experts, communications coaches, voice coaches, dance therapists, sports motivators and more besides - Nigel and Maria eventually emerged, tearily, into a bright new world of success, achievement and rampant positivity.

It was lovely, really, but also quite an exhausting emotional journey, even for the viewer. 'Unzip the clavicles,' said the beautifully named dance therapist, Kerry Ribchester, to Nigel. Later, Nigel admitted that he would probably have preferred to unzip her Rib-chesters: 'Big thank you to Kerry. You're inspirational, you're sassy, you're sexy... and "sorry" to your boyfriend.' Nigel is now in charge of food for 170 Whitbread pubs, while Maria even enjoys making presentations to the police. Yes, there's no doubt at all that a week spent on Dr Atkins's diet at Babington House with a copy of The Rules and a Wonderbra will ensure unbridled happiness for all.

webTitle: You see the bills - and coo

fields.headline: You see the bills - and coo
fields.standfirst: But you don't have to make your own sandwiches to save money, writes  Virginia Wallis
fields.trailText: But you don't have to make your own sandwiches to save money, writes Virginia Wallis.
fields.body:
Around this time of year, financial institutions are fond of publishing surveys showing that, if you gave up eating chocolate, made your own sandwiches and stopped going for a quick drink after work, you could be rich. Perhaps they are right. But why give up life's small pleasures when you could save far more by cutting back on what you spend on the boring stuff?

Could it be that doing something about the boring stuff is, well, so boring as to be apathy-inducing?

It would appear so. According to a recent report by the Department of Trade and Industry on consumer attitudes to switching suppliers, most people are overcome with inertia.

We're not that bad at taking action to make savings on the really tedious stuff: 53 per cent of consumers shop around for car insurance and 30 per cent regularly change buildings and contents policies.

But when it comes to changing mortgage lenders, apathy reigns. While a third of the people surveyed had thought about switching their mortgage in the past five years, a mere 12 per cent had gone through with it. Yet moving your mortgage could finance a chocolate habit many times over: on an interest-only mortgage of £75,000, shaving just one percentage point off the interest rate you currently pay would save £750 a year.

Then there are the savings to be made from switching gas and electricity suppliers. The DTI says we're getting better at taking advantage of competition in these markets but figures from the energy regulator, Ofgem, suggest there is still a long way to go. Although consumers have had the freedom to change the company that supplies their domestic energy for at least two years now, 70 per cent have stuck with British Gas and 80 per cent prefer to remain with their local ex-monopoly electricity supplier.

Consumers have also been slow to profit from lower prices as a result of the opening up of the telecoms market. 'Loyalty levels to BT are high,' concludes the DTI. Only 11 per cent of people have taken steps to save money on their phone bills by moving away from BT.

But apathy isn't entirely to blame. Research commissioned by the telecoms regulator, Oftel, found that 15 million consumers weren't aware that there are at least three different types of telecoms services supplier, and didn't realise they could save up to 20 per cent on phone bills by shopping around.

The DTI puts consumer reluctance to change energy supplier down to the perceived 'hassle factor combined with the risk of change and a view that the savings will not be sub- stantial'. But could it be that the majority of non-switchers are happy with the savings that competition in the energy markets has already brought? Figures from the National Audit Office, show that doing nothing results in a combined saving of £70 a year on gas and electricity.

Or perhaps the doorstep sales methods employed by many of the new energy suppliers put a lot of people off. If the doorsteppers of South London are anything to go by, even when asked nicely, they are unable to give actual tariff information - asking you take their word for it that you will save money. And no fine upstanding consumer is going to fall for that.

The trouble is, they're probably right. On average, the NAO says people who have switched saved £78 a year on gas and £45 on electricity. Not a huge amount compared with switching your mortgage, but enough to pay for the occasional guilt-free chicken tikka sandwich.

Telephone: Good line in cheap calls

To save money on your phone bills, you needn't even change your phone number. One option is to stick with BT but switch to a special package. BT Together costs £2 a month more than standard line rental at £9.99, but halves the cost of national calls and brings international discounts. The £11.99 monthly line rental also includes free calls to the value of £2.40 a month.

The BT Talk Together package costs £14.99 a month and covers all local weekend and evening calls. To make the extra £5 a month worthwhile, you would need to make at least 17 minutes of local off-peak calls each day.

But you can save more on national and international calls through an indirect access company. According to a recent Which? report, a 10-minute national daytime call routed through Eurobell (0800 499 994) will cost 50p less than BT standard rate and 11p less than the BT Together rate. Using One.Tel, quip or WorldxChange (0800 975 1500) could cut the cost of a 10-minute call to the US by as much as £1.70.

Until now, using an indi rect access company involved either dialling a four-digit access code or plugging a special autodialler into your BT phone socket. But thanks to a new service, carrier pre-selection, (CPS) calls can now be switched through to a different company at the telephone exchange.

At the moment you can choose a different company only for national and international calls - although you can use a different company for each type of call. But by the end of the year, you should be able to use different companies for all calls, including premium-rate and those to mobile phones.

One disadvantage of CPS is that pre-selecting one company for a particular type of call won't get the best deal at all times of day. Another is that shopping around for the best deal could involve trawling through the tariff information of over 90 companies (available at www.magsys.co.uk).

But for £24.98 (including VAT and delivery) for a special unit the size of a paperback book, Talk (0800 107 0139) will ensure your calls are always charged at the most competitive rate on the market. The service costs £2 a month (£1 if you pay by direct debit) and there's a connection charge of 2p a call.

Gas: Hot air on savings

There are three ways to save on your gas bills: use less; change the way you pay your bill; and/or change your supplier.

If you pay your British Gas bill quarterly, you can save just over £30 a year if you manage to pay all four bills within 10 days of their issue. But you will save slightly more if you change to monthly direct debit. This secures a price reduction of around 8 per cent which, on a typical annual gas consumption of 19,050 kilowatt hours, represents an annual saving of £34.

Changing the company that sends the bill can produce bigger savings. And since your gas pipes and meter stay the same, the only hassle involved, if you want an accurate idea of how much you could save, is working out your annual gas consumption.

How large the savings will be depends on the size of your gas bill, how you currently pay it and whether you would be prepared to change your payment method on switching supplier. Using figures published by Ofgem, the table on page 2 shows the savings you can make if your annual gas consumption is small (10,000 kWh), medium (19,050 kWh) and large (28,000 kWh).

Cash has calculated that, whatever your consumption, you will save the most - up to 25 per cent - if you currently pay quarterly, don't qualify for British Gas's prompt payment discount and change to paying by monthly direct debit with a new supplier. Next best is the 20 per cent savings if you continue to pay quarterly with a new company. The savings go down to 10 to 15 per cent if you currently pay by monthly direct debit and would carry on after switching supplier.

To achieve those kind of reductions, you need to pick the cheapest supplier. In all cases, the highest savings were from Amerada's Internet-based operation at www.amerada.co.uk. Powergen (0500 24 0500) came a close second but beat amerada.co.uk for those prepared to apply through its website (www.powergen.co.uk) and qualify for its £15 cash-back.

Other companies offering savings worth switching for include: Eastern Energy (0800 092 9292); ScottishPower (0800 400 200); Sweb Gas (0845 073 4343); Yorkshire Electricity (0800 073 4343); and Internet-based Servista Power.

Electricity: Switch on to current bargains

Although the savings tend to be smaller, if you're going to change gas supplier, you may as well change your electricity company too.

Your cables and meter are unaffected and, as with switching gas suppliers, the amount you'll save depends on how you pay, how much electricity you use and who you switch to.

But because electricity prices vary according to where you live - and whether you use standard or Economy 7 electricity - the size of saving you can expect also depends on which regional ex-monopoly company supplies your home. The table gives potential savings if you use standard electricity and switched to the cheapest supplier in your area.

Different prices in different parts of the country also means that no single supplier will provide the best deal in all regions. Your payment method and annual consumption will also have a bearing on which companies will provide the best incentives to switch.

However, it would be worth getting a quote from Amerada's web-based company (0845 305 3000), which was one of the cheapest suppliers in all regions, beaten only by Npower. Npower (0800 389 2388) offers a good deal in all areas except its own and Scotland.

Northern Electric & Gas (0800 996 622), Scottish Hydro-Electric ((0800 223 377), Southern Electric (0800 117 116), Swalec (0800 052 5252) and Utility Link (0845 601 2421) offer some of the lowest prices in at least half of the old electricity regions.

Other companies selling the cheapest power in some areas include: London Electricity (0800 096 5010), Manweb (0800 503 050), ScottishPower ((0800 400 200) Seeboard Energy (0800 092 9292), Sweb (0800 365 200) and internet-based Virgin Energy (0800 085 5008).

Dual fuel deals: Two into one goes nicely

The alternative to buying your gas from one supplier and your electricity from another is to use the same company to supply both.

Ofgem figures suggest that dual-fuel will always be more expensive if you stick with paying your bill quarterly. But if you keep to paying by monthly direct debit, the picture is less clear cut. If you get your gas from British Gas and your electricity from London Electricity, Norweb Energi, Scottish Hydro-Electric, Scottish Power, SWEB or Yorkshire Electricity, the cheapest dual-fuel deal available in your area will reap the same savings as the best deals from separate suppliers.

A dual-fuel deal may be no more expensive if you consume a medium or large amount of energy and you change from paying quarterly to monthly. However, small users tend to get bigger savings from separate deals unless their electricity is currently supplied by London Electricity, Northern Electric & Gas, Norweb Energi, Scottish Hydro-Electric or Yorkshire Electricity.

Companies worth approaching for dual-fuel quotes include www.amerada.co.uk (which was the cheapest in all areas); Powergen (0500 240 500) and ScottishPower (0800 400 200).

A step-by-step guide to switching

1. Work out your annual gas and electricity consumption by adding up the kiloWatt hours (your electricity bill may call these units) from your last four bills.

2. Use the internet to find companies that will save you money. Enter your details into the interactive calculators at www.unravelit.com or www.uswitch.co.uk.

3. Check what kind of contract you are being offered. With rolling contracts, the supplier is free to change the tariff after giving you 10 days' notice, but you are usually free to change to another supplier without penalty. With fixed contracts, the price can't go up during the fixed period, but you could be charged a fee if you decide to switch again before the period is over.

4. Expect the whole process to take about 28 days.

Contacts

For general advice contact energywatch (the newly formed Gas and Electricity Consumers' Council) on 0800 887777 or go towww.energywatch.org.uk. For help with complaints, phone 0845 906 0708 for gas; 0845 601 3131 for electricity. Energy Advice Centre network on 0800 512 012.
