Your payment method and annual consumption will also have a bearing on which companies will provide the best incentives to switch. However, it would be worth getting a quote from Amerada's web-based company (0845 305 3000), which was one of the cheapest suppliers in all regions, beaten only by Npower. Npower (0800 389 2388) offers a good deal in all areas except its own and Scotland. Northern Electric & Gas (0800 996 622), Scottish Hydro-Electric ((0800 223 377), Southern Electric (0800 117 116), Swalec (0800 052 5252) and Utility Link (0845 601 2421) offer some of the lowest prices in at least half of the old electricity regions. Other companies selling the cheapest power in some areas include: London Electricity (0800 096 5010), Manweb (0800 503 050), ScottishPower ((0800 400 200) Seeboard Energy (0800 092 9292), Sweb (0800 365 200) and internet-based Virgin Energy (0800 085 5008). Dual fuel deals: Two into one goes nicely The alternative to buying your gas from one supplier and your electricity from another is to use the same company to supply both. Ofgem figures suggest that dual-fuel will always be more expensive if you stick with paying your bill quarterly. But if you keep to paying by monthly direct debit, the picture is less clear cut. If you get your gas from British Gas and your electricity from London Electricity, Norweb Energi, Scottish Hydro-Electric, Scottish Power, SWEB or Yorkshire Electricity, the cheapest dual-fuel deal available in your area will reap the same savings as the best deals from separate suppliers. A dual-fuel deal may be no more expensive if you consume a medium or large amount of energy and you change from paying quarterly to monthly. However, small users tend to get bigger savings from separate deals unless their electricity is currently supplied by London Electricity, Northern Electric & Gas, Norweb Energi, Scottish Hydro-Electric or Yorkshire Electricity. Companies worth approaching for dual-fuel quotes include www.amerada.co.uk (which was the cheapest in all areas); Powergen (0500 240 500) and ScottishPower (0800 400 200). A step-by-step guide to switching 1. Work out your annual gas and electricity consumption by adding up the kiloWatt hours (your electricity bill may call these units) from your last four bills. 2. Use the internet to find companies that will save you money. Enter your details into the interactive calculators at www.unravelit.com or www.uswitch.co.uk. 3. Check what kind of contract you are being offered. With rolling contracts, the supplier is free to change the tariff after giving you 10 days' notice, but you are usually free to change to another supplier without penalty. With fixed contracts, the price can't go up during the fixed period, but you could be charged a fee if you decide to switch again before the period is over. 4. Expect the whole process to take about 28 days. Contacts For general advice contact energywatch (the newly formed Gas and Electricity Consumers' Council) on 0800 887777 or go towww.energywatch.org.uk. For help with complaints, phone 0845 906 0708 for gas; 0845 601 3131 for electricity. Energy Advice Centre network on 0800 512 012.

webTitle: Other films: Hoodlums, heists and cockneys. (Yes, Ray Winstone's in it)

fields.headline: Hoodlums, heists and cockneys. (Yes, Ray Winstone's in it)
fields.standfirst: The Brit gangster flick is back, with Homeric undertones. But the biggest crime this week is yet another Satanic plot
fields.trailText: Under Suspicion | Sexy Beast | The Criminal | Rage | Lost Souls | The Long Goodbye
fields.body:
Under Suspicion (111 mins, 15) Directed by Stephen Hopkins; starring Morgan Freeman, Gene Hackman

Sexy Beast (88 mins, 18) Directed by Jonathan Glazer; starring Ray Winstone, Ben Kingsley, Ian McShane, Amanda Redman

The Criminal (97 mins, 15) Directed by Julian Simpson; starring Steven Mackintosh, Natasha Little, Bernard Hill, Eddie Izzard

Rage (90 mins, 15) Directed by Newton I. Aduaka; starring Fraser Ayres, Shaun Parkes, John Pickard

Lost Souls (90 mins, 15) Directed by Janusz Kaminski; starring Winona Ryder, Ben Chaplin, John Hurt

The Long Goodbye (113 mins, 18) Directed by Robert Altman; starring Elliott Gould, Sterling Hayden, Nina Van Pallandt

Twenty years ago Truffaut's protégé Claude Miller transposed John Wainwright's gritty crime novel Brainwash from a small North of England community to a smart French seaside resort on New Year's Eve. Garde à Vue (released in Britain as The Inquisitor) starred rough, tough Lino Ventura as a police inspector who calls in smooth, haut-bourgeois lawyer Michael Serrault, dressed in dinner jacket for a smart party, to answer questions about the deaths of two teenage girls, both raped and murdered. A smooth, shallow work, 'simple Simenon' I called it at the time, its strengths lay in what wasn't articulated in the social and sexual tensions between the cop and the suspect.

Stephen Hopkins's moderately entertaining Under Suspicion, which acknowledges both Wainwright's novel and Miller's movie as its sources, shifts the action to San Juan, capital of Puerto Rico, at fiesta time and casts Morgan Freeman as the cop and Gene Hackman as the accused lawyer, two great parts for middle-aged actors. It is not, however, a subtle exercise. The picture gets off to a bad start with a succession of slow-motion and speeded-up shots of San Juan, then Hopkins and his screenwriters open up this chamber piece with flashy flashbacks that go beyond the ambiguity of the French original to place the interrogator in surreal fashion at the scene of the crime. Everything is made explicit, and this undermines the central performances that start out like house-trained dogs and end up with the avidity of hungry East German Dobermans digging into fugitives. Hackman challenges us with a couple of eloquent, dangerous speeches about the attractions of young girls, and the double-ending is disturbing, but less so than intended.

Last year saw a plethora of lousy British gangster movies. The New Year opens with a pair of promising directorial debuts that help to redeem the genre. They're not in the same class as Joseph Losey's The Criminal, Mike Hodges's Get Carter, Nic Roeg and Donald Cammell's Performance, John Mackenzie's The Long Good Friday or Stephen Frears's The Hit. But they're stylish films, worthy of lower-rung positions in the British low-life canon.

Jonathan Glazer's Sexy Beast has an indefensibly awful title and is a spin on its producer Jeremy Thomas's far superior The Hit. A sad, overweight cockney criminal, the emblematically named Gary Dove (Ray Winstone), has retired in his early forties to the Costa del Sol with his bruised ex-porn-flick wife (Amanda Redman). But if you have skills the mob needs you can never escape, and Gary is pursued by the psychotic hoodlum Don Logan (a brilliant Ben Kingsley). Don's been instructed by underworld king-pin Teddy Bass (Ian McShane) to recruit Gary for one last big heist.

Before Logan arrives, Gary experiences a premonition in the form of a boulder that rolls down the adjacent Spanish mountainside and lands in his pool. Sisyphus is talking to him, and we recognise that Gary is Philoctetes, the reclusive archer, whose bow was needed for the Trojan War, and that Don is a modern version of Ulysses, sent to lure him back to the fray. The mode is tough-sentimental and it falls off badly.

Julian Simpson's The Criminal adheres to a more recent mythic model, calling his victim-hero 'J' (Steven Mackintosh), the way Franz Kafka named the protagonist of The Trial 'K'. His J is a sad, down-at-heel London musician who gets sucked into an insane, subterranean intrigue involving Scotland Yard and a secret freelance intelligence agency that functions only through a website. Minute by minute this paranoid thriller grabs you, with sharp contributions from Bernard Hill, Holly Aird and Eddie Izzard. But it never makes sense, socially or politically, the way its 1970s American models - The Parallax View, All the President's Men - do. However, both The Criminal and Sexy Beast are professionally turned movies, worthy of commercial distribution.

Another fairly promising British debut is the Nigerian-born Newton I. Aduaka's Rage, a low-budget movie about three teenage musicians - one white and middle-class, the other two black and living on a Brixton estate - briefly turning to crime. Their motive is to pay for the cutting of a rap record and to settle the drug debts of a wise, elderly Rastafarian who acts as mentor to one of the lads. It's a rough and ready piece shot in documentary style, much of it at night, but it has drive and energy.

The directorial debut of the gifted Polish cinematographer Janusz Kaminski (who won Oscars for Schindler's List and Saving Private Ryan), the sanctimonious millennium horror flick Lost Souls is further sad confirmation that the way into the director's chair doesn't lie through the director of photography's light meter. This badly told tale, deliberately lit in a sickly fashion, has the usual team of obsessed Manhattan Catholics ready to confront Satan - in this case as he prepares to take over the body of Peter Kelson (Ben Chaplin), an agnostic criminal psychologist. Winona Ryder is the misunderstood anti-Satanist, John Hurt is the obligatory European priest conducting dangerous exorcisms. There isn't a jot of humour in this solemn movie.

The welcome two-month long Robert Altman retrospective at the NFT sees the return of his 1973 version of The Long Goodbye. It sets out to turn Chandler's romantic, chivalric thriller on its head, but Altman is closer than he recognises to Chandler. Elliott Gould, however, is the antithesis of the earnest, confident WASPish Marlowes in preceding films (e.g. Dick Powell, Humphrey Bogart, Robert Montgomery, James Garner) and he drifts like a sleepwalker through the movie, very much not in control of events, more a victim than an existential hero.

The picture is studded with references to earlier movies (the gatekeeper at a luxurious private estate will admit people only when they've identified the stars he's impersonating), and apart from Gould most of the leading parts are played by non-actors or people who bring to their roles a variety of associations, mostly now forgotten - Nina Van Pallandt, for instance, who was involved the previous year with Clifford Irving during the Howard Hughes fraud scandal; Sterling Hayden, the guilt-ridden namer-of-names before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, who had come to hate Hollywood; and Jim Bouton, the baseball star turned author. For all the liberties taken with the plot by screenwriter Leigh Brackett, the movie is close in spirit to Chandler and is more optimistic in tone than the novel had been perceived to be when it appeared in 1954 as Chandler's final masterpiece.

fields.headline: Let's make a spectacle of ourselves
fields.standfirst: The rage for watching films through funny glasses comes and goes, but as a 3-D revival of Kiss Me Kate opens, Philip French asks if it's more than a fad
fields.trailText: The rage for watching films through funny glasses comes and goes, but as a 3-D revival of Kiss Me Kate opens, Philip French asks if it's more than a fad.
fields.body:
The silent, black-and-white movie was a passing fancy on the point of extinction 100 years ago, when it started telling stories and became a central part of our modern culture. Since then, every additional element of cinema has begun as a novelty to attract audiences. The Warner brothers, desperately trying to save their failing studio, made The Jazz Singer and everyone else jumped on the bandwagon of the talking picture. The widescreen (which had been around unused for nearly 30 years) was seized on in 1953 by an industry attempting to lure TV viewers from their small, flickering home screen. Other novelties came and went - among them the giant Cinerama with its three-projectors; Smell-o-Vision (used by Mike Todd Jr for one film, Scent of Mystery in 1959 and dubbed Todd-BO by critics); Circlorama (the audience stood in the middle of panoramic 360° images); Sensurround (the whole auditorium shaking during Earthquake).

Oddly the technique that has kept on bobbing up and then disappearing is stereoscopy - 3-D, which demands that audiences watch the film through special glasses that turn the flat image projected onto the screen into an experience of depth. In the week that sees the revival in 3-D of the 1953 MGM musical Kiss Me Kate, one might ask: Is it a serious addition to the cinema, like sound, colour, stereophony? Or is it a carnival attraction fit only to be seen in the funfair atmosphere of Disneyworld or on the giant Imax screen, for which most recent 3-D movies have been made?

The stereoscope, a device for looking at still photographs through a binocular eye-piece, had been a popular parlour toy in Victorian times, and there had been occasional 3-D shorts shown in US and British newsreel theatres in the 1930s. In the mid-1940s the Soviet Union had a studio devoted to experimenting with 3-D. The films were shown in a small Moscow cinema where the audience had to keep their position rigid to retain the 3-D effect. In his final essay, left unfinished at his death in 1948, Eisenstein wrote: 'To doubt that stereoscopic cinema has its tomorrow is as naïve as doubting whether there will be tomorrows at all.'

In 1951 one of the great attractions at the Festival of Britain was a programme of shorts that included several abstract animated films in 3-D by the avant-garde moviemaker Norman McLaren. The following year in America, Arch Oboler, made Bwana Devil, a low-budget film in the 3-D Natural Vision process. It was an adventure yarn about two man-eating lions terrorising the workers building a railway in East Africa. Using the advertising slogan 'A Lion in Your Lap, A Lover in Your Arms', the movie cleaned up at the box-office. The producers even had the chutzpah to put out a press release pouring scorn on the worries of ophthalmologists that sitting in the dark wearing a primitive pair of spectacles with red and green lens might be a trifle unhealthy. 'In fact, it is predicted that viewing a full-length picture in this system may do more for a person with weak eyes than would hundreds of dollars worth of eye treatment in a doctor's office.' This was the time when advertisers were assuring smokers that cigarettes were soothing to the throat.

Over the next year every studio made 3-D films - among them the John Wayne western Hondo, the horror flick House of Wax, Kiss Me Kate and Hitchcock's Dial M For Murder, the only 3-D movie by a director of the first rank. The vogue lasted scarcely 18 months. Audiences found the glasses uncomfortable and the 3-D images disorienting. CinemaScope and VistaVision came to US cinemas in 1953 and here the following year, making the widescreen spectacular all the rage. Most of the pictures shot in 3-D were released here in flat versions, including Dial M For Murder, which didn't get its British 3-D premiere until a screening at the ICA in 1983.

A US proponent of 3-D, M.L. Gunsberg, stated in 1953: 'We feel the day will come, and soon, when audiences will watch a motion picture performance as though the screen were eliminated entirely, and life itself unfolded.' So far, despite talk of devices offering virtual reality, he has been proved wrong.

 Kiss Me Kate runs from Friday until 25 Jan at NFT, London SE1 (020 7928 3232).

fields.headline: Patrick Fugit
fields.standfirst: Star of Almost Famous
fields.trailText: Patrick Fugit, star of Almost Famous.
fields.body:
It can't get much more nerve-racking than this: you're 15, you've never acted in a feature film before, and now you're in a big Hollywood movie. Worse still: you're playing the central character, who is, for all intents and purposes, the director as a teenager. Fortunately for Patrick Fugit, star of Almost Famous, that was all part of the plan.

Inspired by Mike Leigh, Cameron Crowe decided that the lives of his actors should mirror the lives of his actors. So to play William Miller, the round-faced, awkward, naïve and precocious 15-year-old who grows up fast as a journalist on tour with a Seventies rock band, he wanted someone who would start off as innocent as possible.

Even Crowe had reservations about what he was doing. 'I was worried. You know, he doesn't have a lot of so-called technique, which is why I cast him, but it also made us run long and go over budget. But he's so real that I fell in love with the idea of the character being gloriously passive, being the observer at the circus. I just put the camera on him and we watch him watch everything else.'

Fugit's previous experience amounted to two episodes of the sickly drama Touched By An Angel, a Weird Al Yankovic video and a TV movie called Legion Of Fire: Killer Ants. He didn't even know anything about music. 'The [script] pages I was given had been rewritten as politics to keep the movie secret, so I thought it was a movie about politics,' he says. 'And while we were reading, Cameron said, "You're doing great, Patrick. So, do you like rock'n'roll?" I went, "Um, no." And it was silent for a minute. I thought it was an odd question.'

These days, he's thoroughly immersed in Seventies rock, and wouldn't go anywhere without his Led Zeppelin CDs. Meanwhile, he's feeling guilty about the instant success. 'It's crazy. Most people work up to this point by doing something like walking a dog in the background of a Harrison Ford movie. I got rushed to the front of the line. Sometimes it gets uncomfortable when I'm around those starving-actor types. I just want to apologise.'

Coming from Salt Lake City, the whole decadent rock'n'roll world lovingly recreated in Almost Famous is a long way from his life. While William Miller is relieved of his virginity by a trio of groupies in a motel, Fugit's experience of girls couldn't be more different. 'Eighty per cent of the people are Mormon, so that can be a big thing when you're in high school and want to date girls. You get the girl who's allowed to date and you meet her dad who has the gun behind his back, saying, "Have her back by nine".'

Five things you should know about Patrick Fugit

1. He screen-tested for the lead role in Spider-Man, but was deemed 'too young'

2. His first piece of homework for the part was watching Led Zeppelin's The Song Remains The Same

3. Before the film, he owned one CD - by Chumbawamba

4. His hobbies are 'motorcycling and exploring canyons'

5. He comes from Mormon capital Salt Lake City, but isn't a Mormon

 Almost Famous opens on 9 Feb.

webTitle: Blair rescue bid as Nissan threat reopens euro row

fields.headline: Blair rescue bid as Nissan threat reopens euro row
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has mounted a last-ditch attempt to save the threatened Nissan plant as company chiefs blamed Britain's reluctance to join the euro for jeopardising the factory's future.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has mounted a last-ditch attempt to save the threatened Nissan plant as company chiefs blamed Britain's reluctance to join the euro for jeopardising the factory's future.

Thousands of jobs could be lost in north-east England if the car giant carries out its threats to build the new Micra model in France. Blair is understood to have spoken twice by telephone to Nissan president Carlos Ghosn to try to persuade him to keep the contract in Britain and avert a potential economic disaster in the region.

Nissan's decision is potentially explosive politically, since it is bound to reopen debate within the Government over the timetable for joining the single currency.

Although the European Commission is expected to approve a morale-boosting £41 million government grant to the factory on Wednesday, Nissan has made clear that state aid is not its main worry.

'It is the most finely balanced decision I have been involved with in my working life,' said a senior Nissan source. 'We cannot run a business that is losing money. If the Government had been brave enough to say "we will" to the euro, rather than have five economic tests you can fudge any way, the markets would have discounted the pound against the euro.'

The decision would have been tipped in Sunderland's favour, if it were not for the currency problem, the source added. Instead it had been forced into a 'marginal' position.

The criticism will anger Downing Street, which last night declined to discuss Blair's talks with Ghosn.

Losing the new Micra would cost 1,300 jobs at the plant and hundreds more among suppliers.

Related story
City in shock at Nissan threat

fields.headline: U-turn over no-fault divorce law
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Plans to allow no-fault divorces for couples who have been married for as little as a year are to be abandoned by the Government as unworkable.
fields.body:
Plans to allow no-fault divorces for couples who have been married for as little as a year are to be abandoned by the Government as unworkable.

In a significant victory for the pro-family lobby, the Lord Chancellor, Derry Irvine, will announce in the next two weeks that legislation aimed at relaxing the laws on divorce is too difficult to implement and that pilot mediation schemes supposed to end acrimonious divorce battles have caused more problems than they have solved.

Irvine backed away from the reforms when research by academics at Newcastle University for the Government showed that the plans could cost as much as £50 million a year.

Critics pointed out that the money would be better used boosting marriage support services.

The research also revealed that couples who have gone through the new schemes have become embroiled in bitter legal battles because the pilots do not work.

The announcement will signal the death of the ill-fated Family Law Act, one of the last pieces of legislation passed by John Major's government.

The act proposed that couples would not have to prove adultery or unreasonable behaviour before a split could be agreed.

'The results of the research were disappointing,' a source at the Lord Chancellor's Department said. 'In June the interim results showed that there were problems. Now we have the final results and that picture has not changed.'

The move will be welcomed by pro-family campaigners who say that the new legislation was making it too easy for couples to dissolve their marriages.

The act originally said that couples could break up after one year or 18 months if there were children involved, fundamentally changing the present rules which allow couples no-fault divorces after five years only if the couple do not agree on the terms of the divorce.

But an analysis of the way the legislation would work revealed that compulsory 'information meetings' with marriage guidance counsellors exacerbated problems and policies to identify 'saveable marriages' were pushing people more quickly into the hands of lawyers, moves that the new legislation was supposed to stop.

Irvine, who is a close ally of the pro-marriage Prime Minister, will make the announcement alongside a raft of measures aimed at shoring up the family.

Marriage registrars will be given increased powers to warn couples of the commitment they are making before they get married, meaning that register office marriages will now more closely reflect church marriages where vicars and priests often meet couples two or three times before the ceremony.

Marriage counselling and support services will also be given an enhanced role.

It is also expected that the Children Act will be used to block some divorces where there are no agreements in place on how children will be looked after.

Last year The Observer revealed that the Lord Chancellor's Department and the Home Office's family policy committee were supporting a new book which will give couples advice on the perfect marriage.

The Government agreed to support the book after new figures revealed that more than 300,000 couples a year get married, down by 100,000 on the figure 20 years ago. A third of marriages now end in divorce.

Although officials insist that the Government does not want to be seen as interfering in people's private lives, senior figures including Tony Blair and the Home Office Minister, Paul Boateng, are pushing for a more marriage-friendly image from the Government.

fields.headline: More sales success
fields.body: The Observer sold an average of 428,451 copies a week in December, an increase of 5.49 per cent on the same month in 1999. The average sale for the six-month period from July to December was 441,607 copies, a year-on-year increase of 9.64 per cent. In both cases, The Observer's sales performance is once again the best in the Sunday newspaper market.

fields.headline: McGuinness informer 'was a known liar'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The security service agent who claimed that Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness fired the first shot on Bloody Sunday was a known liar who was 'terminated' as an intelligence source, the Government inquiry into the events in 1972 will be told.
fields.body:
The security service agent who claimed that Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness fired the first shot on Bloody Sunday was a known liar who was 'terminated' as an intelligence source, the Government inquiry into the events in 1972 will be told.

In December the Saville inquiry, which is investigating the killing of 13 civil rights protesters, was rocked by evidence that Northern Ireland's current Education Minister 'seemed to have it on his conscience' that he fired the first shot that sparked the deaths.

The inquiry, which resumes tomorrow, was shown British intelligence documents detailing a conversation between a security service officer and an agent codenamed Infliction - believed to be a leading former Provisional IRA member.

A debriefing note said of McGuinness: 'He fired the first shot and nobody knows this. This seems to be on McGuinness's conscience. He has spoken to Infliction about it several times.'

But writing in today's Observer, former MI5 officer David Shayler says Infliction was widely known in intelligence circles as a 'bullshitter'.

Shayler said: '[Infliction] appeared to have particularly good access to IRA Northern Command.

'His information was taken seriously and acted upon for a while. Then, one day, there was a direct clash between Infliction's reporting and another source. Infliction was supposedly the reliable source and MI5 went with his version, only to be made to look stupid.'

'As a result, it "terminated" Infliction - ceased to use him as an agent - and labelled the intelligence he had provided as coming from a "source whose reliability is being re-assessed".'

Related story
David Shayler: Why I blew the gaff

fields.headline: Revealed: air deaths cover-up
fields.standfirst:
Blood clot hazard known for 30 years

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Blood clot hazard known for 30 years.
fields.body:
British airline companies ignored warnings for more than three decades about the deadly effects of blood clots on passengers during long-haul flights, The Observer can reveal.

Despite being warned as long ago as 1968 by leading medical experts about the problems of so-called 'economy-class syndrome', the airlines played down the dangers and gave no advice to passengers on how to minimise the risks. Hundreds of people are feared to have died as a result.

As recently as 1998, airlines and aviation authorities dismissed disclosures in The Observer about the potential danger of cramped seating causing clots, saying there was no evidence.

Yet in a letter published 16 years ago in the Lancet medical journal, experts warned that 'airline passengers, even those on very long flights, are given no specific advice to prevent venous thrombosis'.

Three doctors working at a hospital near Heathrow - Yvonne Hart, D. J. Holdstock and William Lynn - wrote: 'Working in a hospital on the perimeter of London Airport we see a steady stream of illnesses which have developed in flight. The major manifestation of the illness may not occur until after disembarkation. We have seen several patients with thromboembolism presenting in this way, with a near-fatal outcome in one case.'

Dr Dale Egerton, a Hampshire GP who saved his wife's life in 1998 after she suffered a massive blood clot, said last night: 'It beggars belief that the medical team at British Airways did not read that letter to the Lancet. It sets out the problem that the syndrome can develop after disembarkation and calls for research. If it is known that people are suffering DVT [deep vein thrombosis] after they leave the airport, then the airline companies have a moral responsibility to do the research. But nothing was done - an utter disgrace.'

Our investigation has uncovered a culture of deceit at some airlines which has been allowed to thrive due to complacency at the Department of Health and the Civil Aviation Authority.

Today we reveal that:

 airline company doctors have known about the risks of immobility since 1940 and the risks of immobility on long-haul flights since 1968

 British Airways highlights a misleading study on its website which downplays the risks of long flights

 a new study to be published in the Lancet will show compelling evidence of a link between long-haul flights and DVT

 British Airways has not allowed doctors access to its passengers to do more research

 no data on the number of cases of DVT caused by long flights is collected nationally or at major casualty hospital units

 the Civil Aviation Authority has no responsibility to look after passengers

 water, vital to prevent dehydration in long flights, was found, in tests by Britain's Public Health Laboratories, to be contaminated with E.coli and human excrement in 15 per cent of the fountains surveyed on jets using major British airports.

Only now are major air lines alerting customers to DVT on tickets. British Airways now tells passengers to flex their ankles while seated.

The first study warning of the dangers of immobility was published in 1940, and follow-up reports looking at blood-clot risks to passengers in air flights first appeared in 1968.

Dr John Scurr, of University College Hospital, London, is soon to publish fresh research in the Lancet which will show a conclusive link between long-haul flights and DVT.

Dr John Belstead, of Ashford Hospital, near Heathrow, estimates that 15 Britons die a year from DVT developed on long-haul flights.

Egerton, the Hampshire GP, said that if the airlines and the authorities had acted on the warning in the Lancet in 1985, the lives of 225 people could have been saved.

Scurr suspects that the number of deaths could be very much higher. 'Maybe hundreds of Britons are dying every year,' he said.

A spokesman for the Civil Aviation Authority pointed out that it had no responsibility for air passengers.

A spokesman for the Department of Health said that DVT was 'very much a now issue' but admitted that it had not been a high priority in the past.

British Airways has in the past downplayed the prevalence of mortalities from DVT, saying that only two people in the world die each year from blood clots caused on long-haul flights.

Last week BA pointed to its website, showing 'facts and research' on DVT. One study shows that DVT is more likely to be caused in cars rather than planes.

Egerton said: 'What British Airways doesn't say is that this study was done in a part of France where there is no international airport. It is a grotesquely misleading way to deal with a major scandal in the public health.'

webTitle: Bush's Star Wars raises global arms race fears

fields.headline: Bush's Star Wars raises global arms race fears
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George W Bush's America
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A new arms race looms this weekend after reports that Russia and China are preparing to enter into a historic pact, spurred by plans by the incoming Bush administration to plough ahead with a vast missile defence screen.
fields.byline: Ed Vulliamy in New York and Gaby Hinsliff
fields.body:
A new arms race looms this weekend after reports that Russia and China are preparing to enter into a historic pact, spurred by plans by the incoming Bush administration to plough ahead with a vast missile defence screen.

The controversial National Missile Defence programme (NMD) - nicknamed Son of Star Wars - would deploy thousands of air defence missiles to shoot down incoming intercontinental ballistic weapons fired by rogue states or international terrorists.

To be effective, the US would have to be allowed to use the early warning station at Fylingdales in Yorkshire. Former Defence Minister Peter Kilfoyle, writing in The Observer today, warns Tony Blair against the scheme,saying it is a 'dangerous flight of fancy' that would leave Britain vulnerable to attack.

The prospect of renewed international tensions came as Moscow and Beijing announced the forging of a treaty and strategic alliance over arms and space programmes which could rupture the new, post-Cold War world order. If the treaty is developed into a fully fledged alliance, it would be the first to be joined by China in decades.

A source in President Clinton's State Department said: 'The Russians are pretty baffled and more than a little scared. While they want to be seen to welcome and work with the incoming President, they are bound to wonder who this amount of warfaring material is supposed to be against.'

The French Defence Minister is travelling to Moscow for talks on the new missile system, which France opposes.

The British Government is split on the issue, but The Observer can reveal that, privately, it has warned Washington that it should go ahead with NMD only if it can secure international agreement.

'We said to the Clinton administration that we do not want you to proceed unilaterally,' said one Whitehall source. 'That is also the stance we are starting to adopt with the new administration.

'Don't underestimate Number 10's strategy on this - it is not about saying "come on board and roll all over me".'

However both sides of the debate accept the US is not backing down on the idea. Bush's choice for Pentagon Chief, Donald Rumsfeld, has called for a total overhaul of US defence strategy and weaponry, with vast spending increases and the missile defence screen at the core of the new strategy.

Rumsfeld, who also held the office under President Ford, is heir to the hawkish wing which pushed Star Wars and is understood to have dismissed the anti-ballistic missile treaty with Russia, pivotal to the halting of the arms race, as 'ancient history'. Threats from China and 'suspicions' towards Russia were discussed last week between Bush's defence staff and Clinton's defence chief William Cohen. One aide said both nations were 'not allies and certainly not friends'.

The aggressive signals from Washington have alarmed the Foreign Office in London.

Although the Ministry of Defence has been keener not to offend the Americans, insiders say even there opinion is divided on whether Britain should allow its base to be used in what could be an echo of the Greenham Common debacle, inspiring public protest and a likely rebellion on the Labour backbenches.

Kilfoyle says the plan will be 'hugely destabilising' to international relations in a clear warning to Blair not to become involved.

'The British Government will need to decide just how much it's worth to offer itself as a hostage to the fortunes of a misguided - literally and metaphorically - strategic defence initiative,' he says.

'If America's putative enemies do have plans to suicidally attack America, why should we turn ourselves into the primary target?'

Star Wars was pushed into the domestic spotlight by William Hague's announcement last week that a Tory government would support it.

Ministers had hoped that if Al Gore got into the White House, he might drop the idea. But now the issue has become an awkward test of the 'special relationship' in the post-Clinton era.

Downing Street believes technical problems with the system - in tests the interceptors meant to shoot down missiles missed them all - will mean the decision can be put off for months if not years.

The Sino-Russian pact has its origins in a visit by Russian President Vladimir Putin to Beijing last summer, but the final agreements were sealed just before Christmas.

Yesterday, the chairman of the strategic research department at the US Naval Defence College, Jonathan Pollack, said: 'These negotiations are being publicised on the eve of the Bush presidency. Both leaderships are very uneasy about the new administration's plans to accelerate missile defence'.

Pollack said such a move would return the global pattern to an East-West conflict.

webTitle: A million children at risk over TB jabs

fields.headline: A million children at risk over TB jabs
fields.trailText: More than one million children have been denied an essential vaccination against tuberculosis because the Government scheme for protecting young lives has been in disarray for nearly 18 months.
fields.body:
More than one million children have been denied an essential vaccination against tuberculosis because the Government scheme for protecting young lives has been in disarray for nearly 18 months.

Ministers admitted last week they had 'little idea' when new batches of the BCG vaccine would be available, despite a New Labour pledge to vaccinate 750,000 children a year against the disease.

The news comes as the Government is already under fire over safety fears surrounding the MMR vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella.

New figures show that TB has increased to its highest level for 17 years. St Thomas's Hospital in London now has more referrals for TB every day than it used to have in a week only three years ago.

The Government originally said that it would restart the TB vaccination programme 'as soon as possible' when supplies of the drug were suspended in September 1999 over a row with the manufacturer, Celltech Medeva.

But the Health Minister, Yvette Cooper, has now said there are still no plans to revive the scheme, which health experts say is vital if children are to avoid the potentially fatal disease.

'The Department is doing all it can to secure a robust supply of vaccine, and will announce as soon as possible when the routine schools programme can resume,' Cooper said. Children who had missed their vaccinations because the programme was suspended would have them later.

There are fears that the UK is on the brink of a mass epidemic similar to the one that struck New York in 1989, claiming hundreds of lives.

Dr John Moore-Gillon, TB spokesman for the British Lung Foundation, said: 'It's a sign that we're losing the battle against TB.'

The news comes as the Government is already under fire over safety fears surrounding the MMR vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella. New figures show that TB has increased to its highest level for 17 years. St Thomas's Hospital in London now has more referrals for TB every day than it used to have in a week only three years ago. The Government originally said that it would restart the TB vaccination programme 'as soon as possible' when supplies of the drug were suspended in September 1999 over a row with the manufacturer, Celltech Medeva. But the Health Minister, Yvette Cooper, has now said there are still no plans to revive the scheme, which health experts say is vital if children are to avoid the potentially fatal disease. 'The Department is doing all it can to secure a robust supply of vaccine, and will announce as soon as possible when the routine schools programme can resume,' Cooper said. Children who had missed their vaccinations because the programme was suspended would have them later. There are fears that the UK is on the brink of a mass epidemic similar to the one that struck New York in 1989, claiming hundreds of lives. Dr John Moore-Gillon, TB spokesman for the British Lung Foundation, said: 'It's a sign that we're losing the battle against TB.'

fields.headline: Irish army 'can't police Armagh'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: One of Ireland's most respected soldiers has rejected a proposal that Irish troops should be used to plug the security gap left by a large-scale British Army withdrawal from south Armagh.
fields.body:
One of Ireland's most respected soldiers has rejected a proposal that Irish troops should be used to plug the security gap left by a large-scale British Army withdrawal from south Armagh.

Retired Lt-Gen Gerry McMahon said the Irish Defence Forces would be unable to cope with the extra demands put on them by a massive scaling down of the British military presence in the most dangerous part of Northern Ireland. McMahon, who was chief-of-staff of the defence forces between 1995 and 1998, said such a commitment would mean Ireland closing down its United Nations peacekeeping operations and its commitment to the European Union's rapid reaction force.

Republicans are calling for widespread demilitarisation in south Armagh in return for further IRA moves to decommission its arsenal of illegal weapons.

But British Army commanders have warned Tony Blair that if they withdraw and troops or police are killed by dissident republicans as a result, it will be the Prime Minister, not the military, who must take responsibility.

McMahon also told The Observer he was confident Sinn Fein would decouple from the IRA as the price for entering a coalition government in the Republic.

At the end of last year Irish government officials suggested that if the British withdrew large numbers of troops and tore down hilltop spy posts in south Armagh, Dublin would deploy extra soldiers on the Co Louth side of the border.

McMahon, however, said that with 8,500 full-time troops, Ireland had one of the smallest armed forces in the EU. Despite spending less on defence than almost any other European country, the Irish forces had relatively large commitments to UN peacekeeping from East Timor to Kosovo and Lebanon.

'We have three battalions and one armoured squadron stretched along the border. There is a virtual brigade there and I think that is quite sufficient for the job we are currently doing,' he said.

'The army certainly can't move into south Armagh because it's still UK territory and that's where all the action is. And if we were given extra commitments on the border, the only way we could do that is to shift our troops away from UN peace keeping missions and re-think our proposed role in the EU's rapid reaction force. At present we could not plug the gap. The numbers are just not there,' he said.

The general, who served in the Irish Defence Forces for almost half a century, poured scorn on the Dublin government's new Defence White Paper, particularly its assertion that armed republican violence north of the border was over.

'The military have been telling the politicians that it's not settled yet and that our troops are going to be needed there for a long time to come,' said McMahon.

The conflicting demands of domestic security or aid to the civil power, UN peacekeeping and plans to send an Irish battalion to the EU force were putting enormous strain on the military, he added.

The border between south Armagh and Louth has the most active and militant republicans in Ireland. During the Troubles the region was the most dangerous posting in the world for British troops. It is now a stronghold for the dissident republican terrorist group, the Real IRA, which launched its disastrous bomb attack on Omagh in August 1998 from that area.

McMahon said: 'If I was still chief-of-staff and the politicians asked me for more troops along the border I would tell them we don't have enough.'

As the prospect of an Irish general election this year becomes more likely, political leaders in the Republic are turning their attention to Sinn Fein's fortunes and the possibility of the IRA's political wing entering a coalition.

McMahon said the party would have to redefine its relationship with the IRA and declare sole allegiance to one army, the Irish Defence Forces, to enter a government. He was optimistic that this would eventually happen.

'I am convinced Sinn Fein will be pragmatic about this, in the same way that Fianna Fail was following the civil war. When Fianna Fail eventually came into the Dail and then government, they recognised the sole legitimacy of the Irish national army. These were people who were deadly enemies of the army only a few years before during the civil war.

'There is historical precedence for this, and I have no reason to think it will be any different this time,' he said.

Sinn Fein's desire to be in government on both sides of the border is tempered by the Republic's constitution, which Eamon de Valera drew up in 1936. It says that ministers, civil servants and soldiers must swear loyalty to the state's defence forces.

Bertie Ahern, the taoiseach, has also insisted that Sinn Fein must resolve its relationship with the IRA before it can enter any coalition with his party, Fianna Fail.

webTitle: Benefits crackdown to force jobless into work

fields.headline: Benefits crackdown to force jobless into work
fields.trailText: Adult joblessness could be halved under a tough new regime of benefit sanctions and 'wake-up calls' for welfare cheats to be unveiled this week.
fields.body:
Adult joblessness could be halved under a tough new regime of benefit sanctions and 'wake-up calls' for welfare cheats to be unveiled this week.

Education and Employment Secretary David Blunkett insists that jobs are 'there for the taking' and that anyone under 50 who can work must do so.

Writing in The Observer, he says there will be no hiding place for those playing the system. From the end of the month benefits advisers will start making unexpected, random calls to claimants at home, asking them to come into the office - to catch out those claiming but working on the side.

In April, the New Deal becomes compulsory for all under-50s, except for lone parents and the disabled. If they do not accept either a job, training, or voluntary work likely to lead to a job, they will face cuts in their benefit.

The crackdown was criticised last night by the poverty lobby, which said punishing jobless parents financially would penalise their children.

But Blunkett writes that, while many older unemployed workers found the thought of getting back to work 'scary', they had a duty to try.

'We want to ensure that everyone has the opportunity to develop new skills, but we also want them to accept the responsibilities they have towards society,' he adds. 'Those who genuinely want to work will receive all the support and practical help they need from us - those who are taking taxpayers for a ride will soon find that there is no hiding place.'

He says working and claiming is 'quite simply thieving from everyone else' and demands tougher action.

The plans to be unveiled by Blunkett next Wednesday come as the Government braces itself for a fresh wave of job losses in the Corus steel group, while Nissan's Sunderland plant is also under threat. Blunkett insists in his article that new opportunities will offset redundancies in traditional industries.

If the draconian system works, insiders expect to see joblessness among under-50s more than halved in a few years. The proposals are designed to take Labour closer to its commitment to full employment.

The Institute for Public Policy Research think-tank has argued that the Government could aim to have 80 per cent of the working population in jobs by 2010.

'This is very much about a shift from having sorted youth unemployment on to the 25-plus age group,' said a source at the Department for Education and Employment. 'Compulsion helped to solve the issue of youth unemployment.'

The qualifying period out of work before over-25s have to join the New Deal will be cut from two years out of work to 18 months, eventually sucking thousands more into the scheme.

Parents facing benefit sanctions can apply for hardship funds, but these are worth less than benefits, which worries child poverty campaigners. 'We take the basic view that it's inappropriate to sanction people by withholding money, as that's necessarily going to impact on their families and their children,' said a spokeswoman for the Child Poverty Action Group.

Tory employment spokeswoman Theresa May said older workers faced different problems from under-24s, including ageist employers.

'The reluctant 18-year-old might have other problems, but I'm not convinced that compulsion is necessary for the over-25s,' she added.

Next week Blunkett will announce details of a £4 billion programme to rebuild and repair crumbling schools. He will promise new roofs, classrooms, labs and heating systems, and to rebuild or refurbish 650 schools in England.

webTitle: City in shock at Nissan threat

fields.headline: City in shock at Nissan threat
fields.standfirst:
As car firm debates making the next Micra in France, gloomy Sunderland is braced for huge job losses

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: As car firm debates making the next Micra in France, gloomy Sunderland is braced for huge job losses.
fields.body:
Whenever Nissan workers in Sunderland ring up the local tax office, they have a dedicated inspector to help them with their queries.

That's how vital the nearby Japanese car factory is to the local economy.

But will the 'Nissan Hector' be replaced by a dedicated man at the dole office?

If an imminent, knife-edge decision currently being chewed over in Brussels and Tokyo goes the wrong way, the most likely answer is yes.

Nissan supervisor Steve, 37, sits in a pub three miles from the plant after his Friday shift, sipping whisky and flicking cigarette ash from his denim jacket.

He used to make ships, now it's cars and says any idea that the Nissan plant will not continue to flourish is 'horrifying' for the north-east, but particularly Sunderland. Component suppliers will 'crash and burn'.

Steve, who does not reveal his real identity for fear of reprisals from his superiors, worked his apprenticeship on the last shipyard on the River Wear, making ferries and cargo vessels before it closed ten years ago.

'If the plant closed it would devastate the north-east and it would be exceptionally hard for the community in Sunderland to recover from any magnitude of job losses.

'We are very, very reliant on it now that the other heavy industries like mining and shipbuilding have gone. The only other booming business on Wearside now is bloody call centres,' he said.

Around 3,000 of the 5,000 workers at the factory are from the Sunderland area. A further 11,000 component supplier jobs in the north-east are supported by Nissan.

The issue at stake is where Nissan plans to build the next version of that favourite urban runaround - the Micra.

The new model will not go into production until 2003, but the decision to build it in Sunderland or at a factory in France belonging to Nissan's recently-acquired partner Renault, will be made by the end of the month.

The very idea that the north-east might lose out to the French has put the region in shock for two reasons.

First, the Nissan plant is the most productive car factory in the western world and, following Rover's recent decline, has become the largest car maker in the UK, building 320,000 a year with capacity for half a million.

Each Nissan worker makes a record 105 cars a year. The factory has lost just one hour of production to industrial action in its 16-year existence and set the example during the Eighties for the entire UK industry to pull itself out of strike-ridden nosedive.

Second, although losing the Micra will not see the closure of the factory overnight, it is widely acknowledged that it would spell the 'beginning of the end'.

The factory also makes the Primera and Almera cars and these would continue. But for how long, in a global industry that is hugely oversupplied and where factory closures are increasingly commonplace?

The added factors of a weak euro against a rampant pound, for a factory that exports 75 per cent of its production to the Continent, and Nissan's slowness to drive down prices from its suppliers, pushed the Sunderland outfit into loss last year.

Senior Nissan executives insist the decision has not yet been taken and is 'too close to call' until the final numbers on currency projections and cost-cutting programmes are crunched in Tokyo in the next fortnight.

Supervisor Steve is optimistic. He says he has 'inside information' from his engineering colleagues that vital work has already been done to prepare the assembly line at Sunderland for the new model.

Sunderland City Council leader Colin Anderson has had exhaustive meetings with local MPs and believes that, in contrast with earlier gloom, there is now a 'quiet optimism' that the UK plant will win out after intense lobbying and the plant's pledge to cut costs by 30 per cent by working around the clock.

The French unions have also thrown a spanner in the works by declaring that their factory is already overworked.

The final word will be spoken by Nissan president Carlos Ghosn, the tough Frenchman brought in from Renault to drag Nissan back from the brink of overwhelming debt after the Asian economic bubble burst two years ago. He is known variously as 'Le Cost Killer' and the Jackal.

But many workers at the factory are convinced Ghosn has made up his mind and will soon announce bad news for the north-east.

Kev, a 43-year-old assembly-line worker, reckons it is a fait accompli.

'If we don't get the new Micra, it's the beginning of the end. There won't be any proper jobs for people to go to. I'd probably have to work away as a shop-fitter - down south one minute, up in Scotland the next.'

The plant virtually backs on to Kev's home in Castletown, a westerly suburb dominated by council houses and rundown terraces - apart, that is, from the Brookside-style Fulford Grange private estate at one end, where three-bedroom houses are many times the local average at £80,000.

Kev said: 'That's where the supervisors live. We call it Corned Beef Island because they are so up to their eyes in debt with their posh cars and mortgages that's all they can afford to eat for their tea.'

One Fulford Grange resident, whose husband is indeed a supervisor at Nissan, said they 'went upmarket' and moved there from Washington village, on the other side of the factory, when the money started coming in. Average shopfloor wages are around £20,000 a year - but can grow to £26,000 or more with overtime. Supervisors typically earn £28,000.

What would happen if Nissan disappeared?

'They'd have to build a lot more council houses and we'd be moving,' she said, bluntly.

Unemployment in the area is 8.4 per cent compared with the national average of five per cent and Tyne and Wear has just gone into the national top ten divorce hotspots, with 34 marriages failing per 100,000 population, compared with 27 across the UK. Experts blame two typical but contrasting factors - unemployment and punishing shiftwork at places like Nissan.

The slow decline

Late Sixties: Plants making record 1.9m cars a year.

Mid-Seventies: Employment peaks - 200,000 make vehicles, 280,000 in component supplies.

Eighties: Over-production and poor productivity lead to strikes, job losses and rise of foreign imports. British Leyland breaks up - stump renamed Rover Group. Triumph goes bust, Ford buys Jaguar. Nissan heralds new era with factory in Sunderland.

Nineties: Toyota and Honda build plants. Fewer than 300,000 employed in industry.

Now: Production robust at 1.7m cars a year. But Rover hanging by a thread after BMW disposal; Ford to cease production at Dagenham; Vauxhall to close Luton; Nissan threatens Sunderland. 220,000 employed.

 Source: Cardiff University Business School

Related story
Blair rescue bid as Nissan threat reopens euro row

webTitle: Traitor executed after betraying cousin to Israel

fields.headline: Last minutes of traitor who betrayed his cousin to Israel
fields.standfirst:
Police mete out lethal justice to Palestinian spies who are paid to turn family and neighbours over to Tel Aviv's feared security services

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Police mete out lethal justice to Palestinian spies who are paid to turn family and neighbours over to Tel Aviv's feared security services.
fields.byline: Peter Beaumont, foreign affairs editor and Virginia Quirke, in Jerusalem
fields.body:
Yesterday it was Alam Bani Odeh's turn to die, marched before a firing squad of six Palestinian security officers in a crowded public square in Nablus on the West Bank, sentenced to death for collaborating with Israel's secret services in murder.

Cowed and frightened, head bowed and hands cuffed before him, officers of the Palestinian Authority took Bani Odeh's arms and bustled him into a car for his short, final journey to a stake hammered into the centre of a nearby square.

A slight man with a young and fleshy face, his lip covered by a sparse moustache, he could have been dressed for a family outing in a T-shirt and windcheater. But his T-shirt betrayed his destination: a red dot had been painted above his heart to help the marksmen kill him.

Once in the square they tied him to the stake and covered his head. Moments later a line of police formed up and fired into his body, ending the life of a man accused of the most serious crime imaginable in the Palestinian Territories today: fingering a fellow Palestinian for assassination for $2,000.

As the shots rang out across the town, a crowd of thousands who had gathered for the killing shouted: 'God is great!'

Afterwards friends and relatives of the 25-year-old revealed that in his last hours, as he waited to be shot, the young man had sat weeping, holding his three-year-old daughter's hand.

Alam Bani Odeh was not alone in going before firing squad of his own people yesterday morning in the first public executions of collaborators in the present intifada.

In Gaza City too a similarly brutal scene was being played out as Majdi Mikkawi, 28, convicted for his part in the killing by Israeli forces of a senior Fatah official and several of his fighters near Gaza, was also put to death.

The executions - both ratified by Yasser Arafat - took place hours before negotiators from both sides were due to resume the search for peace.

Alam's crime was as serious as could be committed in the Palestinian communities of the West Bank. According to the court that convicted him, Alam sold his distant cousin Ibrahim to an Israeli hit squad for $2,000.

Ibrahim had been a senior Hamas leader in Nablus, a veteran of Afghanistan and an accomplished bomb maker, locked up before the current intifada by Arafat's own men. But as the intifada death toll crept up, the Palestinian leader ordered the release of men like Ibrahim to help the cause.

And when Ibrahim was freed it was Alam who was waiting to drive him.

Alam led him to the car that the Israeli secret services had booby-trapped. A headrest packed with explosives was detonated from a helicopter, decapitating him.

The story of Majdi Makawi, 28, is similar in many details. It is the story of another man who sold out a relative - Jamal Abdel Razek, a leader of Arafat's Fatah movement - to the Israelis. Razek, a Fatah commander in the southern Gazan town of Rafah, died in November when Israeli soldiers opened fire on two cars at a checkpoint, killing him and three other people who Israel said were also militia members.

The recruitment of Alam Bani Odeh and Majdi Mikkawi sent a chill of fear through the leadership of the Palestinian intifada. It confirmed their worst suspicions. Not only had Shin Bet, Israel's secret services, infiltrated the families of Fatah and Hamas leaders but it was using these agents to provide intelligence for their assassination.

It is a claim that the Israelis have not denied, faced with evidence of a shoot-to-kill policy that has claimed the lives of almost a dozen senior Palestinian lead ers. Israeli officials have confirmed some such hits, and defend the practice overall, not least the hits carried out by the elite Kingfisher unit.

What is without doubt is that Israel's security services have infiltrated the Palestinian Authority at every level, among them Israeli agents from Duvdevan, the elite undercover unit that trains Israelis to pass as Arabs so they can operate in secret on the West Bank.

And no one - least of all the Palestinians - is surprised that many of their neighbours are working for the Israelis. During the previous intifada - and in the years of violence that preceded it - Israel recruited thousands of agents to inform on militants in the community.

Some, Israeli Arabs in specialist units, worked undercover in Palestinian towns or were employed in snatch squads. Others were Palestinians who were corrupted with the offer of money or the chance to settle family feuds. Indeed, when Israel handed over police stations and army posts to the nascent Palestinian Authority after the Oslo peace accords, the new occupants discovered the offices were riddled with Israeli listening devices, some booby-trapped.

The identity of Israel's Arab collaborators has become the stuff of fierce contention during the last few months. In the current paranoia even some the most senior of Arafat's lieutenants have been named by gossips on the streets.

Bani Odeh, however, was small fry, recruited 18 months before the killing of his cousin, long before the intifada had even begun. But faced with warnings of possible conflict, the Israeli secret services were already placing extra agents on the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

As the intifada intensified, and they were warned that Ibrahim Bani Odeh was about to be released, they summoned his cousin to a meeting, asking him to bring his car. The Palestinian allowed the Israelis to take the car, allegedly to plant a homing device.

Instead they packed the headrest of the battered Subaru with high explosives, asking Alam to give Ibrahim the car. When the two men separated later that day, with Alam explaining he would hitchhike to a nearby town, Israeli agents blew his cousin's head off.

'People remember executions,' Ghassan Khader, a witness to the execution of Bani Odeh, said last night. 'The people were very happy. They say that he deserved it. webTitle: Uranium symptoms match US report as cancer fears spread

fields.headline: Uranium symptoms match US report as cancer fears spread
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: Inhaling depleted uranium particles causes acute symptoms identical to those claimed by sick servicemen from the Balkan and Gulf conflicts, according to a US government toxicology report.
fields.body:
Inhaling depleted uranium particles causes acute symptoms identical to those claimed by sick servicemen from the Balkan and Gulf conflicts, according to a US government toxicology report.

The 1998 report by the US Agency for Toxic Substances describes symptoms which include fatigue, shortness of breath, lymphatic problems, bronchial complaints, weight loss, bleeding and unsteady gait.

Italy is investigating the suspicious leukaemia deaths of six of its peacekeepers from Kosovo, where the weapons were heavily used by US pilots. Cases of cancer have also been reported among Belgian, French, Dutch, Spanish and Portuguese soldiers. Governments across Europe have rushed to test their peacekeepers, with Turkey the first country to announce it had detected contamination in two of its soldiers.

Britain - one of the last European governments to offer screening last week - continues to deny any significant health risk. Veterans have accused the Ministry of Defence of a cover-up.

The American report will put further pressure on the MoD to announce a moratorium on the use, manufacture and testing of DU ammunition. It follows the disclosure that the US Navy has already phased out DU weapons for its Phalanx anti-missile gun on safety grounds, forcing the Royal Navy to announce on Friday that it was following suit.

A MoD spokesman said yesterday: 'The US manufacturers have decided not to manufacture depleted uranium rounds any more. They are moving to alternatives. We have no choice but to do the same. All current and proposed future buys of Phalanx ammunition will be of the tungsten variety.'

The Navy's move came as newspapers published a leaked Pentagon document from 1993 which warned: 'When soldiers inhale or ingest DU dust they incur a potential increase in cancer risk... that increase can be quantified in terms of projected days of life lost.'

Another warning in the early Nineties came from an official at AEA Technology, the trading name of the UK Atomic Energy Authority, in a document looking at what might happen if all the DU fired in the Gulf War by tanks - about 8 per cent of the total DU used there - were inhaled. If that happened, it said, there could be half a million deaths as a result by 2000.

Experts in DU poisoning claim that some Iraqi crewmen in tanks hit by DU weapons died not from uranium shrapnel but from acute depleted uranium poisoning on the spot.

The New York Times revealed last week that the Pentagon had urged all Allied forces in Kosovo to take special precautions when approaching the remains of DU ammunition. The document - called 'hazard awareness' - was issued by the US Joint Chiefs of Staff and recommended health screening for some personnel.

Last week brought claims by three prison officers from HMP Featherstone, near Wolverhampton, that they had tested for raised levels of uranium following two fires in the last four years at the adjoining Royal Ordnance factory that produces the shells.

 Additional reporting by Nick Paton Walsh

fields.headline: Anna: radical reforms pledged
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Sweeping changes to Britain's child protection system are being planned by Ministers after the tragic case of Anna Climbie, the girl who was murdered after being failed by social workers, doctors and the police.
fields.body:
Sweeping changes to Britain's child protection system are being planned by Ministers after the tragic case of Anna Climbie, the girl who was murdered after being failed by social workers, doctors and the police.

Social work training will be overhauled, and The Observer can reveal that a three-year training programme is set to replace the present two-year course.

Next month the Department of Health will hold a summit on social work to discuss the recruitment crisis which insiders fear will be made worse by publicity over Anna's case. One in five posts in the South East stood empty last year, with a national vacancy rate of 16 per cent.

Mary Marsh, director of the NSPCC, said: 'The time is right to draw up a national strategy to prevent children dying from abuse and neglect, including setting national targets to reduce child killings.'

Health minister John Hutton promised the Government would take any steps necessary to ensure the 'awful case' did not happen again.

Colleagues yesterday defended Haringey social worker Lisa Arthurworrey - widely criticised for her failure to spot signs of neglect and abuse in Anna, who died of hypothermia and neglect at the hands of her great aunt and her boyfriend. Arthurworrey has been suspended, and four others in Haringey's child protection department are also under investigation over the case.

Heath Secretary Alan Milburn launched an inquiry into the case after Marie Therese Kouao, 44, and Carl Manning, 28, from Tottenham, north London, were found guilty on Friday of murdering the girl in February last year. The agencies involved admitted they had failed to protect Anna from 'truly unimaginable abuse'.

webTitle: What me, hunting? I'm just taking the dogs for a walk

fields.headline: What me, hunting? I'm just taking the dogs for a walk
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: It is a timeless country scene: groups of people innocently enjoying fresh air as they walk their dogs. But there will be nothing innocent about a new form of dog-walking set to spring up throughout Britain.
fields.body:
It is a timeless country scene: groups of people innocently enjoying fresh air as they walk their dogs.

But there will be nothing innocent about a new form of dog-walking set to spring up throughout Britain. Fox hunters have drawn up a secret strategy to bypass a law against hunting. They will pretend to exercise their pets when they are, in fact, in pursuit of their quarry.

In a confidential email obtained by The Observer, the former Tory Home Office Minister David Maclean - a key political adviser to the Countryside Alliance - outlines its strategy ahead of Wednesday's House of Commons vote on whether to ban hunting with dogs.

The email, sent on 3 January to the alliance's political unit, states: 'We must work on the assumption that in 12 months' time there will be legislation banning hunting with dogs. I think the banning option is impossible to enforce, and once we stir up the police about its weakness they will be terrified of trying to implement it.'

He advises that the best hope is to ensure that there are flaws in the Bill and to see that pro-hunting MPs do not 'expose or tighten up the loopholes'.

Maclean states: 'It is absolutely vital that the legislation is flawed and sloppy as possible. The Lords must not clean it up. I want every inconsistency, every dubiety, every ambiguity left in. If the law is clear then we are finished, because most of us will not break the law.

'However, the endgame must be that, on the day that a hunting ban comes into force, we can all turn out with our doggies to go walking and the police and learned professors of law will all say that probably no crime is being committed because the law is so unclear.'

Maclean says the alliance should then mount a legal challenge in Europe using the human rights laws, and secondly bring ' the banning legislation into disrepute by testing it to the limit and exploiting all the loopholes'.

According to Maclean, the alliance plans to sabotage the Bill at its committee stage, where a group of MPs scrutinise the Bill before it goes to the House of Lords. In order to introduce flaws, he advises that 'for the committee upstairs, we will need lots of amendments which do not deal with fundamental weakness nor injustices in the Bill'.

The alliance's tactics have outraged backbench MPs. Ian Cawsey, Labour MP and chair of the Commons All-party Animal Welfare Group, said: 'This would be an appalling abuse of parliamentary procedure. The alliance has failed to win the argument in the Commons and now seems to be trying to sabotage the democratic process instead. There is no way we will let them succeed.'

This is not the first time Maclean's role with the alliance has prompted controversy. In May a confidential letter written by the Tory MP for Penrith to Lord Kimball, the alliance's deputy chairman, revealed how Maclean had orchestrated a plot to wreck the Fireworks Bill which would have protected people from bonfire night injuries.

Maclean did this to 'punish' the Government for 'letting their backbenchers play around with hunting', the letter said.

Other confidential alliance documents passed to The Observer show that the group is worried about losing control of some of its members. A strategy document, written towards the end of last year, states: 'Many supporters are threatening to take aggressive action - even eventually to go to prison.' Another paper talks of the formation of a 'provisional wing' of the Countryside Alliance.

Further confidential documents suggest a growing concern among alliance members about the group's chief executive Richard Burge, who is a Labour Party member. One email from chairman John Jackson to the alliance board and other key supporters including Maclean and the Duke of Westminster, says: 'I am furious about the attacks on Richard. It is those people who will lose the game for everyone if we are not careful.'

Mike Baker, UK director of the International Fund for Animal Welfare, said: 'It looks like we can expect increasing desperate actions from the hunt lobby. Their attempts to mislead people into voting for hunting via the so-called Middle Way have failed and [they] now admit that a hunting ban is inevitable... '

An alliance spokeswoman said Maclean's email 'was simply a result of some post- new year brainstorming. We get many such suggestions from supporters inside and outside Parliament. The Government has been working on this Bill for months, so it ought to be well drafted.'

She stressed that 'supporters of hunting do not have a majority on the standing committee and therefore pro-hunting amendments are hardly likely to be accepted'.

Maclean was not available for comment.

webTitle: How names are in our genes

fields.headline: How names are in our genes
fields.standfirst: What you are called is closely connected to your genetic makeup, say scientists - and this surprising link reveals a lot about infidelity. Robin McKie reports
fields.trailText: What you are called is closely connected to your genetic makeup, say scientists - and this surprising link reveals a lot about infidelity. Robin McKie reports.
fields.body:
What's in a name? The question has puzzled writers and thinkers for centuries. Now scientists have provided an answer: our names reveal the nature of our genes and our biological past.

Oxford researchers have discovered that names are more than labels. They reveal critical information about our natures and our roots.

The discovery is being exploited by individuals who are using their DNA to reveal key information about their family trees. One day it might even be possible to name a criminal simply from the DNA that he leaves behind at the scene of a crime.

'We have found that a person's genotype and surname are incredibly closely connected,' said Professor Bryan Sykes, of the Institute of Molecular Medicine, Oxford. 'It is really quite startling, and very informative.'

The Oxford group's discovery is the result of a remarkable investigation into Sykes's own family tree, a lineage that he has traced back to around AD1300. Surnames were first introduced at this time, when laws were changed to allow farm tenancies to be inherited, forcing people to be able to prove their identities.

Nicknames, local geographical terms and - most often - professions were adopted for surnames: hence the plethora of Smiths and Millers in Britain. The name Sykes, however, was taken from a Yorkshire word for boundary ditch - which explains why distribution maps of Sykes's produce a cluster in villages around Huddersfield.

Surnames are inherited through the male line - and so are Y-chromosomes, the packages of genes responsible for conferring maleness on a human. The question Sykes asked was simple: Were the two linked in any way?

'I got the idea for researching the two when I agreed to give a Glaxo Wellcome lecture on genetics and genealogy,' Sykes said. 'I knew its chief executive Sir Richard Sykes would be in the audience, and so I suggested that we should try to find out if we were related.'

With a DNA brush, used to slough cells from a person's cheek, samples of their genes were analysed, along with those from several dozen other Sykeses who had been selected from the electoral register. Both men, and more than half the sample of other Sykeses tested, were found to have the same Y chromosome.

'It was a wonderful discovery, one of those things that shows how exciting science can be,' Sir Richard said. 'Bryan and I now know we have a common ancestor with all those other Sykeses.'

In other words, for the past 700 years a lineage of Sykes' genes has been spreading like a web through generations - and in the majority of cases has remained unbroken. And what is true for the Sykes clan applies to the rest of the country. Research on other surnames has also shown more than half of their possessors share the same Y chromosome.

Chromosomes are shuffled from one generation to another - except for the Y-chromosome which is passed from father to son like a surname. 'What is remarkable is that both name and Y-chromosome have remained linked for more than 20 generations,' said Bryan Sykes.

'It would only take a single act of infidelity to break this link, after all. Yet after 700 years, surname and Y-chromosome remained connected in more than 50 per cent of the men. That indicates an illegitimacy rate of less than 1 per cent a generation.'

Such a figure flies in the face of studies which have claimed that - due to mothers' infidelities - between 5 per cent and 10 per cent of people are unrelated to the person they call dad. 'Our work flatly contradicts those figures, and indicates that family life in Britain has been a lot more stable and trusting than it has been given credit for,' he said.

Individuals sharing a surname can now send off to the professor for a set of DNA brushes and sample pouches and so find out if they share the same Y-chromosome.

Launched last month, the £120 test has proved popular with people researching their family tree, particularly Americans. In cases where two unconnected branches of a surname exist - for example, one from Essex and one from Cornwall - a DNA test can reveal to which group an individual belongs.

'This test only works with men because it relies on the Y-chromosome, of course,' Sykes said. If a woman wants to find out such information she will have to find out via her father or brother.'

Sykes is an expert at tracing lineages - including those of pet hamsters, shown to be all descended from a single female found in the Syrian desert 70 years ago.

He has used this knowledge to set up Oxford Ancestors, a private company that now operates his Y-chromosome analysis service under the commercial label Y-Line.

It also offers another service - MatriLine - which does for female DNA what Y-Line does for the Y-chromosome. 'There is a packet of genetic material called mitochondrial DNA that is inherited through the female line,' Sykes said. 'We can use that to trace back a whole web of relatedness among individuals.'

In one case mitochondrial DNA was extracted from a 9,000-year-old found in the Cheddar Gorge and linked to a local schoolteacher.
