fields.bodyText: What's in a name? The question has puzzled writers and thinkers for centuries. Now scientists have provided an answer: our names reveal the nature of our genes and our biological past. Oxford researchers have discovered that names are more than labels. They reveal critical information about our natures and our roots. The discovery is being exploited by individuals who are using their DNA to reveal key information about their family trees. One day it might even be possible to name a criminal simply from the DNA that he leaves behind at the scene of a crime. 'We have found that a person's genotype and surname are incredibly closely connected,' said Professor Bryan Sykes, of the Institute of Molecular Medicine, Oxford. 'It is really quite startling, and very informative.' The Oxford group's discovery is the result of a remarkable investigation into Sykes's own family tree, a lineage that he has traced back to around AD1300. Surnames were first introduced at this time, when laws were changed to allow farm tenancies to be inherited, forcing people to be able to prove their identities. Nicknames, local geographical terms and - most often - professions were adopted for surnames: hence the plethora of Smiths and Millers in Britain. The name Sykes, however, was taken from a Yorkshire word for boundary ditch - which explains why distribution maps of Sykes's produce a cluster in villages around Huddersfield. Surnames are inherited through the male line - and so are Y-chromosomes, the packages of genes responsible for conferring maleness on a human. The question Sykes asked was simple: Were the two linked in any way? 'I got the idea for researching the two when I agreed to give a Glaxo Wellcome lecture on genetics and genealogy,' Sykes said. With a DNA brush, used to slough cells from a person's cheek, samples of their genes were analysed, along with those from several dozen other Sykeses who had been selected from the electoral register. Both men, and more than half the sample of other Sykeses tested, were found to have the same Y chromosome. 'It was a wonderful discovery, one of those things that shows how exciting science can be,' Sir Richard said. 'Bryan and I now know we have a common ancestor with all those other Sykeses.' 'It would only take a single act of infidelity to break this link, after all. Yet after 700 years, surname and Y-chromosome remained connected in more than 50 per cent of the men. In cases where two unconnected branches of a surname exist - for example, one from Essex and one from Cornwall - a DNA test can reveal to which group an individual belongs. 'This test only works with men because it relies on the Y-chromosome, of course,' Sykes said. If a woman wants to find out such information she will have to find out via her father or brother.' Sykes is an expert at tracing lineages - including those of pet hamsters, shown to be all descended from a single female found in the Syrian desert 70 years ago. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: One man was killed and a second seriously injured when their microlight aircraft crashed on farmland near Sandon, Staffordshire.
fields.body:
Man dies as microlight plunges to the ground

One man was killed and a second seriously injured when their microlight aircraft crashed on farmland near Sandon, Staffordshire. It was thought to have taken off from Liverpool. A man in his late thirties was airlifted to the trauma unit at the North Staffordshire Royal Infirmary in Stoke-on-Trent with suspected internal injuries. A doctor pronounced the other dead at the scene.

Police sealed off the crash site and both the Air Accident Investigation Bureau and the British Gliding Association, the governing body for microlight flying, were informed.

A spokesman for Staffordshire Ambulance Service said the emergency services had reached the 'remote' scene of the accident within seven minutes of being alerted by members of the public. No communication had been reported between the aircraft and the ground.

PC guru under investigation

John Williamson, 34, who as deputy director of Greater Manchester Police public affairs prepared a guide on politically correct conduct, has been suspended pending an investigation into allegations that he sexually harassed four women colleagues at a Christmas party.

His 16-page Power of Language advised the force's 7,000 officers to avoid such terms of endearment as 'love', 'pet', and 'dear' because people might find them offensive.

Rare fungi find

A rare mushroom from North America, seen only once before in Britain, has been found on a roundabout near Leatherhead in Surrey by expert Dr Peter Shaw. It is believed it got into the UK in plant material being sent to Kew Gardens.

Rediscovered opera singer Kyra Vayne dies from cancer

Russian-born opera singer Kyra Vayne, above, has died of liver cancer aged 84. She was popular in London in the Forties and Fifties but her career collapsed with the suicide of her agent, Eugene Iskoldoff, in 1957.

For the next 35 years she worked as a secretary for the BBC. Her singing talent was re-discovered by chance in the early 1990s, which led to the release of four CDs, an appearance on Desert Island Discs and the publication of her autobiography A Voice Reborn.

Nearly 80 years after she fled from Russia she was invited back to perform at Moscow's Bolshoi Theatre to mark the millennium celebrations.

Man's body found on beach

The body of a man has been found on a beach in Tenby, Pembrokeshire. The death is not thought to be suspicious.

Gynaecologist struck off

A retired gynaecologist, found to have used undue force in delivering three babies, was ordered to be struck off by the professional conduct committee of the General Medical Council.

Dr Janusz Wszeborowski, 67, of Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, who was found guilty of serious professional misconduct, acted 'inappropriately and with gross insensitivity when providing treatment to three women during childbirth, and when carrying out a vaginal examination on a fourth patient'. A fifth had been 'considerably distressed' by the 'inappropriate and insensitive use of a mobile phone in her presence'.

In each birth he used a Ventouse Cap, known as a vacuum extractor, and was cleared of pulling on this with undue force. He was cleared of slapping the thighs of two of the women.

Yachtsman rescued

A British yachtsman, aged 60, who left Madeira for the Virgin Islands on Christmas Day, was rescued by the Cypriot bulk carrier Baynes off Cape Verde Islands. The unnamed man was three days adrift after problems with the rudder of his yacht Ozama.

Cloning not sunk by Noah

Scientists say they will renew attempts to clone endangered animals, despite the death of Noah, a cloned gaur - a rare Asian bison - last week. Noah was born to Bessie the cow, last Monday, but died of a bacterial infection. 'There was nothing wrong with our cloning technology,' said Phil Damiani, of the biotech firm, Advanced Cell Technologies (ACT). 'It was bad luck she picked up the bug.'

webTitle: Human Rights Act helps Irish killer avoid justice

fields.headline: Act helps brutal killer avoid justice
fields.standfirst:
Convicted murderer could be 'exported' to England under human rights legislation

Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Convicted murderer could be 'exported' to England under human rights legislation.
fields.body:
A brutal convicted murderer who has confessed to stabbing two elderly Irish women to death may escape trial because he is being transferred to a prison closer to his home and daughter in Leeds.

The families of his victims claim that the move, made possible under new Human Rights Act legislation, to 'export' Mark Nash from Ireland to an English prison avoids a new trial that would throw up allegations of police incompetence and the framing of an innocent man.

They have accused the Garda and the Irish Republic's Director of Public Prosecutions of being involved in a massive cover-up. The decision to allow Nash to exercise his right to be transferred under the Human Rights Act has only confirmed their sus picions that the Irish state wants rid of this troublesome prisoner.

Nash is currently serving a life sentence in Dublin's Arbour Hill jail for the frenzied murder in August 1997 of a young Roscommon couple, Catherine and Carl Doyle.

Nash also confessed to another double murder the same year. But despite giving a detailed confession Nash only ever faced a trial for killing the Doyles.

The trouble for the Garda in the other murder six months earlier was that they had already charged another man with the killings, Dean Lyons, a 24-year-old homeless heroin addict.

On the night of 6 March 1997, Sylvia Shields, 59, and Mary Callinan, 61, were repeatedly stabbed and mutilated at their home in the grounds of Grangegorman Hospital in north Dublin.

The double murder was extraordinarily brutal and the forensic psychiatrist warned gardai that the murderer would strike again.

Dean Lyons who was living rough in Grangegorman was arrested on 25 July and after hours of questioning gave detectives a series of statements admitting he carried out the killings. During the interrogation he was suffering the 'cold turkey' effect of heroin withdrawal.

Lyons also suffered from severe psychiatric problems, which caused him to fear authority figures and put his hand up for things he had never done.

But while gardai trumpeted their triumph in catching the Grangegorman murderer on the Irish state broadcaster RTE, the real killer struck again.

On 16 August 1997, with Lyons in jail on remand, a young couple were brutally murdered at their home on the County Roscommon/ Galway border. Catherine Doyle's sister Sarah-Jane, who was Nash's girlfriend at the time, was beaten around the head with a stove handle, but managed to survive.

The killing, involving frenzied stabbing with a kitchen knife, bore striking similarities to the one in Grangegorman. Mark Nash, the son of an Irish prostitute and a Jamaican father, was arrested the following day by gardai in Galway. After admitting to the murder of the Doyles, Nash then gave a detailed account of how Sylvia Shields and Mary Callinan met their deaths.

The Observer has seen Nash's statements, which include a detailed map he sketched of Shields and Callinan's home. Beside the map Nash wrote: 'Rough Sketch of House where I killed The Two Ladies.'

Critically, Nash also told gardai in his confession to the Grangegorman murder that there was another woman in the house, who he spared.

This was a crucial piece of evidence because none of the news broadcasts or reports into the murder had mentioned the presence of a third woman in the house. Despite Nash's confession Dean Lyons was held on remand in Mountjoy Prison for nine months. Then without explanation or apology, Ireland's Chief State Solicitor withdrew the murder charges against Lyons and ordered his release from jail.

Nash meanwhile was subsequently charged with only the Doyle murders while the Garda carried out an internal inquiry into the handling of the Grangegorman case. The results of that inquiry have yet to be published. The 27-year-old murderer later retracted his Grangegorman confession on the advice of cellmates in Arbour Hill or, as one garda officer put it, 'jail house lawyers'.

A spokesman for the Irish Prison Service confirmed last week that Nash has now applied to be transferred to a jail closer to his home in Leeds, where he can receive visits from his daughter.

'No decision has been made yet as it requires the consent of the prisoner and the two states, Ireland and Britain,' he said.

Catherine Doyle's father Pat, however, said he has been told by the authorities that Nash will be shifted to a prison in England. Pat Doyle and his wife have been left to bring up Catherine and Carl Doyle's four children, the youngest of whom was only a new-born baby when Nash butchered their parents.

'The authorities are looking to get rid of this animal so they can avoid the other trial on the Grangegorman killing. They made a bollocks of that case and now they need to get him out of Ireland before the truth comes out.

'I would like people in England to know what kind of bastard is being transferred to one of their prisons. Several people in the Irish prison service have told me that Nash is a model prisoner, that he has served three years and could be out on good behaviour in five or six years time. This man will kill again. I want him to remain in an Irish jail for life for what he did to my family,' Doyle said.

He added that justice must be done for Dean Lyons given that he had spent nine months in jail for an horrific crime he did not commit.

Lyons's father Jackie supported the Doyle family's call for Nash to be kept in Ireland regardless of the Human Rights Act.

'The Garda were very quick to fit my fellah up for those murders in Grangegorman, which he never did. Dean was innocent, he was an addict and incapable of doing something terrible like that. I want a trial to go ahead into those killings and see that bastard Nash on trial.

'Even though the charges were dropped and he was freed, there is still a cloud of suspicion over Dean. No one apologised or said sorry to Dean about what happened to him.'

The Irish state no longer needs to apologise to Lyons. The homeless heroin addict died alone of an overdose in Manchester just before Christmas.

fields.headline: War artists censored Kitchener's squint
fields.standfirst: Famed Great War recruiting poster drew over a million volunteers but in real life the hero's shifty look kept people at bay
fields.trailText: Famed Great War recruiting poster drew over a million volunteers but in real life the hero's shifty look kept people at bay.
fields.body:
It was the piercing gaze that carried Britain through the First World War: the eyes of Kitchener of Khartoum, staring out of a recruiting poster with the words 'Your Country Needs YOU'.

It is an image recognised throughout the world and copied many times. But a new biography of Herbert Horatio Kitchener reveals that those who worked on this haunting appeal for volunteers to fight in the Great War deliberately hid his pronounced squint.

'Far from being able to follow people with his eyes,' said John Pollock, author of the new study, 'several of those who met him reported that they could not tell whether he was looking at them or not. He had a very definite cast in one eye.'

Pollock's detailed research into the second half of Kitchener's life has uncovered fresh explanations for the distant behaviour of a man whose reputation has been alternately raised up and dragged down. Opponents and historians have attacked Kitchener for being anything from aloof to actively inhumane, but Pollock now believes that the man's restricted vision, combined with the effects of a facial war wound, created a barrier between the veteran soldier and his fellow men.

'I was researching at Nuffield College, Oxford, when I came across the papers of General Lovick Friend, who helped lay out Khartoum with the general when he was an engineer officer. He writes that Kitchener was unable to play tennis or cricket because of his eye sight and that it was impossible to tell when he was looking at you,' said Pollock. 'Then I remembered the words of a journalist who visited Kitchener to ask him about the use of concentration camps in South Africa. He too said that Kitchener was unable to look at him directly.'

The famous poster, recently voted the most powerful advertising image of the last century and which led to the recruitment of the 2,500,000-strong 'Kitchener's Army', came into existence almost by chance. It had first been designed as an illustration in the newspaper London Opinion . Then the War Office, under Kitchener, judged it to be so powerful that it was requisitioned for public use.

Pollock's book says 'K of K's' squint was corrected by War Office artists and the moustache thickened to create an imposing impression. 'It was not actually put out until September, a little way into the recruitment drive designed by propaganda chief Henry Le Bas,' said Pollock. 'But the effect on the number of volunteers coming forward was immediate.'

A BBC documentary three years ago made a number of serious accusations about Kitchener's war record, focusing on his first sanctioned use of concentration camps in South Africa and on his alleged decision to leave hundreds of Dervishes dying on the battlefield of Omdurman without medical aid. The programme also disputed the impact of the famous poster.

The Empire's Flawed Hero, part of the Reputations series, alleged that the poster was never sanctioned by the government and that others were more effective. These findings are challenged by Pollock's new research. 'Within four months nearly 1.2 million volunteers had stepped forward to fight,' he said. 'That is incontrovertible.'

The new volume of his biography, entitled Saviour of the Nation, chronicles the War Office decision to alter the requirements for height to stem the flow of recruits.

Pollock believes that Kitchener's stern bearing was the result of a bullet wound to the jaw when he was Governor in Eastern Sudan. He argues that these physical problems contributed to his failure to communicate and caused him to be disliked.Pollock added: 'Kitchener, as a figurehead and as a man, played an invaluable part in the war effort. I think it is possible that, if he had not been killed at sea in 1916, World War Two might have been prevented.'

Pollock points to Kitchener's strong Christian faith and his early understanding of the need to reconcile with Germany. 'If he had not gone down with the Hampshire in that terrible storm his influence might have gone some way to stop Germany becoming so bitter in the following years.'

Pollock points to Kitchener's strong Christian faith and his early understanding of the need to reconcile with Germany. 'If he had not gone down with the Hampshire in that terrible storm his influence might have gone some way to stop Germany becoming so bitter in the following years.' vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Beavers return after four centuries
fields.standfirst: Ecologists are championing the beaver as a creator and manager of wetlands, but some landowners remain hostile
fields.trailText: Ecologists are championing the beaver as a creator and manager of wetlands, but some landowners remain hostile.
fields.body:
Hunted for its pelt and boiled to make soup, it last gnawed down a tree and dammed a river in these islands four centuries ago. But this year, pitting landowners in a fierce battle against environmentalists, the beaver is set to make a historic comeback.

Originally as British as badgers and foxes, beavers were hunted to extinction about 800 years ago in England and 400 years ago in Scotland. Now two separate projects aim to reintroduce the species to the wild, north and south of the border, following the example of other European countries, including the Netherlands and Germany. Scottish Natural Heritage plans to release beavers in Knapdale forest, Argyll, while English Nature has given the provisional go-ahead to release them in the Fens of East Anglia.

'It's a keystone species,' said David Gow, project manager of the Wild Wood Centre in Kent, a beaver breeder who is campaigning for its reintroduction. 'It makes and manages wetlands, creating habitats for other species. It would bring immense ecological benefits.'

If it has an expanse of water no more than two yards wide, the beaver builds a dam from trees and mud to create a pond as a place to live. It then builds a huge lodge on the edge of the water, with submerged entrances. If anyone damages the dam, it immediately comes out of the lodge to repair it. The ponds can flood huge areas - drowning trees - but they also create habitats and drinking places for many other animals such as otter and deer.

Beavers - which are vegetarians - sometimes graze like sheep, leaving well-trimmed 'beaver lawns' by the waterside.

Looking at a massive mud and log beaver lodge and a felled oak tree in a huge enclosed pond, Gow enthused about their virtues. 'Baby beavers are so cute. They hold hands when they sleep,' he said. He plans to place some Norwegian beavers in a 100-acre enclosure in the Fens, before releasing them completely in the wild.

A survey by Scottish Natural Heritage two years ago showed the public was keen on beavers. Having identified the exact site in Argyll, the body has just finished consulting with those in the immediate vicinity. 'The vast majority of locals are in favour of it. Only a few landowners are opposed,' said SNH spokesman George Anderson.

Landowner Robin Malcolm, whose family has owned 5,000 acres in the area for 200 years, is the most vociferously opposed. He is worried they will bring disease, cut down or drown valuable trees, ruin the drainage of the area, and damage salmon stocks. Top of his concern is their effect on the River Add: 'What happens if they dam some of the tributaries? It could do untold damage to the spawning of salmon,' he said.

SNH insists it is just conducting a trial release of 12 animals, which will be tagged. 'If they do a runner they'll be brought back,' insisted Anderson. If they do too much damage, they'll be hunted down and the project abandoned. 'The only way we'll know how beavers act in the wild will be in a trial,' said Anderson. 'They are very, very easy to trap. We got rid of them before with nothing more than bows and arrows.'

Alison Hay, leader of Argyll and Bute Council, is also committed to reintroducing the beaver, seeing it as an aid to the local economy. 'We think tourists would be drawn to this area, and we see this as a benefit,' she said.

Gow dismisses fears about disease and damage to salmon - which can jump over dams - as nonsense. But on the other issues, he admits that landowners like Malcolm have a point: 'You are going to have a degree of commercial loss when the beaver population develops.'

He also agrees it is likely that, once they are released, they're here to stay, however much damage they cause. 'Do you think the Government is going to tell the public that it is going to kill these cute alphabet animals?'

However, he insists that's a small price to pay, and farmers can be compensated. 'We've got to shed these Victorian values, where every animal that causes any trouble has to be exterminated. Do you need all this timber? Does it really matter if a beaver floods an area? We'll lose a few conifers, but so what? The other environmental benefits will be immense.'

Next month the board of SNH will vote whether to go ahead with the project, which must then be passed by the Scottish Executive. If it gives the thumbs up, beavers will be imported from Norway this summer, held in quarantine for six months and then released in the wild in a year's time. The Environment Agency and local landowners have to give the go-ahead to the fenland project.

The beaver crusade is rapidly getting support in Westminster. Jon Owen Jones, a Welsh Labour MP, said: 'There's a moral obligation on a country that believes you should retain tigers and lions in other countries to reintroduce species we've made extinct.'

There is also an obligation under European law for countries to consider ways to bring back species they have made extinct in recent centuries. Gow sees a long battle ahead with landowners, but is confident of victory. 'This is going to happen. It's inevitable,' he said.

From pelts to painkillers: a guide to Europe's biggest rodent

 The last record of beavers in Scotland is in the seventeenth century when German traders came to Inverness to buy pelts.

 Beavers were last recorded south of the border in Wales when the monk Geraldus was recruiting for the Crusades in the twelfth century.

 Beavers were hunted for their exceptionally warm pelts, used to make coats and hats.

 Hats were also made by shaving off the fur, boiling it and compressing it to make a form of felt.

 Beavers are vegetarian, eating water plants and willow bark, and grazing on grass.

 Beavers build dams from logs and mud if there are no open expanses of water to live in.

 The anal gland of the beaver was prized as a source of salicylic acid, a painkiller chemically similar to aspirin.

 It is Europe's largest rodent, can weigh up to 20 kilograms and lives to about 12 years old.

 Beavers were popular food at Lent, since church authorities said they were 'of the water' and, like fish, could be eaten.

 The beaver has been reintroduced to almost all countries in mainland Europe. There are North American beavers in every state of the US and every Canadian province.

fields.headline: Road lessons 'lead to teenage deaths'
fields.trailText: The country's top paediatricians have called on the Government to halt its driver-education programme in schools because it is leading to more teenage deaths and casualties on the roads.
fields.body:
The country's top paediatricians have called on the Government to halt its driver-education programme in schools because it is leading to more teenage deaths and casualties on the roads.

Research from the United States, Australia and the UK has shown that such teaching projects are good at encouraging more youngsters to get behind the wheel of a car, but do nothing to improve their erratic driving performance.

Some studies have indicated that students who have been through the programmes have a marginally higher accident rate and commit more motoring offences. And one US research project revealed that teenage crashes dropped by a third when the education programmes were stopped.

Yet the Government last month announced a massive expansion of our student programmes - targeting some 750,000 16- to 18-year-olds this year alone.

Using the most conservative estimates from the combined research - that the programmes persuade an extra 2 per cent of young people to get driving licences - this is likely to result in an extra 15,000 teenagers on the roads. About 3,000 of those will have an accident in their first year of driving. At its most extreme an extra 6 per cent or 48,000 may be induced to drive with 9,600 at risk of a fatal crash.

Ian Roberts, director of the Institute of Child Health and a member of the international Cochrane Injuries Group, said: 'It is scandalous that the Government is putting money into programmes based on untested hunches because they sound good, rather than on scientific evidence which suggests they do not work.'

Tomorrow he and road safety groups are to meet with Lord Whitty, the Minister for Road Safety, to express their concerns. So urgent do they consider the matter that, in the meantime, 12 leading community paediatricians from around the country have written to Tony Blair asking him to intervene.

Yesterday a spokesman for the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions rejected the claims. 'Young people of that age are usually already keen to drive. They are bombarded with glamorous images of cars and driving,' he said.

webTitle: City firms get their skis on to perk up staff

fields.headline: City firms get their skis on to perk up staff
fields.trailText: In the eighties there was fire-walking and tree-hugging. The nineties saw paint-balling and go-karting. Now the new millennium has taken corporate bonding to new heights.
fields.body:
In the eighties there was fire-walking and tree-hugging. The nineties saw paint-balling and go-karting. Now the new millennium has taken corporate bonding to new heights.

Forget the free lunch: the only perk to boast of in City circles these days is a weekend on the piste.

Whether you are wooing new clients or keeping your staff away from the headhunters, skiing is the new corporate beano to jolly everyone along.

Big retailers, property consultants and merchant banks are convinced that networking in a picturesque mountain setting works so well that they are shelling out up to £2,000 a head.

'Everyone returns in the evenings, puts their feet up in the bar and talks about what happened on the slopes,' said Natalie Loughran, membership director of the British Venture Capital Association, which was a pioneer in group skiing trips.

Jonathan Blake, a lawyer at London firm FJ Berwin and Co, is a veteran of Alpine bonding. 'I must say these trips are seen as a benefit rather than a burden,' he said. 'It's great fun and there can't be too much talking shop because of what you are doing and where you are. It's far better than the situation when one goes to a conference not for the speeches but to network in the coffee breaks. Mind you, it does depend on the people you go with. I have always gone with venture capitalists - I don't know if I fancy a weekend with the Law Society.'

Companies are beginning to offer tailor-made packages for corporate snow jollies but one of the first firms to notice the niche in the market was Brighton-based Flexiski. 'It seems that this is becoming a quite fashionable thing to do. It is now about 50 per cent of our business,' said manager Nicky Stephenson.

'It is mainly commercial and retail banks and the retail industry where corporate entertainment and rewarding staff or providing incentives for managers is a big part of their business.

'Our cheapest package is probably around £400 for a weekend, but then there is the upper end with five-star hotels and our resort teams arranging things like torchlight descents of mountains and heli-skiing,' he said

It's not all good news though, as one company director who is due to fly off for his firm's 'chalet dally', as he called it, told The Observer. 'I know that the money being spent on this has come out of the Christmas bonus pot for the staff. No doubt that would lose management a bit of goodwill all round should it be known.'

There is always the danger that showering the influential with freebies can one day backfire - when Harrods boss Mohamed al-Fayed gave generous yet unsolicited gifts of hampers to journalists and MPs, it went down like a lead balloon.

Corporate ski trips take the risk a step further - with danger to life and limb included in the package. But the opportunity to aim a crafty snowball at the boss's back is too good an opportunity to miss.

fields.headline: Stars to inspire couch potatoes
fields.standfirst: Sports heroes sign up for campaign to tear the nation's idle youths away from TV and computers
fields.trailText: Sports heroes sign up for campaign to tear the nation's idle youths away from TV and computers.
fields.body:
Top British sports stars will urge the nation's youth to swap PlayStations for trainers in a new war on teenage couch potatoes.

Olympic champions Steve Redgrave and Denise Lewis will be among stars touring schools, youth clubs and community centres telling young people to watch less television and take exercise instead. Seeing their heroes' medals and hearing their success stories is expected to inspire millions of children.

Organisers hope the campaign will reduce the rising number of inactive, overweight youngsters, reverse the decline in school sport and help produce a new generation of world champions. Called Sporting Champions, it will start across England this summer, with around 300 visits in its first year.

Sydney Olympics medallists Matthew Pinsent and Kelly Holmes, and Tanni Grey-Thompson, winner of four golds at the Paralympics, are also among the ranks of high-profile sportspeople already committed to becoming 'evangelists' who will preach the gospel of sport.

David Beckham, Nasser Hussain and Martin Johnson, England's football, cricket and rugby captains, are expected to take part, as are top tennis duo Tim Henman and Greg Rusedski.

'The idea is that young people will be inspired and motivated by the example of people they see on television to become sporting champions themselves,' said Martin Cork, who has helped put together the initiative for Sport England. 'It will champion the values and benefits of playing sport both inside and outside school. We're particularly interested in young people who currently find sport a bit of a turn-off and prefer playing computer games or watching television.

'Sportspeople are used to getting a lot of rewards from what they do. This is a way of putting something back into their sport, and many of them are keen to do exactly that.'

Lewis already visits schools near her Birmingham home, as does Grey-Thompson, who has helped devise the scheme.

Olympic marksman Richard Faulds, who won gold in the double trap clay pigeon shooting in Sydney, said the initiative was overdue: 'I've visited several schools since winning my medal at the Games and the kids get so excited. They love having the gold medal in front of them and being able to touch it, and they ask me what the atmosphere of the Olympics was like and what sort of life sportspeople have.

'I tell them that if they want sporting success badly enough, and have the right commitment, anything's possible. If people like me doing things like that encourage kids to play sport - whatever sport it is, and either seriously or just for enjoyment - then it's a good idea.'

The governing bodies of soccer, rugby, cricket, tennis and athletics have all agreed to get involved. UK Athletics has pledged that 40 track and field athletes, from veterans to emerging talents, will take part in the scheme. Tony Blair, the Prime Minister, has pledged that £1billion will be spent on building more sports facilities in schools.

Sportspeople will tell their young audiences that fair play and sportsmanship are important and warn about the dangers of using drugs to improve performance.

They will be paid £100-£150 a visit, while a nucleus of Sporting Champions 'captains' will receive £5,000 a year for promoting the scheme and recruiting fellow professionals. Local football and rugby clubs will promote the scheme in their areas.

A Sporting Champions club will welcome youngsters of all abilities, from top performers to honest triers. Members will receive personal letters from stars, signed photographs, newsletters, stickers and merchandise. Cork explained: 'A youngster who breaks a leg playing football might receive a letter or email from Stuart Pearce, who broke his leg twice in one season appearing for West Ham, saying: "It happened to me and I recovered, so you can too. Good luck."

Sport England approved the scheme last week and will now decide how much to spend on it. This will probably be around £100,000 a year. Chairman Trevor Brooking, the ex-England footballer, and vice-chair Tessa Sanderson, the ex-Olympic javelin champion, are now recruiting big name participants.

In a separate development, Premiership football stars are preparing to help under-achieving school pupils learn to read. Sixteen of the 20 Premier League clubs already have after-school study support centres. This week Aston Villa star Paul Merson will launch a campaign to encourage people to read books linked to the nickname of the club they support. Fans of Arsenal, known as the Gunners, can choose from a reading list with a military theme, for example.

fields.headline: Deadly form of ecstasy seized
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: A deadly new variant of ecstasy linked to dozens of deaths across the globe has arrived in Britain.
fields.body:
A deadly new variant of ecstasy linked to dozens of deaths across the globe has arrived in Britain.

Substantial quantities of the drug, known on the street as 'Double Stacked', were seized by police in the Birmingham area a few weeks before Christmas. The drug, which is difficult to distinguish from ecstasy, contains PMA, a stimulant 20 times more powerful than amphetamines, and causes the user to hallucinate. PMA has been linked to several deaths in Europe and two people died from taking it in Chicago earlier this year.

Also known as 'Chicken Yellow' or 'Chicken Fever', PMA is often contained in a thick white tablet. Some tablets are known as 'Mitsubushi Turbos' because they have the Japanese car brand's logo etched into the pill.

PMA has not yet had time to make a big impact on the UK club drug scene. 'PMA is a class A drug,' said a senior Scotland Yard source. 'It is the most sexy and the most dangerous. Obviously there's the opportunity for it to get into the club scene and the success of this depends on how much has arrived in the UK.'

PMA, or paramethoxy-amphetamine, was considered responsible for the death of 18-year-old Chicago woman Sara Aeschlimann last year. She died from the collapse of her organs and severe internal bleeding. Her temperature had risen to 108 C and authorities described her body as being 'cooked from the inside'. Substantial quantities of the drug, known on the street as 'Double Stacked', were seized by police in the Birmingham area a few weeks before Christmas. Some tablets are known as 'Mitsubushi Turbos' because they have the Japanese car brand's logo etched into the pill. PMA has not yet had time to make a big impact on the UK club drug scene. 'PMA is a class A drug,' said a senior Scotland Yard source. 'It is the most sexy and the most dangerous. fields.headline: Courier who trades in misery
fields.standfirst:
A former manicurist from Vietnam brings girls from his land to be sold on London's streets. Amelia Hill completes a three-part Observer investigation into child prostitution

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A former manicurist from Vietnam brings girls from his land to be sold on London's streets.  Amelia Hill  completes a three-part Observer investigation into child prostitution.
fields.body:
Toan's large eyes were damp and unfocused as he leant through the car window. 'Give me half an hour,' he slurred. 'I'll get brown - heroin - and come back. Please don't go anywhere - I want to talk.'

Within the hour he was back, emerging from the shadows behind a housing estate in Brixton, south London, which is infamous for sheltering the two roughest drug dealers in the area. 'Let's go to a bar,' he said, clapping his hands together as he jumped into the car. He was alert now, confident and charming. 'I want some coffee.'

Toan is a refugee and a drug addict. Until four months ago, the 35-year-old was a manicurist's assistant in Streatham High Street. Now he is a courier, buying young girls to order from his native Vietnam and bringing them to London, where he delivers them to pimps keen to capitalise on the growing demand for foreign children.

Toan is the final link in The Observer's three-part investigation into a disturbing new development in Britain's sex trade where girls as young as six are brought into the country, imprisoned in private, West End flats and forced to submit to sex with paedophiles.

Toan entered the murky world of prostitution four months ago to support his own heroin habit. 'In eight years in this country, I had never touched drugs,' he said, pouring packet after packet of sugar into his coffee and stumbling around his small English vocabulary to find enough words to express himself. 'But then I spent two days in a drug house with a friend. After so long, I wanted to try it. It was only supposed to be once.'

Within a month Toan, a father of two young boys and the sole provider for his family, was spending more than £100 a day on heroin. His habit put paid to his day job. 'After I stopped work, I had to find enough money for the drugs and to hide the truth from my wife,' he said. Then he remembered the two Vietnamese girls who had started work at the manicure parlour shortly before he left.

'They had paid a man called Duy to bring them here and I saw how easy it was. I knew men who wanted to sell the sex of young girls. Everybody wants young girls now, especially foreign girls,' he said. 'Two years ago it cost £20,000 to get a girl; now it costs half.'

Toan set up business with Duy. 'Already I have seven men asking me for girls - it's amazing,' he exclaimed. 'I have so much money my wife thinks I've had a promotion!'

Toan is from Hong Gai, a city on a part of the Vietnamese coastline so beautiful that travel books refer to it as the eighth wonder of the world. Until recently, however, the province was drowning in violence and poverty, exacerbated by the devastation left behind by the American war. Toan mimes a machine gun and sprays the bar with imaginary bullets to demonstrate the day-to-day violence he experienced.

In 1987, with the help of a Chinese guide, Toan and his partner, Thu, smuggled themselves over the border to Hong Kong, where they were given refugee status.

They married in Hong Kong and had their first child, a son. Toan worked in a cotton thread factory and Thu stitched clothes. In 1992 Britain opened its gates to an enlarged quota of refugees, and Toan brought his young family across. 'I will never leave here now,' he said. 'Here is big money and nice life.'

The girls he buys take a more direct route into the country. With the help of friends in Immigration, they fly from Vietnam to France and are driven to London. The journey costs Toan £11,000; he sends £3,000 to Vietnam, £6,000 to await collection in France and the last £2,000 is paid on delivery. 'Duy never has any problems because if he does I will take my money back and he will be in trouble with the people he has bribed,' he explained.

'Duy will do this for anybody but I don't tell my customers that: they think it's difficult to arrange but it's so easy to order these girls: my customers tell me what they want, I phone Duy and he goes out on to the streets of Vietnam looking exactly for that.

'Many men want the girls to be already taking heroin because then they are easier to own. Duy can get that too - there's no problem. If you want me to get you a girl, I will ring tomorrow and arrange it: she will be here in one month. Or faster, if you pay me more.'

Toan claims it is common for Vietnamese girls as young as 12 to work as prostitutes. 'But because there are so many girls, they are very cheap: they charge only £2 - and that's for the man to do what he wants all night long.'

The girls are, Toan insists, keen to come to England and know what they will be expected to do. 'Duy goes to their home and asks their mother and father, he tells them she will have a sex job and they agree immediately. They know that if their daughter goes to London, she will make big money. It's a big help to the family.'

Toan insists his is a victimless crime: 'The girls I bring over are the lucky ones,' he said. 'Once they have paid off their debt, they are free. Most don't go back to Vietnam. They're very, very happy here.'

For £5,000 Toan will arrange for the girls to get a false passport. The pimps often encourage this to throw the girls further into debt.

'Sometimes the girls are forced to continue working after the debt is paid,' Toan admits. 'But the men make such big money from the girls when they're young that they usually have no more interest in them when they grow up.

'When they are no longer children, the men will sell them on to someone who will put them on the streets or they might escape first,' he said.

'It doesn't matter what happens to them once they get old and that's why I have such a good business: the men will always need new girls and I will always be able to get them. It's so easy it makes me laugh out loud.'

webTitle: Focus: What happened to Brazil's beautiful game?

fields.headline: What happened to the beautiful game?
fields.standfirst:
The reputation of the team once seen as the heart and soul of football lies in tatters. Brazil wants a scapegoat - and politicians are in the firing line. Alex Bellos reports from Rio de Janeiro

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: The reputation of the team once seen as the heart and soul of football lies in tatters. Brazil wants a scapegoat - and politicians are in the firing line. Alex Bellos reports from Rio de Janeiro.
fields.body:
When Ronaldo, the footballer hailed as one of the greatest players in the world, appeared in the Brazilian Congress last week to be interrogated about why the national team lost the 1998 World Cup final, the spectacle quickly descended into farce. 'We lost,' he told the hushed audience, 'because we didn't win.' Yet the star's testimony on what happened to the team in Paris two and a half years ago had a significance that belied his banal replies.

Ronaldo's testimony was part of an unprecedented attempt by Brazil's politicians to call football to account after two years of scandals that have plunged the game into the worst crisis in its history.

While the flamboyant soccer skills of players like Pelé and Romario are a great advertisement for the romance of Brazil, the organisation of the game has always characterised the most corrupt and secretive parts of Brazilian society.

A rising tide of allegations involving illicit enrichment, tax evasion, bribery - even that cocaine has been smuggled in footballs - has left faith in the game at its lowest ever ebb. Football is the strongest symbol of Brazilian national pride, and the health of the game is reflected in the country's self-esteem.

Domestic competitions are farcically run, stadiums are almost empty and the best players play in Europe and Japan. Even the Brazilian national team - once seen as a byword for footballing perfection - has been playing its worst football in decades. It has suffered recent embarrassing defeats to Paraguay and Chile and elimination from the Sydney Olympics by a nine-man Cameroon.

Congress hopes to put football's book in order and restore faith in the beautiful game. The task cannot be underestimated. It is a serious test of Brazil's 16-year-old democracy to modernise itself. 'If there is an area of public life that retains the authoritarianism of the dictatorship, it is football. There is a complete absence of laws,' says campaigning sports broadcaster Juca Kfouri.

Since football is so deeply entrenched in Brazilian life, public confidence in the political system is at stake if the attempt fails. Congress has installed two football inquiries - one in the Chamber of Deputies and the other in the Senate. Dozens of players, coaches, journalists, agents and administrators are being summoned to Brasilia to be questioned. The inquiries have stronger powers of investigation than the police and already have asked for the personal bank records of the presidents of the 20 biggest clubs.

Some of the hearings verge on farce. Congressmen interrogating Ronaldo appeared unable to ask probing questions and instead behaved as if it was a World Cup Final post-match press conference - two and a half years after the event.

Ronaldo was called to shed light on the role the US sportswear manufacturer Nike is alleged to have played within the Brazil squad. Ever since Nike signed a £100 million contract with the Brazilian Football Confederation (CBF) in 1996 it has been eyed with suspicion. After the defeat against France it became the scapegoat. Brazilians feel that under the normal course of events they would have won, so the defeat must have been someone else's fault.

The contract is widely seen as a betrayal of national sovereignty. Not only does it require the team to use Nike kit but it gives Nike the power to organise friendly games with at least eight first team regulars. 'The deal was very good for Nike but very bad for Brazil,' says Congressman Aldo Rebelo, president of the inquiry. 'The CBF sold the team. They betrayed the nation. They may not have had that intention, but that's what they did.' Nike denies exerting undue influence over the team.

Rebelo, a Communist deputy who campaigns to rid Portuguese of English words, believes the psychological pressure of the Nike contract contributed to the convulsions - which some believe were an epileptic fit - Ronaldo is believed to have suffered on the day of the final. He was taken for tests, given the all-clear and played in the match - but only as a shade of his former self.

The real target of the Nike hearing is CBF president Ricardo Teixeira - a national symbol of nepotism and impunity. There is great suspicion over how he accumulated his vast wealth, and he is such a despised figure he rarely attends football matches any more for fear of chants from the terraces. Teixeira had no involvement in sport until he was handpicked to run the CBF in the late Eighties by his then father-in-law, former Fifa president Joao Havelange - another vastly unpopular man.

The inquiries can also be seen as a reaction to the economic liberalisation that has happened since the end of the Brazilian dictatorship in 1985 - a freedom that allowed the CBF to make mega-deals with multinationals. Rather than confining its business to Nike, however, Congressmen have widened the inquiry to a more general exploration of how Brazilian football has sold its soul.

The investigations - which have another year to run - have thrown light on the 'trafficking' of underage players to foreign countries, the connivance of diplomatic officials in forging players' passports and the vast personal fortunes club presidents are alleged to have made illegally from selling players. Brazil exports more footballers abroad than any other country - currently about 10,000.

In the Senate, the hearings started with the colourful testimony of Renata Alves, the former secretary and lover of Brazil's ex-coach Wanderley Luxemburgo. Alves said there was a house in Rio called the 'embassy' where club coaches and presidents would take suitcases of money for illegal deals.

She also turned Luxemburgo into a Brazilian David Mellor, saying he liked her to wear the club Palmeiras's green socks up to her knees when they had sex. Luxemburgo is accused of selecting substandard players for the national team and earning kickbacks on their raised value. He admitted not declaring £3m from tax returns, saying it was a result of disorganisation rather than intent.

The inquiries are the first time football administrators have been called to book by Congress. There is an element of politicians turning their sword on themselves, since the investigations are an unprecedented attack on the promiscuity of football and political power.

Running a football club has long been a route into politics, since it gives you a high public profile and fan loyalty. Before Fernando Collor de Mello was elected Brazilian president in 1989 he had established himself at the helm of the north-eastern club CSA. His son, 24-year-old Arnon de Mello, is now club president, the first step in his political career.

The cosy relationship between football and politics is personified by Eurico Miranda, president-elect of Rio club Vasco da Gama. He was voted to Congress six years ago on a manifesto of defending his club's interests. Vasco fans re-elected him in 1998 with more than 100,000 votes, the seventh highest in Rio state.

He is not the only one. The presidents of first division clubs Cruzeiro, Sport and Santa Cruz are also elected Congressmen, as are many state federation directors and presidents of smaller clubs.

David Fleischer, professor of politics at Brasilia university, says: 'Miranda is flamboyant and a caricature, but he is not the only Congressman representing a corporate interest. Brazilian politics involves interest representation. People say not just that "I represent an interest" but "I am the interest".'

Congress's football politicians form a powerful lobby that has blocked almost all attempts to modernise football legislation - most famously defeating Pelé's attempts to make club administration more transparent when he was Sports Minister from 1995-98. The football lobby managed to stop an inquiry for 18 months, until the Olympic defeat made it politically impossible. When the hearings started last October the football lobby rushed to fill them with its members, hoping to neutralise their effects.

One of Rebelo's main worries is that the lower house's inquiry has been greatly weakened since football-linked deputies now make up about half of its members. As if reflecting the malaise over the game, the 2000 national football championship almost ended in tragedy a fortnight ago when the fencing at Vasco da Gama's stadium caved in and more than 150 people were taken to hospital.

The incident shocked even people already disillusioned with the game. Miranda charged on to the pitch and demonstrated a predictable insensitivity as he tried to have the injured removed as quickly as possible to restart the match. When the Rio state governor, watching at home, called the club to overrule the restart on grounds of security, Miranda on live television called the governor 'incompetent, weak and a poof'.

For the public and press, Miranda's demagogic actions highlighted the need for reform. The poet Geraldo Carneiro said: 'Miranda represents a world that hasn't passed yet, a psychological feudalism that, wherever it goes, rules, and that we as Brazilians need to free ourselves from.'

webTitle: Focus: Blood clots on long-haul flights

fields.headline: The cramped skies
fields.standfirst:
In 1998, an Observer investigation revealed medical evidence linking long flights with blood clots, but more than two years on the airlines have done little to alert the public, John Sweeney reports

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: In 1998, an  Observer investigation revealed medical evidence linking long flights with blood clots, but more than two years on the airlines have done little to alert the public, John Sweeney reports.
fields.body:
The most harrowing moment for Ann Egerton wasn't when she woke up from a long-haul flight more dead than alive - having suffered a massive blood clot to her lungs thanks to 'economy-class syndrome'.

She survived - although she will never be the woman she was before the long-haul British Airways flight from South Africa.

The worst moment came more than two years later when she saw the mother of Emma Christofferson - a fit 28 year old who died of a massive blood clot last October after stepping off a plane from Australia - say on television: 'If only we had known..'

Ann said: 'That makes me so angry. The airlines have known about the dangers for years, and yet they have done too little. Emma Christofferson is one of hundreds of people who have died needlessly. The truth is that while flying you are more likely to die from a blood clot than in a plane crash - and that is a truth the airline companies have been keeping from us.'

An Observer investigation today reveals that British airline companies have for decades sat on evidence that 'economy class syndrome' - blood clots caused by immobility during long-haul flights - is a 'real and mortal danger' to their customers.

Ann Egerton's case was raised in a previous Observer investigation two years ago. 'Had the airlines acted on The Observer's report, then Emma and the others would not have died,' she said. 'Emma should have known of the dangers. The complacency of the airlines has cost many lives of people who need not have died,' said Ann.

The Observer's inquiries into deep vein thrombosis (DVT) on long flights has uncovered a mountain of medical and other evidence that makes a damning indictment of the airlines - one study suggests that hundreds of Britons may be dying each year of the disease.

Doctors have been aware of the dangers of immobility since 1940 - but airlines such as British Airways and Virgin Atlantic have only just started to highlight its dangers to the travelling public. Many other airlines remain silent about the risks.

Our investigation has uncovered a culture of deceit by some airlines which has been allowed to thrive thanks to woeful complacency at the Department of Health and the Civil Aviation Authority.

Today we reveal:

 British Airways highlights a misleading study on its website which downplays the risks of long flights;

 Airline company doctors have known about the risks of immobility since 1940 and the risks of immobility on long-haul flights since 1968;

 A new study to be published in the Lancet will show compelling evidence of a link between DVT and long-haul flights;

 British Airways has not allowed doctors access to its passenger database to do more research;

 No data on the number of cases of DVT caused by long flights is collected nationally or at casualty hospital units;

 The Civil Aviation Authority has no responsibility to look after passengers;

 In tests by Britain's Public Health Laboratories, water - vital to prevent dehydration in long flights - was contaminated by E.coli and human excrement in 15 per cent of the fountains surveyed on jets using major British airports.

Farrol Kahn of the Aviation Health Institute said: 'There has been a major failing of the protection of the public health.'

Ann Egerton's life was saved by the prompt action of her husband, Dr Dale Egerton, a Hampshire GP. He said: 'Since the 1998 article I am appalled at the attitude of the airlines. Only now are things beginning to change - but it is too late.'

Ann had to quit her job as a dentist after the massive blood clot which saw her oxygen blood saturation level drop from 100 per cent to 10 per cent. 'It was amazing she survived,' he said. She had sat in a cramped seat with hand luggage at her feet. What added insult to injury, said her husband, was that a British Airways stewardess lay asleep on three seats in the row ahead of them.

Sitting immobile on a long flight means that massive blood clots can form in the legs. Lack of fresh air, dehydration in a dry cabin and cramped seating all contribute to what some call 'economy class syndrome' but the airlines prefer to term 'traveller's thrombosis'. The most critical condition is immobility. Walking around is good for you, even wriggling your ankles and toes helps the blood circulation. One aspirin taken before the flight will thin the blood - also helping to prevent a clot from being formed.

The blood clot is, in medical jargon, a deep vein thrombosis. If it stays in the leg it can cause stiffness and pain, but if it moves up the body it can cause real trouble. The blood clot can pass through the big vessels of the heart without much difficulty, but when it gets to the smaller vessels supplying the lungs it can cause a massive blockage, cutting off oxygen supply to the body: a pulmonary embolism. It was this that killed Emma Christofferson.

The Observer has established that specialists have known about the dangers of sitting immobile since 1940 when Dr Keith Simpson investigated the mysterious deaths of 23 people who had slept in deckchairs in the Underground during the false Blitz of 1939. Simpson established they died from blood clots to the lungs, and the authorities acted swiftly. Deckchairs were banned and replaced by bunkbeds and the deaths stopped. Sixty-one years on, the authorities - the Department of Health, the Department of Transport and the Civil Aviation Authority - have no idea just how many people are suffering, or have died from, blood clots caused on long-haul flights.

That is not because there has been a lack of evidence. In 1968 doctors P H Beighton and P R Richards wrote a paper on cardio-vascular disease in air travellers, alerting the airline business to the dangers of DVT from long-haul flights. In 1973 Richards wrote again. In 1985 doctors Yvonne Hart, D J Holdstock and William Lynn from Ashford Hospital, near Heathrow, wrote to the Lancet : 'We see a steady stream of illnesses which have developed in flight. The major manifestation of the illness may not occur until after disembarkation. We have seen several patients with thromboembolism presenting in this way, with a near-fatal outcome in one case.' The letter goes on: 'We understand that airline passengers, even those on very long flights, are given no specific advice to prevent venous thrombosis.'

Dale Egerton said: 'It beggars belief that the medical team at British Airways did not read that letter to the Lancet in 1985. The letter sets out the problem that the syndrome can develop after disembarkation and that calls for research. If it is known that people suffer DVTs after they leave the airport, then the airline companies had a moral responsibility to do the research. But nothing was done - an utter disgrace.'

New research by Dr John Scurr of University College Hospital, London, provides conclusive evidence that flying long-distance can kill. In a paper to be published shortly in the Lancet Scurr reveals his evidence. Blood tests were carried out on long-haul passengers before and after long flights. 'The results will show a very definite link between long-haul flights and DVT,' he said.

The critical question is how many people die from pulmonary embolisms after flying. In 1998 British Airways' senior doctor, Dr Michael Bagshaw, told Dale Egerton there were only two cases a year worldwide. But is the number higher?

The closest hospital to Heathrow is the Ashford. There, Dr John Belstead sees 10 deaths a year from pulmonary embolisms of people coming off long-haul flights. Belstead said: 'I would estimate that 15 people a year die nationally from DVTs developed on long-haul flights.'

But Scurr believes this is an under-estimate: 'It can take up to 10 days before a blood clot breaks off and moves to the lungs. What this means is that you can die of the pulmonary embolism days after the flight. I believe that hundreds of Britons are dying every year because of this disease.'

In our original article in 1998, The Observer identified 12 cases of the disease - including Gateshead landlady, Val Clark, who lost a leg because of economy class syndrome. The time delay - depressing the prevalence of the disease - was evidenced by the case of 1-year-old Angie Ruby, who died of a pulmonary embolism 14 days after stepping off a plane from Cuba.

Her father, David Collins, said they had not been warned about DVT before the nine-hour flight to London. 'The seats were so packed we could hardly move our feet,' he said. 'We were told nothing of the risks or what to do to minimise them.'

Scurr said: 'This suggests that there are many other cases out there that we do not know about. Research is vital and it is not being done.'

British Airways points to its website which includes 'facts and research' on 'traveller's thrombosis'. It reads: 'A paper published in "Chest" (February 1999) showed that recent travel is a risk factor for developing DVT. However, of the 160 patients seen, only nine had travelled by air in the past four weeks.'

Dale Egerton said: 'For British Airways to highlight this study is grotesquely misleading. It was done in Nantes, a French provincial city which has no international airport - so no wonder there are so few cases of air-related DVT.'

The BA website continues: 'BA has supported a study of DVT by Dr Patrick Kesteven of Newcastle University. The findings are similar to those above and confirm that although recent travel appears to be a risk factor there is no conclusive evidence that flying is a specific risk in itself.'

But Kesteven told The Observer : 'They are being a bit selective on the website. I am in no doubt that there is a link between long-haul flights and DVT and almost no one in the field doubts this. There is compelling evidence out there. If we could all straighten our legs, then everything would be better.'

Kesteven pointed out that he has received no research money from BA. He did request access to its passengers so he could continue his research, but the request was declined.

webTitle: Comment: Controversy over Bush's choice for Attorney-General

fields.headline: Unrepentant South mounts new assault on Washington
fields.standfirst:
The new President will be sworn in this week amid a storm over his choice of Attorney-General, reports Ed Vulliamy in New York

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: The new President will be sworn in this week amid a storm over his choice of Attorney-General, reports  Ed Vulliamy in New York.
fields.body:
A bitter political fight is marking the days before President-elect George W Bush's assumption of office on Thursday and will grow into the defining issue of the hand-over to the Republicans.

Bush's determination to appoint John Ashcroft, an extreme right-winger, as his Attorney-General is arousing mounting objections within the Democratic Party and US society. Ashcroft has hardline views against abortion, even in rape and incest cases. He is against gun control and led the impeachment of President Clinton.

He comes second in the vote score card of the John Birch Society. He calls the National Endowment for the Arts 'communist-style central planning'. In his native Missouri - where voters were so unhappy with his views that he lost his Senate seat in November to Democrat Mel Carnahan, who had died in a plane crash the month before - he blocked the nomination of a black judge to the federal bench and hankers for the Confederacy's values.

The Senate must ratify the appointment and the Republican leadership is mobilising its whip. The Democrats are debating whether to go to war now or later.

Meanwhile, a group called 'Americans for the Bush Cabinet' is being formed by David Keene of the American Conservative Union, with the aim of combating opposition to Ashcroft and other controversial appointments. 'Everyone knows the campaign isn't over,' says Keene. 'There's no honeymoon for Bush and no let-up by the Democrats - it's just total political war.'

Beyond Capitol Hill, there are hosannas of joy from such figures as preacher Jerry Falwell, the National Rifle Association's Charlton Heston and Pat Robertson - Ashcroft's long-time friend and leader of the right-wing Christian Coalition, who plans to deliver telephone messages to half a million Americans this weekend, urging support. But there is a chorus of outrage from civil rights and ethnic minority leaders, women's and gay groups, other liberal activists and municipal boards of aldermen.

The battle echoes in opposing newspapers, the New York Times stating strong reservations in an unusually long opinion on Friday. Even Ashcroft's local paper, the St Louis Post-Dispatch, urged the Senate to investigate his opposition 'to civil rights, women's rights, abortion rights, and to judicial nominees with whom he disagrees'.

As US Attorney-General, Ashcroft - from a Christian fundamentalist background which forbade alcohol and even dancing - will be the nation's chief enforcer of federal law, overseeing agencies such as the FBI and immigration services, and responsible for the Washington government end of the delicate balance between federal and state power. Such occasions often involve the enforcement of civil rights law, equality laws and laws governing 'hate crimes' targeted against ethnic minorities, women and gays.

Such cases of corrective federal law were typified by the jailing of four policemen acquitted of murdering Rodney King in California. Because of diligent work by prosecutors on the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, the officers were convicted of abusing King's civil rights - a federal felony.

Now the Civil Rights Division fears for its existence, and the civil rights movement and women's groups are worried about Ashcroft's commitment to enforcing such legislation in defiance of his own strongly held beliefs. As a senator, he has many times opposed the existence of the very federal hate crimes he must enforce.

'John Ashcroft is the antithesis of the person required to lead the Justice Department,' says Ralph Neas, president of the civil rights watchdog People for the American Way. 'With the possible exception of Jesse Helms, I do not believe that anyone has a more abysmal record on civil rights and civil liberties.' Ashcroft has been a béte noire for the women's movement since 1978, when, as attorney-general in Missouri, he filed a lawsuit to stop actions by the National Organisation of Women against the state's failure to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment. More immediate concerns are for the right to abortion. In 1988 Ashcroft co-sponsored a Bill to ban all abortion, even in cases of rape and incest. When asked on television what 'one law' he would pass if he could, he replied: 'Outlaw abortion.'

However, he is now bound to defend and enforce the historic Roe v Wade Supreme Court ruling that gave women the right to legal and safe abortion, and that his Bill sought to overturn. Violence against doctors and women at abortion clinics, including murder, has become a crisis and it is up to the Justice Department to act against criminals who single out abortion clinics.

The anti-gun lobby is also wary: the two main gun control organisations, the Violence Policy Center and Handgun Control, last week came out strongly against the appointment of Ashcroft, who opposes all gun control and received generous support from the National Rifle Association.

The signals that Ashcroft is fundamentally opposed to the very notion of federal authority are to be found in an interview in a neo-Confederate magazine, Southern Partisan, which has carried articles praising the Ku Klux Klan and deploring the 'dissipation' of the nation's genetic pool by blacks and Hispanics.

Ashcroft praised the magazine as one which 'helps set the record straight' and argued for the legacy of 'Southern Patriots' Robert E Lee, Stonewall Jackson and the Confederacy's racist president, Jefferson Davis.

Ashcroft says: 'Traditionalists have got to do more - I've go to do more - we've all got to stand up and speak... or else we'll be taught that these people were giving their lives, subscribing their sacred fortunes and their honour to some perverted agenda.' The interview detonated a rebellion by boards of aldermen across Missouri, demanding a retraction that never came.

In 1984, as Missouri attorney-general, Ashcroft intervened in a lawsuit seeking to force schools in Kansas City racially to desegregate. The suit alleged discrimination, but Ashcroft dismissed it.

Five years later Ashcroft was appointed by Bush's father, then President, to a panel on social gaps which concluded the US was not doing enough for equal opportunity. There was one dissenter - Ashcroft, a lifelong opponent of affirmative action. Two years ago there were further racial tensions when Ashcroft accepted an honorary degree from the infamous Bob Jones University in North Carolina, which lost its educational tax status for banning interracial dating and calling the Catholic Church a 'Satanic cult'. However, the text of his acceptance speech, released on Friday, contained nothing to embarrass him: it was an assertion that American public life was based on Christian and 'eternal' rather than civil or temporal principles.

But the Post-Dispatch says that he 'built a career out of opposing African-Americans for public office'. In the most notorious example he helped block the appointment to the federal bench of Judge Ronnie White, who is likely to give evidence to the Senate ratification hearings.

Ashcroft argued against White's appointment on the grounds that he was 'pro-criminal'. He cited a single opinion the judge had written in 1998 - a dissenting view against a death sentence where the convicted man had had an inadequate defence.

But there are two convicted criminals to whom Ashcroft - acting out of character - has shown sympathy. One was his nephew, Alex Ashcroft, who managed to avoid jail having been convicted of growing some 60 cannabis plants in 1992, an offence which usually carries a prison sentence. Ashcroft also helped Charles Sell, a dentist indicted on charges of conspiracy to murder an FBI agent and a federal witness, who is a member of a white supremacist group.

Bush's troubles are not confined to Ashcroft. His choice as Interior Secretary, Gale Norton, 46, a former attorney-general of Colorado, has criticised environmental laws for which, as steward of 500 million acres of federal land and many endangered species, she will be responsible. She, too, is a committed advocate of ' states' rights', and consistently favoured local business interests over environmental concerns.

Last week the controversy deepened with the emergence of a 1996 speech in which she likened her struggle against government to that of the Confederacy, and said that America had 'lost too much' when the South was defeated.

Norton is at the centre of another storm, over a paint company - NI Industries - for which she was a lobbyist. The company is being sued by New York City and a number of citizens over a product from which children in the Bronx allegedly suffered lead poisoning. In her lobbyist filing for the Senate's ratification of her post, Norton said she had handled lead paint issues' for the company.

Johnashcroft.com

The New Confederates

Core beliefs
'God, Guns and Guts Made America Great - Let's Keep All Three,' as bumper stickers say.

God
Defence of American values - enshrined by Confederacy - is defence of God's Kingdom on Earth.

Guns
Any attempt by legislation to restrict purchase or right to bear arms is affront to the Constitution and every American's right to protect his family.

Guts
'The South Shall Rise Again!' - until the Feds send in a Swat team to escort black kids into school, etc.

'States' rights'
Synonym for doing what the hell you want in the Deep South without meddling by federal 'bureaucrats'.

Anti-abortion, Anti-gay
Abortion should be outlawed, homosexuality repressed. Violent war on abortion clinics justified.

Opposition to 'new world order'
Foreign interests, alliances, commitments overseas, the UN, etc. are vehicles by which the federal government is preparing for world government.

Icons

The confederate flag
The struggle to keep it in the flags of Southern states, and flying from state Capitols.

Generals Robert E Lee, Thomas 'Stonewall Jackson and Jefferson Davis
The iron triangle which heroically fought the barbarians as they burnt Atlanta and imposed the Washington tyranny.

Seed cap, tight jeans
Timberland boots, facial hair by day. White shirt and ill-fitting suit for evening functions at Comfort Inn.

David Duke
Former Grand Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, now gone to the hairdresser.

Tom Delay
Former pest exterminator from Texas, now Republican chief whip in the House. Leader of extreme and neo-Confederate Right on Capitol Hill.

Jesse Helms
Southerner, tobacco man, Godfather of the arch-conservative Right.

Gale Norton
Bush's designated Interior Secretary who became the Bodicea of neo-Confederates with the emergence last week of a speech likening her struggle to that of the Confederacy. 'We lost too much,' she said, referring to the South's defeat in the Civil War.

Two years ago there were further racial tensions when Ashcroft accepted an honorary degree from the infamous Bob Jones University in North Carolina, which lost its educational tax status for banning interracial dating and calling the Catholic Church a 'Satanic cult'. He cited a single opinion the judge had written in 1998 - a dissenting view against a death sentence where the convicted man had had an inadequate defence. But there are two convicted criminals to whom Ashcroft - acting out of character - has shown sympathy. Ashcroft also helped Charles Sell, a dentist indicted on charges of conspiracy to murder an FBI agent and a federal witness, who is a member of a white supremacist group. His choice as Interior Secretary, Gale Norton, 46, a former attorney-general of Colorado, has criticised environmental laws for which, as steward of 500 million acres of federal land and many endangered species, she will be responsible.
