I think he felt he shouldn't be married to me - he should let me be free and go to someone who would give me the child I desperately wanted. He felt he was a burden. And to be completely honest, it did cross my mind that what he said was true.

I could go and have a one-night stand and get pregnant and pretend it was his. I thought about things like that. But you know, I didn't just want a baby -I wanted our baby.'

Once the diagnosis came it was easier, because then Helene and Brian felt that they could move forward: 'It wasn't just a life of hoping and wishing, and feeling alone with your problem.' However, they were not eligible for fertility treatment on the NHS. 'In Nottingham, there are six criteria, and we didn't meet all of them. But Nottingham is better than some places, where no one can have treatment on the NHS. It's as if your postcode determines whether you get a family or not. We had to raise the money. It's about £3,000 a go. Borrowing money is always easier than paying it back.

'I injected drugs for five weeks and had my eggs removed; he gave a sperm sample. They put the eggs and the sperm in a dish. The embryo is transferred two days later. You wait, pray, for two weeks, then you find out if you're pregnant or not.' She was. And then she wasn't, because a few weeks after the positive pregnancy test, she had a miscarriage. 'I'd been so excited, so happy, and I'd told everyone. I couldn't stop myself. I felt open to all sorts of pain after the miscarriage. It had worked and then it had been taken away. It seemed so cruel.' But there was also a sense of renewed hope.

'We'd done it once, so we could do it again. And now, family and friends realised what was going on - because we'd told them about it at last, I suppose - and everyone rallied round and gave us support, without asking too many questions. Some people wait after a miscarriage; they need to recover emotionally before trying again. But I had to try as soon as possible - as soon as we'd raised the money for it. The only way I could deal with it was to do something, have some kind of control. So we borrowed money, and this time it worked. I was pregnant with twins. I lost one of the twins, but there was still one left. I was always at my GP with worries, niggles, fears. I suppose I was deeply aware that pregnancies don't go smoothly, that you can't take anything for granted.

'And when he was born - oh, I'd wanted him for so long, I'd dreamt of this, prayed for it, struggled so hard for it. And I think it took a long time to sink in that it had really happened. Now Adam's three, and we have twins of 10 months - by IVF again, but this time I wasn't so desperate. Some people accused us of being selfish. Well, it's hard for people to understand.

But I kept within myself the sense that there was something very special in the end - a great bond between me and my baby. Because of everything, I know and can never forget how very much he was wanted, how precious he is.'

Alex and Will Thorpe

Alex and Will talk with their three-week-old daughter on their lap. She has just been fed; she is drunk and bleary with milk. Every so often she whimpers and stretches her fists in the air. They look down at her as they speak - this is her story, too. She still feels like a miracle to them. 'It is all about timescales,' says Alex. 'At what point do you say you're infertile? At what point does it become a problem? It took three years, I suppose - that isn't very long. But that is 39 cycles, and a terrible long time.'

Now in their mid-thirties, Alex and Will had talked about having children when they first met, though they waited until they felt financially secure before they started trying. 'We were broody,' says Will. 'But then, when we were really trying in a focused way, we forgot what broodiness was, because being broody is a sweet idea, really, happy and positive. But not succeeding is a dark place. The baby isn't there. It's like mourning - grieving for a child you don't have.'

'And you can't let yourself be broody and believe,' adds Alex. 'You have to control your emotions. It's a mind game. If you tell yourself it won't happen, then maybe it will. You lose the joyful sense of possibility.'

After nine months, and an abnormally painful period, Alex went to her GP, who referred her. There were the usual investigations and blood tests, and four months later the first appointment - but never any clear sense of what was wrong: a slightly odd hormone level, maybe polycystic ovaries, but each time the doctors said something different. 'And I started to feel,' says Alex, 'not guilty, exactly. But certainly low in self-esteem.'

'And there is something about fertility that's like a virtue,' says Will. 'People talk about not being "meant" to have children. It is like a failure, somehow. We never talked about the realistic possibility that we would never have a child. And in dark, low moments we did ask: "Why us? Does it mean anything about us?" Sometimes you can't help saying that it's not fair. People have children they don't want. You see them screaming disgusting things at their children. They dislike them, abuse them. And here we are, doing everything we can - but no one ever said life would be fair.'

'And we were out of synch,' says Alex. 'I was sad a lot of the time, and I felt low and bad because I no longer fitted in. Friends were just waiting for us to have a baby. Before, we were all the same. Now they were doing it and we were left behind, out of the loop. And not just in practical terms. The way you look at life is profoundly affected by having children.

'It's hard to talk about. Most people don't get it - unless they're in the same situation. Then you don't even need to say anything, there's just empathy. People tried to protect us - not talking about their babies when we were there, things like that. I felt sad about that, and it added to the sense of being left out. So many of the emotions you feel are very childish, actually - like being left out, like wanting the things that other people have. Pretty basic stuff.'

'It's part of you that hasn't happened,' adds Will. 'A bit of you hasn't been born, either.'

There was a 'demoralising gap' when treatment happened very slowly, and the sludge of waiting lists and bureaucracy thwarted them. Alex had two bouts of hormone treatment which made her feel 'bizarre - hot flushes, shifting emotions, manic stretches'. Sex became 'totally unspontaneous, sometimes a real drag', says Will. The periods kept on coming. They were headed for IUI (Inter-Uterine Insemination), but the doctors were 'very good' about letting them do it in their own time. Alex wasn't ready. She started having acupuncture and herbal medicine. 'The acupuncturist hoped that within a year, even if nothing happened with conceiving, I would at least feel better. She treated me as a whole person, not just a womb that wasn't working. Everything had become so mechanistic and functional. Sex was functional. Sperm was functional. You're an object. She saw that I was demoralised and at a low ebb. She made me feel so much better about myself.'

Nevertheless, they agreed to go ahead with the IUI. They had a holiday planned, and the treatment would begin after that. They would arrange the appointment straight after Alex's period. Their holiday was wonderful. They returned and waited for Alex's period. It didn't come.

'We had to do two tests,' says Alex. 'The first was inconclusive. There was nothing at all in the window.'

'A shadow,' says Will. 'A shadow of a shadow.'

They were supposed to wait three days before the next test. 'I kept wanting to do it sooner,' says Alex. 'But Will just said, "Wait, wait, wait."'

'I was asleep when she did it,' says Will. 'She woke me up by pushing this pee-stained stick in my face and shouting.'

'I couldn't stop laughing.'

'Laughing and poking this stick in my face.'

'The way it happened after the holiday, just before the IUI, it was unreal, almost mystical.'

Will worried his way through the pregnancy. Alex didn't. 'I knew it would be all right,' she says. When their daughter was born, they cried for days, for sheer joy.

Joanne and Lester Evans

Although they have been trying for six years, the Evans do not have children. Now in their late thirties, they got married when they were ready to start trying ('Though looking back,' says Joanne, 'I wouldn't have minded having them before we married'). For several months, they remained reasonably phlegmatic about not succeeding; they knew that a year of waiting was not unusual. They were focused but not tyrannised: Joanne was taking folic acid, drinking little alcohol. Sex was quite planned - 'but nothing,' says Lester, 'in comparison with later, when we were doing it by the clock.'

'Then, after a year or so, I thought I'd had an early miscarriage,' says Joanne. 'I went to my GP, who was extremely unsympathetic. She told me lots of couples had to be patient; I should go away and lose some weight.

I hadn't thought I was overweight. But we did try and be patient. We concentrated on our jobs, doing the house up. We never made a secret that we were having problems with conceiving - that was our way of dealing with it. Everyone around us seemed to be having babies. Pregnant women were a problem for me, generally. I'd give them a wide berth. Maybe I can have children in other ways, and I can touch babies and hold them and love them. But I can never be pregnant. You have to be self-protective; you shouldn't put yourself willingly into the firing line.'

'You can't join in. You haven't got the ticket,' says Lester. 'You don't have the same diaries, the same schedules.'

'We went on lots of exotic holidays,' says Joanne. 'Our friends were poorer than us, messy and tired. But I'd have given anything to be in their position. Anything. People were self-conscious about it, which I understand - how should you behave? There isn't a right way. One couple even had their baby before we even knew they were expecting. People don't want to churn it all up for you.'

'My brother's just had his first baby,' adds Lester. 'And he was very apprehensive about telling us. But our pain shouldn't lessen their joy, and their joy just accentuates the fact that you don't have what they have. We don't resent other people's happiness. I know that for some people it becomes an emotional black hole.'

Lester and Joanne had the tests done, and as with so many couples, they were inconclusive - which perhaps helped them, they think, because there was no sense of blame about it. It was no one's fault or failure, and they have never found out what, exactly, is wrong. They tried IVF. Five times. At £3,000 a time. 'With IVF came a gradual decay of hope,' says Lester. 'We kept on with it, but each time the peak of expectation was higher and the trough of darkness was lower. We were in an increasingly unhappy place. We weren't in control of our destinies. We were in the hands of the doctor, at the mercy of the waiting lists. And doctors are not good at dealing with failed treatment. Particularly when their patients are private, which we were obliged to be, and therefore are customers as well as patients. We did it, five times, and it was, well interesting, maybe; fascinating, you could even say - but it's a course of action I would recommend people to think very, very, very hard about. Because it's a high-stake game and the odds are that you will lose and continue to lose, and physically and emotionally it is very draining.'

They had agreed that they would try three times. Because the third time was a botched attempt, with low-grade embryos, they went for a fourth. Then, because Joanne entered an egg-donor scheme, they tried a fifth. It wasn't the money that made them stop; Lester is well-paid. 'But the gambling analogy is a really good one,' says Lester. 'You can keep going back to the table. We were getting older; the odds were getting longer all the time.'

'And I was on a roller coaster of emotions,' says Joanne. 'High and low. Every time I had treatment, I'd be really happy. This one could be our baby. We'd look at the embryos down a microscope. Everyone at the hospital would be very nice to us, and we had things we could do. Then every time it didn't work, we'd have nothing. No more hospital appointments, no more hope. Nothing. It was like being on hot coals. Periods were a devastation.

'With our fifth attempt, we saw a doctor who was more candid with us, and treated us as individuals. He said we could keep on trying, but that we should know that it would always be marginal for us. And after everything we'd been through, we came to terms with that quite quickly, actually. People say to us: "Oh, it might still happen," and of course it might. But we're not banking on it. We're looking ahead, instead, and going down another route.'

Eighteen months ago, with the failure of their fifth IVF attempt, they started the labyrinthine process of adopting a Chinese baby. They have 'paid for the pleasure' of being approved by the Department of Health. Their papers are in China now. They have a room waiting (not kitted out - 'that would be tempting fate'). As I speak to them, they are waiting for the photograph of their baby to arrive.

I ask them about the strain on their relationship, and they laugh. 'Strain. Well, we don't know anything else,' says Joanne. 'There are other strains from having children, too.'

'All I can say,' adds Lester, 'is that we are still together and happy. That's a testament.' There are all sorts of ways, says Joanne, for life to be unfair. 'We are lucky in other ways. Life's been good to us. And we've got through this and we are so ready for children, I can't tell you how ready.'

May Hickman

'But then, I also had an aunt who was married but didn't have children, and she was wonderful to us, so I knew there were different ways of being connected with children. And that helps now.' She grimaces. 'A bit.'

From adolescence, May had a severe form of endometriosis, and every month her intestines would obstruct. 'From the age of 15, I had 12 operations and lots of hormonal treatment to suppress my periods. I was on big painkillers, and every month I had to be catheterised. The side effects of the hormones were unpleasant - hot flushes, mood swings, weight gain. Actually, it was probably a bit like being pregnant.'

Between the bouts of pain she desperately tried to be normal, but she was a teenager, learning that 'there was something wrong with my womanhood. Gynaecologists are usually chauvinists who ignore the fact you're an anxious young woman. All these men prod you, examine you, shove things up you. I hated being a woman, hated my periods, hated my body. My body was like my enemy.' She had a few sexual relationships - but 'I numbed myself. I liked being cuddled, but the rest'

When she was 23, May was told that her only option was surgical. 'I thought: "OK, I can learn to live with the pain, then." I had learnt how to administer morphine myself, and catheterise myself. Now, though, I started taking more and more to kick out the pain, and one day I ended up hallucinating and my flatmate carted me off to hospital.' When she came round, her father was at the foot of her bed, weeping. Her eyes fill with tears at the memory. 'I knew I couldn't do this any more. I'd become a person I didn't want to be.

I felt androgynous. I'd lost all sense of my femininity. So I agreed to the operation. Afterwards I sobbed and sobbed. I was in a ward with newborn babies everywhere. I was 25 and I could never have babies. For a long time after, I felt empty - well, I was empty, wasn't I? I dressed in baggy clothes. I couldn't open up sexually.'

Gradually, May has come to terms with her situation. She has channelled a lot of energy into her career. She has close friends and a 'man who makes me feel I'm the most beautiful woman in the entire world'. She tells people how a chunk of her life was lost to her, how she has had to re-think her whole identity, because she so wanted a family. And she still feels guilty, though she knows that guilt is a strange and unhelpful emotion.

'But I think it's time to forgive myself. Don't you?'

Beating the baby blues: how to treat infertility

In Vitro Fertilisation and egg transfer
Originally used for women with tubal damage, IVF is increasingly prescribed for patients experiencing infertility with no known origin. Drugs are used to stimulate egg production. The eggs are harvested and mixed with sperm to create embryos. Up to three embryos are deposited in the uterus, after which hormones are often given to support any possible pregnancy. Many clinics store and freeze unused embryos for later use but the implantation rate is lower. IVF offers a success rate of 15 per cent for one treatment cycle and up to 77 per cent for couples who undergo three to five cycles.

Artificial Insemination
This method aims to fertilise the egg by placing a sample of sperm either in the cervix (intracervical) or the uterus (intrauterine) and waiting for fertilisation to take place naturally. Intracervical insemination can be helpful when the male partner suffers from anatomical problems or abnormalities that prevent him from ejaculating normally. Otherwise, it has no advantage over intercourse. Intrauterine insemination involves placing the sperm sample directly into the uterus and is used in cases of poor cervical mucus and unexplained infertility. Drug therapy is used to increase production of eggs before treatment and the semen is analysed to make sure it is suitable. The success rate is about 6 per cent.

Donor insemination
When the male partner's sperm count is very low, artificial insemination using a donor's sperm may be considered. Clinics match the donor profile to the male partner, so that characteristics such as height, hair colour and ethnic origin are very similar. Each sample is screened for sexually transmitted diseases and genetic defects and frozen for six months to allow time to repeat an HIV test. The sample is then placed in either the cervix or uterus, possibly after a course of hormones to stimulate egg production.

Gamete Intrafallopian Transfer (GIFT)
A method that is particularly successful with couples suffering from infertility of unknown origin, GIFT may be used only if the female has at least one fully open fallopian tube. Following a course of drug treatment to increase egg production, eggs are harvested and the best two or three are selected. These are placed in a catheter with the partner's sperm and inserted into the outer ends of one or both fallopian tube. Hormone therapy is usually given to support the pregnancy. Success rates are slightly higher than IVF, but most clinics have stopped practising GIFT because it causes the woman extra discomfort.

Tubal surgery
When blocked fallopian tubes prevent the passage of the egg to the uterus, for example as a result of endometriosis, surgery may be carried out to clear the blockage.

Alternative treatments
A growing number of couples are trying alternative treatments. Chinese herbalism has been credited anecdotally with increases in male sperm levels, while cranial osteopaths work on a woman's skull and pelvis, looking for problems with the natural rhythm of the spinal fluid so as to correct the energy flow. Homeopathy remedies, used for male or female fertility, are based on an assessment of the patient's emotional history. Some are thought to increase egg production. Hypnotherapy treats infertility by working on the belief that it relaxes people and gives the subconscious a message that pregnancy is possible. Acupuncture operates on the principle that infertility may be caused by blocked energy pathways or meridians. Needles are inserted to clear the obstructions.

You have to be self-protective; you shouldn't put yourself willingly into the firing line.' 'You can't join in. You haven't got the ticket,' says Lester. 'You don't have the same diaries, the same schedules.' 'We went on lots of exotic holidays,' says Joanne. 'Our friends were poorer than us, messy and tired. But I'd have given anything to be in their position. Anything. People were self-conscious about it, which I understand - how should you behave? There isn't a right way. One couple even had their baby before we even knew they were expecting. People don't want to churn it all up for you.' 'My brother's just had his first baby,' adds Lester. 'And he was very apprehensive about telling us. But our pain shouldn't lessen their joy, and their joy just accentuates the fact that you don't have what they have. We don't resent other people's happiness. I know that for some people it becomes an emotional black hole.' Lester and Joanne had the tests done, and as with so many couples, they were inconclusive - which perhaps helped them, they think, because there was no sense of blame about it. It was no one's fault or failure, and they have never found out what, exactly, is wrong. They tried IVF. Five times. At £3,000 a time. 'With IVF came a gradual decay of hope,' says Lester. 'We kept on with it, but each time the peak of expectation was higher and the trough of darkness was lower. We were in an increasingly unhappy place. We weren't in control of our destinies. We were in the hands of the doctor, at the mercy of the waiting lists. And doctors are not good at dealing with failed treatment. Particularly when their patients are private, which we were obliged to be, and therefore are customers as well as patients. We did it, five times, and it was, well interesting, maybe; fascinating, you could even say - but it's a course of action I would recommend people to think very, very, very hard about. Because it's a high-stake game and the odds are that you will lose and continue to lose, and physically and emotionally it is very draining.' They had agreed that they would try three times. Because the third time was a botched attempt, with low-grade embryos, they went for a fourth. Then, because Joanne entered an egg-donor scheme, they tried a fifth. It wasn't the money that made them stop; Lester is well-paid. 'But the gambling analogy is a really good one,' says Lester. 'You can keep going back to the table. We were getting older; the odds were getting longer all the time.' 'And I was on a roller coaster of emotions,' says Joanne. 'High and low. Every time I had treatment, I'd be really happy. This one could be our baby. We'd look at the embryos down a microscope. Everyone at the hospital would be very nice to us, and we had things we could do. Then every time it didn't work, we'd have nothing. No more hospital appointments, no more hope. Nothing. It was like being on hot coals. Periods were a devastation. 'With our fifth attempt, we saw a doctor who was more candid with us, and treated us as individuals. He said we could keep on trying, but that we should know that it would always be marginal for us. And after everything we'd been through, we came to terms with that quite quickly, actually. People say to us: "Oh, it might still happen," and of course it might. But we're not banking on it. We're looking ahead, instead, and going down another route.' Eighteen months ago, with the failure of their fifth IVF attempt, they started the labyrinthine process of adopting a Chinese baby. They have 'paid for the pleasure' of being approved by the Department of Health. Their papers are in China now. They have a room waiting (not kitted out - 'that would be tempting fate'). As I speak to them, they are waiting for the photograph of their baby to arrive. I ask them about the strain on their relationship, and they laugh. 'Strain. Well, we don't know anything else,' says Joanne. 'There are other strains from having children, too.' 'All I can say,' adds Lester, 'is that we are still together and happy. That's a testament.' There are all sorts of ways, says Joanne, for life to be unfair. 'We are lucky in other ways. Life's been good to us. And we've got through this and we are so ready for children, I can't tell you how ready.' May Hickman May has only just started telling people she is unable to have children. In her mid-twenties, she had a hysterectomy. 'I always wanted to have this big family,' she says. 'But then, I also had an aunt who was married but didn't have children, and she was wonderful to us, so I knew there were different ways of being connected with children. And that helps now.' She grimaces. 'A bit.' From adolescence, May had a severe form of endometriosis, and every month her intestines would obstruct. 'From the age of 15, I had 12 operations and lots of hormonal treatment to suppress my periods. I was on big painkillers, and every month I had to be catheterised. The side effects of the hormones were unpleasant - hot flushes, mood swings, weight gain. Actually, it was probably a bit like being pregnant.' Between the bouts of pain she desperately tried to be normal, but she was a teenager, learning that 'there was something wrong with my womanhood. Gynaecologists are usually chauvinists who ignore the fact you're an anxious young woman. All these men prod you, examine you, shove things up you. I hated being a woman, hated my periods, hated my body. My body was like my enemy.' She had a few sexual relationships - but 'I numbed myself. I liked being cuddled, but the rest' When she was 23, May was told that her only option was surgical. 'I thought: "OK, I can learn to live with the pain, then." I had learnt how to administer morphine myself, and catheterise myself. Now, though, I started taking more and more to kick out the pain, and one day I ended up hallucinating and my flatmate carted me off to hospital.' When she came round, her father was at the foot of her bed, weeping. Her eyes fill with tears at the memory. 'I knew I couldn't do this any more. I'd become a person I didn't want to be. I felt androgynous. I'd lost all sense of my femininity. So I agreed to the operation. Afterwards I sobbed and sobbed. I was in a ward with newborn babies everywhere. I was 25 and I could never have babies. For a long time after, I felt empty - well, I was empty, wasn't I? I dressed in baggy clothes. I couldn't open up sexually.' Gradually, May has come to terms with her situation. She has channelled a lot of energy into her career. She has close friends and a 'man who makes me feel I'm the most beautiful woman in the entire world'. She tells people how a chunk of her life was lost to her, how she has had to re-think her whole identity, because she so wanted a family. And she still feels guilty, though she knows that guilt is a strange and unhelpful emotion. 'But I think it's time to forgive myself. Don't you?' Beating the baby blues: how to treat infertility In Vitro Fertilisation and egg transfer Originally used for women with tubal damage, IVF is increasingly prescribed for patients experiencing infertility with no known origin. Drugs are used to stimulate egg production. The eggs are harvested and mixed with sperm to create embryos. Up to three embryos are deposited in the uterus, after which hormones are often given to support any possible pregnancy. Many clinics store and freeze unused embryos for later use but the implantation rate is lower. IVF offers a success rate of 15 per cent for one treatment cycle and up to 77 per cent for couples who undergo three to five cycles. Artificial Insemination This method aims to fertilise the egg by placing a sample of sperm either in the cervix (intracervical) or the uterus (intrauterine) and waiting for fertilisation to take place naturally. Intracervical insemination can be helpful when the male partner suffers from anatomical problems or abnormalities that prevent him from ejaculating normally. Otherwise, it has no advantage over intercourse. Intrauterine insemination involves placing the sperm sample directly into the uterus and is used in cases of poor cervical mucus and unexplained infertility. Drug therapy is used to increase production of eggs before treatment and the semen is analysed to make sure it is suitable. The success rate is about 6 per cent. Donor insemination When the male partner's sperm count is very low, artificial insemination using a donor's sperm may be considered. Clinics match the donor profile to the male partner, so that characteristics such as height, hair colour and ethnic origin are very similar. Each sample is screened for sexually transmitted diseases and genetic defects and frozen for six months to allow time to repeat an HIV test. The sample is then placed in either the cervix or uterus, possibly after a course of hormones to stimulate egg production. Gamete Intrafallopian Transfer (GIFT) A method that is particularly successful with couples suffering from infertility of unknown origin, GIFT may be used only if the female has at least one fully open fallopian tube. Following a course of drug treatment to increase egg production, eggs are harvested and the best two or three are selected. These are placed in a catheter with the partner's sperm and inserted into the outer ends of one or both fallopian tube. Hormone therapy is usually given to support the pregnancy. Success rates are slightly higher than IVF, but most clinics have stopped practising GIFT because it causes the woman extra discomfort. Tubal surgery When blocked fallopian tubes prevent the passage of the egg to the uterus, for example as a result of endometriosis, surgery may be carried out to clear the blockage. Alternative treatments A growing number of couples are trying alternative treatments. Chinese herbalism has been credited anecdotally with increases in male sperm levels, while cranial osteopaths work on a woman's skull and pelvis, looking for problems with the natural rhythm of the spinal fluid so as to correct the energy flow. Homeopathy remedies, used for male or female fertility, are based on an assessment of the patient's emotional history. Some are thought to increase egg production. Hypnotherapy treats infertility by working on the belief that it relaxes people and gives the subconscious a message that pregnancy is possible. Acupuncture operates on the principle that infertility may be caused by blocked energy pathways or meridians. Needles are inserted to clear the obstructions.

fields.headline: The real victims
fields.trailText: Most reports of the health effects of Nato's depleted uranium weapons (News, last week) ignore the intended victims - the people of Yugoslavia.
fields.body:
Most reports of the health effects of Nato's depleted uranium weapons (News, last week) ignore the intended victims - the people of Yugoslavia. Shortly after the West halted the bombing, pollution in the air and water were affecting the health of those who attempted to resist Nato's aggression. Nato countries must now pay some compensation to the thousands of Yugoslavians who they killed or maimed.

Those who volunteered to fight in Western armies know they are in the risk business. The primary victims were innocent, or resisting invaders.
Alan Gorst
Cadiz, Spain

 Nato is obliged to clear from Yugoslavia all traces of depleted uranium, compensate all the present and future victims of that lethal weapon, stop using bombs and other ammunition with DU and destroy all existing stocks. Furthermore, all countries must ban the production of ammunition with DU.
Emmanuel G. Drettakis
Former Deputy Speaker of the Greek Parliament, Minister of Finance and Professor at the Athens School of Economics
Athens, Greece

webTitle: Focus: Devolution and the Scottish parliament

fields.headline: This moon's no balloon
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: It is a rule on some of the posher papers that anonymous quotations, if they are rude about third parties, should not normally be used. The convention was spectacularly broken in the Herald last week when an unnamed senior Labour Minister at Westminster said that Henry McLeish was 'thick'.
fields.body:
It is a rule on some of the posher papers that anonymous quotations, if they are rude about third parties, should not normally be used. The convention was spectacularly broken in the Herald last week when an unnamed senior Labour Minister at Westminster said that Henry McLeish was 'thick'.

You don't have to be a Hercules Poirot to guess the source - the pool of suspects would hardly fill a drawing room - but we should not be too surprised in an age of lost innocence. Where once George Formby waited by a lamppost for a certain little lady coming by, Eminem raps obscenely about rape, murder and drugs in Detroit. Parliamentary manners may survive in the Chamber but not beyond.

Henry's sin? His acolytes floated the idea that the Scottish Executive should be called the 'Scottish Government'. In fact he has been using the term for some time - only very few people had noticed.

The fury was uncontained, particularly from Westminster MPs and Scottish Ministers (unnamed). They used the incident to show that Henry had got above himself or, even, that the Scottish Executive was forgetting its place and the deference due to its masters in the south. One particularly pessimistic commentator seized upon the episode as proving the failure of devolution itself.

To me it seems to demonstrate the opposite, that the Scottish Executive is beginning to exercise meaningful choices about how to divvy up its grant. McLeish is determined to fund both the Sutherland recommendations for the care of the elderly and the pay award for teachers, which is reckoned to be worth 23 per cent over three years.

To those who thought devolution should amount to no more than passive regional administration, this may seem something of an affront. And there will certainly be a row at Westminster if Scotland funds Sutherland in full and England does not. But there is no point in having a parliament in Scotland unless it is prepared to make real choices. If this option is open to it then it should not be barred from it.

Nor does the term 'government' imply a reckless bid for more power. In the United States there are both federal and state governments. Indeed, the new Bush administration seems determined to bolster the states at the expense of Washington. In Germany's federal constitution powers are shared between the federal centre and the Länder. Last year, in conversation with senior members of all the parties at Holyrood, I found a general agreement that the word 'government' might be more appropriate. Opposition leaders thought the public might confuse the Executive and its sins with the Parliament itself.

What we are seeing, in fact, is the dynamic consequences of devolution. Last week's stushie told us more about Westminster than Holyrood. The Scottish Ministers and members are the most obvious victims of devolution. At home their impact has been much diluted, both in the media and among the electorate. At Westminster their presence is resented, particularly by English Conservative back-benchers.

Nor has William Hague fully understood the consequences. His proposal to disbar Scottish MPs from purely English business is flawed because such decisions will determine the flow of new public money for particularly programmes across the UK.

It would be better to move towards a proper federal arrangement, involving a genuine division of powers. That would mean having a bicameral UK chamber, and an English Parliament to set alongside the Scottish Parliament and the Assemblies in England and Wales.

But so logical an approach goes against the grain of English constitutional history. Movement has been by degrees and fine adjustments. Devolution is pushing us towards federalism.

The Scottish Parliament is like an ambiguous gibbous moon glimpsed through a wrack of cloud. Is it already on the wane, as pessimists imply, or is there greater glory to come? McLeish may be thick, but he is not wrong.

webTitle: Letters: The government should learn from teachers

fields.headline: It's time for the government to learn from the teachers
fields.trailText: Entice retired teachers back into the classroom (News, last week)? Forget it. One of the best retired teachers I know said she wouldn't go back for £1,000 a week - and she liked the job.
fields.body:
Entice retired teachers back into the classroom (News, last week)? Forget it. One of the best retired teachers I know said she wouldn't go back for £1,000 a week - and she liked the job.

The financial incentives have been useless because money is not the issue. Unions wrangle over pay, but do nothing to halt the real problem... deteriorating classroom conditions. Punitive attitudes, excessive demands for planning and poor support are the real culprits. Politicians barely acknowledge these issues. Let me use a political cliché and 'make it absolutely clear'.

Keep your money! Get off teachers' backs and leave them alone to do the job! You might even find some want to do it again.
Robert Bottamley
Hull, E Yorks

 As a 61-year-old who took early retirement eight years ago, I ought to be an ideal candidate to return to teaching. But as the husband of a serving teacher, I know that it would not work. The changes introduced over the past few years mean that the job has gone away from me. I gave up marking GCSE and SAT papers because I realised classroom practice was so much at variance with my experience. Had the incoming Labour Government sacked Chris Woodhead and boosted teachers' salaries and teacher training programmes in 1997, they would not be facing the current shortages.
David Spilsbury
Birmingham

 The lack of response to the Government's campaign to recruit new teachers surely surprises no one. How long will it take Ministers to realise that they are no longer asking the teaching profession to educate. They are asking teachers to implement a testing, testing, testing programme.

Education develops children's unique talents and skills, their perception, flexibility, wisdom and resourcefulness - qualities which enhance childhood, and enrich adulthood. Testing, on the other hand, encourages a 'quick fix' attitude to life, an 'only today matters' attitude, self-interest, fears of inadequacy, and depression - none of which enhances either childhood or adulthood. The system at the moment is more akin to debt collecting, gathering up mountains of tick sheets, assessment sheets, review sheets and test scores.
Jenny Short
Taunton, Somerset

 Nowhere does your Leader on education (Comment, last week) mention a crucial reason why so many have left teaching. It is not money. The hugely increased amount of (often unnecessary) paperwork is often the straw which breaks the camel's back, wrecking family life and destroying health. We need more than lip service paid to 'reducing the bureaucratic workload'.
Roger Creegan
Burnley, Lancs

fields.headline: Poor rich voters
fields.trailText: It is significant that both major parties have decided to fight the next election on a non-issue, the economy. If they took time to listen to the voters they would hear us all screaming, 'Read our lips - it's the infrastructure, stupid!'
fields.body:
It is significant that both major parties have decided to fight the next election on a non-issue, the economy. If they took time to listen to the voters they would hear us all screaming, 'Read our lips - it's the infrastructure, stupid!'

A train system that is falling apart, an Underground that's a disgrace, schools going on to a four-day week, understaffed and filthy hospitals, police forces and prisons stretched to breaking point, clogged roads, fractured sewers and leaking water services, Immigration, CSA and other agencies in chaos, etc. We are the fourth richest economy in the world and the only one in the West which is oil sufficient - so where does all the money go? Tory or New Labour - it's all irrelevant. The sad truth is, we now have more power as consumers than we will ever have as as electors.
Ted Newcomen
Hastings, E. Sussex

fields.headline: Happy as I am
fields.trailText: I read Nigella Lawson's column today on girls wanting bigger breasts (Comment, last week). I recently went shopping for new bras in my size (A-cup). The majority in this size were padded.
fields.body:
I read Nigella Lawson's column today on girls wanting bigger breasts (Comment, last week). I recently went shopping for new bras in my size (A-cup). The majority in this size were padded.

When I asked if they had anything un-padded I was told 'Most women your size want padded bras'. Not me. I'm getting the message that I should want my breasts to look bigger, but I don't! They have successfully breast-fed both of my daughters and have never bothered me when I do sport. My husband has never complained either.
Elisabeth Smith
Frenkendorf, Switzerland

fields.headline: Joy in numbers
fields.trailText: Has Nicci Gerrard, who wrote that 'Shipman was like a ghastly bureaucrat, a statistician at work' (Comment, last week) ever actually seen a statistician at work? We are neither ghastly nor bureaucratic.
fields.body:
Has Nicci Gerrard, who wrote that 'Shipman was like a ghastly bureaucrat, a statistician at work' (Comment, last week) ever actually seen a statistician at work? We are neither ghastly nor bureaucratic. We bring an intense, joyous, passionate enthusiasm to our work, happily and proudly conscious that our nineteenth-century predecessors discovered the cause of cholera and twentieth-century statisticians the cause of lung cancer.

No activity is so satisfying in itself or so useful to the public as studying statistics. The Observer would be a poorer paper without statisticians.
Frank Oliver
University of Exeter

fields.trailText: In your review 'Did they really say that?' (Comment, 31 December) you stated that last year the Runnymede Trust 'demanded Britain should be renamed the Community of Communities'.
fields.body:
In your review 'Did they really say that?' (Comment, 31 December) you stated that last year the Runnymede Trust 'demanded Britain should be renamed the Community of Communities'.

No, the Trust did not really say that. Your quotation is from a malicious and ridiculous falsehood perpetrated by another newspaper, not from our report.
Robin Richardson
London EC1

fields.headline: Stop whingeing
fields.trailText: When Radiohead, Blur, U2 and the other grown-ups in rock ask their record companies not to release their records, let alone advertise them with videos, adverts, posters, sympathetic media interviews and half-page articles in Sunday broadsheets (that coincide with a new release) then perhaps they can criticise the 'manufactured' pop bands currently dominating the charts of monopolisation (News, last week).
fields.body:
When Radiohead, Blur, U2 and the other grown-ups in rock ask their record companies not to release their records, let alone advertise them with videos, adverts, posters, sympathetic media interviews and half-page articles in Sunday broadsheets (that coincide with a new release) then perhaps they can criticise the 'manufactured' pop bands currently dominating the charts of monopolisation (News, last week).

Stop your whingeing, lads, and stuff your heads back down into your great coats. If you were truthful you'd admit it's all about sales. Go home and count your money and let the children have fun.
Tim Brinkhurst
London N16

fields.headline: Stepfather outraged by kidnap slur
fields.standfirst:
Army hints at possible extortion scheme by Philippines mother as girl, 6, disappears

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Army hints at possible extortion scheme by Philippines mother as girl, 6, disappears.
fields.body:
The Scottish stepfather of a six-year-old schoolgirl seized at gunpoint from her home in the Philippines has angrily dismissed reports that the child's mother may have masterminded the kidnapping in an extortion attempt.

Douglas Grant, 50, speaking from his home in Inverness, said that comments made by a Philippine army officer that his wife, Mina Rasul, was behind the snatch at their home on the remote island of Basilan were 'an outrage'.

The Foreign Office confirmed that it had no evidence to suggest an 'inside' job, but a Philippine army spokesman insisted that 'intelligence reports' pointed to the possibility that the 'kidnap' had been carried out by the mother or a neighbour rather than by some extremist Islamic faction.

Earlier reports suggested that Eiman, who was adopted by Grant when she was a baby, was kidnapped from her front room by four gunmen from the Islamic rebel group Abu Sayyaf, or the larger separatist Moro Islamic Liberation Front.

He added that he had received a handwritten letter from the British ambassador in Manila commiserating with him about his ordeal and explaining that 'everything possible' was being done.

'I have a friend over there who was in my home with my family in the Philippines just 12 hours ago,' said Grant. 'He told me, "Don't worry. I believe your wife. Unless she is a very good actress, she has nothing to do with this".

'It seems to me that people are just making up stories about my wife. I want as much media attention as possible to go back and say that these stories are a load of garbage.'

Grant, a hospitality manager who ran a taxi business in the Philippines and converted to Islam, came back to Scotland last August to care for his elderly parents.

He added: 'You cannot believe the stress that this has caused for me and my family. A spokesman for the Foreign and Commonwealth Office said: 'Our embassy in Manila has spoken to the police task force who are investigating the case, and the task force say that they have no evidence to suggest that it was an "inside job".'

He confirmed that the police were 'keeping an open mind', but stressed there was no evidence pointing to the mother's involvement.

Although Grant has said that he would like to go back to the Philippines to be with his wife and their 22-month-old daughter Khadija, the region has been declared a no-go area.

A duty officer for the 103rd Army Brigade, which is based on the island of Basilan, said yesterday the military were investigating intelligence reports suggesting that either Rasul or her neighbours could have been paid to snatch the girl to extort money from her stepfather.

So far no one has claimed responsibility for taking Eiman, who was seized by four unidentified gunmen at about 9pm on Wednesday. Mrs Grant said they took her daughter after she was unable to meet their demand for 100,000 pesos (£1,300).

The officer said: 'We are still looking for the girl while checking previous intelligence data. Nothing has been ruled out.'

The data include reports that the kidnapping, which seemed extremely random even by Basilan standards - where such actions are quite common - might have been an inside job.

Colonel Saulito Aromin, the commander of the 103rd Army Brigade, was quoted by the Philippine Daily Inquirer yesterday as saying that neighbours of the victim said that the girl's mother, who is a Filipina, did not appear to be worried about her daughter's kidnapping.

'She even went on a shopping spree yesterday,' Aromin reportedly said.

Grant, 50, who is at home in Inverness, dismissed the claims as 'total garbage' and 'ridiculous'. He said the Philippines military was spreading such rumours 'because they have done nothing for the past two or three days to find Eiman and want to divert attention from that'.

A spokesman for the Philippines Army's Southern Command, Colonel Hilario Atendido, yesterday vehemently denied Grant's accusation that the authorities were doing nothing.

'That's completely untrue,' he said. 'We have search and rescue teams out in several places, both on Basilan and other islands.' Atendido said he believed Eiman was probably still on Basilan. 'We are concentrating, but not exclusively, on the hinterland of Tuburan,' he said, referring to a town near Lamitan, the town where Eiman was abducted.

This contradicts statements by Grant, who said his stepdaughter had been taken to another island by the gunmen, who escaped with Eiman in two speedboats down a river.

The British Government is staying at arm's length from the whole dispute. A Foreign Office spokesman said yesterday: 'We're aware of the claims but we don't have any information to confirm or deny them. The investigation is the responsibility of the Philippines police.'

He said that, as Eiman was not a British passport-holder, she 'is formally not our responsibility. But the embassy feels it has a moral responsibility, especially to the father, to keep him informed'.

If the kidnapping is not an inside job the most likely suspect is either one of the many kidnap-for-ransom gangs that operate in the area or one of the two Muslim separatist groups fighting for an independent state from the predominantly Catholic Philippines. These are the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) and the Abu Sayyaf.

Of these, the more militant Abu Sayyaf has the stronger presence on Basilan, where last year it kidnapped dozens of people. It also kidnapped 21 foreigners from a Malaysian diving resort and took them to the island of Jolo, where they were kept for up to five months. It is thought the group made more than £10 million from the operation.

fields.headline: War and the West
fields.trailText: Neal Ascherson is right to say 'we are all Crouchbacks now' (Comment, last week). The West fails to even try to understand the reasons for a war unless its interests are in some way affected.
fields.body:
Neal Ascherson is right to say 'we are all Crouchbacks now' (Comment, last week). The West fails to even try to understand the reasons for a war unless its interests are in some way affected.

Mr Ascherson asks: 'When tens of thousands perish for a line in the desert between Eritrea and Ethiopia, who is achieving anything?' But the 'desert' in question was home to more than 350,000 Ethiopians until Eritrean troops invaded in May 1998. The Eritrean government then bombarded the Ethiopian town of Mekelle when children were in school. As a consequence 52 were killed and many more injured.

The West refuses to recognise these fundamental wrongs for what they were - naked aggression against a peace-loving neighbour. It seems that fighting Hitler was right but fighting the modern-day equivalent is wrong.
Gail Warden
London SW2

fields.headline: Hip operation for ailing Reagan
fields.trailText: Two US leaders - one a former President and the other on the point of departure from the White House - were the subject of health alerts yesterday. Ronald Reagan had a hip operation and Bill Clinton was found to have suspected skin cancer and dangerously high cholesterol levels.
fields.body:
Two US leaders - one a former President and the other on the point of departure from the White House - were the subject of health alerts yesterday. Ronald Reagan had a hip operation and Bill Clinton was found to have suspected skin cancer and dangerously high cholesterol levels.

Reagan, now 89, and his wife, Nancy, had been in their home at Bel Air, California, on Friday night when he suffered a 'regular, simple fall', and was taken to the St, John's Health Centre in Santa Monica.

A hospital spokesman said he had been 'resting comfortably' before the operation, which involved placing a metal pin into the broken area to allow it to stabilise.

The hospital authorities said Reagan, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, had 'responded well', and that his hip would take 'a few weeks' to heal.

The last physical examination of Bill Clinton's presidency showed a skin lesion that will be tested this week to see if it represents a common form of cancer. He was also found to have elevated blood cholestorol which put him in a 'high-risk' category for heart disease.

The President's doctor, Connie Mariano, said he found Clinton in good health but not in the 'top shape' he had hoped for and expected. The cholesterol level was 233, with a low-density level of so-called 'bad cholesterol' at 177 - much higher than the figure of 137 last year.

Dr Mariano attributed the rise to the stresses of the job and to the limits it put on his nutrition and exercise regime.

The doctor who examined the skin lesion, David Corbett, said he found it to be 'small and suspicious' - it was on his back and seemed 'a little pearly'. The results will be available after Clinton leaves office and will be made public. The type of cancer is common, said Corbett, and is not a kind that can produce secondaries elsewhere in the body.

fields.headline: Michael Williams 1935-2001
fields.standfirst: The former director of the Royal National Theatre, Sir Richard Eyre, remembers the actor Michael Williams who died last week
fields.trailText: The former director of the Royal National Theatre, Sir Richard Eyre, remembers the actor Michael Williams who died last week
fields.body:
Michael Williams had a flat face like a cheerful cat, a face that always made you want to respond with a smile as wide as his. Those who only knew him from his TV appearances would remember a deft and charming light comedian. Those who saw him on stage would remember an actor whose performances had the characteristics of his personality: cheerful, quick, cocky, combative, dogged, generous, but always underscored by a thin vein of melancholy. I'd single out his performances as a wry Schweyk and as the only Petruchio I've seen who has succeeded in squaring the circle of making the character loveable as well as credible.

He showed himself as a brilliant farceur (rare that) in Trevor Nunn's musical version of The Comedy of Errors and in Ray Cooney's Out of Order. He possessed the philosopher's stone of theatre acting: this small, neat, dapper man on a large stage could alchemically fuse a thousand individuals into an audience of one.

I only worked with Michael once - an unsuccessful new play at the Aldwych. What I remember most about working with Michael, apart from his pliant skill and his enthusiasm, was the way he behaved after the reviews came out. They were pretty universally bad, but his loyalty to the play, the author, his fellow actors and to a director who, I fear, had probably not served him well, was undeviating. He was a really decent man.

His successes as an actor were many, but there is no doubt that the success that mattered to him most was his marriage to Judi Dench. They looked - and were - made for each other: twins almost, handsome, perfectly formed. Theirs was a fine romance.

A heavy smoker, he was diagnosed with lung cancer 18 months ago. He was not given long to live, but he hung on in great pain, with great courage, for months longer than any doctor had predicted, still optimistic, still radiating an unquenchable good humour. His actor's instinct sustained him till the last, saving himself for the big occasions - his wife's birthday in early December, Christmas, New Year, and finally his investiture on Wednesday by the Catholic church as a Knight of the Order of St Gregory for a lifetime of devotion and charitable work. He died the day after at the cruelly young age of 65.

fields.headline: A Polke in the eye
fields.standfirst: No style is safe from Sigmar Polke's parodies and pilfering. Just don't take him too seriously
fields.trailText:
Sigmar Polke: Music of Unclear Origin Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh, 18 March
Sigmar Polke Anthony d'Offay Gallery, 24 February
fields.body:
Sigmar Polke: Music of Unclear Origin Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art, Edinburgh, 18 March
Sigmar Polke Anthony d'Offay Gallery, 24 February

Sigmar Polke, the artful dodger, is having two separate shows in Britain: his first in London for more than 10 years and his very first in Scotland. It feels right that he should be in both places at once - this slippery, shape-shifting teaser, prolific as any chatterbox and fantastically inconsistent. No thought comes into Polke's head, it seems, without passing at equal speed to a sheet of paper. Which is why the 400 works distributed between these shows represent no more than a smattering of his projectile output.

In London, Polke comes hot on the heels of Anselm Kiefer at the d'Offay Gallery. It's a hard contrast, between these two grandees of German painting: Kiefer the solemn patriarch, with his hard-won, melancholy jeremiads; and Polke, who buzzes like a restless gadfly beside him. But there was a time when they were equally absorbed by Germany's post-war legacy - in Polke's case, roughly the Sixties and early Seventies, when most of the drawings in this show were made.

Doodles in ballpoint and pencil, covering screeds of lined schoolbook paper, these little jabs and skitters are mainly concerned with consumer society. According to one of Polke's titles, 'every German owns 10,000 things' - and here they are, ineptly transcribed from magazines: cakes, slacks, cans, cars, white goods for the happy Hausfrau and those endless strings of German sausages that Polke shoves into German mouths.

He liked to deface ads - bulging biceps on a lingerie model, cartoon bodies, cartoon guns and captions. He liked to be infantile, coarse and quick, his drawings mass-produced but never slick as the commerce he parodied. His first 'Capitalist Realism' show was held in a department store, Polke posing in the window as an awkward mannequin.

Above all - and this was where the theorists circled greedily - he treated art itself as an emporium of styles. He'd do, or redo, Picabia, layering the images one above the other. He'd do sloppy Abstract Expressionism, minus the resonant grandeur, and American Pop without the zip or clarity. You can still see Rauschenberg and Rosenquist in the huge new paintings, with their collaged styles and colliding images, also on show at the d'Offay Gallery. What you can't see any more - if you ever really could - is Polke the daredevil satirist.

It's as if he sought to neutralise rather than send up the past. Picasso reprised in felt pen looks muffled, not mocked. Ab-Ex redone in washy white ink - the artist once signed himself Polek - looks more like spilt milk than Pollock tackled or parried. Why do him if you aren't going to do for him, as it were?

One answer may be that Polke just enjoys putting on the style. Certainly, in these big paintings, he sends the ink meandering about the page with a relish that becomes infectious. Here and there, he also uses a wondrous substance called interference paint, which reflects back a mineral iridescence. As you move about the room, the surfaces glint with ever-changing light.

Polke's mainstay, in the Sixties as now, was the Benday dot he pilfered from Roy Lichtenstein. Since Polke clearly believes that intellectual property is theft, you could hardly call these dots his signature. But they are the most consistent feature of his painting, effortfully done by hand using the round end of a pencil eraser. Robocop, registered as a mass of newsprint dots, emerges from a haze of interference. A knight in shining dots stands amid the fog of war - but I'm falling into Polke's trap: there is no fog, no metaphor, no subtext at all, only a splash of Ab-Ex paint.

You can - and theorists always do - take Polke far too seriously. He was born in former Silesia and I like to think he has an East European sense of humour. Take a title from his Edinburgh show: 'Officials in the former East Germany can be dismissed if they falsely deny Stasi activities.' That little paradox, in which the official is damned either way, would have amused the Good Soldier Schweik. But there's a touch of Glen Baxter in these captions too: '"There's always a pecking order," said Dagmar, straightening the butter knife.'

Polke's titles are generally random, a bit of Dada thrown in to amuse. The Scottish show is amusing, though also bemusing - a series of poster-sized paintings from 1996 intended as 'cosmic tasters' of Polke's career, whatever that means. They are spacey in both senses: some clearly the result of tripping on acid colours (Polke has quit the drugs); others apparently representing marvellous interplanetary movements, sweeps of bright interference in the outer darkness.

As figurative images, these paintings hold their own, no matter how off-hand or whimsical. There goes Baron Münchhausen, flying through a sky of Polke dots; here's Nixon in a few frowning cedillas. Who could resist the Krazy Kat with his fiddle, so frenzied with the bow and gut that he's vibrating into multiple kittens? Or the purple poacher, an eighteenth-century figure sloping by with his gun, beneath a flicker of moonlit lightning?

None of it adds up to more than a weird fantasia - and sometimes you find yourself just counting the styles or layers, the way he inks a cartoon crowd behind a ghostly wash or disrupts a Victorian vignette with a jet of day-glo orange. But here and there, all this hyperactivity resolves into a single, imperishable image - as, for example, the group of 1940s travellers with their bursting suitcases, stumbling through a blind-storm of tumultuous paint. Wartime refugees, the dots of which they are composed seem to disintegrate before your very eyes. It's as if some dire transmission failure had occurred in the final bid to beam them up, to rescue them from history.

fields.headline: Don't blame me, I only designed it
fields.standfirst: From the wobbly bridge to the lightbulb fiasco in Peckham to the tainted Guggenheim in Bilbao - architects are presently getting a rough ride from the critics. But, as  Deyan Sudjic  argues, is it really their fault?
fields.trailText: From the wobbly bridge to the lightbulb fiasco in Peckham to the tainted Guggenheim in Bilbao - architects are presently getting a rough ride from the critics. But, as  Deyan Sudjic  argues, is it really their fault?
fields.body:
See the words 'award-winning' attached to the word 'building' in a news report and you just know what's coming next. It's the set-up for yet another tale of architectural disaster. And last week brought two particularly juicy examples of the genre. In Peckham, south-east London, it was discovered that it takes four days to change the light bulbs in Will Alsop's award-winning library. It had to close its doors to the public while engineers built special platforms around the bookshelves to allow them to get at the 300 lights in the high ceilings.

It was then reported that Frank Gehry's spectacularly popular Guggenheim museum in Bilbao was suffering from a nasty rash that has turned large areas of its famous exterior from shiny silver to dull brown. One American newspaper claimed that just three years after it opened the Guggenheim has started to resemble the 'rusting hull of an abandoned barge'. And nobody is agreed on how to solve the problem. 'The areas involved are gigantic, curved and very difficult to reach,' said a spokesman for the museum.

Actually, the Guggenheim isn't rusting. Its spectacular exterior is made of titanium, and titanium doesn't rust, even in the most challenging environments. According to the manufacturers, what has happened is that the oxide film which coats the titanium has started to thicken and turn an unsightly brown. There is no structural problem; it's just that it doesn't look very good. The trouble started when chemicals were spilled over the surface of the titanium during construction. They reacted with pollutants in the air, fused with the oxide film and rapidly began to spread.

According to Gehry, the problem was that the building wasn't cleaned immediately after it was finished. 'It's frustrating. All they had to do was clean it. We begged them to do so. But now it's embedded and the trick is to get it off without changing the character of the metal.'

He is worried that the roof will start to look like a patchwork. One plan to avoid this is to apply a chemical cleaning foam to the whole building which would require abseilers equipped with ghostbuster-style back-packs. Gehry calls it 'a tempest in a teapot'.

And, of course, he is right. The Guggenheim has not been hit by a structural failure, it's just got a bad case of red-wine stain on the carpet. If this had happened to an industrial shed on the business park on the edge of the city, not the most famous new museum in the world, the news that its skin was turning brown would hardly have attracted worldwide attention.

But it is precisely because Gehry's design for the Guggenheim looks so extraordinary, so counter-intuitive to our ideas of structural logic, that there has been such a wave of schadenfreude about its difficulties. Rust, brown-oxide stains or whatever, spreading all over such a landmark serves to confirm prejudices in the most delicious way. Ahah, so it really wasn't possible after all.

The bigger they come, the harder they fall. The more praise lavished on a building, the more prizes they pick up, the more irresistible are the tales of leaking roofs, spontaneously self-destructing glass and structural collapse.

There are plenty to choose from. Just about all of Britain's better-known contemporary architects have had to deal with the occasional embarrassment. James Stirling's history faculty library at Cambridge experienced so many problems with its greenhouse roof that the university senate narrowly defeated a vote to demolish it, deciding instead to rebuild it.

But this was really more an argument about the politics of Stirling's architecture than about practical issues. The militant fogey tendency in the university saw it as an aggressive modernist intrusion and wanted to get rid of it, even if the cost of a replacement would be more than repairing it. Norman Foster's Sainsbury Centre in Norwich had to have every single aluminium cladding panel removed because of a manufacturing defect. They were replaced with an alternative design using flat white panels.

There have also been problems with the glass walls at his airport in Hong Kong, to say nothing of the celebrated case of the wobbly bridge, though Arup, the engineers, now say they know how to fix the problem. Nick Grimshaw's Waterloo Eurostar station still hasn't resolved the danger of glass threatening to detach itself from the roof.

Richard Rogers had to deal with the difficulties at the Lloyd's building, and in Paris, the Pompidou Centre had to close for a year for a costly makeover of the birdshit-encrusted exoskeleton structure. The problem there was the very success of the building. The Pompidou attracted so many more visitors than it was designed for that it literally began to wear out.

When things go wrong, architects' high profile tends to make them the immediate targets for blame. But it's not the architect who physically builds a structure. That is the contractor's job, and if he doesn't do what is specified by the architect, then any defects are his fault, though lawyers get rich trying to prove that this isn't the case. More and more architecture relies on components manufactured in factories and bought off the shelf. And when they don't perform in the way that the manufacturers say they will, it is their responsibility to put it right.

But attacking architects as arrogant incompetents is as much to do with cultural prejudices as it is based on objective realities. When buildings leak or rust, it offers people who don't like contemporary architecture the same kind of weapon presented by the charges of plagiarism levelled at the Turner Prize short list last year. It's taken as positive proof that not only are contemporary architects incapable of designing buildings that are anything but a blot on the landscape, but they are conmen who can't even keep the rain out.

The weakness with the argument is that embarrassing building failures are not a new phenomenon, and nor are they limited to cutting-edge modern architecture. Think, for example, of the English cathedral builders who, in their constant efforts to out-do each other, were forever building higher and higher spires and seeing them collapse. Chichester, for example, saw its spire blow down in 1850; it had to be rebuilt.

Look at Edwin Lutyens, the last great exponent of what might be called traditional English architecture in the twentieth century. So badly did his towers at Castle Drogo leak that the first step in the National Trust's restoration campaign was demolition.

Florence's architects were so head in the clouds about practicalities that they started a cathedral that would have the largest dome in Italy without having the faintest idea of how they would be able to finish it. In Venice, the great Sansovino, architect to the republic, was threatened with jail following difficulties with the library he built in St Mark's Square.

Building is rarely an exact science. And until a project is actually finished it is hard to predict how materials will behave. But it is perfectly true that there is a predisposition to experiment and innovate in architecture. Architects do enjoy pushing things to the limit, but then, if they are going to make materials do more for less, then they really can't do anything else.

Relying on so-called traditional materials is no answer. Look at how many supposedly traditional brick cavity walls have leaked, how many traditional timber floors have developed dry rot. All the same, the Guggenheim's problems haven't done titanium's image much good. Gehry told the New York Times that he wasn't planning to use it for his project for a giant new Guggenheim in Manhattan. 'I don't think we will have the money, so don't worry about it.'

Meanwhile, Building Design Partnership, the architects of Glasgow's science centre due to open at Easter, Britain's only titanium-skinned building, has hurried to reassure its clients that there is no danger of their building turning brown too.

'We are using a higher grade of titanium,' says partner Colin Allan. 'It isn't going to happen.'

fields.headline: Who gives a Friar Tuck?
fields.standfirst: Advertising watchdogs deplore it, children snigger when they hear it, but does anyone else still care about Ken Tynan's expletive?
fields.trailText: Advertising watchdogs deplore it, children snigger when they hear it, but does anyone else still care about Ken Tynan's expletive?
fields.body:
The Advertising Standards Authority censured the frock-sellers French Connection last week for a newspaper advertisement headed the 'world's biggest fcuk'. French Connection claimed quaintly that, surely, everyone knew the 'fcuk' referred to them. The ASA, though, was having none of it, and snapped back sternly that 'fcuk' was likely to cause offence.

Was it? Really? Especially when aimed at a target audience of demotic, thread-hungry 18-35 year olds? Such is our shifting, shifty relationship with the word 'fuck' that it can simultaneously be used as a laboured way to promote a high-street retailer and an offensive expletive from which newspaper readers need to be shielded.

This ambiguity extends to every aspect of life. By the time you get to work you've probably said 'fuck' five times to yourself already, and twice to the cat. When you trip on the stairs, can't find clean pants or miss the bus then no other word will do. (Linguists say there's something particularly satisfying about the percussive effect of the formula 'f' plus short vowel plus a stop (a consonant such as K, D, G or T in which the flow of air from the mouth is briefly interrupted).

But arrive at the office and it's unlikely that you'll carry on in the same way, at least if you want to make friends and influence people. Richard Desmond, the new proprietor of the Express, may be famous for his love of 'fuck' in all its applications, but the rest of us, boss or not, tend to tone it down at work.

And for those who don't, the penalties can still be severe. Last week, Stephen Pollard, a departing leader writer from the Express, sent a cleverly coded message to the same Richard Desmond. In his final article for the paper, the first letter of each sentence spelled out 'Fuck You Desmond'. Pollard presumably thought he was quite safe, since he had a nice new job at the Times already lined up. The shocking thing is that the Times considered the offence so great that they have refused to take him on. No matter how many times you might think it, telling your boss to fuck off is still something that is better kept in your head.

'The context of talk is crucial,' confirms Dr Lia Litosseliti, senior lecturer in linguistics at Nottingham Trent University. 'As we grow up we develop a highly sophisticated sense of what kind of language it is appropriate to use with different groups of people. The frequency of swearing and the swear words we use when we're relaxing with close friends (especially close friends of the same sex) will be quite different from those we use in a mixed-sex meeting at work.'

What makes it tricky is that the goal posts continue to skip around. 'Back in the early Eighties the culture was different', remembers Dr David Pryce, a university historian. 'It was all about pushing back boundaries, reclaiming taboos, cleaning up language by using dirty words. Lots of my colleagues said 'fuck' as a way of showing that they weren't imprisoned by inherited culture.' These days, he says, it's different. 'We're in a kind of post-fuck consensus. The word really has no power to shock any more and so, paradoxically, there's no need to use it. These days, if I hear a colleague saying fuck at a meeting or in front of a student it just seems bad-mannered'.

But even if you've got work more or less linguistically sorted, dating and mating still represents a huge muddy field of potential embarrassment. 'When a man and woman meet in a social setting, they're making unconscious yet finely judged decisions about what level of sexually explicit language to use with each other,' reports psychologist and body language expert Susan Quilliam.

A woman, apparently, will never say 'fuck' first. However, the moment a man has said it, she'll bat it back to him quickly as a way of letting him know that she is far from being offended.'

'Fuck' is a particularly handy word in dating situations, says Quilliam, because its literal meaning is never trailing very far behind its metaphoric one. 'A couple who don't know each other very well might, after a couple of drinks, start comparing notes about their respective fucking awful bosses. In an indirect way they may be signalling that they are interested in each other as sexual partners. And, of course, if the attraction isn't mutual, the useful thing is that neither person feels they've lost face. It's easy to withdraw gracefully.'

Anecdotal reports about the word's qualities as an aphrodisiac abound. 'I don't use it that much as a swear word, but I'm very fond of its literal use,' says Julia Brown, 37. 'I first decided to sleep with my husband when I heard him say of someone else that what they wanted was a really good fuck.'

Confusing, certainly, in an age of post-political correctness. But the fact remains that there is nothing less sexy than a man who skirts around the word. 'I once went out with a guy who had this habit of saying "Friar Tuck" instead of the word itself,' remembers Victoria Sadler, 42. 'I think he was trying to spare my sensibilities, but the effect was so deeply unerotic that I found it impossible to kiss him.'

The wonderful thing about 'fuck' is its generous inclusiveness. It has no race or gender implications and, while it may describe heterosexual penetrative sex, it isn't sneery about other kinds. By insulting everyone, it insults no one. 'I always think it's weird that I grew up in the Seventies with my parents saying "sodding" and "bugger" quite happily, yet freaking out about "fuck",' says Julia Brown. 'Sometimes I think I'd like to ask them whether they think anal intercourse is less rude than the vaginal variety, but I'm just not sure it would go down very well.'

And, for those who worry about these things, 'fuck' is also conveniently free of any blasphemous intent. 'As a kind of post-Christian I still feel slightly bad about saying "Jesus" or even "bloody", especially in front of my brother, who is a vicar,' says Kate Harris, 38.

'But I feel that he can't really get me for saying fuck. I put it to him once that, surely there was no reason why Church of England clergy shouldn't say it. All the time, if they wanted. But he wouldn't buy it.'

If parents and siblings are tricky to navigate, how much worse is it with children? Not because of their delicate sensibilities but because of a brazen lack of them. Recent outings to the Robert De Niro film comedy Meet The Parents have been marred for adult audiences by the extended sniggering of eight to 12-year-olds every time the surname of the putative son-in-law is mentioned: he's called Focker.

Four-year-olds are regularly coming out with 'fuck', or something which sounds a bit like it. 'I honestly don't know whether Oliver picked it up from me, his much older siblings or nursery school,' agonises Mary Wells, who can't help contrasting this linguistic precocity with her own experience, growing up in the Seventies and Eighties. 'I was 12 before I consciously registered the word, and about 21 before I first dared use it. I mean, I remember being shocked when a school friend at my bog standard comprehensive said "bum".'

Wells has tried on her older children that old line about how repeated swearing suggests an impoverished vocabulary. 'But the problem is, it's just not true,' she admits. 'Some of the cleverest, most eloquent people I've ever known have used "fuck" constantly.'

The alternative is to tell your children the truth - that you just don't like them using the word. 'There's a kind of anger behind repeated use of "fuck" which I find upsetting, particularly coming from a 12-year-old,' says Wells.

In fact, Wells has identified an under-acknowledged but powerful response to over-use of the word. 'It feels angry, bitter, violent, combative,' says Victoria Sadler.

'The woman who sits next to me at work uses "fuck" constantly and it makes me uncomfortable. She isn't saying "fuck off Vicky", but since she's saying "fuck off job, fuck off computer, fuck off coffee machine" I feel that, actually, she'd probably quite like to include me on the list.'
