fields.headline: A whiter shade of play...
fields.trailText: Spinning into Butter Theatre Upstairs Royal Court, London SW1
fields.body:
Spinning into Butter Theatre Upstairs Royal Court, London SW1

You don't have to be Greg Dyke to spot that the British theatre is a very white place. White directors, white writers, white actors (that's changing a bit), white critics. And a white audience. The first night of Rebecca Gilman's drama about racism on an American campus was a case in point. There was one black face in the auditorium. That face belonged to a writer, commissioned to review the play by the BBC: Margaret Busby described with comic weariness how at sensitive moments she felt other members of the audience 'checking her out'.

Which puts a peculiar spin on Spinning into Butter. This is a play - with an all-white cast - about a group of white people who constantly talk about, rather than to, the black people with whom they work. It takes its title from the now-infamous children's story about Little Black Sambo, who watched the tigers that were about to gobble him up chasing each other until they liquidised into a puddle of butter - which L.B. Sambo consumed.

The tigers here are the all-white teaching staff of a Vermont college, dismayed but divided by the news that one of their African-American students has been receiving racist hate-mail. The eager young dean - excellent Emma Fielding, who conveys just the right mixture of perkiness, solemnity and twitchiness - calls in the police. Her colleagues want to use the row as an occasion for debate and self-aggrandisement.

Their jargon-laden position - 'It could be a real learning experience' - is always suspect: David Horowich supplies a very funny performance as an academic dripping with self-regard. Everything is set for a clash between politically correct blethering and forthright action.

And then comes the rub. In a major, unclearly motivated speech, the young dean - perhaps in search of absolution - declares herself a guilty mass of prejudice: she left her previous college because she wanted to be in a whiter place; she thinks Toni Morrison's books 'suck'; she avoids sitting next to black men on the subway, especially if they're 'wearing big puffy coats'. At its Chicago premiere, Spinning into Butter was compared to Oleanna, David Mamet's explosive play about sexual harassment. Gilman - who's unusual in her ability to flesh out her ideas in plots - doesn't pack an equal punch, but she fires a good few shots across the bows of liberal opinion. You can argue that she's delivered only half a play here: no one is going to think that the other faculty members are other than punchbags; no one is going to believe that the dean's views are an all-inclusive truth. You can argue that John Stevenson's design - an enclosed, contextless office - is too limited. But Spinning into Butter does make you want to argue - which is more than most plays do. Not least because those words 'everyone does' expose something about the theatre. That it is confidently addressed to an all-white audience.

The first night of Rebecca Gilman's drama about racism on an American campus was a case in point. There was one black face in the auditorium. fields.headline: I detest housework (and it shows...)
fields.trailText: I think my house stinks. I'm not absolutely certain (because no one can smell their own house) but I strongly suspect that it's not the most fragrant of dwellings. There are too many old things mouldering for it to smell good around here. Fragments of ageing cheese peek out from under the fridge; a long-abandoned crust of toast and Marmite is discovered during excavations beneath my son's duvet. Hang on - he is nearly four years old. He went off Marmite at two and a half.
fields.body:
I think my house stinks. I'm not absolutely certain (because no one can smell their own house) but I strongly suspect that it's not the most fragrant of dwellings. There are too many old things mouldering for it to smell good around here. Fragments of ageing cheese peek out from under the fridge; a long-abandoned crust of toast and Marmite is discovered during excavations beneath my son's duvet. Hang on - he is nearly four years old. He went off Marmite at two and a half.

Our house is like this because I detest housework. It's the endlessness of it that kills me. I do not glow with self-satisfaction when I've cleaned a room; I just have a private bet with myself on how long before it's trashed again. And who cares? No one notices when a house is neat. There is a distinct lack of applause following appliance-wiping sessions. In fact, certain tasks (Hoovering, dusting) are commented upon only when they are not done. What happened to positive feedback?

Housework would be more appealing if there were some kind of incentive. But no matter how vigorously you clean your toilet, you're unlikely to be promoted to Chief of Domestic Duties (whose job it is to make helpful remarks like: 'You've missed a bit'). While careers and relationships peak and trough, housework is unchanging. If I live to be 75, I look forward to 39 years spent scowling at the greasy mark where pedal bin meets lino.

Friends with busier lives than mine manage to keep their houses gleaming. Open a drawer and you are greeted by shiny cutlery all in the proper compartments, not bits of gristle, ancient crumbs and gnarled, plastic teaspoons. Yet I am as dirtyas when I first left home. Eighteen-year-olds are supposed to live in rank surroundings. I am 36 - grown-up enough to purchase Febreeze and Dettox - and have three children under four, all at risk from poisoning.

My partner and I are as sloppy as each other, yet we both stalk around the house, muttering: 'Pick that up. Put that away.' Yes, we have a cleaning lady and she does a sterling job, considering. When I apologised for the underlying odour, she smiled pleasantly and said: 'Some families I work for are so clean it's hardly worth my while. Here, I make a difference.' I don't tell her that, two hours after her departure, the kids' friends arrive and the place is reeking of fish fingers and strewn with toilet roll as if she has never been here at all.

Our previous home was so overrun with mice that we often trapped six or seven a night. The house reverberated with the snapping of traps. 'I can't understand it,' said the environmental health man. 'They're breeding. There must be a food source somewhere.' Only when we moved did I discover a stash of shortbread biscuits which must have slithered under the sofa.

Now I work from home and endeavour to try harder. It's a necessary evil of freelancing that you cannot make the short trip from bed to PC without bypassing mounds of putrid laundry and black squidges which, thankfully, turn out to be flattened raisins.

We are relatively new to the village, so I was cheered by a neighbour with an equally chaotic home. 'Everyone has been saying I should come round to your house,' she said brightly.

'Really? It's a terrible mess.'

'Yes,' she agreed. 'They said it would make me feel much better about mine.'

webTitle: Should I succumb to Mrs Robinson?

fields.headline: Should I succumb to Mrs Robinson?
fields.trailText:
Last weekend I stayed at a friend's house after a party. I woke up early in the morning to find his mother massaging my back. She then climbed into bed with me and made it clear she would like to make love. I felt really embarrassed and put her off, but I can't stop thinking about her. I am 17 and have never had sex, and sometimes I'm terrified about whether I'll be able to do it properly. My friend's mother seemed so willing to show me how to do it that I wonder whether I should go back and tell her I'd like to try. But a part of me feels this wouldn't be right. What should I do?
W.L. of Oxford
fields.body:
Last weekend I stayed at a friend's house after a party. I woke up early in the morning to find his mother massaging my back. She then climbed into bed with me and made it clear she would like to make love. I felt really embarrassed and put her off, but I can't stop thinking about her. I am 17 and have never had sex, and sometimes I'm terrified about whether I'll be able to do it properly. My friend's mother seemed so willing to show me how to do it that I wonder whether I should go back and tell her I'd like to try. But a part of me feels this wouldn't be right. What should I do?
W.L. of Oxford

There is no right answer to this. Many would argue (in their inner minds, if not out loud) that we are put on this earth to procreate, and the sooner you learn how, the better. Others might reason that although at 17 you are physically mature, emotionally you are not.

Becoming sexually active at this age can cause painful conflicts as you find yourself at the mercy of disparate urges: revulsion, excitement, obsessional curiosity, self-disgust and guilt.

Part of you feels this encounter would not be right, and if I were your mother I'd certainly agree with you. (Indeed, if I were your mother, and you succumbed to this woman, I should be so furious that I'd probably tear her limb from limb.) Nor would her son be happy with the arrangement. Imagine his confusion on finding his friend has become his mother's toyboy.

In some cultures, it is usual for a young man to be initiated by an older, more experienced woman, often a prostitute.

The idea is, I suppose, that a man can get over the fears of incompetence that you express with a motherly, kindly sort of woman, before approaching an innocent girl of his own age with a degree of expertise. Men worry much more about the quality of their performance than women do. Women are more concerned about being desired and inspiring love. I don't suppose men's innately competitive egos will ever take that message aboard.

It is always possible that this woman could give you a discreet, sensitive, gentle induction course into love-making. On the other hand, I suspect her motive is not primarily to do you a good turn. She is more likely to be a raddled Mrs Robinson, sated with sexual adventures and desirous of stimulating her jaded appetite with a fresh, different, but essentially temporary and thoroughly selfish experience.

I don't think you should go back to her to recreate the opportunity. Who knows what other factors, such as inhibitions released through drink or drugs, played a part in her frank advances? I think you have probably had a lucky escape.

And don't worry about your ability to do it properly when the time comes; modern youth is infinitely better informed about sex than past generations.

Readers' Replies

Boy, and I mean boy, you blew a golden opportunity, envied and yearned for by many a callow youth - to be coached by a mature, passionate woman into the mysteries and joys of physical love.

You can try to repair matters, but I fancy you will experience mortifying rejection and live with your 'if only' regrets for the rest of your life. I took my chance in similar circumstances in 1955 and still savour it.
A.P. of Port Talbot

Working on the assumption that there is no husband on the scene, this is surely an offer you cannot refuse. What better way for a 17-year-old to lose his virginity than with a willing, experienced older woman?

As long as discretion is assured, both parties gain and nobody loses. However, if the woman does have a partner, that would be a different matter entirely. It's definitely not worth running the risk of splitting up a family just to satisfy your mutual sexual curiosity.
C.R. of Blackheath

Next Week's Dilemma

I feel I have offended my gay friend and I want to know if my opinions are prejudiced or normal.

Despite liking someone regardless of their sexuality, I find the thought of sex between two men quite abhorrent (I am a heterosexual woman). I do not, however, find the idea of two women together abhorrent (although I wouldn't want to do it myself). I tried to explain that I felt it was a preference, not a prejudice, but my friend disagrees, believing that I think gay men are disgusting.
L.R. of London

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

webTitle: And Mummy told me I was the only one

fields.headline: And Mummy told me I was the only one
fields.standfirst: You might think your name is unique, but an 'ego-surfing' film-maker is here to prove you wrong
fields.trailText: You might think your name is unique, but an 'ego-surfing' film-maker is here to prove you wrong
fields.body:
We practise spelling out our name from the moment we can hold a pen. The sound of it has a magical cadence. Although we know we would smell as sweet, or as bad, by any other, we mostly stick with the name we were given until the day we die - when it will be all that is left. I was happy with my name until I found on the internet that I was one of at least 15 Vanessa Thorpes in Britain. Logically, the existence of 14 other people with my name means nothing. It is simply the product of a probability sum. Yet I was disturbed.

One of the many Vanessa Thorpes is a 24-year-old in Leicester who works in a clothing warehouse. She was as disquieted as I was to be confronted with a namesake. 'I didn't think there would be many about,' she said. 'It is strange, but you tend to think you are the only one.'

We established that we are both nicknamed Ness. Spookily, both of us were named after Vanessa Redgrave, our respective mothers having been impressed by seeing the statuesque actress 'in something'. We agreed that we hoped we would never meet. 'It would be complicated if we were in the same room,' she said. Neither of us was prepared to risk the identity crisis that closer contact might provoke.

New York film director Alan Berliner was braver. In tonight's Storyville (BBC2), he tracks down 12 other Alan Berliners and invites them to his place. His film, The Sweetest Sound, tackles the question of names and their power.

The laconic Berliner hosts a once-only dinner party for his international namesakes. The sight of 12 men of Jewish extraction sitting around a bearded man at a supper table has obvious New Testament resonance, but Berliner's subject is not religion, except in as far as it affects our sense of identity.

A self-confessed obsessive who spent years filming a remarkable trilogy of documentaries about his family, Berliner admits the process of tracing the 12 turned him into a 'namoholic'. He coins a nice term for the act of looking oneself up on the internet: 'ego-surfing'.

Berliner's fixation was sparked by one particular irritant - he is often confused, he says, with the French film-maker Alain Berliner, director of Ma vie en rose, who, while not strictly a namesake, is close enough to be threatening - and to qualify for an invitation to the dinner. On the evening of the party, the assembled Alans are revealed to be all roughly the same age and colour (white). Several, like their host and the affable Alain from France, work in the arts. Some even turn out to be distant relatives. The name Alan is judged by all of them to be rather bland, although, of course, it does find a strong advocate in Berliner's mother. Which Berliner's mother? Well, all of them, probably.

The British comedian Dave Gorman has his own run at the subject of names next month in a programme called The Dave Gorman Collection . It tells of the journey he made from New York, via Swindon, to Tel Aviv, covering more than 20,000 miles, to meet an impressive 54 Dave Gormans. He has compiled a compendium of Dave Gorman facts: their average shoe size is eight and most of them have ginger beards.

Gorman worked on The Mrs Merton Show before setting off, literally, to find himself. He took the story of his travels to the Edinburgh Festival last summer in a show called Are You Dave Gorman? His propaganda proved so persuasive that five members of the audience changed their names to his by deed poll.

Funnily enough, there was another show in Edinburgh last year about the same thing. The stand-up comic Neil Mullarkey also traced the story of his own name across the continents. He argued that he had been provoked into the project by the guffaws of disbelief that greet his surname. Was he driven to a life in comedy, he wonders, by people's expectations of the word Mullarkey?

It is pertinent that the 'namoholics' mentioned here are all men. While the sense of a 'family line' is not peculiar to males, it does seem to mean that their names have more purchase on their imagination. For Vanessa and I, on the other hand, the namesake issue was one of passing interest. But things may change. After all, more women are keeping their surname, whether they marry or not. 'I wouldn't change mine if I got married,' said the other Ms Thorpe. 'Most of my friends,even the ones who have babies, have kept their names too.' The trend means women are beginning to claim their own identities. In future, it will be that much easier to trace their life stories. And with less possibility of adopting a new name halfway through life, a new obsession is heading our way.

Storyville , BBC2, 11.20; The Dave Gorman Collection , BBC Choice, 23 January

fields.headline: You can count me out
fields.standfirst: Our lives are ruled by numbers - from credit cards and surveys to school league tables. But the more we measure our lives, the less we actually live them
fields.trailText: Our lives are ruled by numbers - from credit cards and surveys to school league tables. But the more we measure our lives, the less we actually live them
fields.body:
The renowned cosmologist Professor Bignumska, lecturing on the future of the universe, had stated that in a billion years, the earth would fall into the sun in a fiery death. In the back of the auditorium a tremulous voice piped up. 'Excuse me Professor, but h-how long did you say it would be?' Professor Bignumska calmly replied, 'About a billion years.' A sigh of relief was heard. "Whew! For a minute there, I thought you said a million years."'

Douglas Hofstadter, Scientific American, May 1982

Mary Poppins was the first film I ever saw. I was six years, four months old - let's measure it precisely. I remember trotting as fast as I could beside my father along Whitehall, past the Treasury and the other palaces of national calculation, to the Haymarket. And I remember being blown away by the experience, the songs of Julie Andrews and the idea that life should be a little more magical than it was.

Within weeks I knew most of the lyrics by heart, though I barely understood the words. Maybe, in retrospect, I was also a little influenced by Mary Poppins's ridicule of George Banks and his fascination for the kind of order brought by numbers. 'They must feel the thrill of totting up a balance book,' she sings to poor deluded George about his children: '... A thousand cyphers neatly in a row. When gazing at a graph that shows the profits up, their little cup of joy should overflow.'

The irony is lost on him - as it was on me. And though Hollywood is still busily promoting the idea of magic, you would never catch it now making fun of profits or ridiculing the importance of calculation - still less the idea of cyphers neatly in a row. I came away from the cinema determined to make sure I flung my tuppence away on a little old bird woman, rather than marvelling at the strange alchemy of compound interest if I put it in the bank. Yet here I am, 35 years later, with my pension and life insurance, living in a world overwhelmed by numbers and calculation.

It's the same for nearly all of us. There are personal calculations to be made each day, about investments, journey times, bank machines and credit cards. There are professional figures at work, in the form of targets, statistics, workforce percentages and profit-fore casts. As consumers, we are counted and aggregated according to every purchase we make. Every time we are exposed to the media, there is a positive flood of statistics controlling and interpreting the world, developing each truth, simplifying each problem.

We take our collective pulse 24 hours a day with the use of statistics. We understand life that way, though some how the more figures we use, the more the great truths seem to slip through our fingers. Despite all that numerical control, we feel as ignorant of the answers to the big questions as ever.

If you are to be 'calculating', people could mean one of two things about you - both related and equally repellent. It could mean you are constantly weighing up what is best for you in any situation. This is not a compliment. It implies something cold, fish-like and self-interested. But it could also mean you are someone who counts too much, someone who measures things but can't see the reality behind them.

There is something equally clinical about that, but in a disinterested rather than self-interested way. And it can send a shiver down the spine when you come across extreme examples. Like the eighteenth-century prodigy Jedediah Buxton in his first trip to the theatre to see a performance of Richard III. Asked whether he'd enjoyed it, all he could say was that there were 5,202 steps during the dances and 12,445 words spoken by the actors. Nothing about what the words said, about the winter of our discontent made glorious summer; nothing about the evil hunchback king.

Today, Buxton would probably be described as autistic. It is particularly horrifying to hear that his numbers turned out to be exactly right.

The story is funny now as then, but it is also faintly disturbing. Buxton is in some ways a fearsome symbol of the modern age, in which we count everything but see the significance of nothing. There is something inhuman, not so much about his ability to count, but his failure to be moved. We shiver at anybody with no emotions - as if they were amoral, like Dr Strangelove.

Even so, we encounter such 'calculating' man-machines almost every day: the academic who refuses to pass judgment on any problem, however urgent, because there hasn't been enough research; the politician who is so obsessed with opinion polls that he can no longer trust his gut instincts; the social scientist who has laboriously proved with the use of statistics something that anybody else with an ounce of common sense knew already - that the death of a parent can scar a child for life, or that alcoholics have an unusually high depression rate. It's 'official', they say. Like the University of Michigan study which revealed that children who don't exercise and eat junk food tend to be fatter. Or the recent research which showed that areas of high unemployment tend to have fewer jobs.

Ratcheting up the calculations has often been done for excellent humanitarian reasons, driven by impeccably radical reformers. Maybe they wanted to prove the existence of great inequality or disease, like Edwin Chadwick. Maybe they wanted to find a way of aggregating the national accounts to defeat Hitler, like John Maynard Keynes. Or maybe they wanted to force politicians to worry about people's happiness, like Jeremy Bentham. These are people who - for the best of motives - brought the flood of numbers and calculations into the non-scientific parts of our lives.

It still is a way of improving the world. Are your schools not performing as well as they should? Then measure their results. Are you worried about the performance of a council, a company, a hospital? Send in the auditors. You don't trust the professionals? Summarise their decisions in number form. It is the modern way. Numbers - like money - drive out the mysterious power of elites, the clubbable atmosphere of the professions, the patronising attitudes of those thick-set people with glasses and firm handshakes who used to lord it over our lives. Numbers give us back control. But the numbers have proliferated, so that it's sometimes hard to breathe - still less tell the difference between one statistic and another. It is difficult enough to remember your car registration number, PIN, home, work and mobile phone numbers all at the same time. It's almost enough to make you coldly calculating.

The problem is if you don't count what's really important, it gets ignored. There are only so many resources, so doctors must compare the quality of life of a 70-year-old with heart-failure against a suicidal teenager with a long history of depression. Planners have to compare the pleasure and disruption brought by a new 18-screen cinema with the contentment of keeping it as a park. Investors have to compare a notoriously polluting oil company with a dodgy record in human rights with a tremendously successful internet company with three employees and no profits.

They measure, measure, measure, knowing that what they measure is alive and will not keep still, and suspecting that maybe - however much they count - they will not capture the essence of the question they are asking. Things have to keep static if you're going to count them: that's probably why the first statisticians were known as 'statists'. But real life isn't still.

We need answers, but we also know that what is most important to our lives simply can't be pinned down like a still-life. What we can't do is leave things as they are - all of those numbers are making us misunderstand things. And every time a new set of statistics comes out, I can't help feeling some of the richness and mystery of life gets extinguished. Just as individual stories of passion and betrayal get hidden by the marriage statistics, or the whole meaning of the Holocaust gets lost in the number 6,000,000. There is a sort of deadening effect, a distancing from human emotion and reality. Barely discernible, but just enough for it to matter. Our obsession with numbers creates a number of paradoxes.

Counting paradox 1: You can count people, but you can't count individuals.

The definition 'Average Man' belongs to the Industrial Revolution and the twentieth-century world of mass-production and is now a deeply unfashionable term. We can see more clearly today how difficult it is to categorise the widely different individuals who make up the human race. But in the hands of a bureaucratic state, people who don't conform to the norm still get hounded and imprisoned. Or social workers visit them and remove their children. And after all that, when you actually get to know Mr Average, you find he has a bizarre taste in underwear and a hidden collection of Abba records. He wasn't average at all.

Counting paradox 2: If you count the wrong thing, you go backwards .

Because it is so hard to measure what is really important, governments and institutions try to pin down something else. They have to. But the consequences of pinning down the wrong thing can be severe.

Take school league tables. The idea of forcing schools to compete with each other by measuring the progress of children at three comparable moments of their lives, was intended to raise standards. They probably have done in a narrow way. The trouble was that schools concentrated on the test results to improve their position on the tables. That meant excluding pupils who may drag down the results, concentrating on the D grade pupils - the only ones who could make a difference in exam result league tables - to the detriment of the others. If you choose the wrong measure, you sometimes get the opposite of what you wanted.

When farmers and merchants didn't trust each other to provide the right amount of wheat, they could use the standard local barrel stuck to the wall of the town hall, which would measure the agreed local bushel. When we don't trust our corporations, politicians or professionals now, we send in the auditors - and we break down people's jobs into measureable units so that we can see what they are doing and check it. If doctors hide behind their professional masks, then we measure the number of deaths per number of patients, their treatment record and their success rate, and hold them accountable. .

So here's the paradox. Numbers are democratic. We use them to peer into the mysterious worlds of professionals, to take back some kind of control. Yet in another sense they are not democratic at all. Politicians like to pretend that numbers take the decisions out of their hands. 'Listen to the scientists,' they say about BSE or genetically modified food. There has been, in other words, a shift of power from one kind of professional to another, in the name of democracy - from teachers and doctors to accountants, auditors and number-crunchers. And as we all trust the companies and institutions less, we trust the auditors less too.

Counting paradox 4: The more we count, the less we understand.

Numbers allow experts to 'speak one and the same language, even if they use different mother tongues,' said Karl Popper. This is an international language based on centrally imposed definitions. It's a kind of modern imperialism, with no respect for local understanding. Can we really believe the European Union was getting accurate comparisons in its survey asking 60,000 people if they 'could make ends meet'? As if a German, a Greek and a Briton would all understand the same by that. When Pepsi had its slogan 'Come alive with the Pepsi generation' translated into Chinese, it was understood as 'Pepsi brings your ancestors back from the grave'. Microscopic differences in definition create big effects.

Counting paradox 5: The more we count, the less we can compare the figures.

In 1978 the Chief Constable of Greater Manchester, James Anderton, made a challenging speech about crime figures for England and Wales. There had been 77,934 recorded crimes in 1900, he said. In 1976, there were 2,135,713. The country was horrified.

Every generation believes crime is getting worse. In the mid-nineteenth century Friedrich Engels calculated that crime had risen more than seven times since the battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Seventy years later there was the sudden 90 per cent rise in bag-snatching between the wars, mainly because police statistics stopped reporting such thefts as 'lost property'.

The same happened in the 1970s, when police stopped distinguishing between major damage and minor damage (defined as less than £20) and vandalism figures doubled in a year - just before Anderton unveiled his statistics.

Counting paradox 6: Measurements have a monstrous life of their own.

Stalin announced his first Soviet five-year plan in 1928, an enormous undertaking planned to increase gross industrial output by 235.9 per cent and labour productivity by 110 per cent. But these figureswere completely spurious. The fake precision was to lend a pseudo-scientific air to the whole enterprise. The actual effect of the plan was to reduce real per capita income by half, and starve millions on what Stalin referred to as the 'agricultural front'. Even so, he declared the first five-year plan a success 12 months early in 1932, and the second one started right away.

The figures were widely believed, even in the West. But not only were nearly all of them falsified, they carried with them a terrible authoritarianism to try to force them to be true. Which is why one in eight of the Soviet population was shot or sent to a labour camp. Figures are frightening sometimes.

Counting paradox 7: When you count things, they get worse.

In quantum physics, the mere presence of an observer in sub-atomic particle experiments can change the results. In anthropology, researchers have to report on their own cultural reactions as a way of offsetting the same effect. And once you start looking at numbers you keep falling over a strange phenomenon, which is that the official statistics tend to get worse when society is worried about something.

Why, for example, did illegitimacy figures shoot up only after the war babies panic in 1915? At the time of the panic, the number of illegitimate births was astonishingly low - and the number of marriages strangely high. Why was the number of homes unfit for human habitation in the UK in 1967 (after the TV film Cathy Come Home ) almost twice the figure for 1956 - despite more than a decade of intensive demolition and rebuilding?

The death of Stephen Lawrence led to widespread concern about race attacks in London. But after the public inquiry on the subject in 1998, Metropolitan Police figures of race attacks leapt from 1,149 to 7,790 in one year.

It sounds nonsense, but it's true: for politicians who try to measure the elusive source of 'feelgood' in their populations, for business leaders who recognise that the key to success is realising that their assets are intangible qualities which are extremely hard to measure - like knowledge, information or reputation.

Microsoft is an extreme example. Its balance sheet lists assets that amount to only about six per cent of what the company is worth. 'In other words,' says the futurist Charles Leadbetter, '94 per cent of the value of this most dynamic and powerful company in the new digital economy is in intangible assets that accountants cannot measure.'

fields.headline: Yobs for years - and loving it
fields.standfirst: Private Eye cartoonist Tony Husband tells Neasa MacErlean he's part of a team: he draws and his wife handles the finances
fields.trailText: Private Eye cartoonist Tony Husband tells Neasa MacErlean he's part of a team: he draws and his wife handles the finances.
fields.body:
Like acting, drawing cartoons is one of those occupations that create a few well-paid successful practitioners and leave most of the rest earning little and sticking with the boring day job.

Tony Husband is one of the exceptions: the creator of The Yobs 15 years ago in Private Eye, he has been at the top of his profession ever since, winning two categories (best gag, and best strip for The Yobs) in last year's Cartoonist of the Year awards. He's now satisfied and solvent, but did serve a long apprenticeship.

Brought up in Hyde, Manchester, he left school at 16 with a strong desire to do something creative but unsure what. After working for an advertising agency and as a window dresser, he became a 'crap jeweller' in a company where he stayed 12 years. 'It was full of characters and helped me to develop the black humour side.'

Drawing cartoons at night, he published How to use your head: 100 ways of using a severed head . Uses include doorstop and pencil sharpener.

But although he was never particularly good at handling the money he earned, he had a talent for marketing himself. 'I'm a bit of a hustler,' says the 50-year old. 'I've got so many ideas. I just used to bombard people until they begged for mercy.'

Tony Blair's recent pronouncements on yob culture show just how much mileage there is left.

fields.headline: Bill casts his net wider
fields.standfirst:
As Clinton's scourge Kenneth Starr joins the serried ranks of Gates' enemies, Simon Moores looks at Microsoft's spending spree

More net news
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: As Clinton's scourge Kenneth Starr joins the serried ranks of Gates' enemies, Simon Moores looks at Microsoft's spending spree
fields.body:
In the beginning, there was Microsoft, or at least it seems so, for this is the company whose short history is part of the memory of a generation and which has done more than any other since Henry Ford to shape the relationship between man and machine.

Depending on your perspective, Microsoft is a post-industrial anti-Christ or the spark that ignited the engine of the American information economy. It says everything about man's ability to innovate and offers every reason to examine the creeping threat of globalism, multinational power and the basis of anti-trust legislation in the twenty-first century.

Like AT&T before it - under threat of dismemberment and constantly scrutinised by the courts - Microsoft has seen its stock price drop by 60 per cent in the past 12 months.

Its leadership of the industry is under assault from new directions and by new technologies, and it is no longer so able to use its considerable financial and marketing muscle to the disadvantage of rival companies. This giant among software predators will have to be very smart and very fast to survive in the constantly connected world of multiple device types that will be tomorrow's wired generation.

From modest beginnings, the company owes its success to the shrewd purchase of the Q-DOS Operating System from the Seattle Computer Company for the tiny sum of $50,000. This was swiftly turned into MS-DOS and licensed to IBM - and history was made. Ironically, Q-DOS was Microsoft's second acquisition. The first was a technology licence for an equally obscure operating system named Unix, acquired from AT&T in 1980.

Over 20 years later, the Microsoft team is rather larger than the one that could once fit easily into a small room littered with discarded pizza boxes and Coca-Cola cans. In the past 12 months the company, which boasts retained profits larger than the gross national product of many small nations, has been busier than ever; according to one report from Client Server News (CSN), it has made a total of '41 acknowledged acquisitions, investments and joint ventures'.

Most of these investments, totalling around $3 billion, have given Microsoft access to interesting new technologies or guarantees that the recipient of Microsoft largesse will continue to use the Windows platform in preference to any other.

The many interesting investments and acquisitions in 2000 included: MongoMusic, DriveOff.Com Digital Anvil, Corio and Corel. However, Microsoft ended the year with the second- largest purchase in its history, offering $1.1bn in stock for accounting software company Great Plains Software.

The deal, which is aimed squarely at rival giant Oracle's expanding applications software ambitions, will undoubtedly alter the enterprise software landscape as Microsoft seeks to assemble a line of financial and business software services, designed for web-based delivery through its bCentral portal.

Microsoft's decision to expand into the application software business comes at a time when this market appears to be showing promise. Great Plains' closest rival is Sage Software, and the acquisition will allow Microsoft to integrate its forthcoming .Net platform with Great Plains' business management suite, placing it well to offer small business applications through the emerging Applications Service Provider (ASP) route to market.

Microsoft's largest acquisition was its $1.5bn purchase of Visio in September 1999 for stock. At the time, Microsoft's shares were trading at $95. Since then, of course, the value of the stock Visio received has fallen quite dramatically, to $655m. Great Plains is taking the same risk, but it is arguably joining Microsoft's large extended family at a low point in the stock value and is betting on an improvement in Microsoft's fortunes.

To understand why Microsoft is embarking on a course of retail therapy, one should understand that the company's business currently consists of three core product areas: desktop operating systems, desktop applications, and server software. For the future, Microsoft's real ambitions lie in internet-driven services and applications, what it calls its .Net strategy. December's surprise profit warning confronted the company with the threat of declining personal computer sales and a slowdown in corporate IT expenditure, both coming at a vulnerable period in the company's history.

A Morgan Stanley Dean Witter annual survey of IT spending at the thousand largest US companies, revealed that approximately 16 per cent planned to spend less on IT this year, and that 12 per cent had already reduced their spending. A further 14 per cent plan to adjust their spending depending on macro-economic conditions, waiting for the second half of the year to spend the larger part of their budget.

As computer hardware prices fall, Microsoft has been accelerating its efforts to squeeze vastly more revenue out of every single PC sold. However, the evidence of the past 12 months suggests that this strategy is no longer working and that the Microsoft train is in danger of coming off the tracks.

With its historical revenue model under pressure, Microsoft's new consumer and 'Software as a Service' model, the precursor of a more ambitious next-generation internet applications delivery strategy, is failing to shows signs of growing fast enough to balance its transition from a pure product to a services company.

Microsoft's .Net strategy concerns itself with the next phase of the internet - moving away from simple web pages towards the concept of 'web services' or, in layman's terms, making the internet a two-way any time, anywhere, interactive and more integrated environment.

In his visionary role as chief software architect, Bill Gates views the internet of today as relatively unsophisticated and unintelligent. In much the same way as Microsoft, through the arrival of its Windows Operating System, added a veneer of user-friendliness and intelligence to the PC, it now plans to build - and indeed own - a new framework of services, one that will sit on top of the internet and invisibly manage the increasingly virtual world that will surround every facet of our lives.

The Microsoft Network (MSN) remains an important component of the company's overall strategy. While .Net remains either an inspired strategy or a clever exercise in smoke and mirrors, Microsoft still has ambitious plans for the MSN.

Still a rather poor second, in subscriber terms, to America On-line, MSN is growing as a global business-to-business and business-to- consumer exchange, one capable of linking the services of Microsoft's many partners in a compelling collection of 'pay per view' style services. Rather like a Sunday boot sale, Microsoft owns a large playing field and is inviting its partners from across the commercial spectrum to set up shop inside MSN's global shopping mall.

The breadth of Microsoft's ambition is so vast that grasping the bigger picture is as much a challenge to governments as it is to financial analysts. The past 18 months have seen extraordinary focus on the company's anti-competitive behaviour and its struggle to maintain its Operating Systems monopoly.

But while the audience's attention has been on the court drama, Microsoft has been busy buying the twentyfirst century's technology high ground, consolidating its position on any and perhaps every potentially useful technology and platform that takes its interest - and this includes games, digital music, mobile telephony, publishing, television, cable services, software and much more.

Microsoft is attempting to find the perfect wave to ride into the next decade but its greatest worry is the state of its surfboard. The all encompassing .Net strategy is not yet completely seaworthy, and this century's next great technology wave could just as easily swamp the company's ambitions as carry it to the same position of dominance it enjoyed in the last century.

fields.headline: EMI falters at the altar
fields.standfirst: Eurocrats killed the  plan  to merge with Warner. But  Jamie Doward  says it could be second time lucky
fields.trailText: Eurocrats killed the plan to merge with Warner. But Jamie Doward says it could be second time lucky
fields.body:
EMI Executives could be forgiven for thinking their business is the Bridget Jones of the FTSE. Like the thirtysomething diarist, the music giant's attempts to find an ideal mate have suffered a series of ignominious setbacks, leaving some to speculate that the company will never find a union.

Last October the 104-year-old company had to jettison its £13 billion merger with Warner Music of the US after European Commission competition officials signalled they would block the move.

The Commission's decision ended a tortuous series of negotiations since January 2000 and left EMI struggling to maintain its credibility. The company - which had for months spun the line that the merger with Warner was rather akin to signing a hundred new Spice Girls, one of EMI's biggest acts - was then forced to talk up its prospects as a spinster to a dubious Square Mile.

To add to the humiliation, EMI had to tell the City the protracted courtship had cost it more than £40 million. EMI chairman Eric Nicoli must have been longing to return to the good old boring days when he was running United Biscuits.

A year on and EMI could be jilted again. Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate that started life printing hymns 170 years ago and now owns or has stakes in companies as diverse as publisher Random House, Pearson Television and online bookseller Barnes & Noble.com, wants to merge its privately owned music division with EMI, creating the world's largest music company.

EMI's turnover for the last financial year was nearly £2.4 billion, while BMG notched up nearly £3bn. BMG employs more than 11,000 people; EMI a few hundred fewer. The marriage would create a stable of artists reading like a Who's Who in the music business. BMG brings the likes of Annie Lennox, R Kelly and Barry White to the party. EMI boasts the Beatles, Radiohead and Robbie Williams. EMI is the world's largest music publisher. BMG is the number one distributor of singles in the US. The statistics go on and on.

But, because of this potential embarrassment of riches, some fear EMI's chances of getting hitched at the second attempt are remote. Just as euro officials poured cold water on the Warner deal, so they will reject the £10bn merger with BMG, runs the argument. This would be a major setback for EMI, despite its recent protestations that it would be perfectly happy going it alone.

'It makes sense for EMI. It can't go anywhere else but a merger. The industry's very cyclical and it's difficult for quoted companies to constantly meet shareholders' expectations. Look at what happened with Virgin. It was a publicly quoted company and then Richard Branson took it private, saying that music and the stock market don't mix,' said Steve Redmond, publisher of Music Week, the UK trade bible.

The deal might represent the Great Leap Forward long awaited by EMI's shareholders, but at first glance it seems they are going to be disappointed again. Three months after talks between the two companies started questions are being asked about why it is taking so long for both sides to agree a deal that will placate objectors in the Commission.

Insiders, however, say it is still early days. Warner Music and EMI had been talking for nearly four months before news of their romance leaked. The courtship lasted nine months longer. However, Bertelsmann chief executive Rolf Schmidt-Holtz has said he believes a deal can be reached by the end of this month.

The negotiations will be protracted. Only the naive believe the eurocrats will allow the two firms to merge with no strings attached, given the red light the Warner deal received. So the task for BMG and EMI is to soothe Commission officials' anti-trust concerns by suggesting a divestment programme to stimulate competition without ruining the logic behind the merger. Much will hinge on what the two firms can do to alleviate concerns in Germany, a market dominated by BMG.

There has been talk of EMI selling off the high-profile Virgin label. But a total sell-off seems unthinkable. 'It's hard to see how something so integral to EMI could be easily dispensed with,' one industry source said.

Instead, partial divestments on a country-by-country basis look likely. 'They could get their market levels down below key thresholds. They'll be able to identify parts of their catalogues and individual labels which they can divest,' said David Stockley, chief executive officer of DX3, the online music distribution company, and former president of EMI International sector.

It is suggested that one of the few remaining major independent labels will snap up any disposals, turning itself into a global player. But only one independent company has the financial firepower to pull off such acquisitions - Zomba, the privately owned label based in New York. It has grown fat building a stable of teenage stars, notably Britney Spears, The Backstreet Boys and N-Sync.

Whatever the eventual plan, the chances are the Bertelsmann board won't suffer the seismic shock inflicted on Warner's executives when their merger with EMI crashed. 'They were completely taken aback by the EC's reaction. They didn't have the contacts,' Redmond said. Bertelsmann is understood to have held informal talks with officials to gauge opinion, although sources stress the discussions are at a very early stage.

Those familiar with the way the Commission thinks believe EMI may yet get its groove back. 'There's a chance the Commission might consider a different view from the one it took with the Warner deal the second time around. For a company to be rejected twice could seem harsh and the Commission might now be more enthusiastic,' one Commission source said.

Politics, too, could play a part, Redmond said. 'This time around it's about two European companies rather than an American company taking over a European one.'

Much hinges on the issue of 'collective dominance' - whereby several large firms are seen to be dominating a market. It is a new theory in competition circles and, apparently, one not uniformly accepted in Brussels. 'I don't think the Commission wants to be seen as being dogmatic about collective dominance. It doesn't want people to think that if it spikes one deal it will spike them all,' the Commission source said.

If the deal goes ahead music purists will raise concerns about the industry being increasingly the domain of big business. But Redmond is sanguine about the future. 'It will be quite healthy for the music industry. There will be lots of redundancies and talented executives will set up their own labels. It will lead to a blossoming of the independent sector.' An optimistic argument, but one that not even Bertelsmann would have the audacity to raise with the Commission.

As Bridget might have said 'Blurry hell. Why life so difficult?' But then again, she and her true love were united in the end.

fields.headline: Wap phones: now they can't give 'em away
fields.standfirst:
More net news
Wap explained
fields.trailText: Will 'wap' become a verb, like 'zap'? Will the comic-strips of the future contain scenes in which combatants do battle accompanied by words like POW! WHAM!! and WAP!!!? This last is evoked when one character fells another with a tightly rolled business plan, signifying that the victim has been 'wapped', meaning taken for a ride, sold a pup or otherwise duped.
fields.body:
Will 'wap' become a verb, like 'zap'? Will the comic-strips of the future contain scenes in which combatants do battle accompanied by words like POW! WHAM!! and WAP!!!? This last is evoked when one character fells another with a tightly rolled business plan, signifying that the victim has been 'wapped', meaning taken for a ride, sold a pup or otherwise duped.

I ask because a reality distortion field seems to surround Wireless Application Protocol. Wap phones are the ones equipped with slightly enlarged screens which can display anorexic web pages accessed over the GSM networks. For a period last year Wap was hyped as the Next Big Thing. It was the technology that would finally bring the internet to the masses, and black ink to the bottom lines of e-commerce companies.

It would spawn innumerable new services, enabling consumers to spend all their waking hours purchasing stuff online. And what would make it a killer (so the enthusiasts raved) was the way it combined the commercial potential of the web with the micro-billing capability of the phone companies, so that the old dream of getting rich by selling a joke a day for one cent a pop could become a reality.

What a difference a year makes. When the Nokia 9110 phone was first launched - the one with the dinky roller that moved the cursor up and down - you couldn't get one for love nor money. It was the ultimate small object of yuppie desire. Now the networks are handing out Wap phones in return for network subscriptions. So are building societies and online banks.

It's beginning to look as though the only way to persuade people to try Wap is to give the things away. An air of cynical dissatisfaction now envelopes the technology. Once again, irrational exuberance has given way to unreasoning despair. Wap is seen as yet another example of the internet not living up to its promises.

All hooey, of course. Wap phones are not really internet devices at all - merely handsets which can display limited graphics and access specially designed gateway servers via a GSM phone call. In technical terms, Wap has more in common with the circuit-switched technology of 'ye olde fixed-line phone system' than with packet-switched systems like the net or the forthcoming third-generation (3G) mobile networks. So the supposed failure of Wap is not a test of anything to do with the net, and may not even tell us much about the prospects for 3G technology.

Wap's reputation has been undermined by the appalling design of many Wap sites. Jakob Nielsen, an expert on interface design, recently published the results of a survey he'd done of British consumers' reactions to Wap. Seventy per cent of his sample decided not to continue using Wap because 'its services are poorly designed, have insufficient task analysis, and abuse existing non-mobile design guidelines'.

These strictures provoked predictable outrage from the industry. The Wap Forum pointed out that Nielsen's study was based on a sample of just 20 Wap users, that there are 500,000 BT Cellnet subscribers who use Wap and even added in the millions of Japanese users who subscribe to iMode services, which was a bit naughty since iMode technology is different from GSM-based WAP. Then BT weighed in, claiming that traffic on its Wap service rose by 513 per cent in the quarter to the end of December. 'We knew Wap would be popular,' said a BT spokesman, 'but it has outstripped our expectations.'

So is Wap as we know it a turkey or not? The truth is that nobody knows - yet. And by the time we find out, it will have been overtaken by 3G, and the irrational exuberance now building around that. Nothing changes: stay tuned.


John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Swap the label - and lose the plot

fields.headline: Swap the label - and lose the plot
fields.standfirst: Global-minded firms are changing their names in droves. It can be a big mistake, writes  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: Global-minded firms are changing their names in droves. It can be a big mistake, writes Heather Connon
fields.body:
'You should not do a rebrand just to get your share price up,' says Tom Blackett, deputy chairman of Interbrand.

It would indeed be hard for anyone to make a financial case for adopting a snazzy new name. British Steel has hardly set the world singing since it became Corus; and Bright Station is even duller than it was as Dialog or, before that, Maid. Uniq may be shorter than Unigate but its performance since the name change has not exactly been snappy.

Indeed, of the two dozen or so recent name changes, The Observer could think of only three - Zeneca, Centrica and Spirent - that could be described as financial successes.

Of course, the marketing men have a rational explanation: the rebranding was not done properly. 'The problem is you need a clear idea of what you want to be,' said John Williamson, a partner at Wolff Olins, creator of Orange and Go, then British Airways budget airline.

If you do not you will probably end up with a Greco-Roman name (think Invensys, Corus, Elementis - or any of the new names dreamt up over the past decade) that does not mean anything. And, Williamson warns: 'If you have a meaningless name, people will think your business is meaningless.'

Small wonder, then, that the Post Office was trying so hard to convince us that Consignia, the new name it unveiled last week, is not just another bastardisation of a perfectly good Latin word. 'Our new name and identity is a daily reminder of what is at the heart of our organisation. At its most basic level, it describes the full scope of what we can do, in a way that "The Post Office" cannot,' trumpets the press release.

'The root of our new name is what makes our organisation special. To consign means "to entrust to the care of", which is exactly what every customer does when they post a letter, organise a delivery or visit a Post Office branch.'

The Post Office wants a new name to help it go out and conquer the world. While we Brits readily believe that our Royal Mail is the only Post Office, foreigners who have their own variations - Deutsche Post, the US Post Office and so on - may find it harder to swallow. When the Post Office converts to a plc in April, this will add impetus to its international ambitions, making a change of moniker essential.

This also makes the Post Office the latest in a long line of British institutions to play down their roots. British Telecom, British Petroleum, British Airways, and British Gas have all undergone successive revamps aimed at persuading us they are really global companies - and have met with varied success. BA is removing the notorious multicultural tail fins with which it attempted to shrug off its British roots; BP may think it stands for Beyond Petroleum, but the world still thinks it is simply a rather British oil company.

The secret for would-be international industrialists is to look ahead. If BP had started with a name like Shell - what has that got to do with oil, globalisation or even industry? - it would not have this problem now. And Williamson pays tribute to Shell and supermarket group Tesco, as companies that have managed to subtly adapt their image over the years.

But what about a company whose name has become discredited, or is irrevocably associated with a business that no longer sums up the group? Many of the companies that have recently changed their names fall into that category. Some - Harrisons & Crosfield, BTR, Berisford - were conglomerates so anxious to prove they had changed their spots that they changed their names, to Elementis, Invensys and Enodis, respectively. And everyone thought Bowater just made paper packaging, so Rexam was born. Hambro Countrywide made too much of its chain of estate agents, but the company preferred to emphasise the insurance aspect, which is now promi nent in Countrywide Assurance. The water companies tried to pretend they were dynamic service businesses, and came up with silly names such as Kelda and Hyder to show their transformation. Outside the City, Windscale tried to leave behind its accident-prone past by changing its name to Sellafield.

Alas, such cosmetic changes fool no one. Unless there has been some dramatic change in the business itself, the old habits are likely to outlive the new name. Those companies whose change of name has not been accompanied by a change of fortune bear out Williamson's comments about the importance of knowing what your business is for, where it is going and how it is going to get there.

Other name changes follow corporate action such as a mergers or demerger: the new name is intended to show it is a new business. Andersen Consulting has become Accenture following its break-up with the accountancy firm, which kept the name.

The success of these changes is intimately related to the success of the action itself. Zeneca was called ICI Pharmaceuticals until it was demerged from the chemicals group. The shares have never looked back. Interbrand's Blackett, who advised ICI on the rebranding, says that escaping from the low-margin, cost-conscious culture of ICI was energising for the drug company, bringing out its culture of innovation. But how much of that was due to the demerger and how much to the change of name that accompanied the split?

Elsewhere, Diageo has improved following a lack lustre performance immediately after the merger of Guinness and Grand Metropolitan that created it. But Corus has been dogged by the same old problems as when it was boring old British Steel.

So when should a company think about renaming itself, and what will make it a success? Blackett believes firms should consider it if, for some reason, their customers have become out of touch with the services its provides - say they do not know you have a website or are not buying your new products. Williamson says it is a good idea for companies that are if you are losing in their market: 'Marks & Spencer should think about it. It is losing in its market. It has tried to change but I can't see the difference. Its adverts say jeans that fit and sexy underwear. What does that mean?'

But if the performance of companies that have rebranded is anything to go by, M&S chairman Luc Vandevelde should avoid the brand consultants at all costs.

webTitle: Hard lessons for the high street after the hangover

fields.headline: Hard lessons for the high street after the hangover
fields.trailText: Despite all the gloom and doom, it seems that Christmas did happen pretty much as usual this year. The trading statements being issued by retailers shows the usual mixture of good and bad, disappointments and unexpectedly good sales. But underlining them all is one hard fact of life on British high streets: making money from shoppers is becoming harder.
fields.body:
Despite all the gloom and doom, it seems that Christmas did happen pretty much as usual this year. The trading statements being issued by retailers shows the usual mixture of good and bad, disappointments and unexpectedly good sales. But underlining them all is one hard fact of life on British high streets: making money from shoppers is becoming harder.

Look around your high street and the reason will be obvious: there are far too many places to spend your money. The failure of British retailers to make a go of business anywhere else in the world caused a greater space race than anything the Americans and the Russians ever engaged in. The only ones who are guaranteed to make money are those with a truly novel offering and lots of room for expansion. But - as Matalan's precipitate fall from grace on disappointing sales figures shows - even that cannot last forever.

Elsewhere, it is all a matter of the hard grind of paring back costs, having sharper elbows than the competition, giving the customers what they want - and making sure the City does not expect too much. Thus Next's 6 per cent increase in sales, excluding the impact of new openings, would thrill the likes of M&S or Arcadia but it failed to meet Next's high standards.

Likewise, the 5 per cent decline in home shopping sales at Great Universal Stores' home shopping business was exactly in line with its past performance. The City, however, had hoped for better - and was concerned that its Experian information services business in the US was not recovering more rapidly. This destroyed the recent recovery in its share price.

Selfridges managed to win accolades despite using the railways as an excuse for a slightly disappointing 1 per cent increase in like-for-like sales at its flagship London store. What got the City excited was the performance in Manchester, where sales rose 22 per cent over Christmas. If it can achieve such success, what potential there is for expansion around the rest of the country.

But the biggest fall from grace came from Matalan, whose spectacularly successful value retailing formula has made it the stock market darling. Most other retailers would die for the 13.4 per cent rise in sales, excluding new openings, in the last 19 weeks. But that marked a sharp slowdown from the 22.1 per cent growth enjoyed last year - and a rating of 50 times this year's expected earnings makes no allowance for disappointments like that.

Matalan remains the only real growth stock in British retailing. Despite its rapid expansion, it still has only a tiny 2.2 per cent of fashion retailing and it still has an aggressive opening programme. But the collapse in its shares - down 34 per cent on the day - does show that buying fashionable shares is far riskier than buying fashionable clothes. And once these stars come down to earth, it can be hard to get them rising again.

Dixons can testify to that. Its shares have spent much of the last 18 months alternately soaring or sinking depending on the City's view of its holding in internet service provider Freeserve. Last month's sale of its stake to Wannadoo, the French equivalent - due to be completed next month - meant that it could once again focus on the trading revealed in the interim statement last week. It was not as bad as many had feared. Like-for-like sales rose by 4 per cent, although that was fuelled by Dixons, PC World and the international business. Currys continued to struggle, reporting a 2 per cent drop in sales. The group says refurbishments, adverts that hammer home the price message and greater promotions have got it back on track and like-for-like sales did grow over Christmas.

There was also good news on margins. Dixons had warned that its gross margin - the difference between what it pays for a PC and what it charges us - would shrink, so the 1.3 per cent drop on last year was no surprise. It had also promised that cost-cutting - including things like managing its supply chain, reducing the number of faulty machines in the stores - would be enough to keep operating margins, ie what is left after paying staff and store costs, level. It lived up to that promise.

The challenge now is to keep that momentum. Finance director Ian Livingston points out that Dixons has lived with falling prices for its entire 40-year history. That is not necessarily bad - falling prices mean that we are more likely to upgrade to the latest model of digital camera or wap phone. But it also means that management must be constantly on its toes, something that Dixons seems to achieve.

So too does Next. Of course, the fact that more stock had to go into the January sale is disappointing but at least Next manages to hold off on its sales until after Christmas. It is also able to contain them to a few hectic days - stores were opening, to queues, as early as 6am on 27 December - before getting its spring ranges on to the shelves. Next estimates the cost will be no more than £4 million, low enough to mean the shares remain a core holding.

Two interesting statements have yet to appear. First up will be Boots, due on Tuesday. It has already warned that sales in its chemist chain will be hit by the decision to withdraw from 'leisure' ranges, such as gifts, which are strong at Christmas. Analysts are forecasting a drop of anything from 1 to 2.5 per cent in sales. Anything at the lower end of that forecast would be seen as good news.

The statement we are all waiting for - from Marks & Spencer - is unlikely to appear until 23 January, although there have been so many rumours about trading that M&S would be forgiven for wanting to get the news out earlier.

Certainly, reports of its Christmas trading have been awful and the stores do seem to contain a lot of unattractive stock. Most worrying, however, is that no matter how awful the rumours about M&S's trading, the reality always seems to turn out even worse.

fields.headline: Welcome aboard, 007
fields.standfirst: Building luxury boats is one industry where the UK rules the waves.  Faisal Islam  on the marina's Martini set
fields.trailText: Building luxury boats is one industry where the UK rules the waves. Faisal Islam on the marina's Martini set
fields.body:
Forget Silicon Valley. There is one sector of British industry that boasts hi-tech clusters, garage start-ups, and energetic entrepreneurs with healthy tans. Its products feature in the opening scenes of James Bond films, and with 95 per cent of production exported, it may just represent the model for Britain's manufacturing industry of the future.

In the production of luxury powerboats, the UK is a world-beater. The London International Boat Show, which finishes today, offered a peek at giant displays of motorboats produced by the likes of Sunseeker, Princess, Sealine and Fairline. Of course, only a fraction of the estimated 170,000 visitors to the Earls Court show will ever have a chance to purchase the sleek fibreglass cruisers that go by names such as Predator, Phantom and Targa.

Though all the big four companies claim that 'anyone can buy a boat', the image of their customers as playboys, dotcom millionaires, and shady businessmen from Essex is difficult to escape. Immediately in front of Sunseeker's astonishing spaceship-like stand, featuring £13 million worth of floating gin palaces, there's a 'champagne piazza' where you may discuss the design of your boat's custom-built interior. Images, Sunseeker's 'essential guide to the ultimate in lifestyle', carries features on Porsche cars, Bovet watches, Purdey guns, and how caviar should not be eaten with a metal spoon unless it is made of gold. This is no mass-market industry.

But the immense success of the big four is down to far more than luxury branding and clever marketing. 'The British marine industry is one of the few remaining UK industries which can claim to lead the world,' says Howard Pridding of the British Marine Industries Federation, the builders' trade body.

'Despite difficult trading conditions in Europe, 2000 was a successful year, particularly for the larger boatbuilders, many of which have generated record sales.'

Derek Carter is managing director of Fairline, a powerboat builder based for 30 years in the Peterborough area, employing 920 people and with a turnover of £80m.

'The big four powerboaters, through a significant commitment to R&D, have continued to compete against each other, driving on the development of a quality product,' he says.

'Manufacturers concentrate on the boats' sea-keeping abilities and external flair, coupled with luxurious interiors - this sets British powerboaters apart from the competition.'

The industry has four centres: the South Coast, particularly around Poole, the South-west, the Norfolk Broads and the Midlands.

The BMIF, which also organises the Boat Show, issued the first-ever set of industry statistics last week. Its turnover totalled just under £1.5 billion last year, an 11 per cent jump on 1999. More than 8,000 people are directly employed in boatbuilding, with a further 16,000 in related industries.

Marine industries have enjoyed sustained growth for five years, except for a slight slowdown in 1998 when its exports were hit by the strength of the pound against European currencies. That phenomenon has not disap peared, but the industry has managed the situation.

'Because of the exchange rate, the whole industry has turned to the USA,' says Frank Fish, managing director of Sealine, whose T47 was motorboat of the year in the show's British Nautical Awards.

Their efforts paid off, and the US now accounts for a third of sales for the British boatbuilding industry.

Sealine was founded by Fish in a garage next to a house in the non-seafaring town of Kidderminister, in the Midlands. Around 350 boats are now built each year, but, says Fish, the sales total is not a strong indicator of performance. The powerboat makers have climbed the value chain, selling higher- margin luxury goods to a niche market. The emphasis is on engine performance and exterior styling, but interior design is vital as a symbol of luxury.

'When we first started a 25-footer was a big boat, and the toilet was a bucket and chuck-it,' says Fish.

No longer. Demand for larger boats is driven by an ever stronger desire for such luxuries as en-suite bathrooms and more bedrooms. Inside, the interiors are lined with the type of leather used in Aston Martin cars, and equipped with the latest DVD surround-sound technology.

Personalisation of the interior is the apotheosis of this pursuit of maritime motorboat luxury. One customer wanted an office built in his Sunseeker boat, another a recording studio.

A Sunseeker was featured speeding away from MI6's London HQ on the Thames in the spectacular opening scenes to The World is Not Enough, the latest Bond film.

Robert Braithwaite founded the Poole-based company in 1968, selling handbuilt 17-foot yachts. A year later his brother, John, joined as chief designer, and by 1971 turnover was £100,000 and the company employed 10 people. By July last year turnover was £104m, there were 1,050 employees. Their biggest boat is a 105ft super yacht, too big to display at the London show. Anyone dropping by the Boat Show hoping to pick up a Sunseeker is likely to be disappointed. Order books are full for the next two years.

'We've driven the market, creating a vision and a dream, and wealth has grown too,' says Braithwaite, now chairman and managing director of Sunseeker.

It has recently bought two new shipyards, and is investing £25m over the next two years in research and development.

'Being a private company we do what we do because we love it. We have grown by putting back into the company what we earn. We can sometimes take commercial risks that public companies cannot.'

Flotation, it seems, is not an option. 'It's never occurred to us to take it public,' says Derek Carter, of Fairline. 'This is the way almost all the companies have evolved - the founding entrepreneurs are still in place.'

But the ever-stronger demands for such luxury are foundering in the face of technical skills shortages.

'Marine business is a people business. We're very heavily reliant on specific people skills - people who can plane a bit of wood, upholster, or wire a boat up with the right electronics,' says Fish. 'We're having to invest heavily in training people, but I'm a great believer in business contributing as well as government. Both need to come to the party to create jobs.'

In many ways, boatbuilding should be a manufacturing industry of choice for the Government. It has successfully dealt with the strong pound through diversification and has climbed the value chain. The industry also knows the value of marketing.

When the Boat Show first moved to the bigger Earls Court 2 venue, Sunseeker stunned rival exhibitors and spectators with an expensive display that has become standard for the big firms.

Shows are a vital marketplace for the products. This makes the three-week-long logistical nightmare and the odd toppled telegraph pole from transporting 800 boats to congested west London worthwhile. But demand for space has rocketed, the BMIF already has 60 companies on a waiting list to exhibit smaller boats, and wishes to expand its coverage of canal narrowboats. The big four builders cannot display the pride of their respective fleets in such a confined space.

So the London Boat Show is to move to eXcel, an exhibition centre by the Thames in Docklands for the January 2004 show, when those bigger yachts will be on display. And if you can save £10,000 a week between now and then, you may be able to buy one.
