webTitle: South Africa fights Aids drug apartheid

fields.headline: South Africa fights Aids drug apartheid
fields.standfirst:
Access to cut-price HIV pills would save millions of lives worldwide. Why do rich pharmaceutical firms refuse them, asks Nick Mathiason

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Access to cut-price HIV pills would save millions of lives worldwide. Why do rich pharmaceutical firms refuse them, asks Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
Zackie Achmat a 38-year-old black South African, is probably the world's most extraordinary drug smuggler.

As far as anyone can tell, he's the only illegal importer of drugs who has ever voluntarily handed himself in, offered a video of himself clearing Customs and given over all receipts of his transactions to the authorities.

Last October, Achmat, who has the Aids-related virus, HIV, flew to Thailand and bought 5,000 pills to treat people dying of Aids. He then flew back to South Africa and handed his drugs over to his country's government.

The drug was Biozole, an anti-fungal treatment whose patent is owned by pharmaceuticals giant Pfizer.

To buy a Pfizer pill over the counter in South Africa would cost about £9. In Thailand, Achmat scored the same generic drug for 15p.

In trade-law-speak, Achmat's 'parallel importation' of Biozole is a vivid symbol of a growing healthcare scandal of epic proportions. Aids is sweeping through Africa much like the Black Death plague that wiped out so much of medieval Europe. Eminent African doctors are now saying that HIV will do more harm to Africans than slavery did.

Of the world's 34 million people infected with HIV, 25 million live in sub-Saharan Africa. Yet only 25,000 Africans (0.001 per cent of those infected) receive the drugs known as anti-retrovirals which prolong the lives of people with HIV and are freely available in the developed world.

Last week, Achmat was badly ill. Speaking in a whisper from his home, he said: 'Hundreds of people are dying every day in our country because they can't get access to the right drugs. The only thing that is stopping them is the price. I think it's immoral that people are dying just because they're poor.'

Controlling the distribution of HIV drugs are some of the world's most powerful pharmaceuticals companies which, combined, make profits running into tens of billions of pounds.

But in a move that will make Achmat's 'crime' seem utterly insignificant, the might of the world's drug industry, including the UK's GlaxoSmithKline, will, on 5 March, take the South African Government to court over alleged violation of intellectual property rights - essentially, the same principle that got Achmat into trouble.

The constitutional case, which has been rumbling since 1997, will be heard at the Pretoria High Court and could, if appeals are exercised, run for years. Whoever eventually loses will not face damages, but costs running into tens of millions of pounds.

At the heart of the case is a law passed by former President Nelson Mandela giving his country the right to buy huge amounts of generic drugs and sell them cheaply in South Africa. In addition, South Africa could compulsorily license HIV drugs and manufacture them within its borders, undercutting the multinational pharmaceuticals companies. The threat of legal action has so far prevented South Africa acting on this right.

Pharmaceuticals companies believe these measures represent a threat to their balance sheets although, at present, just 1 per cent of drug revenues come from the entire African continent.

But money lost through cheap generic could, drug firms say, be ploughed into more research and development which may ultimately lead to a cure for HIV.

Sanctioning cheap HIV drugs may also irritate hard- pressed health authorities in the western world, which spend up to 10 times more on their anti-retrovirals, and also alert the public as to the true - low - cost of medical drugs.

Furthermore, argue the drugs firms, it is no good farming out cheap pills to countries that don't have robust health infrastructures. Drugs have to be monitored with scans and therapies. If that can't be done, drugs are useless.

But African HIV campaigners argue that drug companies are putting their profits before the health of a whole region.

For the South African government, eager to play a leading role in the global economy, court action is the last thing it wants. South Africa is a fully paid up member of the World Trade Organisation and signed the Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (Trips) agreement, which forces national governments to respect the rights of patent holders. Within the South African government there are major tensions between the health and trade ministries.

'This country has no intention of perpetrating a wholesale violation of intellectual property rights,' said Mark Heywood, head of the Aids Law Project at the University of Witwatersrand. 'It doesn't want to be seen as the Mugabe of the South. But the South African government has a duty to provide care for its citizens, and this is why they passed this law.'

Even a leading pharmaceuticals analyst in the City last week said leading drug firms could afford to sanction cheap drugs tomorrow without it impacting on their balance sheets.

Preferring to remain anonymous, he said: 'It does depend on the amount of usages and the amount given away. These programmes would be phased so that it didn't hit them that hard.'

This court case, which has paralysed HIV healthcare in South Africa, highlights the problems of the entire continent. Many African countries rely on the generosity of overseas governments and pharmaceuticals companies to subsidise HIV drug prices. So far, that aid has been sparing.

Throughout the Nineties, a series of high-level meetings with executives of leading pharmaceuticals companies and Western governments discussed dropping the prices of drugs. But the cost was deemed too high

High-profile offers of cheap Aids treatment from Clinton's administration came with strings.

A £700m offer of cheap drugs from the United States last year turned out to be export-import loans, at commercial interest rates, to buy American drugs at market prices. This offer, not surprisingly, was turned down.

But progress is now discernible. Last May, five of the biggest drug companies agreed to begin talks with African nations to reduce the price of their drugs if countries agreed to health action plans drawn up by a leading business consultancy, McKinsey.

So far agreements have been reached with Uganda and Senegal. Others are set to follow. But rumours suggest that drug companies have sanctioned an increase in drug production to save thousands, rather than millions, of lives.

The British Government has done little to lobby for cheap drugs. Last November, Trade Minister Richard Caborn refused to sanction African nations circumventing Trips by citing 'national emergency' - which they are within their rights to do.

'I don't believe that this or related measures such as parallel importing are the answer here,' Caborn wrote to Ben Jackson, director of London-based Action for Southern Africa (Actsa), last November.

Clare Short, the Minister for International Development, has no substantial initiatives planned in this area.

'Imagine witnessing devastating plague and sitting on a cure for fear of incurring shareholder revolt,' said Ben Jackson of Actsa. 'That essentially is the position of drug companies. Sure healthcare infrastructures have to be in place but it is not an either-or argument. These things can be done simultaneously.'

Within a decade the number of people infected with HIV could reach more than 50 million, the equivalent of the population of France or the UK.

With the South African court case scheduled to begin in less than two months, the calls for pharmaceutical companies to move faster on dropping the prices of HIV drugs to developing countries are sure to get louder.

How Brazil took on the drugs giants - and is winning

In the early Nineties, Brazil faced a serious Aids crisis. The South American country had the fourth-largest number of reported cases of the disease in the world, with about 2.5 per cent of Brazilians infected - in other words more than 3 million people.

But their chances of surviving were increased by a government which undertook 'daring policies' that went against the orthodoxies of international trade.

After years of military dictatorship and escalating foreign debt, the newly elected Brazilian democratic Government defined healthcare as a social right in 1988.

Three years later, Brazilian ministers decided to circumvent international trade agreements. They bought and distributed huge amounts of anti-retroviral drugs.

The desperate measure, which angered pharmaceuticals companies, paid off. Under pressure, the World Bank in 1994 sanctioned a £115 million loan to help pay for Brazil's medical drug bill. This was topped up in 1999 by a similar amount, making Brazil the second largest recipient of overseas HIV-focused loans after India.

Brazil's government used the loan to guarantee free HIV drugs to all who needed them, to train health professionals, to manufacture drugs and to develop infrastructure for free distribution and monitoring.

World Bank loans and Brazil's government policies have contributed to a 38 per cent drop in the number of Aids-related deaths there since 1994. Throughout Brazil, there has been a reduction in hospital admissions, lengths of stay and the incidence of opportunistic infections.

These benefits come at a price. In 1999, government expenditure on access to treatment was £245m.

But overall Brazil has actually saved £291m in three years through fewer/shorter hospital stays, welfare payments and the continued economic activity of those with HIV.

webTitle: Save the people - or you'll kill the country

fields.headline: Save the people - or you'll kill the country
fields.trailText: The big drug companies are big on giving. The arts and sports worlds are grateful recipients of the pharmaceutical giants' largesse. And the big drug companies' websites are peppered with big examples of how they've sponsored a big new project in the Third World or helped out a health organisation here or a worthy pressure group there - big time.
fields.body:
The big drug companies are big on giving. The arts and sports worlds are grateful recipients of the pharmaceutical giants' largesse. And the big drug companies' websites are peppered with big examples of how they've sponsored a big new project in the Third World or helped out a health organisation here or a worthy pressure group there - big time.

But the heavy-handed action that GlaxoSmithKline will take later this year in a South African court shows that such generosity has strictly defined limits.

It has been a long road to the trial and few in the West will have followed it, but the outcome is seen as crucial by those working to combat the spread of Aids and HIV in South Africa and its neighbouring states.

It boils down to the fact that the firm does not want the South African government to sanction the production of cheap drugs, a move initiated under the Mandela presidency in the face of a national emergency.

The big drugs firms are scared that if they turn a blind eye to the wholesale production of cheap, generic drugs in South Africa it will set a dangerous precedent, which will be difficult to prevent spreading.

It is easy to be emotive about Aids. Haunting pictures are all-too-graphic testimony to the way Aids contaminates everything it touches.

But the heartbreaking story of Nkosi Johnson, the 11-year-old Aids victim who captured the world's attention last week, tells only part of the story.

It is banal but vital to understand that not only does Aids kill people; it also cripples their economies. A country's ability to afford expensive western drugs or, more importantly, the health and education systems crucial to combat the spread of the disease, is impaired.

How significant an economic impact could the virus have? Economists estimate that South African gross domestic product will decline by nearly 20 per cent by 2010 because of Aids. In certain parts of the economy, especially those dependent on highly mobile workforces - some of the most at-risk groups - the impact will be even more profound.

And the obvious fact is that the poorer a nation becomes, the fewer resources it has to counter disease. It is a bitter but unsurprising fact to learn that although sub-Saharan Africa has two-thirds of the world's HIV infections and more than 80 per cent of Aids deaths, it accounts for a mere 3 per cent of global spending on Aids.

Amidst all of this it is impossible, naïve even, to ignore the fact that the big drug companies have fiduciary responsibilities. They are answerable to shareholders and their job is to make profits. Without the emphasis on profit, the system breaks down and the incentive to invest in the research and development of new drugs disappears.

But this argument only holds so much water. Drug companies are not averse to trimming their profit margins dramatically in developing countries.

GlaxoSmithKline says it would supply HIV treatments at 80 per cent discounts to prices in the West if, and it is a big 'if', developing countries were to have the correct health infrastructure in place.

But it is difficult to establish adequate screening or fully equipped hospitals when a country's economy is collapsing as the virus spreads. And, of course, as it spreads it creates an ever more vicious circle as more people become infected and a greater strain is placed on limited resources.

The UK Government is reluctant to get involved and Clare Short, the minister for International Development, has been largely silent on the matter.

There will be more haunting photos of Nkosi and others in the coming months and years. But action to save Africa from dereliction is - tragically - unlikely.

And the big drug companies' websites are peppered with big examples of how they've sponsored a big new project in the Third World or helped out a health organisation here or a worthy pressure group there - big time. But the heavy-handed action that GlaxoSmithKline will take later this year in a South African court shows that such generosity has strictly defined limits. It has been a long road to the trial and few in the West will have followed it, but the outcome is seen as crucial by those working to combat the spread of Aids and HIV in South Africa and its neighbouring states. It boils down to the fact that the firm does not want the South African government to sanction the production of cheap drugs, a move initiated under the Mandela presidency in the face of a national emergency. The big drugs firms are scared that if they turn a blind eye to the wholesale production of cheap, generic drugs in South Africa it will set a dangerous precedent, which will be difficult to prevent spreading. It is easy to be emotive about Aids. Haunting pictures are all-too-graphic testimony to the way Aids contaminates everything it touches. But the heartbreaking story of Nkosi Johnson, the 11-year-old Aids victim who captured the world's attention last week, tells only part of the story. It is banal but vital to understand that not only does Aids kill people; it also cripples their economies. A country's ability to afford expensive western drugs or, more importantly, the health and education systems crucial to combat the spread of the disease, is impaired. How significant an economic impact could the virus have? Economists estimate that South African gross domestic product will decline by nearly 20 per cent by 2010 because of Aids. In certain parts of the economy, especially those dependent on highly mobile workforces - some of the most at-risk groups - the impact will be even more profound. And the obvious fact is that the poorer a nation becomes, the fewer resources it has to counter disease. It is a bitter but unsurprising fact to learn that although sub-Saharan Africa has two-thirds of the world's HIV infections and more than 80 per cent of Aids deaths, it accounts for a mere 3 per cent of global spending on Aids. Amidst all of this it is impossible, naïve even, to ignore the fact that the big drug companies have fiduciary responsibilities. They are answerable to shareholders and their job is to make profits. Without the emphasis on profit, the system breaks down and the incentive to invest in the research and development of new drugs disappears. But this argument only holds so much water. Drug companies are not averse to trimming their profit margins dramatically in developing countries. GlaxoSmithKline says it would supply HIV treatments at 80 per cent discounts to prices in the West if, and it is a big 'if', developing countries were to have the correct health infrastructure in place. But it is difficult to establish adequate screening or fully equipped hospitals when a country's economy is collapsing as the virus spreads. And, of course, as it spreads it creates an ever more vicious circle as more people become infected and a greater strain is placed on limited resources. The UK Government is reluctant to get involved and Clare Short, the minister for International Development, has been largely silent on the matter. There will be more haunting photos of Nkosi and others in the coming months and years. But action to save Africa from dereliction is - tragically - unlikely.

fields.headline: Prima Donna kebab'd
fields.standfirst: Melinda Wittstock on why DKI shareholders are up in arms and, below, how Karan lost the cutting edge
fields.trailText: Melinda Wittstock on why DKI shareholders are up in arms and, below, how Karan lost the cutting edge
fields.body:
Donna Karan says she was following her heart, not her head, when she agreed last month to sell out to Bernard Arnault's flamboyantly acquisitive Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy luxury goods empire for a cool $450 million personal profit. Who would have thought the famous American fashion designer had such a head for business?

The deal sent pulses racing on Wall Street. But disappointed investors in her publicly traded company, Donna Karan International Inc, will have to split what they say is a measly $195m between them - if this second part of the LVMH takeover gets the green light from her board.

Karan and her husband Stephan Weiss have already sold Arnault the most valuable part of their fashion empire: the privately held Gabrielle Studio, which owns and licenses all the Donna Karan trademarks, from the upscale Donna Karan New York to the more mid-market DKNY labels. This personal royalty arrangement, while proof of the fashion designer's shrewd business acumen, has long caused disquiet on Wall Street, sucking most of the profit out of the public company while paying Karan and Weiss some $80m from 1996 to 1999.

So it's not too much of a surprise that some shareholders are getting litigious.

In a Delaware court, DKI shareholder Janet Allred has accused both Karan and Weiss of 'preferring their own interest to realise the maximum value on the sale of the trademarks', alleging that their private deal with LVMH had 'effectively thwarted' the company from being shopped around to other buyers to 'maximise shareholder value'. The plaintiff contends the $195m offer for the Wall Street quoted company, at $8.50 a share, is 'unfair' and 'inadequate', adding that some analysts and portfolio managers believe the company is worth between $14 and $15 a share.

Karan went public at $24 in 1996, and the stock had fallen as low as $4 before she and Arnault announced the deal on 18 December. The price tag for LVMH is also less than a third of the company's annual revenue of $662m, and a significantly smaller multiple than European luxury fashion houses such as Fendi were getting last year. Despite the 74 per cent premium to the company's 15 December closing price, most shareholders will lose out.

But since Karan and her Ducati motorcycle-riding husband own 22 per cent of the public company, they stand to pocket another $50m, bringing their total personal windfall to $500m.

'It's the best of all possible worlds for Donna Karan: she gets all that cash, and gets to continue what she does best - designing clothes,' says Harvey Robinson, an apparel analyst with Chapman Company, a Baltimore-based investment bank.

Karan would remain chief designer of a combined Gabrielle and DKI under the LVMH roof, and probably continue to profit as an investor - particularly as LVMH would be able to extract more value from the franchise by ending her controversial royalty arrangement. Karan is the only designer of a publicly traded design firm to retain ownership of her name and receive royalties based on net sales - DKI Inc pays Gabrielle 1.75 per cent of the first $250m, rising to 3.5 per cent of net sales over $1.5 billion. In 1999, DKI paid Karan $25m in a year it made just $10m in profit.

'Donna Karan will no longer be able to skim from the top,' says veteran Wall Street apparel analyst Walter Loeb, 'and that's good news for LVMH, but it comes a little late for DKI investors.'

Marc Ravitz, vice-president of Grace & White, which in September owned 109,700 DKI shares, agrees. 'The value of the Donna Karan enterprise is far greater than what LVMH is paying,' he told the Wall Street Journal, adding that the LVMH cash bid at $8.50 represents 25 per cent of the Donna Karan total revenue.

Richard Barone, chief executive of Maxus Investment Group, said there was 'more money offered on the Gabrielle Studios side and there should have been more on the public company side', adding that he would have been happy with $11 or $12. 'The public company is not worth anything without the other side; the real value is the two together, and Donna Karan holds all the cards.'

So it was amid this investor grumbling - and the possibility of the Allred case expanding to a class action lawsuit - that the DKI Inc board, which last month hired investment banker Merrill Lynch, announced on Monday that it would entertain offers from rival bidders or the possibility of remaining independent.

Some immediately speculated the move would spark a bidding war, bringing in LVMH's bitter business rivals, the Italian fashion house Gucci or the French retail giant Pinault-Printemps-Redoute (PPR). Gucci and LVMH are still locked in legal combat over LVMH's failed bid in 1999. Most market watchers now believe it unlikely that the public company will attract any higher offers, with its most valuable assets already in the hands of LVMH.

Other analysts cited concerns that the Donna Karan brand, more fashion than luxury oriented, could be hurt by the economic slowdown in the US.

LVMH, which owns Dior, Givenchy, Christian Lacroix, Moët & Chandon, Krug, Veuve Cliquot, Fendi, Pucci, Louis Vuitton, Kenzo, Guerlain, Marc Jacobs, Celine, Thomas Pink, Chaumet and other luxury brands, does not believe its latest deal will be derailed.

'The DK International statement is not a surprise and there's nothing in it that precludes us moving forward with the deal. It's a standard, run-of-the-mill statement consistent with the board's fiduciary duties to protect shareholder interests,' an LVMH spokesman said, adding that the litigation is 'without merit'.

Karan is staying silent. But on the day of the deal, she said it was 'the right thing at the right time... I don't do deals with my head only. I did this deal with my heart.'

She added: 'As the world's leading luxury group, LVMH has the expertise, resources, global scale and vision to help me realise the full potential of Donna Karan and DKNY as worldwide luxury lifestyle brands. I have always admired Bernard Arnault and the environment he has created for designers in supporting their creativity, emphasising their individuality, respecting their brands and providing the resources to develop global luxury businesses.'

Perhaps she hasn't spoken lately to Alexander McQueen. LVMH's Arnault apparently drove the controversial McQueen to creative distraction - and into the arms of Gucci, which will now hold the controlling interest in a separate McQueen label.

But Donna Karan is no McQueen. Karan is no doubt more to the elegantly commercial tastes of the French luxury impresario, but then again, some analysts wonder whether she still has the sort of exclusive cachet LVMH normally seeks - her wide array of lines and products are too readily available in mid-price department stores.

webTitle: Council houses: Can't pay? Then you can be rescued

fields.headline: Can't pay? Then you can be rescued
fields.standfirst: Some councils will buy back former council homes
fields.trailText: Some councils will buy back former council homes.
fields.body:
Most people have heard of the 'right-to- buy' scheme, where council tenants buy their houses from their local authority. But few know that some councils will buy your former council house back from you if you are having problems keeping up with mortgage repayments.

The 'mortgage rescue' scheme was devised in the early 1990s when repossessions were at their height.

The little-used scheme means that people get to stay in the house they know and love while councils escape the burden of having to rehouse them. The local authority buys either part or all of the house and the tenant pays rent to them, especially when the house can't be sold on the open market.

But relatively few people have taken advantage of the scheme - 2,000 at the last count, even though repossessions stand at 30,000 a year.

It seems the major stumbling block to the success of the scheme is the fact that people do not want to become tenants after having been owner-occupiers.

Professor Steve Wilcox, who specialises in housing and finance policy at the University of York, says it was usurped by housing associations offering flexible ownership schemes. Flexible ownership schemes are the part-buy-part-rent arrangements oper ated by housing associations. They have proved more popular because the level of ownership can be negotiated up and down.

However, for someone who faces losing their home and being chased by the lender to make good any losses, it is worth considering mortgage rescue. Buy-back schemes tend to operate in areas where there is low demand for housing, but the London Borough of Camden also runs one. You can find out if there is one in your area by ringing the housing department of your local council.

webTitle: Boots in gloom while Safeway rides high

fields.headline: Boots in gloom while Safeway rides high
fields.trailText: Boots will this week disappoint the City as another crop of British retailers announce their Christmas trading figures. Safeway, however, will confirm that its recovery still has momentum
fields.body:
Boots will this week disappoint the City as another crop of British retailers announce their Christmas trading figures. Safeway, however, will confirm that its recovery still has momentum

Boots has already warned that its Christmas sales will be hit by its decision to stop selling compact discs, videos and tableware, which are particularly popular at Christmas. That will mean that - excluding the impact of store openings - sales will be down by as much as 2.5 per cent.

Boots will argue that profits will not be hit to the same extent because the discontinued lines had low margins and the space previously devoted to them is now being used for more profitable health and beauty products.

Credit Suisse First Boston estimates that the withdrawal of these leisure lines will have cut Boots' sales by 4 per cent, but thinks improvement in other areas will see the total down by 2.5 per cent. Boots will disclose profit figures for the period with full-year results at the end of May.

Safeway is expected to show sales up by between 4 and 5 per cent, putting it behind Wm Morrison - which announced 5.5 per cent growth last week - but ahead of Sainsbury, which increased sales by only 0.7 per cent in the three months to December. Tesco, also reporting quarterly sales on Tuesday, is believed to have had a good Christmas.

Analysts had been expecting Safeway's sales growth to slow as it reached the anniversary of its Best Deals Ever campaign, leafleting shoppers with a weekly list of special offers. But so far, sales are still growing strongly.

Other retailers issuing trading statements this week include Kingfisher, where analysts expect sales growth to have slowed still further from previous quarters, and Arcadia - owner of chains Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins - which is expected to show some recovery. Last week, Matalan and GUS disappointed the City while Dixons and Selfridges produced better than expected results.

This week's announcements will leave only Marks & Spencer among major retailers to report Christmas figures. It is rumoured to have had a poor season although it is is also likely to claim that margins are improving.

webTitle: How the DK image just wore too thin

fields.headline: How the DK image just wore too thin
fields.trailText: Donna Karan built her empire on womanly hips - not on what was hip.
fields.body:
Donna Karan built her empire on womanly hips - not on what was hip.

And these days, what's hip is Prada, Gucci, Chloe and Versace - not Donna Karan or DKNY. When did you last see a pop star, movie star, supermodel or any other 'boy with breasts' wearing the label that first made its name and found fame on the New York catwalks as the preferred choice of the Eighties high-powered female executive?

Sure, there was Barbra Streisand, a blushing bride in a Karan wedding dress back in July 1998 when she married James Brolin. And Demi Moore in a Karan advertising campaign back when the actress known for her provocatively pregnant Vanity Fair cover was still married to Bruce Willis. But apart from the creator of the hip TV show Sex and the City, Candace Bushnell, swathed in a garnet red leather and cashmere Karan number for the launch of her new book Four Blondes at Karan's flagship Madison Avenue store in September, it's hard to recall any other zeitgeist star wearing Donna lately.

But not even the most fickle of fashionistas can deny Karan's designing talent, the quality of her work or her creative vision. Her collections still win praise among fashion editors, but also a few well-placed barbs for the woman who launched her empire in 1984 with an easy to wear, stylish and tailored glamour perfect for the businesswoman of the time.

Writing about the current fashion obsession with the early Eighties at New York's Spring 2001 collections, New York Times fashion maven Ginia Bellafante had this to say about Karan: 'In the actual early Eighties, Ms Karan was making bodysuits and other utilitarian garments for working women.

'Her collection shown on Friday [22 September] afternoon showcased a line that was loose and asymmetrical and apparently meant for the woman who said goodbye to the 70-hour work-week at Morgan Stanley, opting for a line requiring chiffon or droopy sleeves... hemlines seemed to fall in layers of poufy triangles. There were a number of beautiful pieces, a striped organza trenchcoat with matching skirt, for example, but for the most part Ms Karan's collection concentrated too heavily on clothes for after dark.'

The subtext is that Karan has been straying too far from her once mighty message - no longer concentrating on clothes that look good on women with mortal size 12 hips - and falling too closely into line with her hipper European rivals.

A year ago, the verdict was even worse: Bellafante said the designer had 'Prada and Gucci on her mind' - apparently too much so for those who admire originality.

That said, Karan clothes are still selling well among career women, well enough for LVMH to value her trademark name at $450 million. 'It is very flattering that they realise the value of the trademarks,' the 52-year-old designer told the business media on the day of the deal.

But it's clear that Karan thinks the luxury imprimatur and deep-pocketed business acumen of LVMH will get her past the financial travails that have unquestionably torn the fabric of her luxury image. Ever since the disastrous flotation of her design house in 1996, public attention has focused more on corporate triage to stem the flow of red ink than on her designs.

Until John Idol took over from Karan as chief executive in 1997 and began an aggressive strategy of cost-cutting and licensing deals, Karan was being battered by investor complaints over what they alleged was excessive spending and now legendary disorganisation. Among other things, Karan had spent prodigiously on foreign travel and expensive fabric.

And as expenses ballooned, sales deflated. But although Idol is credited with turning her company's fortunes around, investors still shunned DKI Inc because of her unique royalty arrangement with her privately held Gabrielle Studio, which many continued to see as an albatross around the public company's neck.

Karan, as well known for her penchant for horoscopes, yoga and 'healing crystals' as she is for her own womanly hips and financial woes, will now be wealthier than most of her rivals - and she can set her head and heart on designing must-wear clothes.

webTitle: Hard man who seeks to bang Corus into shape

fields.headline: Hard man who seeks to bang Corus into shape
fields.standfirst: 'I don't make steel, I make money.'  Profile of  Sir  Brian Moffat by Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: 'I don't make steel, I make money.' Profile of Sir Brian Moffat by Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
A man who heads the world's fifth largest steel producer is expected to have some steel in his backbone. But Sir Brian Moffat, chairman and acting chief executive of Anglo Dutch giant Corus, takes the hard-man reputation further than most. The quiet ascent of the Scottish accountant up the ranks of what was, until recently, British Steel, owes much to his uncompromising use of the industrial guillotine through three decades of turbulence.

He himself once said: 'I don't smile much' - and those who know him describe him as 'cold', 'ruthless' and 'distant'. But compared with some previous heads of British Steel, such as Margaret Thatcher's favourite strike buster Ian MacGregor, he holds the respect of workers and union leaders alike.

They may not like what he does - his best-known aphorism, if it can be called that, is 'I am interested in making money, not steel' - but at least they know what to expect.

Lord Brookman, former general secretary of the ISTC union (formerly the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation), says: 'I have always respected him, although I would not say I have had regular meals with him. He's a shy man, and a hard man. He always found it difficult to look at me straight in the eye.'

Recently Moffat, who retired as chief executive in 1999 but remained as chairman, has been a reluctant executioner, spilling the blood of his joint successors.

He had to sack his own protégé, John Bryant, a veteran of 30 years in steel, along with Fokko Van Duyne, who had shared the role since the 1999 merger of British Steel with the Dutch company Hoogovens.

Moffat made this a public display, saying: 'The board felt it was necessary to make more rapid progress and more decision-making.' In other words, as the Financial Times put it, he, like shareholders, could no longer accept 'pussyfooting' at the top of a company that had seen its shares drop 60 per cent in a year.

The City had hoped the June 1999 merger would equip Corus to fight against the problems of sterling's exchange rate and low global steel prices, and allow rationalisation of plants to save costs. Unions were afraid of UK workers losing out to Dutch ones.

The irony is that the merger talks began on 7 January 1999, the day after Moffat's sixtieth birthday, when he stepped down. Two years later he had to return to finish the job.

For the 33,000 workers at Corus plants in the UK, even the pussyfooting was painful. Bryant and Van Duyne had introduced 4,500 job cuts, and more were expected.

Moffat believed this was not enough, and made it clear that a further swathe of cuts - up to 5,000 - along with the closure of one or more plants could be expected. He is currently deciding where his axe will fall.

This will be familiar territory. Moffat came to prominence in British Steel at the beginning of the 1980s, when he restructured the Port Talbot strip-steel works in the wake of a bitter three-month ISTC strike.

Under Moffat, employment at Port Talbot dropped from 13,500 to 4,700. The pattern was repeated across British Steel. An organisation that in 1980 employed 142,000 workers had 52,000 by 1988, the year it was privatised.

Lord Brookman, who was a union official in South Wales in 1980, recalls: 'It was a very difficult situation in 1980. There had just been a strike, and effectively Moffat was negotiating with a powerful union over what would be more than 50 per cent job losses at the plant. What he did at Port Talbot was followed across the company.'

Moffat's reputation was forged against the backdrop of Thatcherism. His enjoyment of fishing, shooting and farming - he has a small holding in Monmouthshire - attest to Conservative instincts.

His ability to force through so radical a programme was probably a result of British Steel's performance in the decade after he joined in 1968 from accountant Peat Marwick Mitchell. British Steel had been formed with the nationalisation of the 14 biggest UK steel producers the previous year. The Wilson government chose nationalisation instead of the painful restructuring proposed in the 1966 Benson report, which recommended focusing the disparate UK industry on five plants - Llanwern and Port Talbot in Wales, Scunthorpe, Lackenby and Ravenscraig in Scotland - along with reducing output by 9 million tons.

Over the next decade the opposite strategy was pursued. First, British Steel heads Lord Melchett and Monty Finniston proposed production increases and modernisation through new plants. This was watered down by the Heath government, which still agreed to production increases taking output up to 38 million tons, while demanding wholesale or partial closure of some plants, including Corby, Shotton and Ebbw Vale. This was halted in 1974, when Wilson returned, but the oil crisis and world recession hammered the UK's expanding industry, and production targets were halved. By the mid 1970s the UK had the least productive steel industry in Europe. It was ripe for Thatcher, and for Moffat.

Despite his hard-man image, Moffat keeps a low profile. He attracted a little City attention in 1993 when he added chairman to his title of chief executive after the retirement of his brasher predecessor, Sir Robert Scholey.

He won City respect, first through his role in the British Steel privatisation, and then through raising productivity. Now South Wales works produce 6 million tons of steel with 6,300 workers while the Ijmuiden plant in Holland does the same with 8,000. The problem is that Dutch costs are still lower, and Ijmuiden has a wider range of products - a reflection on past investment decisions.

According to Corus, the big problem for the UK plants is that demand from British manufacturers is falling, forcing them to export more, and exposing Corus to exchange-rate volatility. A further irony is that as Moffat plans his cull, the exchange rate is moving back in the UK's favour.

Moffat's preference for a discreet public face has not prevented him from confrontation with unions and with government. In addition, he has launched blistering attacks on government measures such as the climate change levy, and criticised the Government's attitude to manufacturing industry.

Moffat attempted to break down barriers between skilled craft workers and other production workers under the 'Teamwork' initiative in the 1990s. This continued the stream of redundancies but, Brookman remembers, Moffat was against making any compulsory.

But while he has won guarded respect from unions and colleagues, there are those who feel he has done too little to ease the pain of the merger for UK workers while those in Holland have been relatively unscathed - a total of 680 are currently slated to lose their jobs.

As one observer said: 'It looks rather like a takeover of British Steel by Hoogovens. If his forthcoming restructuring annihilates the UK, it will be selling the industry out.'

Moffat has avoided that charge, even from his former adversaries. Until now.

webTitle: Money writes: I wrote to complain - and heard nothing

fields.headline: I wrote to complain - and heard nothing
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I set up a distribution-type Isa with CGU and expected to receive the first monthly income payment on 5 June. At the end of June, I noticed no payment had come through and that the money was reinvested rather than paid out.

CGU agreed to put this right and said payments would start in September. I asked why I received no payment for August and, when CGU failed to explain, lodged a formal complaint.

That was in October and I have heard nothing since.
PB, Nottingham

Financial institutions must complete complaints investigations within two months or tell you why not. CGU, now Norwich Union, says it did write within two months, and responded to your chasing, and cannot understand why neither letter arrived.

Apparently you could not have received an August payment because, when the mistake was uncovered, you chose to keep the additional units that had already been added to the accumulation plan rather than take cash.

You became eligible for payments from the distribution plans from the qualifying date, the twenty-eighth of the month. Income is paid a month later or, when in an Isa, on the fifth working day of the following month. The problem was sorted out in July, so the first payment came on 5 September.

The additional units you kept were worth £44.91 but, had you opted for cash, would have received £48.59. Norwich Union is sending you a £50 cheque, by recorded delivery, to cover the £3.68 shortfall and compensate for inconvenience.

Playing FTSE: How low did it go?

In November 1999, I invested £10,000 in a 12-month eurobond from Eurolife Assurance, yielding 9 per cent interest. The £10,000 was guaranteed not to fall unless the FTSE-100 index fell by more than 10 per cent 'at any time' and was lower at the end of the year than the start.

I did not think it had dropped by that much but Eurolife says it did, at 8.33 am on 17 April, so my investment is worth only £9,747. It is difficult to find a public source detailing the actual lowest figure reached at any time.
BW, Winchester

Early on the morning of Monday 17 April, traders defensively marked prices down, expecting a bloodbath as Wall Street had fallen sharply the previous Friday.

The crash never happened but, for about half an hour, the index showed prices 10.34 per cent down, so the clause kicked in. Eurolife says it was unfortunate that the index dipped so briefly and so narrowly, but the product has no flexibility.

The FTSE 100 is recalculated every minute of the trading day and Eurolife's 'at any time' means at any moment of the day, not, as you might reasonably expect, the day's closing figure.

Eurolife has introduced a new bond paying 11 per cent interest for investors, like you, who lost capital but this type of investment, especially over only one year, is always a gamble.

The Financial Times , on the back page of its Companies and Markets section, publishes the hourly movements of the main indices, with the high and low points for the day, whenever they happened.

Premium on the best maths

My brother owns 4,000 Premium Bonds and I own 500. Many years ago we agreed to split our winnings. He says because he owns eight times as many as I do I am entitled to only one-eighth of any win he has. But, and here is the problem, he says if I win I should give him half. We can't seem to get our heads round this maths poser.
SW, Newcastle

Finding a formula is harder than you think, so I asked Peter Tompkins of the Institute of Actuaries for a definitive reply.

He points out that you own 4,500 bonds between you, your brother holds eight-ninths of the total and you have one-ninth. If you are aiming for an equal share of the prizes, your brother should receive eight ninths of your winnings and you should get one ninth of his.

This is not such bad news for you because, by the law of averages, your brother should win eight times as often as you do.

In a queue for Pru's review

In August 1998, Prudential's pensions review unit said I might be eligible for a review of how my personal pension was sold.

Last September, Prudential sent me a form to sign giving it permission to investigate. I had been under the impression that Pru had been doing that for two years. I am now told that the review will not be complete until 2002. Is this a reasonable period of time for this review to take?
NE, Horsham

Insurance companies are taking years to sort out the pension mis-selling scandal. Urgent cases, including people near retirement, already retired or the beneficiaries of those who have died, should have been completed by December 1998 but 2 per cent have still not had their cases settled.

You are not treated as urgent because of your young age, so come in the second stage of the review. Some non-urgent cases have been completed but insurers can take until June 2002 to work through their lists. The Pru apologises for mistakenly asking you for repeated information and has pushed your name higher up the queue.

Anyone can telephone an insurance company or adviser who is carrying out a pensions review and ask what is going on.

Making whole life mean life

My sister paid premiums into a whole-life policy with the Pioneer Life Assurance Company for her son from 1943. Regrettably he passed away with leukaemia in November.

She is in a quandary about how to proceed because she has been unable to trace the insurance company or its agents.
MT, Bridgend

Pioneer is now part of Swiss Life, which says the policy lapsed in 1979 but there is a tiny amount, under £10, due to your sister. She should send the policy to Swiss Life in Liverpool. Anyone who has lost contact with an insurance company can phone the Association of British Insurers on 020 7600 3333.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1M 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Credit: A welcoming home for those others turn away

fields.headline: A welcoming home for those others turn away
fields.standfirst: Even with a bad debt record you may still borrow, says  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: Even with a bad debt record you may still borrow, says Tracey Boles.
fields.body:
More than 8 million people - one in four of the adult population - have had difficulty obtaining credit from high street banks and other lenders, according to market analyst Datamonitor.

They may have had past debt problems or have county court judgments registered against them. Others are turned away after living overseas and not building up a credit history in the UK. Or it may simply be a case of changing addresses too often or applying for credit a lot. But just because one high street bank or building society rejects you does not mean they all will. If you have two CCJs (they stay on the credit record for six years) registered against you but neither is big and both have been settled, you may be able to get a mortgage from a mainstream lender such as Abbey National, Halifax, HSBC, Nationwide, Woolwich or Yorkshire.

Failing that you could go to one specialising in 'non-status' lending. Non-status lenders have had a bad press in the past for high interest rates and harsh redemption penalties but the sector appears to have undergone an image change of late. Market leader Kensington Mortgage Company says most of its customers are now in the ABC1 category and most sub-prime lenders are members of the Council of Mortgage lenders.

Non-status lender First National Mortgage Company, an Abbey National subsidiary, takes all comers. It says it rewards good payments by dropping interest rates by 0.5 per cent per year. Rates start off at 1.25 per cent above the SVR (standard variable rate) of 7.74 per cent for a loan that is 60 per cent of the value of the property.

Chelsea Building Society's Prospect mortgage is for those who have experienced some kind of financial diffi culty. The mortgage has four 'tiers' geared towards different levels of indebtedness. The product has the advantage of reverting to the SVR provided you keep up with payments for two years. Another advantage is that should you want to switch mortgages in the future it is easier to do so with a household name such as Chelsea behind you.

Bank of Scotland subsidiary the Mortgage Business charges interest of just 1 per cent above its SVR of 8.65 per cent on its mortgage for the credit-impaired. After a year the Credit Solutions mortgage reverts to the SVR provided the customer maintains a perfect payment record. To find out more ring 0845 300 1604.

fields.headline: Wave goodbye, say hello.
fields.standfirst: French buy British port
fields.trailText: The French are taking over one of Britain's historic ports, writes Peter Avis. Normandy local authorities, backed by the European Union, are completing negotiations to buy Newhaven harbour from Sea Containers to revive the all-year ferry service to Dieppe.
fields.body:
The French are taking over one of Britain's historic ports, writes Peter Avis. Normandy local authorities, backed by the European Union, are completing negotiations to buy Newhaven harbour from Sea Containers to revive the all-year ferry service to Dieppe.

Charles Revet, president of the conseil général (county council) of the Seine Maritime department, announced in Rouen last week that a 12,000-tonne Corsica Ferries vessel had been chartered to operate from the end of February. It can carry up to 700 passengers and 50 lorries.

Sea Containers spokesman Steve Lawrence would only say: 'Negotiations for the sale are continuing and will probably be concluded in two or three months.' Revet, of the right-wing Démocratie Libérale party, needs to move fast because he faces a tough local election in March.

The Newhaven and Dieppe economies have suffered severely since P&O Stena closed down its Newhaven operation two years ago - its last ferry service to Dieppe is pictured above.

The French expect to pay £15 million and to spend another £6m on repairs. The EU is due to give £5m. The route once carried up to 1.2 million people a year.

webTitle: Equitable could offer £1.5bn to cap black hole

fields.headline: Equitable could offer £1.5bn to cap black hole
fields.trailText: Equitable Life guaranteed annuity policyholders could soon be in line for a handout totalling £1.5 billion, according to the Equitable Life Action group. But to receive it they must agree to plans to cap the life office's huge guaranteed annuity rate (GAR) liability at its current level and stop it spinning out of control.
fields.body:
Equitable Life guaranteed annuity policyholders could soon be in line for a handout totalling £1.5 billion, according to the Equitable Life Action group. But to receive it they must agree to plans to cap the life office's huge guaranteed annuity rate (GAR) liability at its current level and stop it spinning out of control.

This should stabilise Equitable's financial position and make it more attractive to potential buyers scared off in the past by the size of the GAR liability.

The UK's oldest mutual found it had a £1.5bn 'black hole' on its hands when the House of Lords ruled that it had been unlawful not to honour guarantees set down in its annuity contacts.

About 60,000 GAR policyholders will be offered a one-off payment into their policy now in return for agreeing to a lower annuity rate and relinquishing what could be higher rates when they actually retire, according to Stuart Bayliss, leader of the Action Group.

Any payments would be funded by monies amassed last year when Equitable suspended members' bonuses, says Bayliss. No decision has been reached on how the money will be divided up.

Bayliss hopes to get members' approval for the cap as soon as possible at an 'early AGM' - originally pencilled in for April.

Also under discussion are the percentage of 'yes' votes required to implement the proposals, and the extent of the reduction in the annuity rates. Equitable says it is listening with interest to Bayliss's ideas.

The emergence of a liability-capping plan has revived hopes that Equitable will find a buyer. Interested parties are said to include pan-European consortium Eureko, and Dutch insurer Aegon.

The Prudential is also thought to have re-emerged as a possible suitor, although it insists it is still not interested.

webTitle: Mortgages: Borrowers beware, even if rates do fall

fields.headline: Borrowers beware, even if rates do fall
fields.standfirst: Tracey Boles on the pros and cons of fixed-rate versus discount
fields.trailText: Tracey Boles on the pros and cons of fixed-rate versus discount.
fields.body:
Although the base interest rate was not reduced last week, economists expect a cut soon. So which mortgage should you apply for - a fixed or discounted rate?

A discount mortgage, that tracks the Bank of England's base rate at a level below the lender's standard variable rate, seems tempting if interest rates fall.

But borrowers should think about what they want before choosing a large discount over a fixed-rate product. One disadvantage of discounted loans is that their interest rate can go up as well as down.

Phillip Cartwright, of Bath independent mortgage broker London & Country, advises you to consider the worst: 'Look at how your repayments would be affected if rates went up by one per cent. Could you still afford to keep up with repayments ?'

Another disadvantage of discounted mortgages, according to Cartwright, is that lenders do not always pass on reductions in full when there is a base rate cut. This is why London & Country is recommending tracker mortgages which feel the benefit from any drop in interest rates straight away. The broker favours Halifax's tracker which is set at 0.45 per cent below the base rate until the end of 2002 giving an initial rate of 5.55 per cent for up to 75 per cent of the value of the house. It is penalty-free. For larger loans, Principality and Scarborough both offer trackers.

London broker Charcol recommends Birmingham Midshires 2.5 per cent discount over two years which takes the lender's standard variable rate down to 5.24 per cent, but you will be stung with a penalty of 3 per cent if you want to remortgage in this period.

If you are borrowing the maximum and need to know exactly how much you will be paying, you may be better off with a fixed rate.

Should rates drop during the fixed period, you have the option of switching to a mortgage with a lower rate, although it's important to choose a loan without a redemption penalty if you are really to benefit. Siobhan Hotten, of Charcol, recommends Yorkshire Building Society's two-year fixed-rate mortgage at 4.99 per cent which has redemption penalties during the fixed period.Borrowers can take out loans worth up to 75 per cent of their property's value. Hotten says: 'The base rate would have to go below 3 per cent to make it poor value.'

Another fixed-rate mortgage Charcol favours is from GMAC (a subsidiary of General Motors) which charges 5.49 per cent until March 2003; it has no redemption penalties at any time. At this rate, borrowers can take up to 75 per cent of their property's value - the rate rises to 5.69 per cent if they borrow 95 per cent.

Capped-rate mortgages are often touted as offering the best of both worlds: security and the potential to pass on a drop in rates. There is no limit to how much the rate can fall but there is a 'cap' on rate rises. But Hotten says it is a good idea to compare any capped-rate mortgage to fixed-rate products, as you may be paying for something that never comes into effect.

fields.headline: So Greenspan is mortal
fields.trailText: Do you remember where you were when you heard the news of the Federal Reserve's panic cut in interest rates on 3 January? I heard the news during a brief break in Cyprus from John Bierman, the former BBC correspondent.
fields.body:
Do you remember where you were when you heard the news of the Federal Reserve's panic cut in interest rates on 3 January? I heard the news during a brief break in Cyprus from John Bierman, the former BBC correspondent.

Bierman is co-author with former Observer correspondent Colin Smith of a book (Fire in the Night) on the British Second World War general Orde Wingate. It is a study in leadership and, for some reason, my thoughts wandered to that other well-known study in leadership, the Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan.

Since the Fed is the leading economic policy institution in the world, the fact that it cut interest rates sooner and by more than generally expected immediately gave rise to the question: what does Greenspan know that everybody else doesn't?

But the really interesting question is: did the almost deified Greenspan blunder by not reducing rates earlier? To put it another way: was not the 4 January decision a tacit admission of error, rather than some brilliant stroke that elevates Greenspan even higher on the staircase of the gods of Mammon.

This is certainly the view of veteran Fed-watcher David Jones, of Aubrey G. Lanston. 'Greenspan missed the boat,' he says. 'He misread how fast the economy was slowing in the final months of 2000, when consumers were hit by the double whammy of the negative wealth effect and higher energy prices.'

The wealth effect was the extra spur to US consumer spending that came from the earlier rise in the stock market and property prices. The 'negative' wealth effect was the reverse of this process. Greenspan himself had referred in his New York speech of 5 December to the wealth effect 'being significantly attenuated'.

That was the speech from which one sentence was plucked and whisked around the world's financial community: 'In an economy that already has lost some momentum one must remain alert to the possibility that greater caution and weakening asset values in financial markets could signal or precipitate an excessive softening in household business spending.'

But this was Greenspan covering himself. The context of this remark was one in which he emphasised 'consumer confidence, or sentiment, appears to be holding up reasonably well to date, though there have been some mixed signals of late'. The minutes of the Fed Open Market Committee meeting on 15 November cover all the possible ground, but basically choose to ignore the deflationary risk, which is clear from the discussion, with all 10 voting members concluding 'the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future'.

Well, the world now knows that the foreseeable future lasted about seven weeks until 3 January. A slowdown that had been engineered by the Fed (via earlier rises in interest rates) was compounded by a rise in energy prices equivalent to a tax of 1 per cent of GDP; and, once confidence begins eroding, it can erode faster than policymakers intend.

There are all sorts of conspiracy theories about whether Greenspan was trying to get in first and wreck the incoming Bush administration's tax plans. But it is more likely the Fed was simply doing what it thought was the right macro-economic thing at the time.

This does not mean it does not have views on the tax plans. The Fed chairman is believed to have been angered by suggestions from the Bush economist Larry Lindsay that Alan Greenspan approved the tax plans, whereas what he was really saying was he preferred to reduce the deficit, but as a second best he preferred tax cuts to spending increases.

Greenspan is not a 'supply-sider' and believes in demand management. He has a long and good relationship with vice-president elect Dick Cheney, and would probably approve of a small package of tax cuts compatible with, and not in conflict with, monetary policy.

But Greenspan has proved to be mortal. Even he can misread the data. In the opinion of Jones 'he reached the pinnacle of his success in June 2000 when he began his fourth term'.

Perhaps the great man was also tempting providence if, as insiders believe, he agreed to co-operate with Watergate author Bob Woodward on a biography modestly entitled Maestro .

Or perhaps not. One of the disadvantages of the much trumpeted phenomenon of 'globalisation' is that the inevitable slowdown (and possible recession) in the US economy is already having ramifications, as US corporations cut back on production and orders from their plants around the world.

It is extremely bad news for Japan, whose tenuous recovery in 2000 was export-led, and whose last hope - given domestic stagnation - is the devaluation of the yen now taking place. But traditionally, when the yen becomes more competitive, trade tensions follow.

Latest figures also show the recovery during 2000 in Germany - still Europe's economic powerhouse - was export-led, and that domestic demand in Germany is far from robust.

This means the European Central Bank faces a big test now in ensuring that the Euroland economy keeps going, and makes up domestically for the slowdown in the US and world trade generally. And there is the problem that the euro's recovery may be good for morale, but less good for the competitiveness of exports.

Which leads to an intriguing point about Greenspan's difficulties. In the past, when confidence has swung against the US economy, the Fed has occasionally had to raise interest rates to prevent a necessary fall in the dollar from getting out of hand. The way the financial markets work, the rebound in the euro is almost certain to be overdone. Perhaps the Fed was lowering interest rates while it could.

Perhaps, also, there is scope in 2001 for a series of cuts in European interest rates to boost domestic demand in Europe while helping the US to avoid interest rate increases (aimed at limiting the slide in the dollar). Such a combination would be highly desirable both for the US and the rest of the world.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Airmiles on the cards | Bonuses slashed | House calls
fields.body:
Airmiles on the cards
Frequent flyers with British Airways can clock up airmiles every time they make a purchase with three new credit cards from British Airways and American Express. You have to be a BA executive club member to qualify for the cards, which match every £1 spent with at least one airmile. The cards vary in their annual fees and APRs. For example, the standard card has no annual fee and an APR of 19.9 per cent, while the premium plus card has an annual fee of £120 and an APR of 17.9 per cent.

Bonuses slashed
Falling bonuses on life and pensions policies are expected industrywide following announcements by Friends Provident and Scottish Provident that they are cutting many bonus payouts for 2000. Scottish Provident's annual bonus rates for with-profits life assurance policies are down 0.5 per cent to 2 per cent. Terminal bonuses, payable when policies mature, have also been slashed. Analysts say the cuts were necessary after a year of poor returns on the stock market. Insurance analyst Ned Cazalet, of Cazalet Financial Consulting, says they herald a tough year ahead and further demutualisations.

House calls I
Nearly half of new homeowners face unforeseen problems, according to research by HSBC and the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. About 11 per cent undertake major repair work. ' Choosing your home', a free guide, is available from HSBC or on 0870 494999.

House calls II
Advice on buying, maintaining, improving and selling property is available on www.freeserve.com/ property, a joint initiative between Freeserve and the bank Bradford & Bingley.

Home guard
Mortgage payment protection insurance plans are failing to save some homeowners from legal action or repossession, according to Mortgage Finance Gazette. In a survey of lenders, Cardiff solicitor John Collins found that '47 per cent of lenders would still continue with a repossession action' if a homeowner had MPPI. Borrowers could lack sufficient insurance, or may not be using the insurance to meet their mortgage payments.

Tops for Tessas
Bristol & West has delivered the best-paying Tessa (tax-exempt special saving account) with its stock market-linked product, according to adviser Chase de Vere. It paid out £15,942, while the average variable-rate Tessa paid £12,456 and the average fixed-rate Tessa paid £12,810. The Chase de Vere Guide to Maturing Tessas is free on 0845 609 2005 or from www.chasedevere.co.uk. Alliance & Leicester has also produced a free Tessa factsheet, available in branches. Tessa savers whose plans end this year need to transfer the capital to a Tessa-only Isa if they want to continue earning tax-free returns.

Young guns
More than 15 venture capital trusts are expected to launch in the next few weeks, doubling the investment capacity available to £500 million. Individuals prepared to invest in young, unlisted companies can put up to £100,000 in a trust, getting an income tax rebate of 20 per cent, deferring capital gains on a previous investment and enjoying tax-free capital growth and income. A free guide is available from Hargreaves Lansdown on 0800 138 0456.

fields.headline: Is this sacrifice Equitable?
fields.standfirst: Policyholders at the heart of the firm's crisis are being asked to surrender part of their guarantee in order to give everyone a chance of better payouts.  Tracey Boles and  Neasa MacErlean report on what the latest plans might mean for you
fields.trailText: Policyholders at the heart of the firm's crisis are being asked to surrender part of their guarantee in order to give everyone a chance of better payouts. Tracey Boles and Neasa MacErlean report on what the latest plans might mean for you.
fields.body:
Equitable Life met last week with regulators and policyholders' representatives to see if it can cap the £1.5 billion guaranteed annuity rate liabilities which have scared off a succession of buyers.

It looks as though all policyholders could benefit from this plan, although it may seem to those holding guaranteed annuity policies that they will lose out.

By proposing a cap, the policyholders' representatives and regulators are asking people who have bought a guaranteed annuity rate (GAR) as part of their policy to accept less than they are entitled to, says insurance analyst Ned Cazalet.

One proposal being considered is to reduce the value of the GAR, typically 8 to 10 per cent, by one-fifth in a trade off for future certainty and a lump sum.

Given this information GAR policyholders may be tempted to move their money. However, Nick Bamford of Cranleigh independent financial advisers, Informed Choice, recommends waiting to see what level the cap is set at, then seeking independent financial advice. He points out that payouts from GAR policies are not only affected by the GAR rate, but also by the strength of the with-profits fund's performance.

Unfortunately the outlook is not good for the Equitable fund because its management has already switched the emphasis of the closed fund's portfolio from high performing equities to fixed-interest securities. This means the fund is likely to produce a steadier return, but reduces its potential for growth.

But if the liabilities are capped, it may still be possible for Equitable to find a buyer willing to open the fund to new business. This would enable it to increase its holdings in equities again and thereby increase the potential for bigger payouts. So GAR holders are being asked to sacrifice part of their guaranteed annuity rate to give all policyholders the chance of better potential payouts.

A cap would make the position of with-profits policyholders without a GAR 'more certain', according to Robert Hall of actuaries Watson Wyatt. Their future hinges purely on the performance of Equitable's with-profits fund so they would benefit from the fund being sold and reopened. A cap would also limit the money taken out of the fund to pay GAR policyholders, thereby improving prospects for non-GAR policyholders.

Another set of policyholders who haven't known whether they are coming or going in recent weeks are those with income drawdown policies. The life office originally said it would resist any attempts by some members to switch providers as allowed under new income drawdown rules which come in this spring. But Equitable has since relented and now says it will not stand in the way of any transfers.

So what should you do?

Unit linked policies are invested separately to the with-profits policies and are therefore unaffected by the current crisis according to union GMB, which has many members with Equitable pension schemes.

Surprising as it may sound, the options for with-profits pensions and AVC investors in Equitable Life seem to be fairly clear-cut. Advisers seem to be agreed that most people should find another home for their money for future contributions, but that they should not yet move the Equitable funds they have already built up.

For people who are making monthly contributions into company pension and Additional Voluntary Contribution schemes , there is little point in continuing to pay in money into Equitable Life's with-profits fund. This is because the funds are subject to a 10 per cent penalty for people who moved their funds out before they retire. The penalty could even be raised to as much as 25 per cent - so there is little point in taking this risk unless, according to Raj Mody of actuary Bacon & Woodrow, 'you are close to retirement or have a guaranteed annuity'.

'Trustees are all actively looking at the options,' says Peter Thompson, of actuary William Mercer. Many actuaries are holding their members' AVCs and pension contributions in deposit accounts before they choose another insurance company to run the pensions and AVC schemes. Most trustees will hope to have the new arrangement in place by the end of the financial year. If members' funds are put into deposit accounts in the meantime, they will still get the full tax benefits for the current financial year.

Many employees will need to tell trustees explicitly what should happen to their funds, says pensions solicitor Andrew Powell, of Hammond Suddards Edge. 'You should contact the trustees if you want to make a change,' he says to people who are in schemes where they have the choice between investing in Equitable Life and other insurers.

'Don't panic' is the message Peter Thompson wants to get over to people thinking about what to do with the funds they have built up. 'Don't think that you must move your money now.'

Powell advises people to wait before moving out and taking the 10 per cent hit on their fund that any transfers away from the with-profits fund attract. Raj Mody warns people to be sceptical in cases where other insurers and financial advisers say they can make up the 10 per cent penalty in the form of discounts and other incentives: 'They will be recouping it in charges.'

However, if performance goes downhill in the longer term, more and more investors will bale out of the with-profits fund, weakening it still further. With this scenario Bamford says you would be better off taking your money elsewhere despite the 10 per cent exit penalty. Look for a with-profits fund which is 'strong, with a high equity exposure and a good free asset ratio'. Bamford says those of Standard Life, the Prudential, Liverpool Victoria and Norwich Union meet the grade.

The life office originally said it would resist any attempts by some members to switch providers as allowed under new income drawdown rules which come in this spring. But Equitable has since relented and now says it will not stand in the way of any transfers. So what should you do? Unit linked policies are invested separately to the with-profits policies and are therefore unaffected by the current crisis according to union GMB, which has many members with Equitable pension schemes. Surprising as it may sound, the options for with-profits pensions and AVC investors in Equitable Life seem to be fairly clear-cut. Advisers seem to be agreed that most people should find another home for their money for future contributions, but that they should not yet move the Equitable funds they have already built up. For people who are making monthly contributions into company pension and Additional Voluntary Contribution schemes , there is little point in continuing to pay in money into Equitable Life's with-profits fund. This is because the funds are subject to a 10 per cent penalty for people who moved their funds out before they retire. The penalty could even be raised to as much as 25 per cent - so there is little point in taking this risk unless, according to Raj Mody of actuary Bacon & Woodrow, 'you are close to retirement or have a guaranteed annuity'. 'Trustees are all actively looking at the options,' says Peter Thompson, of actuary William Mercer. Many actuaries are holding their members' AVCs and pension contributions in deposit accounts before they choose another insurance company to run the pensions and AVC schemes. Most trustees will hope to have the new arrangement in place by the end of the financial year. If members' funds are put into deposit accounts in the meantime, they will still get the full tax benefits for the current financial year. Many employees will need to tell trustees explicitly what should happen to their funds, says pensions solicitor Andrew Powell, of Hammond Suddards Edge. 'You should contact the trustees if you want to make a change,' he says to people who are in schemes where they have the choice between investing in Equitable Life and other insurers. 'Don't panic' is the message Peter Thompson wants to get over to people thinking about what to do with the funds they have built up. 'Don't think that you must move your money now.' Powell advises people to wait before moving out and taking the 10 per cent hit on their fund that any transfers away from the with-profits fund attract. However, if performance goes downhill in the longer term, more and more investors will bale out of the with-profits fund, weakening it still further. With this scenario Bamford says you would be better off taking your money elsewhere despite the 10 per cent exit penalty. Look for a with-profits fund which is 'strong, with a high equity exposure and a good free asset ratio'. Bamford says those of Standard Life, the Prudential, Liverpool Victoria and Norwich Union meet the grade.
