webTitle: Pensions: Equality comes home to roost for divorcees

fields.headline: Equality comes home to roost for divorcees
fields.standfirst: High-flying females fear they will be on the giving end of settlements under the new pension-sharing rules, reports  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: High-flying females fear they will be on the giving end of settlements under the new pension-sharing rules, reports Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Many women may have whooped for joy on 1 December when the new 'pensions-sharing' rules allowed them to get part of their husband's pension fund on divorce. But the rules apply equally to both sexes - and younger generations of women may find that they are on the giving rather than receiving end of many divorce settlements.

In fact, campaigners and lawyers are clear that the law should treat men and women equally. 'It's going to happen more often in the future that women are losing part of their pension fund,' says Sallie Quin, one of the founders of Fairshares, the group which campaigned for pension-sharing. 'It's perfectly right and fair that this should happen. As more and more women are earning more and choosing a career, the figures are going to even out. I can envisage a day when it's going to be 50/50.'

The Divorce Corporation, a Sheffield-based company that values pension funds for divorce settlements, has seen the proportion of valuations of pension funds built up by women grow from 5 to 10 per cent in the five years since it started this work. 'This reflects the way females have started to get higher-salaried and pensionable jobs,' says spokesman Keith Popplewell. 'That started in earnest about 15 years ago.'

The even higher earnings of the new female dotcom workers and other high-fliers could take another 10 years to filter through. 'A pension needs to have been growing for at least five to seven years before it becomes valuable enough for the divorce courts to take an interest in it.'

But, of course, the hard-luck stories are also starting to come through. Mrs X's husband left her and their two children five years ago to start another relationship. She is now 'terrified to agree to divorce him in case he can get half my pension'. They lived together as a married couple for only six years. She hopes that any claim on her would be kept to this period - rather than the full 25 years in which she has been earning and paying into a pension.

David Davidson, head of family law at solicitor Charles Russell, says it is 'early days yet' to see how judges will interpret the new laws on dividing pensions, but there is precedent for looking only at the period of cohabitation when dividing assets.

Another strong argument for Mrs X seems to be the fact that she worked consistently to build up her pension while her husband was less committed: 'He has been sacked three times now from various jobs - for inefficiency and disciplinary reasons.'

James Copson, family law partner at solicitor Withers, agrees: 'If a husband can be shown to have been feckless during a marriage, his claim ought to be proportionately reduced.'

Mrs X is in the same position as many other mothers contemplating divorce.

She has taken the lead in bringing up the two children, caring for one com pletely and sharing care of the second. Her husband pays maintenance for the first child. Copson says: 'In a divorce settlement, the primary carer piggy-backs on the children and will get more as a result.'

Also in Mrs X's favour is the fact that, on their separation, she sold the marital home 'as I could not keep up the mortgage payments, and gave him half the proceeds'. So she has already been more than willing to make a fair settlement.

No one really knows how the courts will interpret the new pension-sharing rules, nor the 'pensions-earmarking' rules that were introduced in 1996, allowing couples to split the future income from a pension rather than its current underlying assets.

Only 1,000 couples are thought to have used the earmarking rules so far. They are relatively unattractive because the right to get the pension income dies when the original owner of the fund dies.

Also confusing the picture is the White v White divorce settlement case last year. This case overturned tradition and held that settlements for wealthy divorcing couples should aim to distribute assets equally, rather than give the junior partner enough to live on and maintain his or her standard of living. Divorce lawyers and campaigners are wondering how much this ruling will now filter down to couples with fewer assets. 'White v White will have a big impact,' says Quin. 'And if your assets are only £45,000 between the two of you, not £4.5 million as in White v White, it's even more important that you split them 50/50.'

When it comes to splitting pension assets, women should be aware of how pensions are valued. Members of money purchase pensions can argue that they need a slightly larger share than their husbands. This is because women live to 79 on average, while men live to just 74.

It is thus more expensive for women to buy an annuity, the financial products that pay out a fixed sum per month to people after they retire.

Popplewell of the Divorce Corporation says the room for manoeuvre is not huge. The most he would expect to see a woman successfully claim on these grounds would be 53 per cent of the pension valuation, leaving 47 per cent for the husband.

If the wife is in a final salary scheme, where she is building up a right to a pension based on her salary at retirement, rather than an investment, the case will be different.

She will not need to buy an annuity because she will get a pension when she retires, rather than a pot of money that needs to be converted to an annuity. The way the system now works, she may find that her husband is given a smaller portion of her pension than he really deserves. This is because the system for valuing final salary pension schemes is notoriously mean in its effect on the junior spouse.

In pension circles, controversy has raged about the valuation of final salary pensions for divorce. In most cases, the pension will be valued to exclude the likelihood of future pay rises, promotions and enhancements to the pension scheme - a good system for high-flyers but bad for their ex-spouses.

In the very long run, there may be greater equity among spouses over pensions through the new stakeholder pension, which comes on the market in April. Carers and other people out of paid employment can put up to £3,600 a year into the stakeholder, claiming tax relief at the basic rate even if they are not working.

Quin says: 'Any of us with any sense will in future say to our partners: "I'll stay at home, but you can bang in £3,600 for me each year into a stakeholder".'

fields.headline: Analysts face bias inquiry
fields.trailText: The independence of City analysts' research is to come under the spotlight as part of the Government's review of institutional investment.
fields.body:
The independence of City analysts' research is to come under the spotlight as part of the Government's review of institutional investment.

Senior Whitehall officials are deeply concerned about the quality and independence of reports produced by analysts - employed by large investment banks or broking houses - and how much the reports cost fund managers, who use them to make investment decisions.

Fund managers say analysts are influenced by their corporate finance departments, which generate the majority of banks' income through fees on mergers and flotations of client companies. As a result analysts write overwhelmingly positive reports on clients or prospective clients.

Officials became alarmed before Christmas, when analysts covering the flotation of Orange were forced to have their reports vetted by the company in return for financial information.

They want the Treasury-commissioned Institutional Investment Review, investigating the performance of fund managers and the management of pension funds, to examine the role of analysts.

Whitehall sources say Paul Myners, chairman of Gartmore and of the Guardian Media Group (owner of The Observer ) who is heading the review, shares officials' concerns about independence.

He is examining the cost of the analysts' research, which is paid for by fund managers in the commissions they hand to banks and brokers when they buy or sell shares in the market.

A government source said: 'Paul Myners is looking at the issue of commissions. Commissions are volume-driven, and fund managers are paying ever-higher amounts for what is a declining value product.'

However, Myners is said to believe it is up to fund managers to find alternative sources of independent advice - by building up their own research departments.

Officials have been concerned over the role of investment banks, particularly in the flotations of high profile dotcom companies such as Lastminute.com and QXL, which have slumped to fractions of their initial prices.

Tony Watson, chief investment officer at Hermes Pensions Management, says: 'The Chinese walls between the research department and the corporate finance are very difficult to maintain. You can see that in the predominance of "buy" recommendations over "sells".'

webTitle: Heather Connon: Don't stay too long in the doghouse

fields.headline: Don't stay too long in the doghouse
fields.trailText: 'Beware fund managers in turmoil. That is the conclusion from the latest Spot the Dog report produced by financial adviser Bestinvest.'
fields.body:
Beware fund managers in turmoil. That is the conclusion from the latest Spot the Dog report produced by financial adviser Bestinvest, its analysis of investment funds which have done badly over the past three years.

Bottom dog by far is Scottish Widows, which now manages nine of the 57 funds in Bestinvest's doghouse. Worse, they are among the larger funds included in the table: looked at by value, Scottish Widows funds account for £3.9 billion of the £9.1 billion dog funds. Widows has around £62 billion of retail funds under management, so the dogs account for more than 6 per cent of that business.

To be fair to Widows, it has managed only two of the nine funds for the whole three years. The other seven were managed by Hill Samuel or Abbey Life, both part of Lloyds TSB, until the banking group finally acquired Scottish Widows last year.

As the unlucky investors have found, takeovers can be bad for their wealth. Taking over a life company is a protracted business and, in the two years or so it took to complete, the fund managers at Hill Samuel doubtless spent at least as much time worrying about what Scottish Widows' arrival would mean for their future as they did about their funds.

Integrating the businesses has not gone that smoothly either. Many Hill Samuel managers decided not to move to Edinburgh, where Scottish Widows is based.

Scottish Widows itself has lost a chief investment officer, a deputy chief executive, a head of UK equities and a head of institutional UK equities since the integration plans were unveiled last May. The key question for unfortunate investors in the dog funds - Abbey Assets and Earnings, Abbey General, Abbey Global Opportunities, Abbey International, Hill Samuel British and Scottish Widows' Balanced, UK Equity, UK growth and UK Smaller Companies funds - is what happens now?

Bestinvest is not enthusiastic about Widows and says existing investors should think about switching to alternative funds, and new investors should avoid them. Lloyds TSB customers should note that this could include them: any investment product bought through the banking group will now be managed by Scottish Widows.

Widows is anxious to stress that it has now got its act together. However, if any of the Widows funds account for a large proportion of your investments, you should consider switching at least part of the holding to someone with a more consistent track record. If it is a small part, you could just hope it comes right.

webTitle: Property: House auctions make a bid for the mainstream

fields.headline: House auctions make a bid for the mainstream
fields.standfirst: Going, going, moved. This method is by no means bargain basement selling, reports  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: Going, going, moved. This method is by no means bargain basement selling, reports Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
In a market dogged by delays and let-downs, house auctions are among the quickest, surest ways of buying or selling property. But auctions account for only 5 per cent of all transactions in Britain - so why do so few people think of selling or buying a home this way?

Auctions have traditionally been sniffed at by estate agents as a second-rate way of selling what they regard as second-rate homes - those repossessed from mortgage defaulters, houses requiring complete modernisation or hard-to-sell places such as flats above shops.

But last autumn's quiet property market led to greater interest in auctions and a realisation that they can offer a good deal to buyers and sellers alike. Look through a catalogue now and you will see detached houses of the type that fetch big prices by conventional means.

'I'm amazed more people don't desert sale by private treaty [the conventional route] and at least try an auction,' says Gary Murphy, an auctioneer at Allsops in London. 'Auctions now have most types of property on sale, at least in the market below £500,000. For buyers they prevent gazumping because all the rival transactions are dealt with in three minutes in an auction room, you see what everyone else is doing, and if you are the highest bidder, it's yours, by law.'

Murphy claims the seller benefits, too. 'We did a controlled experiment with the Metropolitan Police when it was selling off its married quarters, and we found those properties which went to auction fetched better prices than those which went to private treaty.'

Most househunters are unhappy about buying in the traditional way on the basis of a 10-minute visit with an estate agent. In theory, auction purchases could be more hit and miss, so a wise buyer will prepare with some simple steps set out by the Incorporated Society of Valuers and Auctioneers.

 Order a catalogue, usually available three weeks before the auction. Identify properties which interest you and visit them. Some auctioneers arrange group viewings. Find out, too, if the house you want has a minimum 'reserve price'.

 Get a survey of the property you want, although this may have to be done speculatively well before you get to the auction. Many auctioneers get one done in advance on behalf of the seller to avoid multiple surveys on one house, and the winning bid reimburses the cost to the vendor.

 Sort out your finances well before you enter the auction room. If you are the successful bidder, you must pay 10 per cent immediately to the auctioneer; then you have to move in and pay the remaining 90 per cent within a short period, normally 28 days. There are often stiff legal penalties if you contravene these payment and moving schedules.

 Hire a solicitor familiar with conveyancing and auctions. Some house vendors or their auctioneers will have prepared a 'seller's pack' of title deeds and local council search information ready for the buyer, similar to the Gov ernment's proposal for all types of property transaction by the end of 2002.

 Set a spending limit, and make clear hand signals and verbal bids - and keep a clear head to avoid being carried away in a bidding war.

Property auctions lend themselves peculiarly well to online trading. Some 'live' auctions allow online bids too, but these can place the electronic bidder at a disadvantage because he or she does not see or hear the main bidding in the room.

Now some totally online auctions are being piloted. Last year a company called Homes4Living sold two new apartments in a marina at Eastbourne by placing floor plans and 360-degree 'virtual tours' of the flats on a website. The auction allowed only online bids over a two-week period, and people had to provide evidence that they had the funds and legal go-ahead before being registered as bidders.

'We had 150,000 hits on the site over the auction period. Of those about 300 registered for the potential to bid,' says Homes4Living sales director Anna Fendi. Both flats reached their reserve price.

A company called Thepropertylot is starting a similar service on a larger scale in the spring. It is also offering to sell houses registered with conventional estate agents via internet bidding and split the commission if a sale is successful.

Director Martin Constable says: 'Purchasers will be able to bid for properties from the comfort of their home or office. They'll also have longer to consider their bids, which reduces the pressure that many feel in a traditional auction environment.'

But traditionalists say there is one big psychological disadvantage in online auctions. Murphy of Allsops says: 'When you're on a computer screen you can't see the whites of the eyes of those who want to deny you the home you're bidding for.'

fields.headline: Nomura leads in pubs race
fields.trailText: Nomura, Britain's biggest landlord, is emerging as the clear favourite to take control of Whitbread's 3,000-strong chain of pubs, put up for sale last month.
fields.body:
Nomura, Britain's biggest landlord, is emerging as the clear favourite to take control of Whitbread's 3,000-strong chain of pubs, put up for sale last month.

The leisure giant, which wants to concentrate on health clubs, restaurants and hotels, would prefer to sell its entire pubs portfolio to a single buyer. Sources in the brewing industry say, so far, the Japanese bank is the only interested party known to have tabled a bid for the whole estate.

Whitbread has indicated that it believes the 3,000 pubs, 1,700 of which are leased, with the remainder managed, are worth between £1.4 billion and £1.6bn.

Other bidders, notably Alchemy Partners, the venture capital firm that tried to buy Rover last year, and Pubmaster, the company formed out of the ashes of the Brent Walker empire, are also interested, but would prefer to bid for only part of the estate. Punch Taverns, which owns 5,000 pubs and last year bought Allied Domecq's estate, is not thought to be interested at present.

Nomura already owns more than 5,000 pubs. It also owns the UK's biggest off-licence chain, First Quench, which has 2,500 stores.

Analysts have speculated that the number of pubs coming on to the market could be bad news for Whitbread's hopes of commanding a pre mium price for its estate. Bass has put 900 pubs up for sale, while Scottish & Newcastle is keen to offload 700 pubs. In addition, Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries, Britain's largest regional brewer, with 1,700 pubs, is at the centre of a fierce bidding war.

Wolves' management believes it is close to securing backing for a buyout of the company, stalked by venture capital company Botts.

webTitle: Drugs giants sue to cut HIV lifeline

fields.headline: Drugs giants sue to cut HIV lifeline
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The might of the world's drugs industry, including GlaxoSmithKline of the UK, is suing South Africa over alleged violation of intellectual property rights.
fields.body:
The might of the world's drugs industry, including GlaxoSmithKline of the UK, is suing South Africa over alleged violation of intellectual property rights.

The action will reignite a furious row between African countries, where 25 million people are infected by the HIV virus. Only 25,000 of these have access to the drugs they need to stay alive.

In a case to be heard at the Pretoria High Court in March, companies will try to prevent South Africa from making or buying abroad huge quantities of cheap, generic drugs to treat patients.

Anti-HIV drugs from countries such as Thailand can cost as little as a tenth of the price of buying them from the multinationals. Drugs firms refuse to grant price cuts to developing countries until their health systems are deemed 'sophisticated'.

Whoever loses the case in South Africa won't incur damages but will have to pay costs running into tens of millions of pounds. The action will tarnish recent progress made by African governments and the pharmaceuticals industry in relieving this massive health crisis.


South Africa fights Aids drug apartheid

fields.headline: Internet hoax rocks shares
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The feverish, rumour-fuelled world of internet bulletin boards has taken a sinister turn, sparking a police fraud squad inquiry.
fields.body:
The feverish, rumour-fuelled world of internet bulletin boards has taken a sinister turn, sparking a police fraud squad inquiry.

Last November someone posted on the bulletin board of venture capital fund 3i what looked like an official Stock Exchange announcement. It said that Mercury, the investment fund, had sold shares in Minmet, the quoted mining firm. This was important because Mercury's presence on Minmet's share register is a significant factor in persuading private investors to hold onto its shares.

But the announcement was bogus. It had been cut and pasted from an announcement by a totally unrelated company. Someone had removed the original name, Pilkington Tiles, and replaced it with Minmet.

The prank, believe Minmet executives, may have destabilised its volatile share price, which last year rocketed on hopes that a discovery of gold in Brazil could see massive revenues in the future.

This weekend, Kent fraud squad officers confirmed that they were investigating the case following complaints by Minmet, which has an office there and is quoted in Dublin.

Minmet executives believe the perpetrator is part of a sophisticated 'deramping' syndicate out to sell short the company's shares in a bid to buy them at deflated prices. 'We've no doubt that this is organised,' said chief executive Michael Nolan. 'We've been regularly targeted on bulletin boards.'

Minmet has been one of the highest profile companies in Ireland. The possibility of the big Brazilian find turned its shares into some of those most talked about, even in UK internet chat rooms. The stock has recently fallen, although the company's recent results have been in line with its expectations.

webTitle: Help! I want to move my bank account

fields.headline: Help! I want to move my bank account
fields.trailText: From 1 January this year, most banks agreed to 'co-operate to ensure customers can move their account to another bank or building society as smoothly as possible'.
fields.body:
Don't worry: the process is becoming far easier than it used to be. From 1 January this year, most banks agreed to 'co-operate to ensure customers can move their account to another bank or building society as smoothly as possible'. This agreement was part of an extension to the Banking Code - a voluntary statement of good practice which has been signed by most banks.

Many people have been put off switching current accounts because they worried that some of their direct debits or standing orders could get lost or delayed in the process. Now, however, the bank you are leaving should send a list of such details to your new bank.

Your new bank will ask you to authorise these transactions. A traditional lender will want you to sign a separate authorisation for each direct debit. But the newer, streamlined banks will send you just one piece of paper to sign, a letter listing all your direct debits and standing orders.

Although this is the theory, there seem to be some problems at the moment in practice. Research conducted by Halifax subsidiary Intelligent Finance suggests that the traditional Big Four are not up to speed yet. Nevertheless, they are heading in the right direction.By the end of this year, the process should be even smoother when an electronic procedure 'to deliver an automated direct debit transfer system' is introduced across the banking industry. Banks will be able to pass information electronically to each other and to the 'merchants', the mortgage lenders and other businesses that receive money through direct debit and standing order transactions. Not only will this be quicker and less administratively onerous for the customer, it will also reduce the scope for human error.

Banks are finally trying hard to take the pain out of switching current accounts, recognising that this will reward the most efficient of them. HSBC, for instance, hopes to complete the account-opening process in seven working days and plans to give compensation of £10 if it misses any of its own deadlines and benchmarks.

webTitle: Comment: Talking may make life more equitable

fields.headline: Talking may make life more equitable
fields.trailText: 'The refusal of Equitable Life's new chief executive to admit that the insurer's problems add up to a crisis must have infuriated many policyholders.'
fields.body:
Crisis, what crisis? The refusal of Chris Headdon, Equitable Life's new chief executive and former chief actuary, to admit that the insurer's problems add up to a crisis must have infuriated many policyholders.

Their pension provider has been closed to new business, and they have suffered months of anxiety over the future of their pensions. Even if Equitable is finally sold, any hope of a windfall for its members - the policyholders - is long since lost.

Although insensitive, Headdon is right in that policyholders need not take immediate action. The insurer is solvent and policyholders will still receive pensions, even if they are smaller than expected.

But couldn't it all have been avoided? Some policyholders, including Stuart Bayliss, leader of the Equitable Life Action Group, approached the Equitable in 1998 with plans for a compromise on how to handle the guaranteed annuity rates sold to 90,000 people. Bayliss believes this could have halved the £1.5 billion liability the firm now faces.

That particular deal may not have been viable. How can we know? Members were never told about Equitable's situation, or allowed to express an opinion.

Now Equitable is negotiating with its policyholders over a compromise, there is hope. It is finally doing as it should - talking to its members (see page 17).

SEVEN-YEAR prison sentences and £5,000 fines may seem a bit extreme for parents who try to cut the cost of childcare by paying their nanny cash in hand.

But think about the effect their tax evasion will have on the nanny. By not paying her portion of income tax, they will not be able to pay her National Insurance contri bution. In the short term this means she will not be able to claim unemployment benefit if she loses her job, or maternity benefit if she becomes pregnant. In the longer term she may not have sufficient NI contributions to qualify for the basic state pension.

Many parents don't declare their nanny's earn ings; even more don't pay wages during holidays, or any maternity allowance.

Nannies are expensive, particularly because they are paid out of parents' net earnings, but this is all part of the deal you take on when deciding to have children. It's an expensive business, but there should be no scrimping on childcare.

fields.headline: Of nine lives - and man's best friend
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley  on insurance policies that will help pay the vet's bill
fields.trailText: Jill Insley on insurance policies that will help pay the vet's bill.
fields.body:
With veterinary fees rising by 11 per cent a year, taking Tibbles or Fido for treatment is becoming expensive.

The RSPCA estimates that 40 per cent of the cost of owning a dog or a cat lies in unforeseen vets fees. 'Some pets never develop an illness or have an accident. But if your dog is hit by a car, or your cat needs referring to a specialist, thebill is going to start at £1,000,' says Emma Nutbrown, a spokeswoman for the charity.

Pet insurance, which covers pet owners against the cost of vets' fees, can help ease the cost of caring for an animal. When Jasmine, a blue burmese, got into a fight with another cat last year, her left eye became inflamed. Initially the vet diagnosed an infection, and when eye drops didn't work he operated to remove her third eyelid. But the problem continued. 'This time we saw a different vet, who had specialised in opthalmology. He spotted that Jasmine had an ulcer on her cornea,' says Maria, Jasmine's owner.

Jasmine needed another operation to enable the eye to heal. In all, her treatment cost more than £800. 'Luckily Jasmine was insured for vet's fees. I had to pay an excess of about £30 on four different occasions, but that was much better than having to fork out the full amount,' says Maria.

The RSPCA considers pet insurance to be an integral part of responsible pet ownership. But how do you choose the right policy? Even basic policies differ dramatically in price, as the table shows. If your finances are tight, it is obviously better to buy the cheapest policy rather than none at all. Saga's pet insurance, which can be bought by owners aged 50 or more, is the cheapest for both dogs and cats, but cover for vet's fee is lim ited to £2,000 per year. This may seem a lot, but a serious operation or treatment for a condition such as arthritis could exceed this amount. In addition, the excess for elderly pets - those aged 10 or more - rises to £85 per claim.

It is also worth checking the insurer's terms for chronic conditions. Statistics gathered by Pet Plan show that nearly 40 per cent of claims go beyond a 12-month period. But some policies, such as that offered by Dog Breeders Insurance, limit cover for a chronic condition to just one year.

You should also check that the premium does not increase with a history of claims. The RSPCA's policy is priced cheaply to encourage owners to insure their pets for the first time, but if you make a claim, your premium will increase.

Third-party liability is important for dog owners. This covers you for legal costs and compensation if your dog causes an accident or injures another person, and they sue for damages. It is not necessary for cats as they are considered wild animals legally and you cannot be held responsible for their behaviour.

Finally check the terms for insuring your pet after a certain age. Some insurers will not renew policies for pets once they reach the age of eight. Others, including PetPlan, will continue insuring existing policyholders when they reach eight but will not take on new applicants at that age.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: We do like to retire beside the seaside

fields.headline: We do like to retire beside the seaside
fields.standfirst: Pat and Thomas want to enjoy their time without tax worries, they tell  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: Pat and Thomas want to enjoy their time without tax worries, they tell Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Pat and Thomas Taylor

Ages 62 and 75

Live in Newcastle upon Tyne

Occupations Retired

Earn State pensions

Mortgage None

Debts None

Investments Isa, Premium Bonds

Pensions Receiving state pension

Aims To invest proceeds from trading down house

Pat and Thomas Taylor are moving to a small flat in Whitley Bay, two minutes away from the seafront. After 30 years in an old, high-ceilinged house with a large garden, they have decided to trade down to something easier to manage.

Pat says: 'We have bought a small flat down at the coast. We read a lot and walk a lot, which is why going to the coast is a nice extra dimension. The garden here is getting a bit much for us and it is surrounded by large sycamore trees which have a preservation order on them, so every autumn my poor husband has mountains of leaves to clear up.'

They have just the state pension to live on, but in Whitley Bay their outgoings will be cheaper. They have no car but the flat is only two minutes from the Metro.

Over the years, instead of saving, they have spent their money on the old house because it always required a lot of attention: 'We have only been able to do bits and pieces to it as we could afford it, because we never borrow money. We have added rewiring, new gutters, a new bathroom, and finally, about 10 years ago, we got round to central heating and new windows.' The Taylors feel they would never stop spending money on the house and it would always be a worry.

The new flat will need decorating but nothing more: 'It has a lovely fitted kitchen and a nice bathroom, so we don't have anything to do.'

Nor will they have any upkeep problems: 'A maintenance agreement covers all the outside work, garden and walls. We have to join the tenants' association and every year they reckon up. All the work is done, a balance sheet sent to you and it costs about £400 a year with limits on how much the bill can rise each year.'

Pat and Thomas will have to adjust to having less space but are happy with their choice: 'After always living in old houses with high ceilings and large rooms, looking around at modern flats we were absolutely horrified. I couldn't believe the tiny modern bathrooms, but we have been lucky to find something that suits us.'

They are selling the old mortgage-free house for £85,000 and paying £62,000 for the flat: 'After all the costs, we estimate we will have £20,000 to invest to provide us with extra income and an emergency fund.'

Their only other savings are £1,000 in a Newcastle Build ing Society Isa and £2,500 in Premium Bonds which produce winnings of £100-£150 a year. Their main concern is tax: 'We do not pay tax at all at the moment and we want to know how much leeway there is with the investments before we have to pay tax.'

Adviser 1: James Dalby

With £20,000 to invest, they are most unlikely to have a tax problem. In the current tax year they have over £1,800 a year in unused personal tax allowances plus married couple's allowance for people over 65. This is not straightforward but, for the Taylors, effectively reduces any tax bill by up to £525.50.

Not wanting to take risk limits their investment options to cash-based ones, but I would encourage them to consider taking a little risk with some of their money so that they can benefit from capital growth. Placing, say, £5,000 in a with-profits bond is a good option. They can take an income of 5 per cent a year, still leaving some potential for capital growth. Compa nies to consider include Norwich Union, Scottish Equitable and Scottish Mutual.

For an emergency fund, I suggest £5,000 in the Scottish Widows Instant Access account at 6.25 per cent gross, or they could use mini cash Isas; Britannia building society offers one of the most competitive, with tax-free interest of 6.85 per cent.

The balance of £10,000 could earn monthly income, perhaps in the Capital One Bank 30 Day Saver account. The annual interest is currently 6.62 per cent.

They should each complete a form R85, available from banks and building societies, so all interest is paid gross.

James Dalby works for Bates Investment Services

Adviser 2: Joanne Cox

Mr and Mrs Taylor will not pay tax on the lump sum as it comes from the sale of their main residence, although, in future they may pay tax on any income from investments they buy with the money.

Thomas's pension is £4,960 a year and at 75 his personal allowance is £6,050, so he could earn another £1,090 a year before paying tax.

Mrs Taylor can receive a further £786 before paying tax. They could each have £3,000 in a cash Isa although, on the downside, few cash Isas pay out interest monthly.

As Mr and Mrs Taylor are risk-averse, they could consider National Savings Income Bonds, which pay 5.95 per cent and, on £20,000, earn £1,190 a year, well within their combined allowance. They should invest proportionately to take advantage of their individual tax allowances; by investing no more than £10,000 in Mrs Taylor's name they will both keep within their allowances.

The disadvantage of National Savings is that there is no capital growth and, while they may not be looking for that as such, without it their money loses purchasing power.

An investment which could satisfy both the income and growth need would be a with-profits bond. These are not risk-free but the Taylors would have no extra tax to pay.

Joanne Cox works for Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers

 Advice is for guidance only

Thomas's pension is £4,960 a year and at 75 his personal allowance is £6,050, so he could earn another £1,090 a year before paying tax. Mrs Taylor can receive a further £786 before paying tax. They could each have £3,000 in a cash Isa although, on the downside, few cash Isas pay out interest monthly. As Mr and Mrs Taylor are risk-averse, they could consider National Savings Income Bonds, which pay 5.95 per cent and, on £20,000, earn £1,190 a year, well within their combined allowance. They should invest proportionately to take advantage of their individual tax allowances; by investing no more than £10,000 in Mrs Taylor's name they will both keep within their allowances. The disadvantage of National Savings is that there is no capital growth and, while they may not be looking for that as such, without it their money loses purchasing power. An investment which could satisfy both the income and growth need would be a with-profits bond. These are not risk-free but the Taylors would have no extra tax to pay. fields.headline: Plunge into luxury living
fields.standfirst: Alexander Garrett looks at the pros and cons of installing a swimming pool
fields.trailText: Alexander Garrett looks at the pros and cons of installing a swimming pool.
fields.body:
One of the most fascinating aspects of flying over south-east England is the countless small, turquoise rectangles you see below you. Global warming may not have given us a Mediterranean climate quite yet, but new material technologies have combined with economic prosperity to such a degree that owning a swimming pool, once a privilege reserved for Californians and millionaires, is becoming commonplace in the UK.

Last year, 4,500 pools were installed in the UK, up from about 3,000 in 1995, according to the Swimming Pool and Allied Trades Association (Spata). It says the installation rate should reach 5,000 this year.

According to Spata, an above-ground pool with attractive decking can cost as little as £2,500, including filtration unit, pumps and pipework. In-ground liner pools can cost £6,000-£7,000 on a DIY basis or £13,000 fully installed. Fibreglass models cost slightly less. Galvanised steel pools are a relatively new option, at £10,000 installed; and the most expensive is a concrete pool, typically ranging from £18,000 to £30,000. Indoor pools tend to sit at the more expensive end of the scale (and have the added cost of building a home for them).

All this choice can be confusing. The people who sell concrete pools say their permanent structure lasts for ever, and that a liner could be punctured. The liner people, on the other hand, stress the huge improvements made in the materials on offer, and say reinforced versions come with a guaranteed life of at least 10 years.

Simon Thorogood of Norfolk-based Aqua Pool Services says: 'A lot of people are certainly under the impression that pools cost a lot more than they do. With all the products out there, you can have a liner pool now to the same standard as a tiled concrete pool.'

In practice, it's a bit like arguing the merits between a real wooden floor and a laminate imitation; the latter undoubtedly does the job, but can never quite emulate the look of the real thing.

In addition to the pool, essential accessories are a filtration unit and, for all but the hardiest of souls, heating. You can even use your central heating system.

Annual running costs are lower than one might expect: about £500 to cover chemicals and heating for a family-sized pool in use from May to October. The larger the pool, though, the higher the cost of keeping it heated.

Installing the pool yourself - digging the hole, putting up breeze-block sides and so on - can save a lot. Spata estimates one-third of pools are DIY jobs. But opinions vary as to whether this is advisable. Spata spokeswoman Barbara Kay says: 'With galvanised steel pool kits, you are encouraged to do it yourself, but you would need building skills to put in a concrete pool. In any case, seek expert advice.'

You don't usually require planning permission for an outdoor pool, unless the property is listed or in a conservation area, but it is as well to check with your local planning authority. Also take the advice of a surveyor, especially if the site is prone to damp or flooding.

That leaves the big question: is a pool a good investment for your property or a liability that will put off potential buyers? In London, opportunities for pools are restricted. Tim Wright, of FPD Savills, says an outside pool is generally a 'complete waste of time', because it is likely to take up too much of whatever garden is available.

Your chance of building an indoor pool in your garden is also likely to be vetoed by planning authorities. That leaves the option of an indoor pool in a part of your house, such as the basement or in an existing extension.

'Five years ago, I would have said that an indoor pool was a mistake, because of the smell of chlorine and humidity problems, but now I would have to change my mind,' says Wright. He believes a pool can be a valuable asset and repay its investment, so long as it is not at the expense of other essential accommodation. In a recent luxury development in Kensington, half the 23 houses had pools in the basement and the remainder had games rooms. Those with pools sold at a £250,000 premium.

In the country, there is a different set of considerations. James Laing, head of country house sales at agent Strutt & Parker, says the popularity of pools has generally been on the increase thanks to warmer weather and people wanting to recreate the ' dolce vita ' lifestyle experienced on overseas holidays.

Laing says: 'An indoor pool in a well-designed complex adjacent to the house and architecturally compatible adds considerable value, because it enables the super-fit commuter to have a swim before work in the morning. Equally, a pool away from the house can be an asset.

'The pool that definitely devalues is the one that is installed in a hurry outside the kitchen window, so that mother can keep an eye on the children.'

A big disadvantage with an outdoor pool is that, for half the year, it is likely to sit there unused. The trick is to tuck it away in a discreet corner, ready to resume its role as your piece of Shangri-la once the sun shines again.

 This article is from the January issue of Money Observer, on sale at newsagents at £3.50. For 12 issues at £31.97, a £10 saving, call 0870 870 1324 and quote reference MYAH001.

webTitle: Make sure your nanny won't land you in jail

fields.headline: Make sure your nanny won't land you in jail
fields.standfirst: Richard Murphy outlines a scheme for keeping parents solvent - and out of prison
fields.trailText: Richard Murphy outlines a scheme for keeping parents solvent - and out of prison.
fields.body:
Parents who pay their nannies cash in hand could be jailed for up to seven years and fined up to£5,000 following a change in in the law.

No one knows quite how many nannies there are in the UK, because so many are paid in this way. Most nannies negotiate their salaries in net terms, preferring to leave the payment of any tax and National Insurance to their employers, the parents - and they have often failed to pay some or all of the income tax due to the Inland Revenue.

But from 1 January, paying an employee cash without handing over the proper tax to the Inland Revenue became a criminal offence.

The most common way to pay tax on behalf of a nanny has been through Pay As You Earn (PAYE). This has proved expensive for parents, who receive no tax benefits or reliefs - any payment comes out of the employer's taxed income. A nanny earning £225.80 net a week, £11,742 a year, will incur £2,153 income tax and £1,105 employee's National Insurance, making a total £15,000 a year. In addition the parent has to pay a further £1,297 of employer's NI, making the total cost £16,297. The table shows how this works.

Now, however, there is an alternative and legal way of making the payment - and saving money.

This may be the time to set your nanny up in her own private limited company. The Revenue has been attacking most 'personal service companies' - companies owned by one person and supplying all their services to one customer. But the law that does this also makes it clear that if the company supplies services to someone who is not in business, such companies are quite legitimate. Parents are not in business as parents, so a nanny can be a one-person personal service company.

In addition, last October it was also made clear that minimum pay legislation does not apply to directors of their own companies who have no contract of employment. This means a nanny who has her own company is free to set her own pay rate. This is very important in this alternative payment plan.

So how does it work? First you have to set up a company. As you will have to use an accountant to work this scheme, you may as well buy the company from your firm of accountants. This and all accountancy fees should cost no more than about £1,200 a year. Your nanny has to own this company and be a director, but one of the parent employers should be company secretary.

They can then take responsibility for the administration. (You have to be realistic here: your nanny may not be too keen on this part of the job.)

Once the company is set up, it bills the parents for the nanny's services. The amount billed should be just enough to cover all its costs. Using the same example as before, this total is £13,767. If you want to keep admin to a minimum, levy bills quarterly in advance. This would make each bill £3,441.75. State on the invoice that fees are not refundable. It is critical that paperwork such as invoices is done. If it is not, this scheme could be challenged as a sham, which it is not when done properly.

Your nanny's salary will now comprise two parts - salary and a dividend, both paid by the company. The salary should be just enough to make sure your nanny has an NI credit. If she is paid £83.50 a week, she'll pay no tax on the salary and NIof just 75p. There is no employer's NI. The net pay is £82.75. The annual cost is £4,342. She now needs another £142.25 per week, or say £7,400 a year. This can be paid as a dividend.

Companies that make less than £10,000 of profit a year pay 10 per cent corporation tax. A dividend has a 10 per cent tax credit attached to it and a basic-rate taxpayer (which the nanny will be) pays no additional tax on receipt of a dividend. So, the company has to have profits after 10 per cent tax of £7,400, which means pre-tax profit is about £8,225. This is used to pay the dividend and the nanny pays no tax at all on it.

Now the company has three costs: the profits to pay the dividends, the salary and the cost of running it. These amount to £8,225, £4,342 and £1,200 respectively or a total of £13,767. Paying the same nanny under PAYE costs £16,297, so the saving could be £2,530, after costs. This is summarised in the table above.

You will need some help with this. Bills have to be raised, dividends have to be paid and recorded properly, and the company will have to prepare and file accounts. So you should consult an accountant. But the scheme is legal and cost-effective at a time when there will be a clampdown on 'cash in hand' nannies. It has to be worth considering.

fields.headline: Learning to be fearful
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Dyslexia will be eradicated by the end of the decade, it is claimed, thanks to a machine developed by Nasa to test astronauts.
fields.body:
Dyslexia will be eradicated by the end of the decade, it is claimed, thanks to a machine developed by Nasa to test astronauts. Using this space-age device, dyslexic children are overcoming feelings of disorientation and learning to read and write.

This would be fantastic if it were true. Nearly 20 per cent of all primary-school pupils are registered as having special educational needs, usually because they have dyslexia or a related syndrome: dyspraxia (also known as clumsy child syndrome), Attention Deficit and Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), Asperger's, or any of the other Autistic Spectrum Disorders. One extreme estimate puts the annual expenditure on these children at £7.1 billion, out of a total education budget of £20bn.

Yet despite the rush to diagnose - the number of primary-school children with special needs has risen from 11 per cent to 19 per cent in four years - no-one knows what causes learning difficulties, or can clearly define the symptoms. The diagnosis often reveals more about the person making it than about the child. Educationalists tend to identify dyslexia, occupational therapists and paediatricians dyspraxia, psychologists ADHD, and speech and language therapists Asperger's.

For parents of an otherwise bright and healthy child who is failing at school, it is, of course, a relief to have a diagnosis. Therapies then become available; even, perhaps, miracle cures. But how useful is a diagnosis if the syndrome turns out to have numerous causes and many manifestations? Some treatments - cod liver oil, throwing bean bags, doing jigsaws - undoubtedly work for some children, but it's not clear how long the effects last. There are experts who think that with one-to-one attention, you might be able to get the same results doing almost anything.

Some children are undoubtedly different. They fall over a lot, don't understand about personal space; they make different connections from other people; have strange mental lacunae. But what's really weird is an education system that fails to take account of them.

You can see how teachers' minds work: 'My methods are effective for 80 per cent of the class, so they must be good. It's the three children a year I'm not reaching who are at fault.' This may, however, be looking at the problem the wrong way round.

A high proportion of children registered as having special needs haven't learned to read, while some schools consistently register less than 1 per cent of their pupils. In others, apparently, well over half the pupils are handicapped. (This, remember, is supposed to be a physical, not a social condition.)

There has been no research into this discrepancy (though given the amount of money special needs is sucking out of mainstream education, you might think it would be a priority). But it begs the question, are teaching methods somehow involved? At one school that has no dyslexic children, Kobi Nazrul in Tower Hamlets, the head teacher - acknowledging that some systems are better than others - believes the reason is the children use a good phonics method, so that by the age of six, they are all able to read.

Most 'good' primary schools accept that several children leave Year 1 unable to read. The Government's literacy and numeracy strategy aims to have 80 per cent of children at acceptable levels for secondary schools by the time they transfer, writing off the other 20 per cent. It's not to our credit that we then give them a label to explain their failure.

Some children don't fit the pattern we have set for them. They struggle to concentrate and have difficulty forming letters. But given that these problems appear to have many causes and respond only uncertainly to treatment, the least we can do is find out what methods infallibly teach them to read. Then we have to engage them, which may mean rather less rigidity in the curriculum. If some schools can do it, so could the others.

webTitle: How can we avoid a personal email ban?

fields.headline: How can we avoid a personal email ban?
fields.trailText: My bosses are worried about people sending naughty emails to each other and getting the company into trouble. But , of course, we all find it extremely useful to be able to send the occasional email to friends or family. How can we persuade them not to ban personal emails?
fields.body:
My bosses are worried about people sending naughty emails to each other and getting the company into trouble. But , of course, we all find it extremely useful to be able to send the occasional email to friends or family. How can we persuade them not to ban personal emails?

Some organisations have already put a ban in place. The danger for employers is that they can be held liable if one employee is seen to be harassing another by sending them lewd emails, and since the potential payout in these cases is unlimited, it is not surprising that some human resources departments are worried.

Legally, the company can simply inform you all that personal emails are not permitted, but in practice a ban would be difficult to achieve in many businesses.

The internet exists to facilitate communication and an employer who tries to ban personal emails is exhibiting a confused view of its connections with the outside world. The company would also need to ensure that all staff - from the managing director down - were obliged to obey the rule, and MDs may not find this so appealing.

A better plan for an employer is to lay out an email policy and make it clear that abuse of the system will result in disciplinary proceedings and, in bad cases, possibly the sack.

Legal advice from Lewis Silkin

fields.headline: Nailing a deadly legacy
fields.standfirst:
Building managers will have a greater duty to protect workers from asbestos, writes Caroline Palmer

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Building managers will have a greater duty to protect workers from asbestos, writes Caroline Palmer
fields.body:
Aa many as 1.5 million workplace properties in the UK are thought to contain asbestos in some form or other. So are employees still being put at risk by the hazardous fibres? The Health and Safety Executive has plans in the pipeline to tighten the law on the way asbestos is managed in buildings.

The proposals will place a new duty to manage asbestos on those responsible for these buildings. HSE chairman Bill Callaghan says: 'There are 3,000 deaths a year from asbestos-related diseases, all of which could have been prevented. This is an intolerable toll of human suffering and misery. It is a grim reminder of the cost of health and safety failure, and of the benefits if we manage this problem successfully."

A quarter of the people now dying from asbestos-related diseases worked in the building trade. They may have breathed in asbestos dust during their day-to-day work with asbestos materials or because work with asbestos was carried out near them. The Health and Safety Executive says that until recently it was believed that those now dying from asbestos-related diseases, for which is no cure, were exposed to large amounts of asbestos either regularly or during a single spell of work. But itis now thought possible that repeated low-level exposure, such as during routine repair work, may also lead to asbestos-induced cancers.

Electricians, plumbers, building maintenance workers, shopfitters and carpenters may still be at risk when they carry out refurbishments, repairs or maintenance work on buildings containing asbestos. Even office workers could be affected if building managers are poorly informed themselves or do not communicate the risks adequately.

Daniel Wildey, a senior health and safety officer at Westminster City Council, says this is a major issue. 'London has many old buildings which were adapted for office use using asbestos. There is a tendency for people to make assumptions that contractors are compe tent. Asbestos was used extensively in the Sixties and Seventies as a fabric in the office environment, and people who manage buildings need to know where this material is.

'Maybe a contractor comes in to install some computers. The office partitions or ceiling tiles may be made of asbestos. If they are disturbed by being drilled through, for instance, not only will the contractor be put at risk but harmful dust could be left in the room for employees to breathe in.'

There is no safe level of asbestos dust in the atmosphere. Although office workers can be put at some risk in this way, the HSE has identified computer installers, particularly cabling installers, fire alarm installers, window blind fitters and telecommunications engineers as those most in danger.

UK asbestos injury lawyer Nigel Tomkins feels strongly, however, that people working in offices should not panic. He believes that there is not much risk in offices and that raising people's awareness could be counter-productive. 'People are more at risk in their lofts at home. Asbestos in offices tends to be well hidden away.' He does admit that once someone starts doing work on the building and drilling holes, they need to be aware of the asbestos risk.

Tomkins is concerned that the knowledge that asbestos is present in a building can make people overreact in certain situations. For instance, if asbestos tiles are in good condition and not being worked on, it is much safer to leave them in situ, he believes.

'I've seen unnecessary panic where asbestos has been discovered in a school, for instance. The school has been closed and the asbestos has been ripped out. This would probably have done more harm than good, because a lot of dust would be created in the process of dismantling.'

The HSE is convinced that raising awareness about the presence of asbestos in buildings is essential if accidental exposure is to be prevented. Wildey agrees. At the moment an employer has a duty to carry out a risk assessment of the workplace, of which looking out for asbestos is part.

The problem is that this is reliant on the employer considering asbestos a potential hazard. This is not always the case - the employer may not have thought of it at all.

So while at the moment the duty on employers to manage asbestos is implicit, new legislation will make it explicit and will provide much more guidance.

This guidance is essential if the HSE is to succeed in putting a stop to the kind of cases it has had to prosecute over the years where, often through ignorance or lack of communication, people have been unnecessarily exposed to asbestos dust.

Cases have included an employer who used his own family, as well as employees, to smash up asbestos insulation board ceiling tiles in three shop units he was refurbishing for his own use. No precautions were taken. He was fined £1,000 and ordered to pay £500 costs.

Another case involved Granada Hospitality and again involved asbestos insulation boarding, this time over the servery of a disused restaurant. Again no precautions were taken, which put the three contractors doing the work at risk and also, to a lesser degree, exposed Granada employees who still occupied a small office in the corner of the restaurant.

Reporting on the case, the HSE stated that Granada 'had an asbestos survey done in 1995 which identified the asbestos involved, but this was not passed by themselves to the contractors due to inadequate managerial control'. Granada was fined £6,000.

It was in 1924 that the first clear case of death due to asbestosis appeared in medical literature. Today, says Tomkins, the number of victims worldwide can only be guessed at.

In a paper he delivered at an conference of European personal injury lawyers on the subject he said: 'The scale of the asbestos tragedy is - like the substance itself - literally breathtaking. No one can do more than guess at how many lives worldwide will be claimed in the end. The only thing we can know with any certainty is that the legacy will be here for decades to come.'

webTitle: Stone Age bosses aren't all that bad

fields.headline: Stone Age bosses aren't all that bad
fields.standfirst:
Evolutionary psychology suggests you go with basic instincts. By Simon Caulkin

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Evolutionary psychology suggests you go with basic instincts. By Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
The knottiest problems in management are usually not to do with formulating strategy or carrying out routine operations (unless of course you are the railway industry). Time and again when managers are asked what causes them most grief, they reply that it is the most basic things of all: 'People' and 'change'.

But here's a puzzle. Human beings are social animals. We are brilliantly equipped for appraising, interpreting and communicating with others. We are also wonderfully adaptable. We change and grow all our lives. We change homes, partners and governments. We swap fashions at the drop of a hat or hemline. But if that's the case - if people are naturally good at change and communicating - how come companies make such a hash of it?

According to Nigel Nicholson, professor of organisational behaviour at London Business School, the answer (as to a number of other management paradoxes) is to be found in the emerging discipline of evolutionary psychology. Basically, EP marries the framework of Darwinism with modern theories of genetics and neuropsychology to propose that psychology as well as physique is the product of evolutionary winnowing.

Applied to business, as Nicholson does in his book Managing The Human Animal (Texere, £18.99), EP suggests that most organisational practice runs directly against the grain of human program ming. Much of our behaviour is hardwired for the successful hunter-gatherer lifestyle of our prehistoric ancestors; and this 45,000-year-old psyche - putting emotion before rational analysis, vision before the other senses, narrative before more dispassionate forms of analysis - is understandably alienated among the chart boxes and serried hierarchies of the large modern organisation. 'You can take the manager out of the Stone Age, but not the Stone Age out of the manager,' as Nicholson puts it.

Precisely because we are so adaptable, humans can seemingly put up with an awful lot. The changes that have led people from the outback to the urban jungles of New York or London, from small groups of hunter-gatherers to the teeming bureaucracy, have brought vast benefits in terms of productivity and the ability to support ever larger populations.

But there's a cost. 'The further we get from our origins, the more the propensity for disorder grows,' says Nicholson. In society, that surfaces as social conflict, crime, mental illness and alienation. Business has its own version of these dysfunctions: the suppression of emotion and stress, disempowerment and alienation, low trust, management by fear, discrimination (the tyrannies of, respectively, rationality, bureaucracy, politics, dominance and tribalism).

No wonder introducing change fails, or for that matter teams work fitfully if at all, or most decisions are just plain bad. Organisations take things that people do naturally - change, work together, make joint decisions - and make them do them unnaturally.

One of the chief culprits here is rationality. Paradoxically, as an explanation and model of human behaviour, rationality is a fantasy. Despite the much-made comparisons with the computer, the brain isn't naturally equipped for it, being much more at home with fuzzy nonlinear approximations and intuitions than computational tasks such as statistical analysis or even simple arithmetic.

This doesn't mean that rational systems are impossible or unnecessary. On the contrary, they are all the more essential to correct human biases and manage manmade complexities that are beyond the power of the brain to control. They are what makes the trains run on time (if you see what I mean) or prevent nuclear power stations from melting down (likewise).

What is harmful, says Nicholson, is the dualism (mind/body, reason/emotion, nature/nurture, humanity/ natural world) which makes humans believe that rationality untainted by emotion is the norm; that reason is undisputed king, instead of an equal partner in a human dialectic.

The evolutionary psychology view of the world is controversial. It suggests that leaders may be born rather than made, that organisational gossip and politics are universal, and that gender differences make the male-constructed world of business inherently hostile for women.

It is hard, admits Nicholson, for some groups to accept such conclusions. They are bad news, he says cheerfully, for consultants and other unreconstructed dualists, whose fundamental assumption is that nature is subservient to nurture (to put it crudely, any change can be accomplished by enough brainwashing).

Bright young MBAs at the start of their careers, he notes, are particularly resistant to the notion of constraints to their wide-ranging ambitions, while CEOs and senior managers firmly reject the EP interpretation of executive pay as aggressive display, of hierarchies as a reflection of male preoccupation with status, and of many acquisitions as ego- and empire-building as much as rational strategy.

Yet Nicholson is adamant that EP is the very opposite of a counsel of resignation or despair. For a start, the ideal organisation in EP terms (no surprises here) is exactly the one that most people would like to work in: small units, with a flexible hierarchy and leadership; working largely in team projects but recognising the individual; diverse, with high trust and high involvement; self-critical. Better, these attributes correspond quite closely to those of the 'high-performance workplace', which is emerging from the research as consis tently more productive, creative and profitable than less human-centred versions. Nicholson's favourite company is Semco, a Brazilian firm that has torn up the management handbooks and whose direction is almost entirely dependent on the motivation and ingenuity of employees.

At a less exalted level, the new Darwinism offers a check against corporate decision-making. 'The history of post-agrarian civilisation has been largely a story of humans reacting with limited insight to changes they wittingly or unwittingly engineered,' Nicholson writes. 'We continue to be outpaced by our own inventions.' The antidote: manage the human animal. Deliberately use systems to support rational inadequacies. Build community. 'Know thyself,' says Nicholson. 'Only the system that knows itself has control over its destiny.'

webTitle: How to deal with a weak boss

fields.headline: How to deal with a weak boss
fields.trailText: 1 Recognise the signs. Weak bosses are often aggressive and emotional because they can't find rational ways of controlling their environments. In the past, they were often physically violent; now they tend to be manipulative, volatile, irascible or inept. They frequently create chaotic, confused atmospheres with blurred boundaries and lines of responsibility and communication because they're scared of taking decisions or being blamed if things go wrong.
fields.body:
1 Recognise the signs. Weak bosses are often aggressive and emotional because they can't find rational ways of controlling their environments. In the past, they were often physically violent; now they tend to be manipulative, volatile, irascible or inept. They frequently create chaotic, confused atmospheres with blurred boundaries and lines of responsibility and communication because they're scared of taking decisions or being blamed if things go wrong.

2 Move away if your destiny is controlled by this sort of person. Many Conservative politicians - including Shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo - are reconsidering their political futures because the power vacuum at the top of the party is leading to mayhem and back-stabbing. In a more ordinary work environment, you could wait 15 years until that nice but ineffectual boss swings you a pay rise. Timid people can ruin lives, too.

3 Consider your boss's motivation. The 'weak but vain' type wants the kudos of perceived power, creating great opportunities for a strong and effective deputy or eminence grise figure. Margaret Thatcher hoped that she could effectively carry on as party leader and Prime Minister - 'back-seat driving' - when she was succeeded by John Major, someone she considered weak. 'Encourage your boss to make the right decisions for you,' says psychologist Dr Sandi Mann, author of Managing your boss in a week (Hodder & Stoughton, £6.99).

4 Understand that fear is the main motivator for many weaklings. 'They will always be looking for some opportunity not to make decisions,' says office worker Pat. 'So you have to think through every idea you present to them.' Don't take their comments at face value - look for their motivations. 'One way forward,' says Pat 'is to provide the frightened ones with some certainty and reliability. You could wield more power if they trust you as a fixed point in their changing universe.'

5 Play on their fears when they suggest daft projects. 'I have to congratulate you: what a courageous stance to take,' is a particularly good line, according to veteran office politician Rachel. 'Wait until the boys in finance hear that one' is almost guaranteed to make them shuffle back. But never let on you regard your boss as a twit: once crossed, a weak person can lack the clear-mindedness to re-evaluate your worth. They often fight dirty.
